DORNBLUM--Sylvia. May 8, 1921 - May 2nd, 2013. Loved by her friends. Services Sunday at 12 noon from Schwartz Bros. Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. Interment at Mt. Hebron Cemetery alongside her beloved sister Pearl.

LaMONTE--Phyllis, 97, went on her final trip on May 3, 2013. She lived in or visited 43 states and 58 countries. Her mother and father, Minnie and Max Rothhouse, were liberal American parents. At the age of 21 she married Abe Gottlieb and had her son Michael (married to Kelly) and daughter Bobbie (married to Robert Falk). She has six grandchildren and 13 great grandchildren all her pride and joy. While she was married to Abe Gottlieb, who died in 1976, Phyllis was an interior designer and owner of an art gallery on Madison Avenue. Her fees were always donated to charity. Through the art gallery she placed art in the Metropolitan Museum, the St. Louis Museum, and the Museum of Modern Art. She was active in seven charity organizations and served as officer or board member. Phyllis married Sidney LaMonte in 1976. They have spent 38 years together traveling around the world and enjoying life. Phyllis's motto was that of comedian Joe E. Lewis "we only live once and if you do it right, once is enough." Private services will be held at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery in Hawthorne, New York on Wednesday May 8, 2013 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to your favorite charity in her name.

DURKIN--Mary Pritchard. Mary Pritchard Durkin, of New York City died on May 1, 2013 after a long battle with lung cancer. Mary was born on January 19, 1941 in Minneapolis, MN and was the daughter of Elizabeth and Manion Pritchard. She is survived by her husband of 38 years, Charles P. Durkin Jr., her son, Charles P. Durkin III, and daughter-in-law, Kristen. She had two sisters, Elizabeth and Anne (deceased), a brother, Thomas, and eleven nieces and nephews. Mary is a graduate of Sacred Heart School in Lake Forest, IL and the University of Minnesota. Following graduation Mary moved to New York where she was a teacher and an independent photographer for a number of years. Mary maintained houses in East Hampton, NY, Boca Grande, FL, and Kempton, PA. She was a member of the Colony Club, Maidstone Club, and the Gasparilla Club. Her interests included bridge, politics, travel, entertaining, water aerobics, dancing, and ice skating. Mary devoted her life to her family and many friends. She was fiercely loyal, deeply loving, principled, courageous and thankful for the many joys in life. We will miss her always. The Mary Durkin Fund for Student Life has been established in her memory at St. Andrew's School, 350 Noxontown Road, Middletown, DE 19709 to which contributions may be made in lieu of flowers. Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Monday, May 6, 2013 at 4pm at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street. Interment private.

LAFER--Fred S. The Taub family and the Henry and Marilyn Taub Foundation mourn the loss of our friend, confidant and trusted advisor, Fred S. Lafer. Fred provided sound advice, guidance and friendship to two generations of our family, to our Foundation and to so many others. Fred's remarkable insight, wisdom and energy will be missed, but his good name and good deeds will remain universally admired. We offer our deepest condolences to Barbara, Deborah, Diana and Gordon and to the extended Lafer Family. Marilyn Taub, Judy and Ron Gold, Shelley and Ira Taub, Benay and Steven Taub and all of your friends and colleagues at The Henry and Marilyn Taub Foundation.

HABER--Ruth. Beloved wife of Martin. Devoted mother of Lynn Peteroy, Steven and Jeff. Adored grandmother of Lauren, Matthew, Jonathan and Maya. Dedicated to fostering the lives of young Musicians. Services 11:30am Sunday, May 5, 2013 at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY www.boulevardriversidechapel.com

LANDAU--Ruth, 91, beloved wife of 66 years of Herbert Landau, (deceased) mother of Marcia Landau Burkett, and husband Zack Burkett, Kali Landau Hess and husband Narada, Jill Landau Reich and the late Ron Reich, Philip Landau and wife Lori Landau, fiercely loving grandmother to Rachel Hess and Char Skidmore; and Abhaya Hess, Sarah and Nathan Reich and Jake, Eli and Samara Landau, as well as great-grandmother to her most recent joy, Ari Skidmore-Hess. Ruth is also survived by her best friend and sister Judy Sandler and husband Rusty Sandler and many nieces and nephews. A passionately political woman, she was a graduate of Hunter College where she earned a degree in Music. She enjoyed the arts, often attending museums, theater, ballet and the opera. She was also an amateur archeologist, but she loved nothing more than sharing the lives of her children and grandchildren. She orchestrated countless family celebrations that will never be the same without her. Mrs. Landau was an indomitable spirit who will be greatly missed. A private family burial was held on Thursday. Donations can be made to Moveon.org, or http://www.musiciansoncall. org

ZACCARIA--Joseph J.,on Wednesday, May 1st. Beloved brother and uncle. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, 10am at St. Anthony's Church, Sullivan Street. Over the last few weeks, moments sacred and profane have played out each night in the boxy, cinderblock sanctuary of Nativity Church on Second Avenue. The altar, candles and tabernacle have been put away, replaced by a bare-bones set where the youthful cast of “Stand-Up Tragedy” confront and comfort one another under the gaze of an unblinking Christ.
 
The church is a stand-in for the play’s Trinity Mission School, where an idealistic white teacher tries to save a bright but troubled Latino teenager. Its Lower East Side location lent the production a certain authenticity of place that appealed to Category 7 , which is staging this revival of Bill Cain’s 1989 play .

“Lucky Guy,” the Broadway play by Nora Ephron, which stars Tom Hanks as the newspaper columnist Mike McAlary, has recouped its $3.6 million capitalization after only eight weeks’ worth of performances, the show’s producers said.
 
Preview performances began on March 1 and since the official opening on April 1 the production has consistently grossed more than $1 million at the box office each week.

The April 15 tax deadline is now receding in our collective rear view mirror. Nothing to do now, but to start collecting records for next year. Right?
 
Unless, of course, you are audited by the Internal Revenue Service.

The major shift of emphasis that the Metropolitan Museum made in its concert series this season, the first programmed entirely by Limor Tomer , as general manager of concerts and lectures, will carry at least through another season and seemingly far into the future, Ms. Tomer announced on Tuesday. She has largely abandoned the traditional series of classical recitals and chamber concerts in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in favor of nontraditional events related to Met exhibitions and, in many cases next season, actually taking place in the galleries.
 
The “gallery-hopping,” as a news release calls it, begins on Sept. 17 and 18, with “The Grand Tour,” celebrating completion of the museum’s new European Paintings Galleries, 1250-1800, with four early-music performances, successively featuring the ensembles Tenet , Dark Horse and Quicksilver and the harpsichordist Jory Vinikour , each in a different gallery. It continues on Sept. 28 with a day devoted to the composer and performer John Zorn (who will celebrate his 60th birthday on Sept. 2).

An analysis from the Pew Charitable Trusts finds that the use of the mortgage interest deduction varies widely across the country, with concentrations on the East Coast and in the West, and in areas with higher property values. The average size of the deduction varies, too.
 
Less populated areas use it less, the report found , so any change in the deduction is likely to be felt differently in various geographic areas. The analysis uses Internal Revenue Service state-level data from 2010 and ZIP code data from 2007 on the number of tax returns, the number of mortgage interest deduction claims, the amount of interest deducted and federal income taxes paid.

The producers of the Broadway musical revival of “Jekyll & Hyde” announced on Friday that the show would come to a premature end, with its final performance on May 12, after only 15 previews and 30 regular performances at the Marquis Theater. It was scheduled to run until June 30.
 
Although the production had a 25-week national tour before coming to Broadway, no plans were announced to move it to another location, either on Broadway or elsewhere. It is the latest show with music by Frank Wildhorn to flop on Broadway, a list that includes “The Civil War,” “Dracula,” “Wonderland” and “Bonnie & Clyde.”

For any opera singer one performance can be enough to put a strain on her vocal cords but what about performing two major roles in the same day?
 
On Saturday at the Metropolitan Opera the mezzo-soprano Elizabeth Bishop will lend her voice not only to the matinee production of Poulenc’s “Dialogues of the Carmelites” as Mother Marie, but she will also step into the role of Fricka for the the 8 p.m. performance of Wagner’s “Das Rheingold.” Stephanie Blythe, who was to sing the role, has fallen ill.

The 2013 Edgar Awards featured a few surprising winners when they were announced at a banquet ceremony in New York on Thursday night. Among them was “Live by Night,” the latest work by Dennis Lehane, which was crowned the best novel of the year over the best-selling “Gone Girl” by Gillian Flynn.
 
Meanwhile, “ Devil in the Grove ” by Gilbert King, which chronicles the story of four black men who were falsely accused of raping a 17-year-old white woman in Florida in 1949 and won a Pulitzer Prize for general nonfiction last month, was beaten in the best fact crime category by “Midnight in Peking” by Paul French, a book that follows the murder investigation of a 19-year-old English girl in Peking in 1937.

Mario J. Gabelli is more likely to be listed among the United States’ best-known money managers than among its highest paid chief executives. But that is not because he does not qualify for both lists. He does.
 
Mr. Gabelli belongs on a short list of chief executives of public companies who have earned more than $750 million in total compensation. That’s right: more than three-quarters of a billion dollars.

A nagging sense seems to pervade the public’s mind that the nation’s biggest banks still pose a risk to the wider economy, despite all that has been done since the 2008 financial crisis. 
 
It seems that disquiet persists even at the heart of the regulatory establishment. The latest call to action came on Friday from Daniel K. Tarullo, a governor at the Federal Reserve, an agency that plays a crucial role in shaping new banking rules.

Aerosmith, James Taylor and Jimmy Buffett will perform along with several other bands to raise money for survivors of the April 15 bombings at the Boston Marathon and the families of the people killed in the attack, The Associated Press reported . The concert is scheduled for May 30 at the TD Garden. It will benefit One Fund, a collection for victims of the attack. Other musicians who have promised to perform include Jason Aldean, Boston, Extreme, Godsmack, the J. Geils Band, Carole King and New Kids on the Block. The comedians Dane Cook and Steven Wright are also included in the lineup. Tickets range from $35 to $285 and go on sale Monday .

TEL AVIV — I was impatiently waiting my turn to get on the Sunday morning radio show. The previous segment, involving two lawyers debating sexual harassment allegations against a well-known TV personality, went overtime after one of the lawyers asked, “Can I add something about the new currency bills?” “The bills?” the anchorman replied. “We will discuss the bills controversy at the second half of the show.” But the lawyer insisted: He just wanted to say that the notes’ design was an outrage. The other lawyer barged in: “We can agree on this.”
 
Israel’s new currency bills , officially presented to the government on Sunday, bear the images of two eminent Israeli poets: Shaul Tchernichovsky and Nathan Alterman. The green 50 shekel bill (Tchernichovsky) and the blue 200 shekel bill (Alterman) will be put into circulation during the second half of the year. Another two bills, also showing poets — for 20 shekels (red; Rachel Bluwstein) and 100 shekels (orange; Leah Goldberg) — will be issued in 2014.

Margaritaville, Atlantic City 
 
The franchise inspired by Jimmy Buffett’s tribute to Key West is coming to the Jersey Shore, with the opening of two restaurants and a casino area on May 24. A giant green blender will greet diners at the 14,000-square-foot Margaritaville restaurant, where they can order cheeseburgers, Key lime pies and, of course, margaritas. It also features an exterior deck along the Boardwalk, a stage for live entertainment and a retail store. On the beachfront, LandShark Bar and Grill will serve beach favorites like fresh boiled shrimp and fish tacos. And inside the Resorts Casino Hotel, there will be a Margaritaville-themed area with 12 table games and 160 slot machines.

Unlike conventional hoteliers and restaurateurs, the Singapore-based Peng Loh, owner of Unlisted Collection — a growing family of hip, design-focused boutique hotels and restaurants in Singapore, London and Shanghai — opens properties based on one simple principle: opportunity. Rather than actively pursue new projects from the ground up, Loh waits for the right situation to present itself. And his newest hotel, One Leicester Street in London’s Chinatown, which opens May 1, is no exception.
 
Chef Fergus Henderson and Trevor Gulliver opened the St. John Restaurant and Hotel in 2011. Despite keeping the rooms booked and earning a Michelin Star, Henderson and Gulliver soon found themselves in a financial pickle. “Trevor and Fergus, who are good friends of mine, rang me one day and asked for help,” Loh explains. “It was a purely opportunistic buy, and I was in the right place to help out.”

“ Babe ” (1995) had a sweet, bucolic simplicity. The sequel, “Babe: Pig in the City,” (1998) directed by George Miller and one of the greatest of all fantasy movies, has a loony visionary magnificence. Mixing animatronics with live action, it seems at times like a giant Rube Goldberg machine, leading to disaster before delivering us to the release of slapstick. But this happy story of often melancholy enchantment also approaches the overwhelming empathy of a Vittorio De Sica film. A crippled dog dreaming of being able to happily chase butterflies in paradise would be at home among the poor, hopeful dreamers in De Sica’s “Miracle in Milan.” The prideful old orangutan insisting on dressing before he escapes from a laboratory might be a simian Umberto D.
 
The story has Babe, above, the sheepherding pig, and Farmer Hoggett’s wife (round, pink-cheeked Magda Szubanski) traveling to the city to earn enough money to save their beloved farm. They become separated and Babe winds up in a hotel that surreptitiously caters to animals, where he’s taken advantage of and then rallies the creatures to rise to the best versions of themselves. As only great humanist art can, the film returns you to the piercing primal sorrows of loneliness, hunger, losing the safety of home.

1. Kelly Clarkson (Season 1; Finish: Winner)
 
It’s hard to believe now, but Clarkson was overshadowed for much of Season 1 by Tamyra Gray and Justin Guarini. But her big-band Judy Garland performance of “Stuff Like That There” set the standard for the whole series.

The 1940s have always been the problematic decade of the golden era of American movies, bookended by the fresh, casual impudence of the ’30s and the neurotic unease of the ’50s. Great movies were made, but usually by directors (Preston Sturges, Orson Welles) or in genres (film noir) that pushed against the general cheer and wholesomeness, the tone much of Hollywood saw as its duty during wartime. Which is why, in the context of that determined normalcy, “Leave Her to Heaven” (1945) feels like such a shock. 
 
Here was a movie drenched in vibrant Technicolor and in the conventions of melodrama (the source was a best seller by Ben Ames Williams), starring popular, attractive performers, Cornel Wilde and Gene Tierney. It all promises Hollywood lushness, but at its cold little heart is Tierney’s Ellen, one of the most convincing and unsettling psychopaths in movies. She is an insanely possessive romantic who marries a successful novelist (Wilde) and sets out to eliminate every rival for her attention, including her unborn child and her teenage brother-in-law (Darryl Hickman, near left, with Tierney and Wilde), disabled from polio. Tierney doesn’t go in for histrionics. What’s frightening about her is how normal she can seem, even refined. Ellen allows her brother-in-law to drown in a lake, sitting a few feet away in a rowboat, her face absolutely impassive.

A sturdy brow, speculative eyes, a smile that won’t turn on for just anybody or anything: If there’s one face you can trust, it’s Glenn Ford’s. Which is why Ford’s performance in Delmer Daves’s 1957 western “3:10 to Yuma” — as a murderous stagecoach robber who’s taken into captivity and does his damnedest to wriggle out of it — is both thrilling and unsettling. That movie is a world apart from “Jubal,” another Ford-Daves collaboration made just a year earlier. In “Jubal,” Ford plays the title character, an honest drifter who lands a job as foreman on Ernest Borgnine’s ranch, only to become ensnared in a trap laid by Borgnine’s randy wife, played by Valerie French. One picture gives us the Ford we want to believe in, straightforward and virtuous; the other gives us a Ford — wily, silver-tongued, seductive as all get-out — who uses our trust against us. How to choose a favorite?
 
Better, maybe, to just call it a tossup. It’s great fun to watch Ford in “Jubal,” shrinking from the advances of Ms. French’s frustrated, predatory ranch wife. He pities her and he fears her — she could cost him his job — but mostly he just wants to do the right thing. Ford’s Jubal may be the trustworthy sort, but that doesn’t strip him of his sexual allure. Understandably, he has to show a preference for the prim young miss from a just-passin’-through religious sect (Felicia Farr, who also appears in “3:10 to Yuma”). But Ford always stops short of being too nice — beneath his Sunday-school manners, there’s a hint of foxiness.

That we’ve had time to get used to Mike Leigh’s mixture of caricature and naturalism makes it no less singular. The 20-something twins in Mr. Leigh’s “Life Is Sweet” (1990), one of the director’s peaks, can stand for the spectrum of his characterization. Natalie (Claire Skinner), a plumber who prefers the simplicity of men’s shirts and abjures the fuss of makeup, is entirely at home in her own skin. Her sister Nicola (the astounding Jane Horrocks, below left, with Ms. Skinner) is a gibbering mess of tics: she chain smokes, makes nasty remarks, has scratching jags in which she attacks her own skin and, barely hidden from her sister and parents (Alison Steadman and Jim Broadbent), is anorexic. It’s fitting that Ms. Skinner plays Natalie simply, and that Ms. Horrocks takes a stylized approach to a woman devolved into a mental and physical wreck. Mr. Leigh’s flexible methods accommodate both styles. 
 
In between are Ms. Steadman and Mr. Broadbent, capturing the cheerful personas that this middle-class couple, good parents still clearly in love, assume to deal with everyday life. It’s a measure of the humanism inside Mr. Leigh’s portraits that everyone is a candidate for grace. That comes in a scene in which Ms. Steadman confronts Ms. Horrocks, pouring out her fears and love for her daughter, risking losing her by making her emotions naked but realizing she will lose her if she stays quiet. It’s a scene whose pain and beauty you recognize you must live with from the moment you see it. ( Criterion ; May 28; Blu-ray, $39.95; DVD, $29.95) CHARLES TAYLOR

147

 
That’s the number of wigs worn in Broadway’s “Motown: The Musical,” about the pioneering Detroit record label and its world-class musicians like the Supremes and Smokey Robinson. As Diana Ross, Valisia LeKae wears 11 different wigs alone. But that’s not all in the faux follicles department: There are also 60 pieces of facial hair, including a soul patch on a Temptation and Stevie Wonder’s goatee. Quickest hair change? — 35 seconds.

A report in the Arena column last Sunday about the exhibition “Artist/Rebel/Dandy: Men of Fashion” misidentified a photograph from the show. It was taken by Ike Ude — not by the Leila Heller Gallery, which represents him.
BLASS--Norman. We will miss our dear friend Norman and all his great stories. Condolences to Jackie and family. Vera and Stanley Miller and Family

BRONSON--Alan, On April 30, 2013. Preceded in death by his beloved wife Evelyn. Devoted father of Dr. Mitchell Bronson, Bonnie Herskowitz and Robin Ward. STEPHENSON--Conrad D. The governors, members and staff of The Real Estate Board of New York mourn the passing of Conrad D. Stephenson, who died on April 25. He was 85 years old. Connie served on REBNY's Board of Governors and was Vice President of the Institutional Owners Division from 1981-1991. Connie was born on May 14, 1927 in Brooklyn and was raised in St. Albans, Queens. Connie earned degrees from Fordham and NYU before joining Chase Manhattan Bank in 1950. He left for 17 years to do real estate lending on Long Island and thrived in his banking career, but his love of the military called and he re-enlisted in the Army Reserves, achieving the rank of Colonel before retiring in 1980. Connie played an active role in financing many real estate projects in New York thru senior management positions he held with several major financial institutions including Chase Manhattan Bank, The Bowery Savings Bank, and The First National Bank of Chicago. Connie was the CEO of Pan Am Equities from 1993-97 and was a director of Reckson Associates. Connie was instrumental in financing many of Glenwood Management's and H. J. Kalikow's residential developments and played a significant role in several commercial and mixed use projects including 101 Park Avenue, 9 West 57th Street, and Trump Tower. Connie was recognized as a philanthropic leader by his colleagues in the real estate industry when he received the prestigious Kenneth R. Gerrety Award in 1991. He was deeply involved in many prominent charities, most notably the National Jewish Center for Immunology and Respiratory Medicine. We express our sincere condolences to his wife Judi and the entire Stephenson family. Rob Speyer Chairman Steve Spinola- President

VOGL--Otto. Professor Otto Vogl, 85, passed away peacefully April 27, at home with his dear wife Jane Cunningham Vogl and dog Gracie by his side. Otto was a dynamic visionary who was one of the global leaders in the development of plastic. He was born on November 6, 1927 in Traiskirchen, Austria, near Vienna. He studied organic chemistry, receiving his Ph.D from the University of Vienna in 1949, having completed his thesis on steroids. In 1952, he went to the University of Michigan as a post-doctoral fellow where he met and married Jane. They then moved to Princeton University where he continued his research. In 1956, he joined DuPont in Wilmington, Delaware, which was the beginning of his illustrious career. At DuPont, Otto was one of the pioneer researchers on aldehyde polymerization (plastics). He was there for 14 years before becoming a full professor and one of the founders of the Polymer Science and Engineering Department at University of Massachusetts at Amherst. In 1983, he left UMass to accept the newly created position as the Herman F. Mark Professor at the Polytechnic University in New York, the first endowed polymer professorship in the country. He recognized science as an international language and tirelessly taught and lectured worldwide. During his academic career, Otto Vogl supervised approximately 100 students and postdoctoral research associates from around the world, published 450 scientific papers, wrote an additional 150 science related articles and held of over 50 US and foreign patents. He served on 15 editorial boards and received many international awards and four honorary doctoral degrees. Otto was also very active in committee work in the polymer field, and developed and led many of its critical organizations. He was a member of, among others, the National Academy of Sciences, the National Science Foundation, the American Chemical Society, the Austrian Chemical Society, the Pacific Polymer Federation (which he founded in furtherance of his commitment to international science), and the prestigious Royal Swedish Society of Sciences. Otto is survived by Jane, his wife of 57 years; their son Eric of Houston and daughter Yvonne of New York; eight grandchildren; one great-granddaughter and Gracie, his dog. He will be deeply missed by all. A Funeral Mass is planned at 10am on Tuesday, May 7th at St. Brigid's Church in Amherst, Massachusetts.

The following were posted on nytimes.com/weddings in response to the Field Notes column “Divorce Whisperer? Mediating With Parents Isn’t Easy” in Sunday Styles on April 28.

 
When was I planning my wedding, my parents had just separated after a 23-year marriage. There was animosity, and it was a trial for me to deal with both of them separately on many choices. The night before the wedding at the rehearsal dinner, there was a lot of partying, toasts and laughter. My dad took me aside and asked me to change the seating plans and seat them together. What should have been my beauty sleep was spent rearranging people at tables until 2 a.m. In the end, though, it was nice that they were able to put everything aside and act civil for my big day. I will always appreciate that.

As states cut education budgets in response to the nation’s continuing economic woes, student-to-teacher ratios are again on the rise after decades of decline. This resurrects an age-old debate in American education: does class size really matter?
 
To many educators, the answer seems obvious: Teachers who have fewer students can give each child more attention and tailored instruction. And parents agree. For years, annual surveys conducted by the New York City Department of Education have shown that the top priority of school parents is reducing class size , far outpacing “more effective leadership,” “more teacher training,” “more or better art programs,” “more challenging courses” and both “more preparation for state tests” and “less preparation for state tests.”

Los Angeles’s tourism agency is hoping to entice visitors to find new ways to explore the city. Do you remember the last time you saw someone driving their family around in a gargantuan American station wagon as if they meant it? I’m not talking about a college student driving a load of friends around in granny’s hand-me-down or that weird neighbor who’s all “cold dead hands” about his ultimate suburban driving machine. No, I mean run-of-the-mill families of 4.5 who drive to schools, jobs and doctor appointments with mom and dad up front, a surly teenager or two in the back seat and one to one-and-a-half children way in the back, bouncing around on the rear-facing fold down, making faces at people through the back glass.
 
It’s probably been a while, if at all, since you’ve seen that, because the age of the full-size station wagon is gone. Not that our taste has drifted toward more diminutive, economical vehicles (the minivans, S.U.V.’s and pickup trucks that supplanted wagons are essentially the same thing). But the classic station wagon that was familiar to American driveways for decades fizzled into oblivion not long after General Motors ceased production in the mid-’90s of the bulbous behemoths better known as the Chevy Caprice and Buick Roadmaster estate wagons.

When Qantas Airlines decided to revamp the uniform for its flight attendants, it did what any self-respecting carrier would do these days: it enlisted a Paris-based designer (Martin Grant) and showcased the collection (navy shift dresses and suits with flashes of red and fuchsia) using a supermodel (Miranda Kerr) in a fashion show.
 
The Australia-based airline, which introduced the uniforms this month in Sydney, is the latest carrier to team up with designers or brands to update their flight attendants’ attire, a trend that became popular during the 1960s, when Emilio Pucci created mod designs for Braniff International Airways. It has picked up steam over the last year.

Talking to your car can be like trying to reason with a recalcitrant toddler. It often petulantly refuses to obey your commands or, worse, does the opposite of what you want. But in-vehicle voice recognition systems are gradually improving, as demonstrated by the new version of Chevrolet’s MyLink system.
 
Connected services are expected to continue to be a major selling point, and Chevrolet went to great pains to emphasize the system’s debut on the all-new, front-wheel-drive only 2014 Impala. Standard on the LT and LTZ trim packages, the revamped next generation MyLink was one of the highlights described by Phil Carlisle, product manager for the Impala, at a press briefing in New York last week.

RAFFEL GRUBER--Suzanne, (nee Goldberg) of Philadelphia, PA and Long Branch, NJ, June 18, 1925--May 3, 2013. Daughter of the late Harry and Jennie Goldberg; beloved wife of the late Maurice Gruber and former wife of the late Forrest Raffel; loving mother of Ellen Miller (James), Ginny Karabell (Leonard) and Joan Koven (Seth); cherished grandmother of Nina, Jacob (Annie), Liza, Daniel, Laura, Zoe and Eli; adoring sister to Adele Block and the late Wilma Miller; and beloved aunt to Peggy Danziger (Dick), Tom Block (Marilyn), and Tanfield Miller. We will miss your genius for making our lives fun and the glorious panache with which you lived your own. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to the Friends of the Wissahickon: (www.fow.org)

WINGATE--Ardis Swenson, died at home in Bronxville, New York on May 4 at age 106 and six months. Born in Zumbrota, Minnesota, on November 1, 1906, Ardis was a long-time resident of New York City and Lloyd Harbor, Long Island, and the widow of Henry S. Wingate (1905-1982), former Chairman and C.E.O. of International Nickel Co. of Canada, Ltd. A 1928 graduate of Carleton College, she married Harry on September 11, 1929, and was active in The Blue Hill Troupe in New York from 1937 to 1954, singing lead soprano roles in many Gilbert and Sullivan operettas. With Harry at her side for fifty-three years, she raised two sons, Henry K. Wingate (Otis, Massachusetts) and William P. Wingate (Sheboygan, Wisconsin). Survivors also include Hank's two sons, Peter H. Wingate (Denver, Colorado) and Robert H. Wingate (Tarrytown, New York) together with Rob's wife, Sandra, and their children Samantha and Nicholas; Bill's wife, Anne H. Wingate, and their son, William J. Wingate (Santa Clarita, California); and Ardis' housekeeper of 45 years, Mary B. Clarke, who became her steadfast caregiver, companion, and friend. The family and close friends will gather for a private graveside service. In memory of Ardis, donations may be made to Jansen Hospice and Palliative Care, 69 Main St., Tuckahoe, NY, 10707, to The Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd., PO Box 286800, Yorkville Station, New York, NY, 10128, or to a charity of the donor's choice.

RIBICOFF--Peter, 76, of New York City, died at home after a long illness on May 3, 2013. He is survived by his wife, Mercedes, his children, Jacob and Judith, his daughter-in-law, Julia, and three grandchildren, Gabriel, Benjamin, and Jonah.
SIEGLER--Alvin. A wonderful friend. A great human being. You enriched our lives. We will miss you, but never forget you. Lore and Harry

On Jan. 9, 2003, Jamie Perez was slashed by two fellow students at Evander Childs High School in the Bronx. He recovered, and his mother, Nancy Torres, sued the City of New York for negligence, claiming lax security. 
 
Her lawyer, Richard J. Katz, might ordinarily have filed suit against the Board of Education, except that a year before the assault, the State Legislature had voted to vest the mayor with the power to appoint the schools chancellor. As part of the new governance, a Panel for Educational Policy was created, a majority of whose members the mayor appointed.

LOUIS--Herbert. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Herbert Louis and extend sincere condolences to his family. Alan Fischer, President

Signature Theater’s revival of August Wilson’s “Piano Lesson” and the Playwrights Horizon production of “The Whale” were the big winners on Sunday night at the ceremony for the Lucille Lortel Awards, which honors Off Broadway works. “The Piano Lesson” won the most awards in competition — four — for outstanding revival, director (Ruben Santiago-Hudson), lead actress (Roslyn Ruff) and featured actor (Chuck Cooper). “The Whale,” by Samuel D. Hunter, won for outstanding play and lead actor for Shuler Hensley, who played a morbidly obese man coming to terms with his mistakes and fears. Jessica Pabst also won for her costumes for “The Whale.” 
 
Other Lortel winners were “Dogfight” for outstanding musical and choreographer (Christopher Gattelli); “All the Rage” for solo show; Annie Funke for featured actress in “If There Is I Haven’t Found It Yet,” playing opposite Jake Gyllenhaal, also a Lortel nominee; Clint Ramos for set design for “Wild With Happy”; Scott Zielinski for lighting design for “A Civil War Christmas”; and Leah Gelpe for sound design for “Slowgirl.” Special awards were also presented to Todd Haimes, artistic director of Roundabout Theater Company, for lifetime achievement; Signature’s production of “Old Hats,” for outstanding alternative theatrical experience; the playwright Neil LaBute; and the Theater Development Fund.

BRAUNSTEIN--Mickey. Mickey lived life with passion and a sense of adventure. We will all miss him. To our dear friend Barbara and the entire family we send our love and support. Sallie, Jo, Michelle, Judy, Nancy and Laurie

After more than 18 seasons in the major leagues, Yankees starter Andy Pettitte knows what the ball is supposed to feel like once it leaves his hand. There is a certain subtlety that makes it difficult for him to explain the feeling, but he knows by touch. He knows almost immediately after he throws a pitch how it will arrive at home plate without even seeing it land in the catcher’s mitt.
 
For the second game in a row, the ball did not feel comfortable coming out of his hand. Pettitte is releasing it at the wrong moment, and he knows it. The curveball that is supposed to loop down is instead floating sideways. He has lost the feel for his cutter, one of his signature pitches, and he cannot predict right now whether it will tilt sideways or back up.

BRAUNSTEIN--Mickey. Mickey, you were a part of the best things in our lives. You are gone much to soon and we will miss you terribly. Your music, your love, your smile will remain with us forever. We send our love and sympathy to Barbara, Lisa, Julie and the family. Sandy and Steve Perlbinder

Online education is a sprawling category that encompasses everything from open online courses on physics, history and other college subjects to intensive, multiday workshops on photography on sites like CreativeLive.
 
Then there’s the wild teaching scene on sites like YouTube, where it sometimes is difficult to find a life skill for which there is not a short how-to video made by somebody, somewhere. I realized this once when, flushed with frustration, I searched for a video on YouTube on how to convert an uncooperative Transformer action figure into vehicle mode. A capable young instructor made me, and my child, very happy that day.

Dear Diary:
 
When I heard “Somebody help me!” from an old blind man on the corner of 24th and Eighth at a sidewalk detour, I did not hesitate to link arms. Swept up in my own philanthropy, I forgot that I was still decked out in last night’s rave attire, tiny purple and blue ripped denim shorts and an “I ♥ NY” crop top.

Dear Diary:
 
It was so obviously Barbra, underneath her enormous glasses and big straw hat, that I figured the best thing to do was pretend I didn’t notice, so I moseyed back to my post somewhere between Van Gogh’s cypresses and Gauguin’s walking stick.

The hip-hop producer AraabMuzik was shot in the chest during a a robbery in Providence, R.I., on Wednesday and remains hospitalized, the police said.
 
The producer, whose real name is Abraham Orellana, was riding with a friend in a black Nissan Infiniti when someone opened the rear door, got in the back seat and brandished a revolver, according to a Providence Police incident report. It was shortly after midnight. Alarmed, Mr. Orellana and his friend got out of the car. The robber fired a shot then fled. The bullet entered Mr. Orellana’s left chest and exited his lower back, the police report said.

The American Repertory Theater at Harvard University – a company that has been the birthplace of several Broadway hits, including the recent revival of “Pippin” and the controversial reworking of “Porgy and Bess” – will present six productions in its 2013-14 season in Cambridge, Mass. 
 
In addition to Robert Schenkkan’s “All The Way,” which was already announced , the lineup includes “Witness Uganda,” a musical by Matt Gould and Griffin Matthews, and an adaptation of Shakespeare’s “Tempest” by Aaron Posner and Teller, of Penn and Teller.

8:28 p.m. | Updated A group of private equity firms led by Bain Capital and Golden Gate Capital is near a deal to buy BMC Software , people briefed on the matter said on Sunday, nearly a year after an activist hedge fund sought to push the technology company onto the auction block.
 
The group is expected to pay around $46 a share, one of these people said, valuing the company at over $6.5 billion. A deal could be announced as soon as Monday, though these people said that final details were still being negotiated and talks could still fall apart.

BROOKS--Lynn, (nee Marilyn Schwarz), founder of Big Apple Greeter, passed away suddenly on May 4, 2013, surrounded by her husband, three sons, daughters-in-law, and grandchildren. Lynn was the loving and adored wife of Stan Brooks, long-time news reporter for 1010 WINS radio. Lynn was born in Mt. Vernon, NY on September 10, 1930 to B. Leo Schwarz and Beatrice Rothschild, and was raised by her father and stepmother, Ruth Cohen Schwarz. She was the sister of William O. Schwarz. Lynn attended Julia Richmond High School, Pennsylvania College for Women, and Hunter College. She attained a MA degree in Human Relations from New York University. Lynn worked at the National Conference of Christians and Jews, Adelphi University, and the International Center of New York, before going on to found Big Apple Greeter in 1992. Lynn loved New York City its cultural attractions, its parks, and, most of all, its diversity and she took great pride in establishing an organization that enabled thousands of visitors from around the world to share in her appreciation of the City and its people. Lynn was a life-long fighter and activist for civil rights, women's rights, and social justice. She was recently chosen as a winner of a nationwide Later-Life Story Contest by the Center for Productive Longevity. Lynn is survived by her husband, Stan, her sons, Rick, George, and Bennett, her three daughters-in-law, seven grandchildren, two great-grandchildren, and six nieces and nephews, as well as countless admiring friends and colleagues. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, May 7, 2013 at 10:00AM at the Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations will be gratefully accepted by Big Apple Greeter, 1 Centre Street, New York, NY 10007.

An influential shareholder advisory firm has recommended that investors withhold their support for three JPMorgan Chase directors, citing “material failures of stewardship and risk oversight” in the wake of a big trading loss last year.
 
The firm, Institutional Shareholder Services, or I.S.S., urged shareholders not to vote for three directors who serve on the board’s risk policy committee — David M. Cote, James S. Crown and Ellen V. Futter. The results of the vote will be announced at the bank’s annual meeting later this month.

At Facebook’s headquarters in Palo Alto, Calif., are stark white posters with bright red statements like “Done is better than perfect” and “Move fast and break things.”
 
These disruptive philosophies embody the spirit not just of Facebook but of Silicon Valley. Yet today, when technology companies have become the prime targets of rogue governments and hackers, the ideologies that drive these companies to provoke could end up disrupting these companies.

Marissa Mayer is trying to repair Yahoo’s image by upgrading benefits for working parents. 
 
On Tuesday, Yahoo announced a revised paid leave policy for new parents, more than doubling the time, in some cases, that employees with babies are able to take off. The new benefit comes after Yahoo spurred a nationwide debate over family-friendly work policies when it banned working from home in February.

The High Line announced on Wednesday that it had begun taking online reservations, at thehighline.org , for visits to the last undeveloped section of the rail line, between West 30th and 34th Streets, where for the next year seven sculptures by the artist Carol Bove will be on view. The High Line originally planned to charge $6 for a visit but decided on Monday to make reservations free.
 
The undeveloped section, sealed off behind a fence, will be fully opened to the public late next year, left in its near-wild state with only a walkway to allow visitors to walk along its length to the line’s northern end.

ROME – Vatican officials say they have found what could be the first European images of American Indians in a fresco painted within two years of Christopher Columbus’s first voyage to the so-called New World.
 
The lightly sketched group of men — nude save for what appear to be feathered headdresses and posed as if dancing — emerged during the restoration of a fresco of the “Resurrection of Christ” by the Renaissance artist Pinturicchio, painted in one of several rooms he decorated for Pope Alexander VI between 1492 and 1494.

In pain because of infected teeth, Luatany Caseres, 34, then a factory worker in Durham, N.C., was desperate to see a dentist.
 
At an emergency dental clinic that treats the uninsured, a receptionist told Ms. Caseres that the schedule was full. When she returned a second time in still greater pain, the receptionist told her, “I can’t get you seen.” On her third visit, Ms. Caseres’ swollen cheek bulged as if a lollipop were stuck there. Still, she was told that she would have to wait.

A Los Angeles-area jeweler has been formally charged with making illegal stock trades based on secret information obtained from a former senior partner at the accounting giant KPMG. 
 
Prosecutors unveiled charges in Federal District Court in Los Angeles on Monday against the jeweler, Bryan Shaw, who has agreed to plead guilty to conspiracy to commit securities fraud. He will disgorge about $1.3 million in illicit trading profits.

Adding omega-3 fatty acid supplements to a vitamin regimen to protect against age-related macular degeneration , the leading cause of blindness in the United States, did not slow progression of the disease, a large new study has found.
 
About a decade ago, a study carried out by the National Eye Institute showed that a formulation consisting of vitamin C , vitamin E, beta carotene and the minerals zinc and copper reduced the risk of developing the advanced stage of macular degeneration by roughly 25 percent over a five-year period.

Only 15 months old, Vivian Andorf underwent her sixth cardiac catheterization . Her cardiologist inserted a flexible tube through a tiny artery in her leg and wended it to her heart in an attempt to treat her narrowed veins and arteries, the result of a congenital condition.
 
In prior procedures, the first of which she had at a mere 3 weeks old, an adult-size catheter had to be used. Catheters sized for a child, let alone an infant, were not available. The larger catheter took longer to insert and was more likely to injure her already abnormal blood vessels, said her cardiologist, Dr. Alex Golden of the Cleveland Clinic Children’s Hospital.

SOBEL--Burt, MD, Dr. Sobel received his MD at Harvard, graduating magna cum laude in 1962. He completed his internship and residency training at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston and his fellowship training at the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute followed by academic and administrative leadership positions at the University of California, San Diego, Washington University and Barnes Hospital in Saint Louis (Director, Cardiovascular Division). In 1994 Dr. Sobel began serving as Chair of the Department of Medicine and the E.L. Amidon Professor of Medicine at the University of Vermont. His vision and energy revitalized the Department of Medicine expanding its research endeavors, education programs, and clinics. During his tenure as Chair, Dr. Sobel created the Cardiovascular Research Institute at the University of Vermont and Fletcher Allen Health Care to enhance the research mission of those institutions and in 2005 left his position as Chair to become the Institute's first Director. He continued to serve as a Professor of Medicine and Biochemistry, earning the E.L. Amidon Award for Teaching Excellence in 2007 and being named a University of Vermont Distinguished University Professor in 2009. Dr. Sobel was internationally recognized as a leader in cardiovascular medicine. He pioneered ground-breaking research in cardiology that had a major impact on how heart-attack patients are treated, including extensive research on the dissolution of blood clots and heart disease in patients with Type 2 diabetes. He was the recipient of numerous prestigious awards, including a Research Career Development Award from the National Institutes of Health and a Distinguished Scientist Award from the American College of Cardiology, among many others, and was a leader in subspecialty societies including the American College of Cardiology, the American Heart Association, and the Society for Experimental Biology and Medicine. He had more than 800 manuscripts published, and edited major cardiovascular and medical scientific journals. He was a fierce optimist, a passionate sailor, an enthusiastic skier and above all, a dedicated friend to many. He leaves behind his wife of 55 years, Susan, his children, Jonathan and Elizabeth, and granddaughter Skye. Burton E. Sobel, M.D. died at his home in Colchester, VT on May 3, 2013. A funeral service will be held at 11 am on Wednesday, May 8, in Temple Sinai Synagogue, 500 Swift St., S. Burlington, Vt. with interment to follow in Lakeview Cemetery. There will be a memorial service at the University of Vermont in the fall.

SIEGLER--Alvin M. MD, Emeritas Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology at SUNY Health Science Center in Brooklyn died on May 4, 2013 at the age of 90. Formerly of Woodmere, NY, currently of Boca Raton, FL and Southbury, CT. A graduate of NYU School of Medicine with an MD degree, he received a Doctorate of Medical Science (DSc) from the University of Pennsylvania. Dr. Siegler specialized in Infertility and was a pioneer in gynecologic endoscopy. He co-authored seven books primarily on the use of endoscopy in gynecologic surgery. He was among the first physicians to use the hysteroscope to search for abnormalities within the uterus. He introduced the technique in China in 1980. Dr. Siegler served as President of the American Association of Gynecologic Laparoscopists, The New York Obstetrical Society, and the Fallopius International Society. A physician for more than 50 years, he leaves a legacy of dedication to scholarship, research, teaching, and the excellent and compassionate care of his patients. Loving and beloved, he is survived by his wife of 65 years, Marcia Malawista Siegler, daughter Dr. Judith Carol Siegler, son Samuel Lewis Siegler MD and his wife Kathy Spenard Siegler, grandchildren Kate, Kevin, Alex, Scott, and Jeffrey, great-grandchildren Tristan and Aiden, nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. He embraced life with passion and enriched it with his creative hands, keen mind, and loving heart. He will be with us always. Memorial Services Thursday, May 9 at 1pm Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, 11115 Jog Road, Boynton Beach, FL. Donations in his memory may be made to The Alvin M. Siegler MD Scholarship Fund in OB-GYN. Please pay to the order of The HSCB Foundation (memo-Acct #

JANOW--Hugh. The funniest guy we know died Friday. JACOBY--Aaron. The Hebrew Academy of the Five Towns and Rockaway mourns the passing of Aaron Jacoby, esteemed past president of Hili and HAFTR, beloved husband of Lillian Jacoby and father of Suzanne, Michelle, Steven and Alan. HUGHES--John F.,of Ridgewood, NJ passed on May 4th. Beloved husband of 54 years of Margaret "Peggy" Hughes, loving father of John Hughes, Jr., Carol Thomas and husband Peter, and Marianne McGuinness and husband Gerard. Cherished grandfather of Clare, Chris, Colin, Catie, Meg, Lizzie, and John. A graduate of Fordham, he served as a US Marine in World War II. As a film editor for 20th Century Fox, his work included a documentary short subject, "Survival City", which won the Academy Award in 1955. At ABC News he contributed to documentaries, one which won an Emmy in 1964 and one that earned him a Peabody Award in 1965. He directed "I am a Soldier" which followed an infantry company in Vietnam, and "The Race for the South Pole" received an Emmy nomination. He later served as radio and television media liaison in Public Affairs for the Port Authority. Family and friends may visit Tuesday 2 to 4 pm and 7 to 9pm at the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. Funeral Mass is Wednesday at 10:45 am at Mt. Carmel RC Church in Ridgewood.

HOLMAN--Barbara Lucas, 90,From Columbus OH, New York, NY, Stanford, and San Francisco, CA, died peacefully on January 4, 2013, in Irvine, California. She was born to Homer C. and Lela Hay Lucas on February 10, 1922 in Columbus, OH. She is survived by her three children Mike, Andrea, and Alison, five grandchildren Jessica, Joaquin, Amanda, Coryna, and Sofya; her sister Kathleen Lucas Barber, nephews Bob and John, and niece Ann. Barbara graduated from Bryn Mawr College (BA, philosophy, 1942) and Yale (MS Nursing, 1945; PhD Public Health, 1955) when women rarely pursued higher education. She was an Army nurse who cared for quadriplegic soldiers and researcher at Columbia University before moving to Stanford, CA with her husband, Halsted R. Holman, in 1960. While raising children, she continued her research. In 1970 she co-authored an article demonstrating that racial discrimination and work stress contribute to racial disparities in mortality, foreshadowing current research on health disparities, occupational health, and stress-related disease. Barbara was known for her quiet generosity, adherence to principle in the face of adversity, and her deeply-held belief that all people are equal and deserving of respect, regardless of class, race, ethnicity, religion, or sexuality. She passionately supported the Civil Rights and anti-Vietnam war movements. In the 1980s, when HIV was devastating the gay community and gay men were being vilified, she ardently supported gay rights, especially through her love and support for her nephew, Charlie Barber, a gay rights activist. Her beliefs in the goodness of humanity and the power of education led her to support educational programs for underprivileged youth. Dr. Barbara Lucas Holman will be remembered as a deeply resilient and loving woman. Comments may be sent to BHolman--mem@yahoo.com.
GROSS--Jerome (Jerry) Born October 20, 1929, died April 22, 2013. Beloved husband of Phyllis Gross, and beloved father and grandfather.

GREGORY--Cecelia Dohen, of Montclair, NJ, died peacefully at home on Saturday, May 4th, 2013 surrounded by her children. Born July 23, 1929, in the Woodlawn section of the Bronx, NY, Mrs. Gregory was the daughter of William J. and Elizabeth A. Gutscher Dohen. A graduate of St. Barnabas High School, she attended the College of Good Counsel, White Plains, NY, and later earned a Bachelor of English degree from Kean College, NJ. She and her husband, Edward Reed Gregory, who died in July 1999, were married October 28, 1950. They began their married life in Bayside, NY, and moved to Montclair, in 1969. Mrs. Gregory is survived her eight children, 21 grandchildren, two step-grandchildren a great-grandson, a sister, as well as many nieces and nephews and very dear friends. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10am, Wednesday, at St. Cassian R. C. Church, Bellevue Ave., Montclair. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Visiting will be on Tuesday (today) from 2-4pm and from 7-9pm at Caggiano Memorial, 62 Grove St, Montclair. caggianomemorial.com. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory to Catholic Relief Services, or the Oratorio Society of New Jersey, would be appreciated.

 Bank of America and MBIA, the troubled bond insurer, have reached a $1.7 billion agreement to settle a long-running legal dispute over mortgage-backed securities that became troubled when the financial crisis blossomed.

Don’t look back, Donald Trump; when it comes to having one’s name emblazoned all over New York City, Ronald Perelman might be gaining on you.

Perelman Center for Business Innovation, will be one of a growing roster of facilities in New York City bearing the Perelman name.

THE FACTS 

 
Americans as a whole consume too much sugar, that much seems to be clear . But where is most of the sugar in our diets coming from?

OMAHA — A little under an hour into the question-and-answer session at Berkshire Hathaway ’s annual meeting here on Saturday, a name searing with history but now largely forgotten was mentioned: Henry E. Singleton.
 
Mr. Singleton was, arguably, the Warren E. Buffett of the 1960s and ’70s, though hardly famous. His company, Teledyne, became a remarkably successful and huge conglomerate, with an assortment of related — and unrelated — businesses. Like Mr. Buffett, Mr. Singleton was a modest man with a rare sense of rationality. He didn’t pay his shareholders dividends; he was convinced he could allocate the money more profitably. And he was right more often than not.

An art review on Friday about “At War With the Obvious: Photographs by William Eggleston,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misidentified the state where Mr. Eggleston resides. It is Tennessee (in Memphis), not Mississippi.

An article on Monday about Reynold Levy, who is stepping down as president of Lincoln Center, referred incorrectly to the $8 million he is trying to raise for the annual spring gala. It would be a record for a gala held by Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts; it would not be a record for a gala held at Lincoln Center. (A gala there for the Metropolitan Opera’s 125th anniversary in 2009 raised more than $10 million.) And an accompanying picture caption, using information from Lincoln Center, misidentified an actress shown dancing with Mr. Levy. She is Colleen Dunn, not Deborah Yates.

3:44 p.m. | Updated The Broadway revival of Lyle Kessler’s “Orphans,” starring Alec Baldwin, Ben Foster and Tom Sturridge, will close on May 19 at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater, the show’s producers announced on Monday. 
 
The news came days after the show received two Tony Award nominations: for best leading actor (Mr. Sturridge) and for best play revival. “Orphans” had been scheduled to run through June 30.

HONG KONG — After a lackluster 2012 and slow start this year, Hong Kong’s financiers are hoping to revive interest in initial public offerings. To test investor appetite, many companies are hiring armies of investment bankers in their efforts to market new shares.
 
In the three years through the end of 2011, Hong Kong had ranked as the world’s biggest I.P.O. market by the amount of money raised. Yet so far this year, new share sales have declined 14.3 percent, to $1.12 billion, from the same period a year earlier, according to Thomson Reuters data. Companies seem to believe that the answer to turn fortunes around is to employ large numbers of stock underwriters.

Updated, 6:20 p.m. | It has been an eventful few days for Vincens Vuktilaj.
 
Arrested last Friday in connection with a string of necklace snatchings in the Bronx, Mr. Vuktilaj made bail the next day, celebrated his 18th birthday on Sunday, was re-arrested Monday morning and proceeded to lead the police on a prolonged manhunt in subway tunnels and around Harlem after he escaped — handcuffed and shoeless — from custody.

An article on Wednesday about airport lounges for premium-class travelers misstated the number of years that Etihad Airways has been flying out of Kennedy International Airport. It is six years, not four. The article also misstated the size of a private waiting room for Emirates Airlines in Terminal 4 at Kennedy. It is 12,000 square feet, not 4,000.

Billy Crudup ( “The Coast of Utopia” ) and Shuler Hensley ( “The Whale” ) have been added to the cast for the two-play repertory of Harold Pinter’s “No Man’s Land” and Samuel Beckett’s “Waiting for Godot” coming to Broadway this fall, the producers said Monday. Mr. Crudup will play Foster in “No Man’s Land” and Lucky in “Waiting for Godot,” while Mr. Hensley will take on Briggs in “No Man’s Land” and Pozzo in “Godot.” They will join the previously announced cast members Ian McKellen and Patrick Stewart for a 14-week run at the Cort Theater that is scheduled to begin with previews on Oct. 26 and an opening night set for Nov. 24. Both works will be directed by Sean Mathias. The specific schedule and performance dates for each play have not been announced.

A jazz entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the Harlem Jazz Shrines Festival misstated the date and misidentified the site of Lakecia Benjamin’s performances, and misidentified the site of Patience Higgins’s performances. Ms. Benjamin’s performances are tonight; they were not scheduled for Monday night. And performances by both Ms. Higgins, who will play on Thursday night, and by Ms. Benjamin are at Showmans Jazz Club, not at the Apollo Theater. (The performances are being presented by the Apollo.)
An obituary on Saturday about the guitarist Jeff Hanneman, a founder of the band Slayer, misspelled the name of one of the bands with which Slayer has toured. It is Megadeth, not Megadeath.

An article on Monday about the return of a looted dinosaur skeleton to Mongolia referred incompletely to the United States agencies and officials making the return. They are Immigration and Customs Enforcement of the Department of Homeland Security, which had custody, and the Justice Department’s United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. They are not only Justice Department officials. The article also omitted the name of a Mongolian paleontologist who, with Mark A. Norell of the American Museum of Natural History, played a role in halting the auction of the skeleton last year. She is Bolortsetseg Minjin. And because of an editing error, the byline for the article misspelled the writer’s surname. He is Ralph Blumenthal, not Bumenthal.

A new study suggests that men with prostate cancer who take statins may have a lower risk of dying from the disease than those who do not.
 
Statins are not recommended for prostate cancer prevention or treatment. But researchers studied 1,001 prostate cancer patients diagnosed between 2002 and 2005, of whom 289 used statins, which are given mainly to lower cholesterol. They followed them for an average of six years, during which there were 123 total deaths, 39 from prostate cancer.

Aerosmith has canceled a show in Indonesia because of security concerns after the police stopped an alleged plot to bomb the Myanmar Embassy, news agencies have reported . 
 
The concert promoter, Ismaya Live, said the show on Saturday for 15,000 people in Jakarta had to be called off for safety reasons, though it did not spell out a connection with the bomb plot.

I share a lot of dinners with my closest friends, Maggie and Steve, and over the past year I’ve sampled some wonderful sweet pickled vegetables at their house — radishes and turnips, cauliflower and cucumbers — laid out with other nibbles that we enjoy with drinks before dinner. Every time I ask about the recipe and every time Steve tells me it’s from the Momofuku cookbook. Then I go home and forget about it.
 
But last week, with a surfeit of vegetables bought on impulse at the farmers’ market and plans for a trip that was going to take me away for five days, long enough for some of them to come to no good in my refrigerator, I decided I’d look up the Momofuku/David Chang recipe and put up my vegetables before leaving.

An Editorial Observer on Sunday about the San Joaquin Valley incorrectly recounted California’s history. California was under American military control immediately before statehood; it was never a United States territory.

For all her talent and determination to help children eat better, Michelle Obama could still pick up a few pointers from Helen Butleroff-Leahy, a 66-year-old former Rockette turned registered dietitian.
 
 Ms. Butleroff-Leahy devotes her time to teaching children in disadvantaged neighborhoods about eating healthfully and exercising regularly. Her lessons take the form of musical productions, rehearsed in classrooms and on the stages of 52 New York City public schools so far. Children from each school do gymnastics and dance to a rap-based script by Roumel Reaux that entertains while explaining the essentials of good nutrition. The 45-minute production by Ms. Butleroff-Leahy is called “My Plate: The New Food Guide Musical.”

LOS ANGELES — Breaking with a practice that had narrowed Oscar voting in certain categories to those who had seen films on the big screen, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Saturday said it would provide members with DVD versions of nominees in the best foreign film and best documentary short categories, while allowing all voters to cast a final ballot in those races.
 
With the change, all Academy voters are now permitted to vote in all 24 Oscar categories, whether or not they have seen the nominees in a theater. Hawk Koch, the president of the Academy, announced the change at a meeting on Saturday of its members — in person and via video — in Beverly Hills, New York and the San Francisco area.

Air pollution has been linked to cardiovascular disease, and now researchers may be closer to understanding why: it increases atherosclerosis, or hardening of the arteries, a known risk for heart attack and stroke.
 
Researchers did ultrasound examinations on 5,362 men and women over 45 in six metropolitan areas, measuring the thickness of their right common carotid artery, one of two arteries that carry oxygenated blood to the neck and head. Then they followed them for an average of two and a half years, comparing the thickening of their arteries as observed by ultrasound with air pollution data measured by concentrations of particulate matter. The study appears in the April issue of PLoS Medicine.

American children born outside the United States may have a significant advantage over the native-born: They are less likely to have allergies.
 
Researchers studied 79,667 children taking part in a national health survey.

Lauryn Hill, the Grammy-winning singer and songwriter, was sentenced to three months in prison on Monday afternoon for failing to pay income taxes on about $1.8 million in earnings.
 
The sentence in federal court in Newark, N.J., was a major setback for Ms. Hill, 37, a critically acclaimed but reclusive artist whose solo debut album in 1998, “The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill,” established her as a major figure in R&B and hip-hop, earning five Grammy Awards. The Senegalese singer Youssou N’Dour and the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho were named the winners Tuesday of the 2013 Polar Music Prize. Each will be awarded one million Swedish kronor, or about $150,000, and will be invited to a ceremony in Stockholm on Aug. 27.
 
The award committee said Mr. N’Dour, 53, who is known for mixing traditional song forms from Senegal with eclectic styles from Latin America and the United States, had been given the prize not just for his contribution as an entertainer but also because he had “worked to reduce animosities between his own religion, Islam, and other religions.”

Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey ascended to become one of the country’s top political stars almost in spite of his weight — dismissing those who questioned whether his size disqualified him for higher office as “ridiculous” and “irresponsible.” 
 
Now, like some overweight politicians before him, Mr. Christie has embarked on a major effort to shed pounds at a time when his eyes are on the presidency. Saying that “a whole bunch of other things” had not worked, he revealed on Tuesday that he had undergone weight loss surgery three months ago. He is now 40 pounds lighter.

It is only natural for the Metropolitan Opera to refresh its offerings regularly with new productions, even when an old one has been successful. But it is hard to imagine the Met retiring John Dexter’s 1977 staging of Francis Poulenc’s masterpiece “Dialogues des Carmélites” (“Dialogues of the Carmelites”).
 
 Last seen there 10 years ago, the production returned on Saturday afternoon for a three-performance run. It was as austerely powerful as ever, ennobled by an exceptional cast and the purposeful conducting of Louis Langrée.

“Cops,” one of the original reality shows on television, is moving to cable after 24 years on network television.
 
Starting in September, new episodes of the show will be televised exclusively on Spike TV, the president of Spike, Kevin Kay, announced on Monday. Spike will also have the rights to some past episodes of the series.

SOLOWIEJCZYK--Henry, adoring husband of over 50 years to wife Anita devoted son to Sarah and Zelman and devoted brother to sister Sephora loving father to Joseph, Jack, David and Alan and grandchildren Arielle, Joshua, Gabrielle, Joelle and Dylan passed away on Saturday May 4th while on an extended holiday at the home of his son Alan on the island of Bali. Born in Antwerp Belgium Henry's youth was interrupted by the upheaval in Europe during WWII. Resettled in New York with family served in the US military from 1944-1945 in the South Pacific. Henry followed his father into the successful diamond firm of Lieber and Solow until he formed Solow & Co., Inc. in 1997 where he remained active till his last days. Henry was active in Jewish affairs in Long Beach Long Island while raising a family with wife Anita. Henry was an active supporter of the Hebrew Academy of Long Beach Temple Beth El and Yeshiva Bnei Torah as well as Chabad Lubovitch. A successful diamantaire with an old world charm that will surely be missed by all that knew him. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Chapel at 189 Amsterdam Ave. at 76th St. Thursday, May 9th at 11:45am

SIEGLER--Alvin M. MD, Emeritas Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology at SUNY Health Science Center in Brooklyn died on May 4, 2013 at the age of 90. Formerly of Woodmere, NY, currently of Boca Raton, FL and Southbury, CT. A graduate of NYU School of Medicine with an MD degree, he received a Doctorate of Medical Science (DSc) from the University of Pennsylvania. Dr. Siegler specialized in Infertility and was a pioneer in gynecologic endoscopy. He co-authored seven books primarily on the use of endoscopy in gynecologic surgery. He was among the first physicians to use the hysteroscope to search for abnormalities within the uterus. He introduced the technique in China in 1980. Dr. Siegler served as President of the American Association of Gynecologic Laparoscopists, The New York Obstetrical Society, and the Fallopius International Society. A physician for more than 50 years, he leaves a legacy of dedication to scholarship, research, teaching, and the excellent and compassionate care of his patients. Loving and beloved, he is survived by his wife of 65 years, Marcia Malawista Siegler, daughter Dr. Judith Carol Siegler, son Samuel Lewis Siegler MD and his wife Kathy Spenard Siegler, grandchildren Kate, Kevin, Alex, Scott, and Jeffrey, great-grandchildren Tristan and Aiden, nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. He embraced life with passion and enriched it with his creative hands, keen mind, and loving heart. He will be with us always. Memorial Services Thursday, May 9 at 1pm Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, 11115 Jog Road, Boynton Beach, FL. Donations in his memory may be made to The Alvin M. Siegler MD Scholarship Fund in OB-GYN. Please pay to the order of The HSCB Foundation (memo-Acct #

MINOT--Jeffrey. December 26, 1939 - May 6, 2013. Resident of New York, NY, formerly Harrison, NY. 1961 BA Syracuse University, 1964 LLB New York Law School. MINER--Marilyn Stuart, 93, of Lakewood, Colorado passed away Saturday, April 27, 2013. Born in Pawnee, Oklahoma in 1920, Marilyn grew up in the Tulsa area, where she met Paul Lincoln Miner, whom she married in 1940. They moved to Chicago, when Paul joined the Navy during World War II. Upon his return from duty, the couple relocated to New York, where Marilyn spent much of her life, first living in Greenwich Village, where she and Paul ran the Provincetown Playhouse (which was founded by the playwright Eugene O'Neill), and, later, in New City, New York, where the Miners started a family. Marilyn worked for many years as an advertising copywriter. She was also a theater actress, she appeared in a few small movie roles, and she was a published short story author and journalist. In her later years, she lived in Brewster, New York, but she moved to Evergreen, Colorado in 2007 to be closer to her eldest son, Stuart Lincoln Miner of Denver, by whom she is survived along with her youngest son, Timothy Webb Miner of Sherborn, Massachusetts, along with five grandchildren and one great-grandchild. A service for Marilyn will be held at 2:30 pm on Saturday, May 11 at Jefferson Unitarian Church, 14350 W. 32nd Avenue, Golden, Colorado 80401. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Nature Conservancy, www.nature.org. Please share condolences at HoranCares.com.

MIELE--Joel Arthur Sr.,(Captain U.S. Navy, retired) (Rear Admiral New York Naval Militia) of Howard Beach, NY, died peacefully at home on Monday, May 6th, 2013 surrounded by his wife Josephine, children Joel, Jr., VitaMarie Miele Chu and Janet Powers and brother Jean Miele, sister Lana Miele, and Eleanor Miele Herczeg. Born May 28, 1934, in Jersey City, NJ, Mr. Miele was the son of Gennaro S. and Eleanor N. Miele. A graduate of Brooklyn Technical High School, he attended Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, where he earned a Bachelor of Civil Engineering degree. He enlisted in the United States Navy in 1957, was commissioned in the Civil Engineer Corp., served over three years on active duty and 29 years on inactive duty, and retired at the rank of Captain in the Reserve of the Corp. He began practicing as a professional engineer in 1960, served as New York City Department of Buildings Commissioner from 1994 to 1996, served as New York City Department of Environmental Protection Commissioner from 1996 to 2002, and served as a Commissioner at the New York City Board of Standards and Appeals from 2002 to 2005. He and his wife, Josephine Ann Miele, were married February 14, 1959. They began their married life in Norfolk, VA, and moved to Howard Beach in 1961. Mr. Miele is survived by seven grandchildren, a brother, two sisters, many nieces and nephews and very dear friends. Interment at Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, VA. Visiting will be today and Thursday from 2-4pm and from 7-9pm at Quinn-Fogarty, 162-14 Sanford Avenue, Flushing. A service will be celebrated Thursday at 8pm at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to the American Parkinson Disease Association, Inc., or the Queens Library, would be appreciated.

HUGHES--Mildred C.,died peacefully Sunday, May 5, at age 89. The beloved daughter of Mabel Fraser and Paul Hughes, Mildred was born in New York, attended the Garden Day School in Jackson Heights, and ultimately returned to live in the Towers Coop in Jackson Heights with a magnificent view of the Manhattan skyline. A wonderfully offbeat world traveler, Mildred served in the Marine Corps from 1945 to 1946, and was educated at Cornell and SUNY Binghamton, receiving her masters degree in political psychology from Long Island University. She fell in love with the Middle East, studied Arabic and taught in Yemen. A self-confessed news junky who cherished her Scottish heritage, Mildred fell asleep listening to BBC World Service on her shortwave radio, read The Economist, and enjoyed solving double-crostics. Visitation Wednesday evening 7 to 9 at Conway Funeral Home, 82-19 Northern Blvd., Jackson Heights. A funeral service will be held on Thursday 1pm at Community United Methodist Church, 81-10 35th Avenue, Jackson Heights.
GOLDMAN--Alfred. My great friend and mentor - l learned from you, I laughed with you and now I will miss you immeasurably. My heartfelt condolences to Dorothy, Byron and to Ellen. Rodney Propp

COOPER--Evelyn Kazdan, died peacefully at home at the age of 99 years and 8 months. Evelyn was the wife of Norman S. Cooper (deceased); mother of Jonathan S. Cooper, sister of Jean Mack and David F. Fickler. In 1934 she married Alvin Kazdan and moved to Louisville, KY. In 1938 Alvin died and Evelyn went to live in Chicago, IL. She attended the University of Chicago and received Bachelor and Master degrees and was qualified as a professional social worker. Her work brought her back to New York City and it was where she met Norman Cooper, MD. They got married in 1945, a marriage which lasted for 60 years. At all times Evelyn sought to be a responsible wife, a loving mother and a committed social worker. From 1959 to 1979 she was employed by MSKCC as Director of the Dept. of Social Work until her retirement. Evelyn was a woman of determination. She and Norman both had common goals. She loved New York with its ever changing scenery and its challenges. Service will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel located at 630 Amsterdam Ave, New York City on Thursday, May 9th at 11:30am.
