A picture essay on Wednesday about the Kenya Derby at Ngong Racecourse in Nairobi referred incorrectly to the track. It is one of the few horse-racing tracks in a 3,300-mile swath of Africa between Egypt and Zimbabwe; it is not the only one.

The fate of Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase could hinge on a small, London-based firm that is virtually unknown, even on Wall Street.
 
The firm, Governance for Owners, has been tasked with voting the shares of the bank’s largest shareholder — the asset management behemoth BlackRock — on the question of whether to split the jobs of chairman and chief executive. Mr. Dimon been chairman since 2006 and chief executive since 2005.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Monday about a judge’s ruling against George T. McDonald, a Republican mayoral candidate in New York City, in his effort to challenge the city’s donation limits, referred incorrectly to the rules for the city’s campaign finance system. Candidates receive matching funds in return for agreeing to limits on spending, not to limits on donations.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Monday with the continuation of an article about the effects of an $85 billion cut in federal programs on communities throughout the country described incorrectly in some copies a fund-raiser held by a Head Start program in Colorado Springs to deal with the cuts. The fund-raiser, “Fill a Chair,” in which chairs decorated by children are being sold, has so far financed two slots in the program; the fund-raiser has not sold just two chairs.  In addition, the article referred incorrectly to the location of two Head Start projects in Maine where budget cuts have forced closings. The projects are in the municipalities of Topsham and Whitefield — not in “Pejepscot, Me.” and in “North Whitefield, Me.” (Pejepscot is a community in Topsham and North Whitefield is a community in Whitefield.)

An article on Sunday about the National Rifle Association’s annual convention referred incorrectly in some copies to the organization’s selection of James W. Porter II as its new president. He was officially chosen president by the group’s board of directors on Monday; he was not elected during the convention, which ended on Sunday.
An article on Monday about the Yankees’ 5-4 loss to the Oakland Athletics misstated the age of Yankees starting pitcher Andy Pettitte. He is 40, not 41. (He turns 41 on June 15.)

Because of an editing error, an article on April 30 about the first speech to Parliament by Italy’s new prime minister, Enrico Letta, in which he said he would move quickly to stimulate growth and jobs while easing some unpopular austerity measures, misstated Italy’s economic rank among European Union countries. It is the fourth largest, not the third largest. (It is the third largest among those bloc countries that use the euro.)

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Monday with a music review of an updated version of “HPSCHD” by John Cage and Lejaren Hiller, at the Eyebeam Art + Technology Center in Manhattan, reversed the given name and surname of a harpsichordist who performed. As the review correctly noted, he is Neely Bruce. And also because of an editing error, the review omitted part of the name of the group to which the designers of the installation for the performance, Joshua White and Brock Monroe, belong. It is the Joshua Light Show, not the Joshua Light.

During the dot-com boom, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the venture capital investment firm, all but minted money, making prescient early investments in Netscape Communications, Amazon.com and Google and delivering astonishing returns to investors. Along the way, it became a symbol of Silicon Valley.
 
But the firm has hit a rough patch over the last decade, frustrated by unsuccessful forays into clean technology and by a catch-up effort to take later-stage stakes in social media companies.

ALBANY — Something was missing at a public hearing held by the State Senate on Tuesday to examine New York City’s campaign finance system: the public.
 
Even before the hearing began, government watchdog groups complained that Republicans who led the panel would not allow them to testify.

This summer at the almost defiantly unhip South Street Seaport , there shall be pop-up boutiques housed in shipping containers. There shall be outdoor film screenings with lounge-chair seating. There shall be SmorgasBar. And, the lords of artificial weather willing, there may be glitter rain.
 
The seaport has long been the province of tour buses, serpentine lines for the Statue of Liberty-bound Water Taxi and chain stores like Ann Taylor, along with a collection of historic ships and maritime buildings. But starting Memorial Day weekend, a season of hipper programming called See/Change will try to lure New Yorkers to the banks of the East River, in a bid to speed the seaport’s recovery from the ravages of Hurricane Sandy. More than six months after the storm, almost every ground floor shop is still shuttered, their windows painted to hide the gutting taking place inside.

The folksinger Patty Griffin will give the opening concert of the 35th annual “Celebrate Brooklyn!” festival in Prospect Park on June 5, kicking off an eclectic 29-performance series featuring acts like Big Boi, Calexico, Os Mutante, the Waterboys and the gospel star Bebe Winans.
 
Held at the Prospect Park Bandshell, all but five of the concerts are free. The proceeds from the ticketed events, which showcase some bigger acts, go to underwrite BRIC , the arts organization that has put on the festival since 1979.

To Shop: Is It a Bar? A Grocery? Actually, It’s Both

 
The full name of the hot new bar in the financial district is the Dead Rabbit Grocery and Grog. We get the grog part, but grocery? The mixologist Jack McGarry, who owns the bar with Sean Muldoon, also a mixologist, and the restaurateur Peter Poulakakos said it’s a tradition going back to the early 19th century, put in place to satisfy the temperance faction. “Bars had to sell food,” he said. “They were called spirit grocers.” So in the rear of the ground-floor bar are shelves of condiments, jams, canned seafood, chips and pickles (often English and Irish) and items like bitters, made in-house. “It’s mainly stuff that keeps, but we hope to add cured meats and cheeses,” Mr. McGarry said. “There are very few places to buy these things in this neighborhood”: Open 11 a.m. to 4 a.m., 30 Water Street (Broad Street), (646) 422-7906, deadrabbitnyc.com .

Eggplant is often described as a polarizing food, one that people either love or hate. I’m the counterexample. I like it well enough, unless it’s overcooked, which emphasizes the mushy texture and slight bitterness that seem to repel so many. That tendency toward bitterness, especially when combined with the spinach in Mary McCartney’s dish of eggplant wraps , makes it a difficult pairing. I think of reds first, but nothing too tannic, which would clash with the bitterness. The sweet and spicy fruit of a lighter-weight zinfandel would work well. So might a lively Sicilian red like a nero d’Avola or a cerasuolo di Vittoria. Assertive whites would work well, too, like a sauvignon blanc, even a flamboyantly styled example, or a good, dry chenin blanc, like a Vouvray or Savennières.
 
What would you pair with these eggplant wraps ? Post your suggestions in the comments section.

Recipe Lab , a monthly feature, invites you to cook with the Dining section. This month we’re making Southern fried chicken from “The Way to Fry,” by Norman King. If you’d like to take part in the video chat, you can find details here . 

 
Many modern cooks have never learned to fry. We are convinced that fried food is unhealthy, unpopular and messy. But Norman King, a lifelong Southerner, a registered dietitian and a food editor at Southern Living, is out to change that.

Blue Note Records, a storied label in jazz, has plans to partner with ArtistShare , a pioneering crowd-financing platform, for a hybrid called Blue Note/ArtistShare. The joint venture suggests one tactical response to the pressures now facing the record business, especially in and around the jazz field.
 
The new arrangement — orchestrated by Brian Camelio, the founder of ArtistShare; Bruce Lundvall, chairman emeritus of Blue Note; and Don Was, Blue Note’s president — will essentially serve as a low-risk development arm of the label. Blue Note will help select the artists, and apply its imprimatur and promotional resources to each finished album. But the costs of recording will be shouldered by fans, in the standard mode of ArtistShare projects. Musicians will retain full ownership of their master recordings.

Demand for electronic devices seems to be growing faster than the number of outlets available to charge them. Hoping to provide power to those in need, Etón has introduced a series of portable backup batteries called BoostBloc.
 
The BoostBloc batteries come in three options, each offering greater power than the last, with internal lithium ion batteries that provide an electrical charge measured in ampere-hours. For instance, Eton’s most powerful block, the BoostBloc 6600, provides 6,600 milliampere-hours, enough to fully charge a smartphone three times.

TRANI--Salvatore J.,72, of Brookville, NY and Palm Beach Gardens, FL died on May 7, 2013. Sal was born on February 13, 1941 in Brooklyn, NY. He was a veteran of the US Navy and held a BS and MBA from New York University. Since 2005, he served as Executive Managing Director of BGC Partners. Prior to that, he served as President and Chief Executive Officer of Garban/ICAP Corporates. Over the span of his 50+ year career, he played a leading role in the development and subsequent globalization of the inter-dealer brokerage business. He began his professional career at Stern, Lauer and Co. and later joined Mabon, Nugent and Co. eventually becoming Chairman and CEO of IMI N.A. He was a member of the Board of Trustees of Boston College and a founding member of the Boston College Wall Street Council. He was a board member of the Copshot Foundation, as well as a founding member of the NYC Police and Firefighters Widows' and Childrens' Fund, and the Inner-City Scholarship Fund. He was also a member of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity, a Knight of Malta and a Knight of the Holy Sepulcher. Beloved husband of Marianne, loving father of Allison Kellan (Robert) and Christiane Koundourakis (Alex), and loving grandfather of Tanner, Luke, Jaimie, Brooke and Lia. Survived by brothers Joseph and Dominick Trani, sister Ann Trani Coppolo and many nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at St. Jean the Baptiste Church, in New York City.
TAYLOR--Benjamin, "Brie", April 26, 2013 in Westerly, RI. He was former Dean, Professor of Art, Artist and Author.

STEINBOOK--Helen, of Toms River, NJ, on May 7, 2013. Beloved wife of Nathan. Former resident of Coconut Creek, FL and NYC. Devoted mother of Melvin Steinbook (Susan Avny) and Linda Grossman (Ted), cherished grandmother of Matthew, Benjamin, Andrew and Michael. SMITH--Dr. Howie, 56. Beloved husband of Joan. Loving father of Alyssa, Joshua, Eric and Benjamin. Son of the late Nat and Arlene Smith. Stepson of Priscilla Smith. Died in Albany, NY on May 8, 2013. Funeral on Friday at Temple Beth Emeth in Albany.

ROSEN--Marilyn R.,86, formerly of Syosset, NY and Plainview, NY, passed away on May 7, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Stanley Rosen. Daughter of the late Robert and Selma Schecter. Mother of Daniel J. Rosen (Beverly), Andrew S. Rosen and Lawrence H. Rosen (Kathleen). Grandmother of Tracy, Hannah, Sam and Kelly. Sister of Marie. Steadfastly devoted to her family and friends. Funeral today 11am at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Memorial donations may be made to the AHRC Nassau.

RABINOWITZ--Larry, on May 6th, 2013. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of Larry, after a valiant fight against heart disease. Beloved husband of Angelica. A most loving son to Iris and Stanley. A cherished brother of Suzanne Kramer and Jeffrey Rabinowitz. Larry's humor, compassion and zest for life will be missed by all whose lives he touched. Services today, 1pm at Gutterman's 8000 Jericho Tpke. Woodbury, NY 11797

NUSSBAUM--Josephine, on May 4. Loving wife of Albert. Devoted sister of Grace Ann Propcopis and Frank Figlia. Memorial Service will be Friday, 1:30pm at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), Madison Ave at 81st.

MORRIS--Joseph M. Beloved husband of Fay. Devoted father of Ann Kornhauser, Sue and Avi Kendi. Adoring grandfather of Evan, Lindsay, Craig, Daniel and Matthew. Loving great-grandfather of Mollie. Past President of I.J. Morris Funeral Homes. Funeral service at Temple Beth Shalom of Roslyn at 11:30am on Thursday May 9th. Interment Monterfiore Cemetery Saint Albans, NY.

MIELE--Joel A.,Sr. The Zoning Advisory Council mourns the loss of Joel A. Miele, Sr., P.E. As an engineer in private practice and an official at various zoning and building agencies, we admired his talent, integrity and understanding of the issues faced by our community. We extend our condolences to his family. Sheldon Lobel, President Zoning Advisory Council

MIELE--Joel A.,Sr. The Board of Trustees of Queens Library mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, Joel A. Miele, Sr., P.E. He served the people of Queens as a library trustee for more than 32 years with wisdom and humor, and was president of the board in 1995 and 1996. We extend sincere sympathies to Josephine, and all of Joel's friends and family. The Board of Trustees of Queens Library Jacqueline E. Arrington, Chair Thomas W. Galante, President and CEO

MIELE--Joel A.,Sr. The American Parkinson Disease Association joins the many grieving at the passing of Joel A. Miele Sr., PE, chairman of our board of directors and friend. Miele Jr., PE; his daughters Vita Marie Chu and Janet Powers and their families. Leslie A. Chambers President & CEO

LIBRETTO--Ellen V.,66, passed away Saturday, May 4th after a brief illness. A fifth generation New Yorker and graduate of Queens College, BA 68 anthropology MLS 1970. She held a managerial position in New York City public libraries coordinating young adult services, training librarians, working with teams and coordinating reading materials for adults. Following a career in the library system, she joined Random House as library marketing manager for Ballantine Books where she worked with such authors as Ray Bradbury, Elizabeth Berg, Anne Perry and Collin Powell. After leaving Random House, she consulted on library marketing for several independent publishers. As an author, she wrote the YA non-fiction book "The General Slocum Ferryboat Fire of 1904", as well as books in the library field including "New Directions for Young Adult Services" and the much referenced "High/Low Handbooks: Best Books and Web Sites for Reluctant Teen Readers". She dedicated her recent retirement time to the research of a documentary DVD, now under production about her great-grandfather, world famous sculpture and artist Frederick Triebel whose works include the Soldiers and Sailors Monument in Peoria, IL, honoring those who served in the Civil War. Libretto is survived by husband Adam Conrad, brother George Stauffer and in her words "a motley crew of cousins and friends".

KLEIN--Lillian, 99 on May 7, 2013. Devoted wife of 66 years to Harold Klein. Celebrating her are her children, Ellen Siroka Robinson, Jane W. Parver and Tony Klein, daughter-in-law Jennifer Boyer Klein, grandchildren Matthew Siroka, Jesse and Tim Klein, their spouses Alejandra Siroka, Isaiah Seret and great-grandsons Asa and Indi Seret. Born September 7, 1913, she fulfilled Seward Park High School's prophecy as girl most likely to succeed, earning her M.A. from Hunter College in embryonic biology and working with Dr. Stella Chase in a ground-breaking study of childhood congenital rubella syndrome. At 98 Lillian's enthusiasm for life and aqua-aerobics was awe-inspiring. Volunteer, avid traveler and bicyclist, her intelligence, vibrancy and dedication to family leave a legacy of inspiration and love.

FISH--Robert. (March 12, 1935 - May 5, 2013). Born in NYC. Entrepreneur, Philanthropist, Successful Business & Family Man. Co-Founder of Right Management Consultants. Harvard graduating class of 1956. He will be missed.

DAVIS--Beatrice Greenapple, 87, of Floral Park, NY, died at home on May 7, 2013, surrounded by her loving family. Born April 7, 1926 in Brooklyn, NY. Beloved daughter of the late Pauline and Jack Greenapple. She is survived by Melvin, her loving husband of 67 years; cherished daughters Deborah, Jamie Germaine (Greg Ross), Susan Pereira (Vanderlei); grandchildren Jenna(Carolyn), Paul (Michelle), great-grandsons Brodie and Keegan, brother Larry Greenapple, sister Florine Dorfmann and nieces and nephews. Bea was a graduate of Brooklyn College, received a Masters in Education with a specialty in reading from Hofstra University, and completed additional graduate studies in that field. Throughout her career Bea taught at many levels, from nursery to graduate school. She also chaired the reading department at Westbury Jr. High School in New York for several years. After her retirement, she pursued her lifelong love of words and literature by devoting her creative energy to writing poetry. She had two books of poetry published, and numerous poems have been included in various anthologies. Bea was an active member of Temple Sinai of Roslyn, serving on a number of committees. She was an outstanding cook and baker, and her family always looked forward to her holiday meals. Bea and Mel spent many happy summers at their cottage on Prince Edward Island, Canada. Family was paramount in Bea's life and her happiest times were having family gathered together for holidays and celebrations. Funeral services at Temple Sinai of Roslyn Heights, NY, Thursday, May 9th at 11:30am. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery. Shiva will be observed at the Davis home. Donations may be made to a charity of choice.

CURRAN--Eileen M.,of Waterville, Maine, died April 22, 2013, aged 85. She was born in Ann Arbor, Michigan, on 11 May 1927, the only child of Edward O. and Laura (Meyer) Curran. She received a B.A. degree with highest distinction from Cornell University in 1948; an Honours B.A. from Cambridge University (England) in 1950; an M.A. from Cambridge University in 1953; and a Ph.D. from Cornell in 1958. She was an instructor of English at the University of New Hampshire, 1951-1954; a teaching assistant at Cornell, 1950-51 and 1954-56; instructor in English at Ohio University, 1956-58. At her death, she was professor of English emerita at Colby College, where she taught from 1958 until retiring in 1992. From 1973 to 1976 she was also director of Colby's Miller Library. An authority on 19th-century British periodicals, she was an associate editor of The Wellesley Index to Victorian Periodicals, volumes 1-3, contributed to other reference works, and published many articles, both in print journals and more recently on-line. There are no immediate survivors. At her request, there will be no visiting hours or services. Those so desiring may make contributions in her memory to the Colby College Library.

The three-time All-Pro Ronde Barber is retiring after a 16-year career with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers that included a Super Bowl title and five Pro Bowl appearances. The Buccaneers said Barber, the 38-year-old twin of the former Giants running back Tiki Barber, would not return to play on a defense overhauled since the end of last season. Tampa Bay acquired Darrelle Revis, Dashon Goldson and the second-round draft pick Johnthan Banks for its secondary. Barber played cornerback for 15 seasons before moving to safety last year.

Want quick information about your computer’s wireless connection? Clicking the Wireless Network Connection icon in the Notification area of the Windows desktop taskbar opens a panel that shows the name of the current network. Passing the mouse cursor over the network’s name displays a ScreenTip listing the signal strength, type of encryption security and other details. A link at the bottom of the panel opens the Network and Sharing control panel for wireless-network management and settings.
 
Taskbar icons may vary from computer to computer as some manufacturers have their own network-management utilities in the taskbar, like Lenovo’s ThinkVantage Access Connections software, but the general Windows network settings are just a couple of clicks away from the Control Panel in the Start menu. The Network and Sharing control panel in most recent versions of Windows also has a link to a troubleshooting wizard for helping with network-connection problems ( bit.ly/SEVZQS ).
A chart on Wednesday with an article about the stock market’s performance on Tuesday was published in error. The chart showed the Dow Jones industrial average’s activity for Monday.
Fog obscured views Wednesday along the Coney Island Boardwalk. Heavy rain fell across the region; three inches was recorded in Central Park by midafternoon.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about surgery that Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey had in February to lose weight referred incorrectly to a physician with whom he had an angry back and forth over the danger of his weight. The physician, Dr. Connie Mariano (not identified by name in the article), is a former White House doctor, not a former surgeon general.

An article on Wednesday about hospitals’ widely varying billings for the same procedures misstated part of the name of the federal agency that released the billing data. It is the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (not the Center).

An article on Monday about the Syrian government’s public condemnation of Israel for its powerful air assault on military targets near Damascus misstated the year of Syria’s most recent armed clash with Israel. It was 1982, when Israel invaded Lebanon and briefly fought with Syrian forces, not 1973.

An article in some editions on Tuesday about the Rangers’ 4-3 victory over the Washington Capitals in Game 3 of their N.H.L. playoff series referred incorrectly in some copies to Brian Boyle’s goal for the Rangers that tied the score, 1-1. He scored at 12 minutes 50 seconds of the first period, not the second period. And the goal came as the Rangers’ second power play expired, not their fifth.

An article in some editions on Tuesday about a forum for New York City mayoral candidates organized by the animal rights group Nyclass misspelled the given name of a leader of the group and also misidentified the office she holds. She is Allie Feldman, not Ali, and she is the group’s executive director, not its president.

Because of an editing error, the Economic Scene column on Wednesday, about the United States’ lag in high-speed broadband, misstated the number of homes served by AT&T, which is expanding its U-verse high-speed network. It plans to make the network available to 33 million homes, an increase of 8.5 million; it does not currently serve 100 million homes.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Tuesday with a report in a roundup of science news about the 20th anniversary of the world’s first Web site misstated the year the site was posted. As the report correctly noted, it was 1993, not 1983.

An article on April 24 about conflicting reports on the fate of two Syrian archbishops who had been seized on a road trip outside their home city of Aleppo misidentified the position within the Greek Orthodox Church that is held by Tony Yazigi, a relative of one kidnapping victim. He is a priest, not a bishop.

A correction in this space on Tuesday for a jazz entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the Harlem Jazz Shrines Festival referred incorrectly to a musician, Patience Higgins, who will perform at Showmans Jazz Club in Manhattan tonight. He is a man.

An article on Wednesday about three women who were freed after being imprisoned inside a home in Cleveland for almost a decade misstated the given name of the uncle of the three brothers arrested in connection with the case. Their uncle is Julio Cesar Castro, not Julian. The article also misstated the given name of the father of the brothers. He was Pedro (Nona) Castro, not Julio.

LAS VEGAS — Just outside the grand ballroom at the Bellagio hotel early Wednesday morning, Anthony Scaramucci, the backslapping host of the country’s largest hedge fund conference, spotted Gregory J. Fleming, president of Morgan Stanley Investment Management and one of Mr. Scaramucci’s most important business relationships.
 
“Is your kid still in town? Does he want to meet Train?” Mr. Scaramucci asked, referring to the adult-contemporary rock band performing at the event. “It’s great to have you here; it really means a lot to me.”

Jabra , best known for its Bluetooth phone accessories, is making its first foray into Bluetooth premium headphones with the $250 Revo Wireless .
 
While the Revo has the fashionably overstated bass sound, it also has an equalizer app so you can dial the bass down to a more realistic level — or up to a brain punishing thud.

Microsoft named Amy Hood, an executive at the company, as its chief financial officer, the first woman to hold the top finance job at Microsoft. 
 
Ms. Hood, 41, joined Microsoft in late 2002 and was most recently the chief financial officer of Microsoft’s business division, the unit that oversees its lucrative Office suite of applications. She replaces Peter Klein, Microsoft’s chief financial officer who announced recently that he was resigning to spend more time with his family.

Kenny Chesney has his seventh No. 1 album on the Billboard 200 chart as “Life on a Rock” sold 153,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Garth Brooks is the only country act with more No. 1 songs on the chart, with eight. Last week’s No. 1, Michael Bublé’s “To Be Loved,” slipped to No. 2 in its second week, with 96,000 in sales. Justin Timberlake’s “20/20 Experience” holds at No. 3 with 68,000. Fantasia’s “Side Effects of You” was No. 4 in its second week, with 36,000, while “The Heist,” from Macklemore & Ryan Lewis, rose from No. 11 to No. 5, with 35,000.
 
Macklemore & Ryan Lewis racked up a second No. 1 song this week with their recent release “Can’t Hold Us,” joining an elite club of acts who have seen their first two singles rise to the top of Billboard’s Hot 100 . The hip hop duo’s “Thift Shop,” featuring the singer Wanz, has been in the Top 10 for months and held the No. 1 spot for six weeks, though not all in row. This week that song slipped down to No. 6. Billboard said the duo is the first act to send its first two charted singles to the top of the chart since Lady Gaga did so in 2009 with “Just Dance” and “Poker Face.” Bruno Mars, as a solo artist, pulled off the same feat with “Just the Way Your Are” and “Grenade.”

Jeffrey K. Skilling, imprisoned for the last six years because of his role in the fraud that caused the collapse of Enron, has reached a deal that could reduce his sentence by more than a decade.

It was a simple question about improving airport security, the kind that candidates for mayor field up to three times a day at campaign forums across New York City.
 
But a flippant reply from Joseph J. Lhota, a Republican, has unleashed an unusually angry and biting reaction from the region’s police officers, inflaming a group that Mr. Lhota has long viewed as a natural political ally.

More than 100 people gathered in front of the New York Public Library’s Fifth Avenue flagship building on Wednesday afternoon to register opposition to the library’s renovation plan .
 
The rally against the project (known as the Central Library Plan) was timed to coincide with the quarterly meeting of the library’s trustees.

An article last Thursday about Williamsburg, Brooklyn, erroneously included several products that are not sold at the store By Brooklyn. Its merchandise does not include dandelion and burdock soda, lovage soda syrup or Early Bird granola. The article also referred incorrectly to the address of the thrift shop Vice Versa. It is on Bedford Avenue, not Bedford Street.
An article last Thursday about elaborate ways to ask for prom dates misspelled the maiden name of an etiquette expert. She is Lisa Mirza Grotts, not Lisa Mira Grotts.

A picture last Thursday with the Beauty Spots column , about cosmetics made from byproducts of bees, was published in error. It showed Rodial’s Bee Venom Super Serum, not Bee Venom Eye, which can be seen at nytimes.com/fashion.

The frontman for the Christian metal band As I Lay Dying was arrested on Tuesday in Oceanside, Calif., and charged with attempting to hire a hit man to kill his estranged wife, the San Diego County Sheriff’s Department said.
 
Detectives arrested the singer, Tim Lambesis , 32, at 2 p.m. in a store shortly after he had asked an undercover detective to murder his wife, who lives in nearby Encinitas, the sheriff’s department said. The investigation began a week earlier, when sheriffs received a tip that Mr. Lambesis had asked someone else about performing a hired killing. The singer was charged with solicitation of another to commit murder. No other details about the investigation were given.

For a group that split up more than four decades ago and never reunited, the Beatles are certainly finding plenty of opportunities to appear on Broadway. “Let It Be,” a popular British concert show based around the band’s music, will make its mop-topped way from the West End to Broadway this summer, press representatives for the production said on Wednesday. 
 
“Let It Be,” which was created to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Fab Four, had its debut at London’s Prince of Wales Theater last fall, then transferred to the Savoy Theater, where it continues to play an open-ended run.

Having a hard time imagining a palatial Republican Club in the middle of blue Manhattan — with a sumptuous main lounge, fireplaces at either end, that offers a panorama of Bryant Park through its great windows, and an oak-trimmed dining room where each of the pilasters is topped by an “RC” crest? 
 
Would it sound more like a New York story if we told you that the Republicans reluctantly turned the clubhouse over to a bunch of journalists, after which the building was used by a drug-rehabilitation program that installed a mural, depicting the path out of addiction, along the curving grand staircase on which luminaries of the Republican Party once trod?

WASHINGTON — It may soon be easier and faster to surf the Web at 30,000 feet.

Roger Federer, the second seed and defending champion, made an early exit Thursday from the Madrid Open, his first clay tournament of the year. Kei Nishikori’s 6-4, 1-6, 6-2 victory over Federer was the second major upset of the week; Novak Djokovic, the world No. 1, was defeated by Grigor Dimitrov on Tuesday. Rafael Nadal, the favorite to win the tournament, advanced to the quarterfinals by beating Mikhail Youzhny, 6-2, 6-3.

The Minnesota Orchestra , where musicians have been locked out in a labor dispute since October, announced on Wednesday that it had canceled its concerts through June 2 – effectively, the rest of its season. At the same time, Michael Henson, the orchestra’s president and chief executive, announced a series of concerts for late July and early August, with repertory drawn from this season’s unperformed programs, saying in a statement that the concerts were added because “we are not willing to give up on our entire season.”
 
But those summer concerts are theoretical: throughout the season, the musicians have refused to negotiate during the lockout. Management, however, emboldened by the settlement last month of a similarly contentious labor dispute at the Saint Paul Chamber Orchestra , has asked the players to negotiate on May 20, 21 and 22, with the assistance of a federal mediator.

ATLANTA — Inside Craig Ivey’s travel bag are objects reminiscent of the Middle Ages.
 
He has a steel, rounded shield; a five-sided, wooden shield; a red, white and blue surcoat; a protective vest; a wraparound helmet, pockmarked with dents; steel pads to hide his forearms, knees, legs and hands; and a blunt-edged sword designed to inflict pain but not cut. His collection cost about $4,000.

The nation’s largest cardiovascular health organization has a new message for Americans: Owning a dog may protect you from heart disease. 
 
The unusual message was contained in a scientific statement published on Thursday by the American Heart Association, which convened a panel of experts to review years of data on the cardiovascular benefits of owning a pet. The group concluded that owning a dog, in particular, was “probably associated” with a reduced risk of heart disease.

Even as demonstrators were outside the New York Public Library’s flagship Fifth Avenue building on Wednesday, protesting the library’s renovation plans, the library’s trustees were inside deciding to make the first public expenditure on that plan: $9 million for the project’s architect, Norman Foster. 
 
The allocation is the first part of $150 million in financing that New York City has committed to the project. All told, Mr. Foster will be paid $11.5 million for the project’s design phase; the additional funds will come from private sources, the library said.

It may sound like a solution: You are mired in debt and a telemarketer calls, offering to help reduce the amount you owe, in exchange for a fee.
 
But consumers should be very wary of such calls, said Claire Rosenzweig, president and chief executive of the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York. “If someone just willy-nilly calls you and says they can reduce your debt, just don’t do it,” she said. The better choice is to hang up and do your own research about the legitimate resources that are available to help you, she said. Then, you can initiate your own call, once you are comfortable with an agency’s credentials.

For airline passengers who wonder what carriers will think to charge for next, Frontier Airlines has an answer that is threefold: nonalcoholic drinks, carry-ons and using Expedia. Soda, coffee, tea and juice will soon cost $1.99 for basic- and economy-fare ticket holders. Water in a glass will be free, but not bottled water. Some members of Frontier’s frequent-flier program are exempt from the fee, which was announced in conjunction with a $25 to $100 fee to stow carry-ons for basic passengers who booked their ticket through a third-party site. The fees are expected to take effect this summer.

Why suffer through grumbling vacations with others when it’s so much more blissful to go it alone?

 
The first rule of travel is that you should always go with someone you love, which is why I travel alone. The writer’s life is more openly narcissistic than most, yet it takes a true connoisseur of self-involvement, a grand master in the art of selfishness, to experience the world’s delights as they are meant to be enjoyed: through one pair of eyes, via one set of ears, with the perfect use of your own nostrils, tongue and touch. I believe that traveling alone is the last great test of who you are in a world where everyone aches to be the same.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday, about New York City parents who try to balance where they will live with where they want their children to go to school, misidentified the school in Brooklyn that has a curriculum of dual-language immersion starting in prekindergarten, as well as art, music, dance and fencing. It is Public School 705, also known as the Brooklyn Arts and Science Elementary School, not the Exceed Charter School. (They are in the same building.) The article also misidentified the Manhattan neighborhood where Kelly Bare and Jonathan Cohen lived before moving into a two-bedroom rental in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. It is the Lower East Side, not the East Village.

With her impeccable eye and philanthropic largess, Carla Fendi is aiming to revive the faded glories of the once majestic Spoleto Festival.

 
On a quiet morning in the Umbrian hill town of Spoleto, Carla Fendi is pacing the stage of a 19th-century theater that now bears her name. “Come here,” she says, conspiratorially, in low-pitched Italian, taking me by the arm to inspect the back of a vast hand-painted stage curtain. She runs her index finger over the spots where conservationists sewed up tears and points out where gaping holes were patched with thermoplastic backing — all part of Fendi’s $1.5 million renovation of the theater. “I am in awe of the artisans who made this curtain whole again,” she says. “There were so many holes, they looked like clouds.”

This column appears in the May 12 issue of The New York Times Magazine.

One of the most exciting installations in New York City the week of the Frieze Art Fair can be found not on Randall’s Island but in Chelsea, in the basement of the Hôtel Americano . There, the German artist Tobias Rehberger has constructed Bar Oppenheimer, a facsimile of his favorite Frankfurt watering hole, which he describes as both a sculptural artwork and a utilitarian space. The space, which opens May 10 and will remain open until July 14, dazzles the senses with its salonlike atmosphere, tight dimensions and prismatic black-and-white stripes; it’s also a functional bar where anyone can stop in for a drink during the life of the project.
 
Bar Oppenheimer reflects Rehberger’s interest in creating sculptures, objects and environments that make references to humdrum mass culture while altering their spirit and import through the addition of color, textures and new dimensions. In 2009, the artist won the Golden Lion award at the 53rd Venice Art Biennale for his redesign of the event’s cafeteria, a white space he flooded with giant black polka dots, mirrors and dapples of bright pink and yellow. About his latest project, Rehberger said, “I love that this installation is essentially a little bar within a bar. And it reinforces my desire to create spaces that are paradoxical — spaces that, to look at, are both attractive and camouflaged.”

Inner Mongolia, China, Aug. 21, 2012

 
Last summer, I was in Xiang Sha Wan, an area along the eastern edge of the Gobi Desert in the Inner Mongolia autonomous region of China, traveling with a Japanese photographer. Roughly translated as “the singing sands,” Xiang Sha Wan is known for its incredibly huge sand dunes. Among them, a Mongolian businessman built a theme park, which includes a soon-to-open hotel, a ski lift and a geodesic dome theater where dancers, singers and actors perform. It’s a surreal spot, out in the middle of nowhere, perfectly captured by this shot I took

The Mexican architect Tatiana Bilbao may favor Brutalist forms, but with her signature light touch she’s creating her country’s most elegant buildings.

 
If your first thoughts of Mexico are of drug wars and narco-terrorism, you may have missed out on one of the most improbable cultural resurgences of recent memory, one that has touched filmmaking, art and, now, architecture.

Ever think twice about using Airbnb , the Web site for short-term home and apartment stays, for fear the traveler or host could be posing under a false name to run a Nigerian prince-style scheme on you? To put your mind at ease, Airbnb added identity verification last month to its site so you can be sure the person you’re e-mailing is who he says he is. Users can upload a photo of their driver’s license or passport and confirm personal historical data about themselves, and Airbnb will compare that information with their Facebook or LinkedIn profiles or Airbnb reviews to verify their backgrounds.

Continuing its series of philanthropic collaborations with fashion and interior designers, the online home marketplace One Kings Lane tapped eight talents to create limited-edition prints for its inaugural Designer Series Beach Towels sale. The prints range from kitschy silhouettes of beach gear and diamonds (by Robert Verdi) to floral motifs (by Tracy Reese and Nanette Lepore) to geometric patterns (by Rebecca Minkoff, Celerie Kemble, Steven Alan and Jenni Kayne). Because they’re produced in the same basic colors, they can be mixed and matched easily. Beginning Monday, each designer will take a turn having a sale on OneKingsLane.com , offering several prints each for a few days at a time, with the proceeds benefiting a charity of the maker’s choosing. The first is Tracy Reese’s collection in support of AIDS Fund-New York Community Trust on May 13; the last is Jenni Kayne’s set to benefit Baby 2 Baby on June 18.
 
Designer Series Beach Towels, $29; onekingslane.com/beachtowels (beginning May 13).

Herbert Blau, a fiercely iconoclastic theater director, scholar and theorist who staged some of the earliest productions of Beckett, Brecht and Genet in the United States, died in Seattle on May 3, his 87th birthday.
 
The cause was a sarcomatoid carcinoma of the chest, a type of cancer, his family said.

Back when air travel was new and glamorous, the check-in desk, where an elegant air hostess would greet you, was a delightful way to start your journey. Nowadays, it is more often the site of overwhelmed agents contending with long lines of frustrated travelers.
 
Citing this reason, the low-cost British airline EasyJet closed all its airport check-in desks last month and replaced them with bag-drop desks, following the lead of its competitor Ryanair, which removed its check-in desks in 2009. Now EasyJet passengers are encouraged to check in online beforehand and print their boarding passes before arriving at the airport or download them onto smartphones.

Nigel Peake’s rural Irish roots were the muse for his 2011 book of drawings, “ In the Wilds .” This year, the artist moved to Lausanne, the Swiss city on the shores of Lake Geneva, to teach architecture. The new setting influenced a series of 26 pen drawings that will be on view for a month starting today at the Paris boutique Colette . Peake’s “story of drawings,” as he calls it, tells the tale of a young boy who is afraid of the dark and takes solace in building boats. As with his other work, there is no visible human presence—the boy is only implied through images that hint at a larger narrative. For those who can’t make it to Paris to see the originals, Peake has self-published a limited-edition compilation of the images, called “In the Dark.” 
 
The precision of Peake’s drawings, which have been commissioned by the likes of Hermès, is what makes them captivating: through a strong awareness of geometry, he conveys a sense of peaceful stillness, spirited yet solemn. He does so with humble tools: “I like pens because you can carry them around in your pocket and use them to instantly make something,” he says. The context for his work, whether it’s self-published zines or campaigns for high-profile clients, doesn’t affect the way he makes it: “I love to draw, and so that remains,” he says.
Rub-a-Dub Victoria Harbor in Hong Kong is now home to a 54-foot-tall inflatable duck. The installation, by the Dutch artist Florentijn Hofman , will stick around until June 9.

An article and a picture caption last Sunday about hiking in the Bernese Oberland of Switzerland misspelled the surname of a James Bond villain in Ian Fleming’s novel “On Her Majesty’s Secret Service,” and in a film of the same name, whose lair was the revolving Piz Gloria restaurant on Mount Schilthorn. He is Ernst Stavro Blofeld, not Blofield.

Though Neil LaBute’s drama “reasons to be pretty” was nominated for three Tony awards in 2009 and received largely good reviews , it closed after a short run , without winning any of the awards. Were some put off by the opening scene’s expletive-fueled rant that one character, Steph, unloaded on Greg, her soon to be ex-boyfriend? ( At one performance an audience member was provoked enough to scream back at the actress, Marin Ireland.) 
 
Whatever led to the closing, there is good news for those of us who appreciate Mr. LaBute’s (admittedly sometimes loud and profane) honesty: the coming “Reasons to be Happy,” his companion piece to the earlier “reasons.”

Forum, Stratford, Ontario 

 
Billed as a festival within a festival, this series of more than 150 talks, film screenings, comedy shows, musical performances and tours gives a backstage glimpse of the Stratford Festival’s theater productions, which run through October. After taking in “Romeo and Juliet” (above), which opens May 27, you can hear the essayist Adam Gopnik talk about the role of feasts in Shakespeare’s works, over dinner, on May 31, or the director Tim Carroll explain the original pronunciations of Shakespeare’s text on June 1.

The artist Joshua Abelow creates a drawing inspired by Gabrielle Calvocoressi’s poetic encounter with a deer in the twilight.
 He’s huge. Standing there in the woods where I didn’t even see him at first. He doesn’t know I’m looking and then he moves a little bit and kicks the ground. I was walking by myself as the sun set. I kept going in deeper to the greenest spot until I found a clearing. He was the clearing. He took the clearing up and stood there still and watched me till I saw him. I saw his shoulders first and then his neck. I think he was so golden in the sun I didn’t know what he was. And I thought the branches were his horns. I thought he was an eight point stag. And how his chest made a kind of giant heart out of me out of my eyes looking. And he let me look. He stood there in the green not moving. I thought his horns were leaves. I saw eight branches coming from his head. He didn’t stop my looking. He didn’t run away. I watched the whole of him. I saw his arms and the taper of his legs. He let me watch him for maybe hours but really moments like a gift. Like when you’re almost home and smell them cooking supper but you’re still outside and could just turn back around. We stood like that together. He let me touch the whole of him. Every rise and muscle. He let me rest on the hollow of his neck and breathe it in for four whole breaths. He said my name or he shook his head inside the leaves and sighed and let the light come into us. He let the light hold us for a while.

You may not get room service or a terry cloth robe, but what Airbnb vacation rentals lack in amenities, they make up for in unbelievable, sometimes rather bizarre experiences.

 
One of urban life’s uncommon diversions is the chance to ransack the drawers of an anonymous neighbor. Airbnb is the Internet service, for those of you who don’t have a Danish architect leafing through your local Lonely Planet at your kitchen table right now, that lets “hosts” rent their extra bedrooms or entire apartments, mansions, tiki huts or goatskin yurts to travelers. In only five years, Airbnb has created a marketplace that offers 300,000 listings in 35,000 cities in 192 countries. It’s been so successful that half the tech start-ups these days go around flattering themselves with Airbnb comparisons: there’s an Airbnb for boats, and one for power tools, and probably one that will let you rent out your extra sheep to fertilize somebody’s lawn. Airbnb, for its part, might bill itself as a cheaper, roomier, warmer way to overnight — less deracinated than a hotel, but without the creaky-floorboard unease of a bed and breakfast — but the great unadvertised draw is the chance to spend time amid somebody else’s trappings.
Designers new to horology are shaking up the field with sporty, thoroughly unbusinesslike wristwatches.

This month, the interior decorator James Huniford unveils a brand-new Chelsea showroom and a sophisticated furniture collection , made up of the type of pieces the designer previously created only as one-offs for his high-profile clients. The designs, Huniford says, are meant to be “user-friendly” — scale and contemporary livability are paramount, and dimensions, as well as upholstery, are all customizable. This is furniture that inhabits that elegant territory somewhere between modern and classic. A tufted slope-armed sofa ($7,800) is refreshed with a casual low-slung profile; a campaign-style side table ($4,800) is cheekily updated with a not-remotely-portable stone slab and chains; and a two-tiered occasional table ($5,800) has a brass base with an industrial feel. “I like the tension between contrasting materials,” the designer says. “Metal and stone, wood and glass.”

Obsessed with W. B. Yeats’s epic poem “The Wanderings of Oisin,” the perfumer David Seth Moltz traveled to Ireland and Scotland to collect inspiration for HYLNDS, his latest collection for the Brooklyn-based D. S. & Durga . What emerged from his travels are three unisex scents that each evoke the lands in the Celtic myths Yeats drew upon: one is Isle Ryder, an accord of jasmine, gorse and poplar bud that conjures Finlaggan, ruins of a castle in the middle of a lake on the peaty island of Islay.
 
$180; barneys.com .
Harnessing the dark side with black bikinis and a leather cover-up.
From painted toes in the hot sand to the tickle of a silk scarf at your neck, simple pleasures make the best of summer.

WHILE A NEW GENERATION OF ARTISTS and designers are coming up with modern ways to reinterpret the classic combination of blue and white at the same time, its antique porcelain predecessor is hitting record highs at auction. Whether it is Valentino’s oversize florals, influenced by Delftware, on strict puritan-collared dresses, or Rem Koolhaas’s Casa da Música in Porto, Portugal, with abutting panels of traditional azulejos, the trend is unmistakable.
 
The cobalt compound that gives blue-and-white porcelain its color was brought to China from Iran by Mongolian invaders in the 13th century. Once its use as a pigment had been perfected, the great trade arteries that ran from East to West began to flow with new, distinctively patterned ceramics, spawning a mania for all things blue and white — to the extent that European and Ottoman factories began to produce their own hybrid designs in order to meet the insatiable demand. The craze gradually spread to interiors and textiles, from the tiled walls of merchant houses to gilded chinoiserie pavilions specially built to display princely collections of the precious porcelain.

It’s little surprise that the Japanese, who have a way of perfecting culture imported from abroad, would be drawn to the art of surf. Josh Rosen, a co-owner of the tastemaking lifestyle brand Saturdays Surf NYC , which opened a store in Tokyo last year, is frequently impressed by the meticulousness of “all the little accouterments”: cars outfitted with slots for surfboards and luggage racks that fold out as surfboard caddies; wet suits on hangers; and blankets to change on.
 
When he first surfed in Japan, Morgan Collett, Rosen’s business partner, was surprised by just how crowded the breaks were. The past five years have seen a major resurgence of interest in the sport, and in the breezy style that goes along with it. Takashi Kumagai, a stylist and photographer, notes that even nonsurfers love the laid-back look. In the 1970s, Tokyoites with no intention of getting in the water went so far as attaching boards to the roofs of their Volkswagen Beetles; these days, they might wear brightly striped pocket tees and beachy, slim-fitting chinos, like those sold at Saturdays — which, conveniently, just unveiled a second international outpost in the port city of Kobe. Junji Uchida, who edits two Japanese surf magazines, says the sport increasingly attracts urbanites who appreciate the outdoorsy lifestyle but aren’t necessarily interested in surf’s high-performance, competitive side, which dominated the culture in the ’80s and ’90s. These days, he says, it’s about being “fashionable, organic and healthy. During the week you work in the city, and on the weekends you go and hang out at the beach.”

The definitive guide to culture and style, updated daily at tmagazine.com . 
 
See James Turrell’s “skyspaces” at different times of day; listen to an audio of the history of blue-and-white ceramics; take a tour of the best hotel gardens around the world; plan where to stay, eat and go in Marin County, Taroudant and Spoleto; and watch the artist Tom Sachs’s hilarious video for VistaJet. Check out T tweets, Instagrams and posts for around-the-clock coverage from the Cannes Film Festival and the Venice Biennale.

Rupert Everett Is So Not an American Movie Star
 
(Page 140) In just 15 minutes with Rupert Everett, the British photographer Nigel Shafran knew he’d gotten what he came for at the Duke of York’s Theatre in London: the most telling shot of the actor who recently played Oscar Wilde in “The Judas Kiss.” Sarah Lyall, a London correspondent for The New York Times who is at work on a book about the News International phone-hacking scandal, interviewed Everett for T. A fan of his memoirs, she considers Everett’s work a refreshing find on the shelves of celebrity autobiographies, “these kinds of ghostwritten things where you can tell that they dictated it to someone and it’s incredibly stupid and boring,” whereas Everett’s are brave, honest, funny and well written.

This year, Fire Island’s legendary enclave the Pines celebrates its 60th anniversary season, but its real heyday dates to the 1970s and early ’80s, when fit young men started streaming into the area, earning the Pines its reputation as a sand-swept gay bacchanal. Tom Bianchi’s Polaroids captured the liberated mood of those days, and they’re now collected in a handsome book, “ Tom Bianchi: Fire Island Pines ” (Damiani).

DICK--Marion Pokoik . Thinking of you today on Mother's Day, especially remembering the devoted mother you were to all of your children and grandchildren. Your daughter, Gail.
SPETTER--Dr. Matthew Ies Memorial Service on Saturday, June 8, 2013 NY Ethical Culture Society 2 West 64th St, NYC. Doors open at 2:30pm. Program at 3pm RSVP (718) 548 -4445

SCHULMAN--Gerda L. A Memorial Service to celebrate the life of Dr. Gerda L. Schulman will be held on May 19, 2013 at the Roosevelt House Public Policy Institute at Hunter College, 47-49 E. 65th St. New York, at 11:30 am, in the Four Freedoms Room.

WOLSEY--Thomas, died at home April 29th. Born in Aachen, Germany in 1924, Tom moved to England in 1936. There he started his design career and in 1960 became the art director of Town magazine helping launch the careers of many photographers including David Bailey and Terry Donovan. Moving to New York in 1972, Tom worked for ad agencies Ogilvy, Scali and Ally & Gargano winning many awards. He is survived by his wife Joyce Fabian Wolsey, daughter Natascha Wolf, grandsons Isaac and Kahlil, great-grandson Lorenzo. Tom loved Mozart, 14th Century art and fava beans and he will be greatly missed.

WATSON--Aldren Auld, book illustrator and author born in Brooklyn, 1917, to artists Eva and Ernest Watson. His final work, "Waterfront New York: Images of the 1920's & '30's," is forthcoming in July. More information at: www.AldrenWatson.com. Survived by eight children and many other relatives. He was predeceased by parents; brother Merlin Auld Watson; grandson James Watson Harrah.

THACKARA--Virginia Mason, 78, South Burlington, VT; also Red Bank, NJ, died April 29, Ft. Myers, FL. Graduated Masters School, Dobbs Ferry, NY, and Hollins College, Virginia. Member of Seabright Beach Club and Rumson Country Club. Leaves husband of 56 years, Walter M. (Pat) Thackara; daughter Pamela T. McCoy, Navesink, NJ; son Charles H. Thackara and wife Maribeth, Colchester, VT; five grandchildren and a great-grandson. Service June 14, 11am, St. George's By-The-River, Rumson, NJ. Donations: Amyloidosis.org or St. George's, Rumson.

STRACHER--Alfred, PhD. SUNY Downstate Medical Center mourns the passing of Alfred Stracher, PhD, an exemplary researcher, teacher and mentor. He was a member of the Downstate faculty since 1959, and Chairman of the Department of Biochemistry from 1972 to 2006, the longest serving biochemistry chairman of any medical school in the United States. An eminent scientist whose research focused on the chemistry of muscle proteins and the molecular processes underlying neuromuscular and neurodegenerative disorders, Dr. Stracher was the first to suggest using protease inhibitors as potential therapeutic agents in treating muscular dystrophy. Dr. Stracher was also a leader and pioneer in the field of drug targeting and drug delivery. In 1997, Dr. Stracher was appointed Distinguished Professor by the SUNY Board of Trustees, the highest academic rank SUNY bestows. Dr. John F. Williams, President Dr. Ian Taylor, Senior Vice President for Biomedical Education and Research Dr. Mark Stewart, Dean, School of Graduate Studies

STERN--Sandy, 76, of Chevy Chase, MD, previously NYC. Beloved wife for 42 years of Roger; loving mother of Jordan, Andrew and wife Michelle, Edward and wife Alison; adoring grandmother to Sophia, Conor and Phoebe; Samuel, Charlotte and Jack; and Matthew and Daniel; and devoted aunt and cousin. Sandy graduated from the University of Michigan and remained actively involved in alumni affairs and recruitment. She had a long career on Madison Avenue as casting director. Her passion was the dramatic arts; she attended hundreds of shows. Always with a stack of headshots on her desk, she advised many actors. She was an avid bridge player, but loved nothing more than sharing the lives of her family and friends. She orchestrated many family celebrations and vacations. Sandy was often described as a force of nature. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Monday, May 13th, 2013 at 9:45am, with burial to follow at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY.

SILVER--William V. Our hearts are broken with the loss of your loving friendship, curious and brilliant mind, incomparable sense of humor, and loving support. Your wonderful spirit will remain with us forever. Our love and admiration to Mandy and Michael and the whole Silver/ Jaffa family. Marjorie & Joe, Barbara & Jimmy, Alexis, Ali, Kate and Charlie

SCHUYLER--Leonard H.,M.D., beloved husband of May Schuyler, father of Hope Schuyler Hacker, M.D. and the late Lawrence Schuyler, D.O. and grandfather to Lewis Schuyler and Jennifer Hacker, passed away on May 10, 2013. Dr. Schuyler served in the U.S. Army-Duke 65th General Hospital during WWII and was an Attending Physician at New York Presbyterian Hospital for over 50 Years. Dr. Schuyler deeply valued the opportunity to care for his patients and considered it a privilege up to the day of his retirement. Service to be held at WM .G. Miller and Son, 371 Hooker Avenue, Poughkeepsie, NY 12603, Tuesday, May 14th at noon. In lieu of flowers, please consider a contribution to: Hospice Care of Hackensack, NJ, 25 East Salem St. 2nd Floor, Hackensack, NJ 07601. 201-342-7766.

ROSEN--Herman E.,1919-2013, died at his home in San Diego on April 13. Born in New York and raised in the Bronx, he graduated the Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point, NY in 1944. He served on merchant ships in WWII and wrote about one ill-fated voyage in his memoir "Gallant Ship, Brave Men." He had a long career in fund raising and public relations for the Jewish service agencies UJA, HIAS, and B'nai Brith. His beloved wife Susan died in 2012. He is dearly missed by his sons Dan (Nancie), and Fred, daughter Marji Abel and grandchildren Zoe, Justice, and Bodhi.

ROSENBLATT--Helene S.,89, formerly of Scarsdale, NY. Passed away on May 10, 2013. Helene was strikingly beautiful throughout her life. Elegant, warm, loving. Admired and respected by all. Recognized at 1994 Cornell graduation as oldest ever recipient of bachelor's degree. Later served as research assistant to Prof. Pillemer. Beloved wife of the late Robert Rosenblatt. Devoted mother of Bill (deceased)/Roberta, Ron/Susy, David/Robyn, Larry/Linda, Ann/Stuart Arbeit. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Adored role model. Private graveside service. Shiva: Sunday, 4-7pm, 490 Bleeker Ave., Mamaroneck; Monday, 5-8pm at the home of David and Robyn Rosenblatt. Memorial service planned for the future.

POLSTER--Sandor M.,died March 21 at his home in Manhattan at age 71, after battling gastric cancer for over two years. Born in Columbus, OH, Polster was an inveterate New Yorker and born to be a true journalist. His career spanned The Associated Press in Columbus, OH and Portland, ME, the New York Post as a rewrite man and City Hall reporter during John Lindsay's mayorship and network television, as the International writer with Walter Cronkite and Dan Rather at CBS and as the Editor-Producer for Tom Brokaw at NBC. In 1993, Polster and his family moved to Durham, ME, where he began freelance writing for magazines and blogs. He worked for two years as a columnist with the Bangor Daily News and one year as editor of the Brunswick Times Record. In 1999, he became the adviser to the Bowdoin College newspaper, The Orient and was hired to teach political journalism at Colby College. Polster is survived by his wife, Rea Turet, and daughter, Rebekah Polster, a son-in-law, Timothy Hansen, and grandson, Benjamin Miller Hansen, of Brooklyn, NY. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, May 15 at 2:00pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street.

NEUHAUS--Philip Ross. Philip Ross Neuhaus of Houston, passed away on the 23rd of April 2013, at the age of 93. Mr. Neuhaus graduated from St. Mark's School, 1938, and Yale University, 1942. He was president of Wolf's Head. He served as captain in the U.S. Army with the 124th Horse Cavalry, where he was charged with training, maneuvers and tactics of the division of more than 700 men, part of the Mars Task Force, who marched over 400 miles on the Burma Road in the China-Burma-India Theatre in World War II. Co-founder and CEO of Underwood, Neuhaus & Co with Joseph Rice Neuhaus and Milton Underwood, he was still enjoying a 66 year career in the investment business. Philip Neuhaus was preceded in death by his son, the late Philip Ross Neuhaus, Jr., his wife, Barbara Haden Neuhaus, and his step-daughter Barbara George Briner. He is survived by his daughters Lacey Neuhaus Dorn, her husband, Tucker; Elizabeth "Betts" Neuhaus Armstrong, her husband, "C.D."; and Joan Neuhaus Schaan; and his grandchildren, Lacey Neuhaus Dorn, Philip Prizer Armstrong, Katherine Neuhaus Armstrong, Laura Hilliard Armstrong, and Daniel Ross Schaan. He is also survived by his loving step-children Jennifer George Kuebler and Mark; John Harris Masterson and Catherine; Cecil Haden Masterson; and William Douglas Masterson and Shelly; and their children. A more detailed notice, including a listing of survivors and other specifics can be found at: www.chron.com. Services were held at Christ Church Episcopal Cathedral and burial and Glenwood Cemetery.
MACDONALD--Pirie, died on April 19, 2013. A memorial will be held on June 29, at 2pm in the Congregational Church of Bridgewater, Connecticut.

LIBRETTO--Ellen V.,66, passed away Saturday, May 4th after a brief illness. A fifth generation New Yorker and graduate of Queens College, BA 68 anthropology MLS 1970. She held a managerial position in New York City public libraries coordinating young adult services, training librarians, working with teams and coordinating reading materials for adults. Following a career in the library system, she joined Random House as library marketing manager for Ballantine Books where she worked with such authors as Ray Bradbury, Elizabeth Berg, Anne Perry and Collin Powell. After leaving Random House, she consulted on library marketing for several independent publishers. As an author, she wrote the YA non-fiction book "The General Slocum Ferryboat Fire of 1904", as well as books in the library field including "New Directions for Young Adult Services" and the much referenced "High/Low Handbooks: Best Books and Web Sites for Reluctant Teen Readers". She dedicated her recent retirement time to the research of a documentary DVD, now under production about her great-grandfather, world famous sculpture and artist Frederick Triebel whose works include the Soldiers and Sailors Monument in Peoria, IL, honoring those who served in the Civil War. Libretto is survived by husband Adam Conrad, brother George Stauffer and in her words "a motley crew of cousins and friends".

LANDSMAN--Hilda, 90, on May 9, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Aaron, Loving mother of Karen (David) Landsman Kolasinski and Julie Landsman. Superb grandmother of Bennett, Jordan and Owen Kolasinski. Memorials to Phelps Hospice, 701 N. Broadway, Sleepy Hollow, NY 10591.

LAGUDIS--Esme, 84, of Wayne NJ on May 7th, 2013. Beloved wife of Nicholas (62 years), mother of Stephanie Neckles, Maria Lechich, Stella Lagudis, Yiayia to Christina, Alexander, Nicholas, and Stephanie. Esme, born in Brooklyn to Thomas and Stella Giannos, was a brilliant linguist and a 1950 graduate of Hunter College. We will miss her timeless beauty, elegance, and aesthetic guidance. Countless slides of happy world travels will serve as a memorial to her rich life and our wonderful family.

KAREL-GOLDREYER--Yetta. November 24 1917 - April 30, 2013. Lived in The Bronx, Yonkers, Lake Oscawana in Putnam Valley, NY, Lincoln Towers in NYC, Lauderhills, FL, and Equinox Terrace in Manchester, VT. Dental Hygienist for NYC Schools and Clinics followed by a 35 year career at the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York as Associate Director of the Woman's Campaign and head of Special Projects and Legacies Department. A warm, loving, socially conscious, and productive lady "ahead of her time". Predeceased by husbands Irving Karel, and Louis Goldreyer, brother Sam and sisters Trudy and Dorothy. She will be missed by daughter Elinor (Joel) and son Michael (Gloria), grandchildren Daniel, Miriam, (Mike), Emily and Gregory, great-grandchildren Shayna and Emmett and brother Edward (Vera). Laid to rest at New Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Queens, NY. Contributions in memory can be made to ATZUM (www.atzum.org); National Alliance on Mental Illness-Vermont (www.namivt.org); Maccabi Games of Greater Washington, Rockville, MD.

HILBURN--William J.,beloved son of Wendy (Jay) and Bill and brother of Anne, died at home from complications of Spinal Muscular Atrophy on May 2, 2013. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 1st, 2013, at The Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 91st Street, at 11am. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to an organization that helped his family nurture, sustain, and care for Will: www.SKIPofNY.org, www.BrickChurch.org, www.HenryViscardiSchool.org and Division of Pediatric Critical Care Medicine Research Fund, c/o Jo-Anne Elikann (Administrator), Weill Cornell Medical College, 525 E. 68th Street, M-508, New York, NY 10065.

HARGES--Michael T.,of New York and New Canaan, Ct. died on January 21, 2013 at Marin General Hospital, Greenbrae, CA. An engineer by profession, together with an associate, founded Empire Devices Products Corp. a successful electronics company in Upstate New York. He retired at an early age, enjoying his family and his many interests, in particular his passion for antique cars which he collected and helped restore. He is survived by his wife Janet, son Christopher and daughter-in-law Elizabeth, Fairfax, CA, daughter Elisabeth and son-in-law Andrew Harrison, London, UK, daughter Marian Mc Neil, Concord, New Hampshire, son Michael, Santa Monica, CA. and three grandchildren. He will be missed by all who knew him. A private memorial service is planned for later in the year.

GRISDALE--Michael L. Grisdale, January 23,1940-April 19, 2013. A born explorer Michael followed a global career in Intl. Marketing. Always a gentleman he touched so many with his diplomacy and integrity. He is deeply loved and will forever hold a place in the hearts of his family.
GREENBERG--Jack. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Amy, Nancy and Michael.

GRACE--F. Cecil, 97, of Katonah, NY on Tuesday, April 30, 2013. Founder of the F. Cecil Grace Positive Role Model Program. Born August 1, 1915 in New York City. Graduate of Harvard University, United States Army World War II Veteran. He was a member of Squadron A of the New York National Guard. In August 1941 he was commissioned 2nd Lt. in the Signal Corps and assigned to the Electronics Training Group. He was sent with the army's first 30 to study radar in England, then attached to the Royal Air Force; specializing in airborne radar. He went overseas in July '44 as chief radar observer of a night fighter squadron with the 14th Air Force. He invented a device for FM radio that was accepted by the Signal Corps for patenting. He is survived by his beloved wife, Boo.

FRANKLIN--Frederic. Dancer, coach, rehearsal master, teacher, choreographer, guardian of ballet history, raconteur extraordinaire. You retrieved lost Balanchine choreography for our video archives and gave us 60 hours of taped reminiscences. Your inimitable spirit is preserved for posterity. The George Balanchine Foundation

FALK--Beatrice, born July 30, 1917, died peacefully on May 3 with family by her side. She is survived by her brother Ira Friedman of Delray Beach, FL. Bea was predeceased by her husbands Charles Rotstein and Nathan Falk. She was a graduate of both Hunter College and NYU. Bea was a retired teacher and long standing member of the UFT. Bea's love and knowledge of the Lower East Side was incredible and something she shared with everyone she met. She was a member of MoMA and the Met museums, as well as a frequent patron of theater and Indie films. She loved attending the Shakespeare class at the Stein Center and lectures at the Ethical Culture Center. Bea was always on the move but cherished quiet afternoons people watching in Battery Park. Her curiosity about the world led her to a love of traveling and folk dancing, something she shared with both her husbands. Bea will be missed by family, friends and by the city she so loved.

de DUVE--Christian. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend and colleague Christian de Duve. One of the founders of modern cell biology, Dr. de Duve was Andrew W. Mellon Professor Emeritus and a recipient of the 1974 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, which he shared with his Rockefeller colleagues Albert Claude and George Palade. Research by Dr. de Duve centered on the identification and characterization of the organelles of living cells. He is best known for his discovery of lysosomes, subcellular particles that function in many ways as the digestive system of the cell. This basic discovery underlies the current understanding of several inherited disorders, including Tay-Sachs disease and Gaucher's disease. In his later years, Dr. de Duve's investigations focused on the origins of life on our planet. In 1974 he founded the International Institute of Cellular and Molecular Pathology, a biomedical research institute modeled on The Rockefeller University, at the Catholic University of Louvain. The institute was renamed the Christian de Duve Institute on the occasion of his 80th birthday in 1997. Dr. de Duve was a brilliant scientist and a gifted teacher, mentor and author. He will be greatly missed. We extend our condolences to his children Thierry, Anne, Francoise and Alain and to his many colleagues on campus. Russell L. Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President

CRARY--Miner Dunham, Jr.,died peacefully on Tuesday, May 7, 2013, at the age of 92. Born in Warren, PA in 1920, Miner was a partner at the New York law firm Curtis Mallet-Provost, Colt, and Mosle where he practiced trusts and estates law for over 60 years. Miner graduated from Amherst College in 1942. He served in the Navy during WWII as a supply officer and paymaster in the Pacific, and went on to get his law degree from Harvard University after the war. Like many of his generation, Miner had a passion for civic involvement which he demonstrated by supporting education, the arts, and his community. His service included working on the Cold Spring Harbor School Board through the district's construction of its first high school, and volunteering much time to his alma mater Amherst College, for which he was awarded the Medal for Eminent Service. He was a longtime trustee of The American University in Cairo. Miner served on the boards of the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute and the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington, NY. He also volunteered as a legal advisor and judge for the Village of Asharoken, in Northport, NY. Miner was a devoted family man, and deeply attached to Mary his late wife of 63 years. He was known for the hospitality he and Mary extended to all who shared outings at their home on Duck Island in Northport, NY. As a devoted tennis player and spectator, he offered patient but firm on-court tutelage to several generations of players. He will be remembered for his kind, gentle, generous, and appreciative manner. Miner is survived by a loving extended family that includes his brother, Horace I. Crary of New Canaan, CT; four children: James, Marcy, Harriet and Miner; eight grandchildren and six great- grandchildren. He was predeceased by his sister, Winifred, and his daughter, Edith. A service will be held for Miner at Mt. Auburn Cemetery, 580 Mt Auburn Street, Cambridge, Massachusetts, in the Story Chapel on Saturday, June 8th at 2:00, followed by a reception. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation to www.hospicegoodshepard.org, which provided remarkable care and support to Miner and his family, or to your own local hospice organization.

CASPER--Enid Ruth, 93, died May 8, 2013, surrounded by her children, Jeffrey, Daniel and Lisa. She was predeceased by her husband, Sidney, and sister, Carol. Enid was born in the Bronx to Fannie and Morris Wagner, grew up in Brooklyn, and graduated from James Madison High. She completed bachelor's and master's degrees in Psychology at the University of Michigan, and further studied at NYU. In addition to teaching psychology at CCNY, she taught remedial reading and was a child psychologist in several public schools, including Westbury and Great Neck, NY. After the sudden, untimely death of her beloved husband in 1964, she remained a dedicated and resourceful single parent while continuing to work full time. In her retirement, she discovered a passion and talent for sculpting, and over two fruitful decades produced many beautiful works. When she could no longer wield chisel and mallet, she sharpened the crackerjack skills of her game - bridge. She is survived by her children and her cherished grandchildren, Samuel and Nora, and Sophie and Julia, and she was a dear mother-in-law to Lauren and Josh. Enid was smart, curious, caring and fiercely independent, as well as a wonderful mother, grandmother, and lifelong friend to many. She fostered lasting relationships, including those from her childhood in Brooklyn, her college years in Ann Arbor, and throughout her adult life. All who were lucky enough to have known her will miss her dearly. Donations to: doctorswithoutborders.org are greatly appreciated.

A wave of change is coursing through the French city of Nantes, bringing cool new eateries, hotels and culture.

 
Nantes has broken the Madame Bovary curse that’s turned so many other French provincial towns into snoozevilles. The city, recently named Europe’s green capital by the European Union, is now a popular weekend destination for eco-conscious Parisians who have been lured by the fresh air and a raft of exciting new hotels, restaurants and cultural spaces. Much of the activity is centered around the old docklands along the Loire, now home to effortlessly hip restaurants like L’Uni (36 rue Fouré), an adventurous modern bistro, and Les Bouteilles (11 rue de Bel Air), easily the city’s best wine bar, with plenty of Loire Valley vintages. Among the new hotels is the 28-room Sozo (doubles from about $140), built inside a 19th-century chapel with barrel-vaulted ceilings and original stained-glass windows. Best of all is Le Lieu Unique , a magnificent belle époque structure that was once an LU biscuit factory and is now a cultural center complete with a bar, a bookstore, a design shop and even a Moroccan-style hammam.

An article in the Summer Movies special section last Sunday about the new film version of “The Great Gatsby” misstated part of the name of the theater company that re-enacted F. Scott Fitzgerald’s novel under the name of “Gatz.” It is Elevator Repair Service, not the Elevator Repair Company. The article also misstated the given name of the actor who played the title character in the 1926 version of “The Great Gatsby.” He was Warner Baxter, not Warren.
An entry in the film listings in the Summer Movies section last Sunday about “The Wolverine” misstated the movie’s release date. It is July 26, not June 26.
An article last Sunday about “Felt,” a sex-therapy TV series on Logo that uses puppets, misstated part of the name of an old TV series that had puppets. It was “Crank Yankers,” not “Crank Anchors.”
An article last Sunday about Sylvia Plath misstated the number of years that have elapsed since her suicide. It was 50 years ago, not 60.

An article in some editions last Sunday about a plan that would require residents of Alwyn Court, in Midtown Manhattan, to leave their homes so that a crane boom at the construction site of the tower One57 could be replaced misstated, in some copies, the amount of money that an Alwyn Court official was told residents would be reimbursed for relocating temporarily. It was up to $1,500 per apartment, not up to $1,000.

An article on March 24 about the South Korean capital, Seoul, misstated the political leanings of the current Seoul government. It is an economy-minded conservative government, not an economy-minded “socialist” government. The article also described incorrectly the political views of Park Won-soon, the mayor of Seoul. He ran as an independent candidate and was elected as a “welfare-minded replacement” to the previous mayor, not as a “socialist replacement.” And because of an editing error, part of the name of the South Korean company with which the clothing designer Tory Burch entered into a partnership was misspelled. It is Samsung Cheil (not Chiel). A reader pointed out the errors in an e-mail on April 14. This correction was delayed for further research.

An article last Sunday about a new program that gives young delinquents in New York City local options for rehabilitation, including group homes — instead of incarceration upstate — misidentified, in some editions, the agency that had contracted with Good Shepherd Services, which operates one such home. It is the city’s Administration for Children’s Services, not the state’s Office of Children and Family Services.

An article last Sunday about news media competition in Alaska misidentified the Anchorage television station where Lynne Lott, an assistant professor of journalism at the University of Alaska, Fairbanks, once worked as a reporter. It is KTVA, not KTUU.

I joined my father, Claude McGaughey; my brother, Reeve; my stepmother, Alison; and a few family friends in watching the 139th Kentucky Derby on a small television in an office at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky.
 
For all of my father’s expertise as a Hall of Fame trainer, his horses have won other major events while he has watched on television, and he can be superstitious. This is the race my father dreamed about winning from the time he was a child in Lexington, Ky. And so we watched the Derby on television rather than from a private box. He was leaving nothing to chance.
