Photographing the cooks at Big Wong Restaurant in Chinatown this spring, Victor J. Blue captured that moment, he recalled, when “the choreography of chaos, of steaming noodles and sauté pans and glazed duck on the chopping block all comes together to fill orders coming in, orders out.”

May 6 — The Met Costume Institute previewed its exhibition, “Punk: Chaos to Couture.” The 800 guests entered the Great Hall, where a 15-foot chandelier glittered with simulated razor blades, symbolizing the anarchy of punk. Above, Anna Wintour (who helped raise $11.3 million for the museum) greeted guests at the grand stairway, lined by American and British flags made of roses. Punk’s grit was captured in the reconstructed 1974 bathrooms of the club CBGB (minus the drug paraphernalia). There were T-shirts of the queen and a picture of the current pope pinned to a jacket. 1. Deborah Harry, a voice of the movement. 2. Vivienne Westwood, who turned fashion on to punk. 3. Zandra Rhodes, another fashion punk pioneer. A Bergdorf window, top far right, embodies the punk theme. Bottom row: women accessorized with biker jackets and safety pins.

An article last Sunday about the legal case surrounding creation of a realty trust whose properties would include the Empire State Building misstated the middle initial of a member of a group that bought a stake in the building in 1951. He was Roger L. Stevens, not Roger I.

A chart with an opinion essay last Sunday about discarded electronics misstated the estimated total weight of cellphones thrown away in the United States from 2006 through 2010. It was about 85,000 tons, not 0.85 million (850,000) tons.

But what’s kept him from becoming a mainstream leading man — the cranky impudence, the lacerating British wit — is precisely what makes him so attractive.

The smallest thing can set him off. “Going to work in the evening, I have to be very careful not to get into a situation that gets me into a mood.”

For his fervent private collectors, James Turrell’s celestial skyspaces are an exercise in blind faith. The temperamental artist regards them as test runs for his life’s work in the Arizona desert. Somehow, everyone’s happy. 

 
With his long white beard and measured manner of speech, the acclaimed light artist James Turrell cultivates the image of a cosmic cowboy. It’s a compelling presentation, and an effective tool in his long-running campaign to seduce patrons and collectors into what he describes as “another kind of seeing.” The “skyspaces” and “dark adaptations” Turrell creates for the homes, gardens, swimming pools, screening rooms, pagodas and pyramids of private collectors — almost anywhere the artist determines that the arrival of light at dawn and its departure at dusk can be captured to its full, revelatory effect — may differ in attribute and design, but they all pay tribute to and serve Turrell’s higher calling: the Roden Crater Project, northeast of Flagstaff, Ariz., that is his inspiration and his burden and will one day be the centerpiece of his substantial legacy.

ROGERS--Frances, of Great Neck, NY, died peacefully on May 11, 2013 at the age of 99. Beloved wife of the late Henry Rogers. Adored mother of Barbara and Larry. Cherished grandmother of Marc and Sarah, Stacey and Brian, Matthew and Ashley, and Heather. Revered great-grandmother of Dylan, Maddie, Logan, and Robert. A woman of indomitable spirit and strength of character, she will be missed by all who knew her. Services will be held Monday, May 13, 2013 at 10:00am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 11021.

PANEM--Gertrude Sachs, born August 27, 1910. Devoted wife of the late Morris, loving mother of Janet and Sandra, grandmother of Joshua, and a friend of everyone. Talented artist, early feminist, avid tennis player and an inspiration to young people for over 100 years. Missed but never forgotten. Services Monday, 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

PEIX--Alice J.,101. Born December 15, 1911, Worcester, MA. Attended Smith College, graduated from Kathrine Gibbs. Her husband, Charles H. Peix died in 1985. She is survived by two sons, J. Douglas Peix of Mattituck, NY and Charles Peix. www.carrfuneralhome.com

MORTON--Lee Eugene Sr.,on May 9th. Lee was a retired American Airlines pilot, a retired Air Force Veteran and a Cornell University graduate, class of 1954. Beloved husband of 57 years to Mary Morton; loving father of Kathleen M. Morton and Dana M. Emery; loved grandfather of five: Michael and Marie Morton and Rob, Matt and Will Emery; beloved brother to Dr. Phillip Morton and Paul Morton. A celebration of life will be held at Rumson Country Club on 18 May at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations in Lee's memory may be made to the "Lee Morton '54 Ivy AMI Fund" at Cornell University.

MOLL--Bertram Daniel, on May 11, 2013, Bertram Daniel Moll, known to many for his kindness, compassion, and profound devotion to his wife Nessa, died peacefully in San Diego, California. The cause was complications from Alzheimer's disease. He was 87. Bert was born in Brooklyn, New York to Nathan and Bella Moll, immigrants from Eastern Europe. He attended Erasmus High, NYU, and Harvard Law School. During World War II, he served as a sergeant in the Army, stationed in the Philippines. Married to Nessa Ernstoff Moll for 55 years, they settled first in Rockville Centre and then Port Washington, both on Long Island. They later moved to Greenwich Village, Farmington Woods in Avon, Connecticut and then San Diego. Bert and Nessa shared a passion for politics, movies, theatre, The New York Times' Crossword, international travel, classical music and chocolate. Bert joined the Legal Department at Long Island Lighting Company and appeared on its behalf in the United States Supreme Court. He later joined Con Edison's Legal Department and subsequently moved into a business role as a Vice President, assuming responsibility for Con Ed's oil and then gas supply. He was dedicated to the communities in which he lived, serving on the school board and as a board member of Group House for troubled teens in Port Washington. Bert also served as a law guardian in the Nassau County Family Court. In Farmington Woods, he served on the Boards of the Home Owner's Association and Tax District. Bert was an ardent sports fan and had a love-hate relationship with the Yankees, Knicks and Jets. He enjoyed playing tennis and golf and could swish a set shot from 25 feet with admirable consistency. Bert's integrity, generosity and devotion to wife and family were an inspiration to all who knew him and will never be forgotten. In addition to Nessa, Bert is survived by his son Steve and his wife, Rhonda, daughter Laura and her husband, Dave, and daughter Julie and her husband Nick, as well as by grandchildren Karly and Nina, Evan and Jeremy, and Nate, Owen and Ben. Bert was predeceased by his parents and his brother Arthur. Contributions in Bert's memory can be made to Alzheimer's Disease Research Center, 8950 Villa La Jolla Drive Suite C129, La Jolla, CA 92037.

Devoted grandmother of Jenny, Joseph, Benjamin, Jacob, Ezra, Rachel and Edward. Proud great-grandmother of Anna, Leo and Elliott. Beloved aunt, cousin and friend. She lived her life with unwavering courage, spirit and joy. She will be missed. Services Tuesday, 12:45pm "Sinai Chapels" 162-05 Horace Harding Expy Fresh Meadows, NY.
MAKARI--Jack G.,M.D., 95, pioneer of cancer immunology, discoverer of the Makari Intradermal Test, loving husband, father and grandfather, passed away on May 4th in Suffield, CT.

Roger Savell, President Lee Charles, Secretary

CUBA--Fredric. Dearest husband, father, grandfather, marketing executive and friend. At 78, Fred died peacefully after a short battle with cancer. A native New Yorker, Fred grew up in Pelham Parkway in the Bronx. He graduated from Columbus High School and the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania. He then joined the army where he was stationed in Gelnhausen, Germany. Returning to New York, he received a Masters in Statistics from NYU. He spent most of his career at Ogilvy & Mather advertising agency, rising to become Market Research Director, Senior Vice President. In 1980, he started his own market research company bringing him great satisfaction and success. In retirement, with his keen sense of humor and sharp intelligence, Fred drew a wonderful circle of friends at the Institute For Retired Professionals where he studied and taught, and at the 92nd Street Y. Fred loved spending time with his family, cooking, drinking wine and laughing. He is survived by his loving wife of 50 years, Marion. They traveled the world and explored the wonders of New York City - the opera, museums, theater, neighborhood walking tours and of course, brunch. He is predeceased by his dear son Jonathan. Fred is survived by his beloved daughter Stephanie, adoring son-in-law Lawrence Cunningham and granddaughter Rebecca; his daughter-in-law Randi and grandson Aaron; and his niece Jennifer Komittee. A funeral will be held Tuesday, May 14, 2014 at 11am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st St.) in New York.
BREGMAN--Dorothy. March 20, 1940 - May 12, 2013. www.riversidememorialchapel.com (Mt. Vernon, NY)

BERNSTEIN--Deborah L.,Our hearts are broken at the loss of our dear wife, daughter, mother and sister. Deborah was a shining star who passed far before her time. She graduated Summa Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa from Dartmouth College and began her career at Goldman Sachs. Deborah earned an MBA from Stanford Graduate School of Business and returned to Goldman. At Pequot Capital, in San Francisco then New York, she was a venture capital Partner. At Aquiline Capital, she was a private equity Partner. Services will be held Tuesday, May 14, 3:30pm at The Riverside Amsterdam Ave at 76th Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Dress for Success, ASPCA, WWF, Neighborhood Cats, the Lighthouse International. Deborah was loved by all and will be deeply missed. David Miller Asher Miller Caroline Kresky Michael Bernstein

El Museo del Barrio’s board president, who was named in a recent discrimination claim by the museum’s former director, will leave her position at the end of her term on June 30, museum officials said on Friday. The official, Yaz Hernández, is departing as the museum searches for a new director and struggles to find its fiscal footing. 
 
“I deeply believe in El Museo’s mission to honor Latino, Caribbean and Latin American cultures and believe the institution has a bright future,” Ms. Hernández said in a statement released Friday. “Because of my other board commitments, I will be stepping down as president of El Museo’s board when my term expires in June. However, I will remain actively involved, and my husband, Valentín Hernández, has been proposed to join the board because of my family’s deeply held commitment to the success of the institution.”

Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts raised $9.4 million at its spring gala on Thursday night, a record for the organization. The gala honored Lincoln Center’s president, Reynold Levy, who is stepping down in December after 11 years. The evening started with the total at $8.2 million, but during the speeches, Katherine Farley, Lincoln Center’s chairwoman, announced that an additional $1.2 million had been raised for the creation of the Reynold Levy Fellowship for Harvard Business School graduates interested in nonprofit organizations.
 
Mr. Levy, who is known for his dogged fund-raising skills , said in his remarks that his middle name was “gala” and that he was grateful for the fellowship created in his honor. “$1.2 million I didn’t have to raise,” he said. The gala featured Audra McDonald, who performed in a packed Avery Fisher Hall before the seated dinner for 1,200 in a tent on Damrosch Park. Those in attendance included the actress Anne Hathaway, the talk-show host Kelly Ripa and the late-night TV host Jimmy Fallon.
An article on Friday about how doors can be frequent targets of gunfire in public housing complexes misidentified the location of the Polo Grounds Towers. It is in Harlem, not in East Harlem.

Dear Diary:
 
A few weeks ago I gave a tour at the Metropolitan Museum of Art to a group of second-grade children from a New York elementary school. Among the works of art we looked at was Edward Hopper’s “Tables for Ladies.” It shows a scene in a restaurant with a waitress, a cashier, and a couple sitting at a table across from each other, but not seemingly engaged.

An article in some editions on Wednesday about frustration at the city among Staten Island residents about mold cleanup since Hurricane Sandy erroneously included a group among volunteers that have cleaned mold from thousands of homes. While volunteers from the Mennonite Church are part of the mold remediation process, for instance installing siding to a home once the mold has been removed, they have not actually cleaned mold from homes.

A correction in this space on April 26 for an article about the effect pollution in China is having on the lives of children referred incorrectly to Zhang Xiaochuan. He is the grandfather of Wu Xiaotian, 4, who appeared in an accompanying picture wearing a mask that he uses when playing outdoors. Mr. Zhang is not the grandfather of “another 4-year-old.”

While visiting Manhattan recently from Pennsylvania, I had a most unusual experience.

The long-sought quantum computer, a machine potentially far ahead of today’s best supercomputers, is almost as hard to define as it is to build. For at least a few particular uses, however, the unusual computer made by D-Wave Systems now seems to be very fast indeed.
 
Next week a professor at Amherst College will present her findings about the performance of the D-Wave machine, which its makers say makes use of such unusual properties of quantum physics as a particle’s ability to move in one direction and its opposite at the same time.

In my two years of commuting on the F train from Essex Street to my office, there has been one constant — the man with the guitar and pan flute.

Apple and Samsung Electronics are sucking up every penny of profit in the handset business. But Samsung’s mobile business is growing fast, and the question is: Could it surpass Apple in profit next quarter?
 
Analysts at Canaccord Genuity, an investment research firm, think so, according to a new report. The report, issued on Monday, said that in the first quarter of the year, Apple took 57 percent of profit in the handset business, while Samsung took 43 percent. That shows substantial growth for Samsung’s phones. For comparison, in the first quarter last year, Apple raked in 74 percent of profit, and Samsung took 26 percent.

To the degree there was a human face of Watson, the “Jeopardy!” computer champion, it was David Ferrucci. He was the I.B.M. researcher who led the development of Watson, an artificial intelligence engine. The goateed computer scientist was always articulate and at ease in front of a camera or a microphone.
 
Dr. Ferrucci has left I.B.M. to join the giant hedge fund Bridgewater Associates. And the weight of the Watson-related fame, it seems, played a role. “I was so linked to the Watson achievement, and where I.B.M. was taking it, that I felt I was almost losing my identity,” he said in a recent interview.

In his 12 years as chief executive of Exxon Mobil , Lee R. Raymond had a reputation for bulldozing analysts and long-winded shareholders and going toe-to-toe with government authorities. 
 
Now as the lead director on the board of JPMorgan Chase , a crucial shareholder vote on splitting Jamie Dimon ’s jobs as chief executive and chairman could hinge on whether the 74-year-old Mr. Raymond is seen as strong enough to stand up to Mr. Dimon.

Merrill Brockway, a director and producer who brought high art to millions of Americans by presenting many of the 20th century’s greatest dancers and choreographers on the PBS television series “Dance in America,” died on May 2 in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 90.
 
His death was confirmed by his partner of 17 years, John Eric Roybal, his only immediate survivor.

Fredrick L. McKissack, who quit a career in construction to join his wife in writing more than 100 children’s books about African-American history, a piece of which his family owned as distinguished builders and architects, died on April 28 in Chesterfield, Mo., a St. Louis suburb. He was 73.
 
The cause was congestive heart failure, said his wife, Patricia C. McKissack .

On the program she invented, on the network where she worked for the past 37 years, on the medium where she broke barriers and rules for more than 50 years, Barbara Walters will announce on Monday morning, definitively and with no regrets, that she is calling it a career. 
 
“It’s time,” Ms. Walters said, previewing the announcement she will make to the national television audience watching her daily program, “The View.”

Last week was a good one for common sense and manning the barricades in New York. The City Planning Commission recommended limiting the special permit that allows Madison Square Garden to operate at its current site, which opens the door to fixing Penn Station, trapped below it.
 
And the Museum of Modern Art blinked.

DEAR DIARY:
 
As trains rumble underground and cars honk their horns and people rush in every direction, the park quietly grows and thrives and moves in the breeze.

If the young women who packed 54 Below at 11 p.m. on Friday didn’t emit the piercing screams you would hear at a Justin Bieber concert, it was because Aaron Tveit , the handsome 29-year-old star they came to adore, is a decade older, and these fans were in their late teens and 20s. But the atmosphere suggested a more restrained version of the fervor exhibited by Beliebers. 
 
 Mr. Tveit (pronounced tuh-VATE), who starred on Broadway as Gabe in “Next to Normal” and as Frank Abagnale Jr. in “Catch Me if You Can” and on film as Enjolras in “Les Misérables,” has the dreamy good looks of a high school sports hero who elicits collective sighs of longing. The good news for Broadway and cabaret is that his charisma coincides with talent, discriminating taste in material and a modesty that doesn’t seem faked. His band — Bryan Perri on piano, Eric Davis on winds, Michael Blanco on bass, and Damien Bassman on drums — matched him in poise and precision.

Moviegoers ignored naysaying critics and swarmed to Baz Luhrmann’s stylized 3-D adaptation of “The Great Gatsby” over the weekend. But “Iron Man 3” (Walt Disney Studios) repeated as the No. 1 box office draw in North America, taking in $72.5 million, for a two-week total of $284.9 million. “Gatsby,” adapted from F. Scott Fitzgerald’s classic novel and starring Leonardo DiCaprio in the title role, sold about $51.1 million in tickets in second place — an astounding result for a period drama.
 
Although “Gatsby” received mixed-to-negative reviews , Mr. DiCaprio remains a “Titanic”-sized draw among women, and Warner Brothers backed “Gatsby” with a highly effective marketing campaign. Still, the film was not cheap: Warner Brothers and Village Roadshow spent more than $150 million to produce it (about $100 million after factoring in tax credits), according to trade media reports . And 3-D sales were soft: Only about 33 percent of ticket buyers opted to see “Gatsby” in that format.

Schaffer. Beloved mother of Mindy and Greg White. Cherished grandmother of Andrew and Jessica. Loving stepmother to Laurie Disick and family. RUBIN--Phillip H.,A.S.I.D., age 87, peacefully at home in New York City, May 2, 2013, after a successful career creating interior designs independently for some of America's most affluent families and richest individuals; in addition to having served countless retail customers during his early years with Sloan's and B. Altman's. A 1947 graduate of the University of Chicago, followed by study at the Parsons School of Design, having served in the United States Army during WWII, Phil shared committed relationships with both Louis Ehrlich, who died in 1976, and then with Robert Davies, who died in 2007. With each lifemate he traveled the world for both pleasure and business, while spending summers in Cherry Grove, Fire Island, NY. For the last five years, although in declining health, cousin Michael Goldstein, friend Alton Bader and caregiver Roger Mabao insured that Phil continued to fully enjoy New York's cultural life.

POLSTER--Sandor M.,died March 21 at his home in Manhattan at age 71, after battling gastric cancer for over two years. Born in Columbus, OH, Polster was an inveterate New Yorker and born to be a true journalist. His career spanned The Associated Press in Columbus, OH and Portland, ME, the New York Post as a rewrite man and City Hall reporter during John Lindsay's mayorship and network television, as the International writer with Walter Cronkite and Dan Rather at CBS and as the Editor-Producer for Tom Brokaw at NBC. In 1993, Polster and his family moved to Durham, ME, where he began freelance writing for magazines and blogs. He worked for two years as a columnist with the Bangor Daily News and one year as editor of the Brunswick Times Record. In 1999, he became the adviser to the Bowdoin College newspaper, The Orient and was hired to teach political journalism at Colby College. Polster is survived by his wife, Rea Turet, and daughter, Rebekah Polster, a son-in-law, Timothy Hansen, and grandson, Benjamin Miller Hansen, of Brooklyn, NY. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, May 16 at 2:00pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street.

NATHANSON--Susan Malvin, passed away peacefully at 73, on May 13, 2013, after a long battle with Parkinson's Disease. She was born in New York on November 20 1939, the daughter of Ann Rabinowitz Malvin, and Irwin Malvin. On June 14, 1959, she married Noel (Buzzy) Nathanson, and they celebrated their 50th Wedding anniversary prior to his death in 2010. Susan received her undergraduate degree from Adelphi University, and later returned to receive her Master's Degree in Social Work, dedicating most of her professional years to fundraising for the Samuel Field YM-YWHA. A loving and devoted wife, mother, sister and grandmother, she will be sorely missed by all who loved her. She is survived by her children, Gary Nathanson and his fiance Jennifer Hart, Debra and Victor Giaime, Lisa and Jeffrey Rosen, her sister Wendy, her sister-in-law Bobbie, and her grandchildren Brian, Alexander, Daniel, Rachel, Sarah, Jacob, Talia and Kaylie. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Woodbury, NY on May 14, at 1pm. Shiva will held at Lisa's home at 55 Pasture Lane, Roslyn Heights, NY, following interment at the New Montefiore Cemetery. In addition, the family will be receiving visitors at Lisa's home on Wednesday May 15, from 1-9pm.

CUBA--Fredric. Dearest husband, father, grandfather, marketing executive and friend. At 78, Fred died peacefully after a short battle with cancer. A native New Yorker, Fred grew up in Pelham Parkway in the Bronx. He graduated from Columbus High School and the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania. He then joined the army where he was stationed in Gelnhausen, Germany. Returning to New York, he received a Masters in Statistics from NYU. He spent most of his career at Ogilvy & Mather advertising agency, rising to become Market Research Director, Senior Vice President. In 1980, he started his own market research company bringing him great satisfaction and success. In retirement, with his keen sense of humor and sharp intelligence, Fred drew a wonderful circle of friends at the Institute For Retired Professionals where he studied and taught, and at the 92nd Street Y. Fred loved spending time with his family, cooking, drinking wine and laughing. He is survived by his loving wife of 50 years, Marion. They traveled the world and explored the wonders of New York City - the opera, museums, theater, neighborhood walking tours and of course, brunch. He is predeceased by his dear son Jonathan. Fred is survived by his beloved daughter Stephanie, adoring son-in-law Lawrence Cunningham and granddaughter Rebecca; his daughter-in-law Randi and grandson Aaron; and his niece Jennifer Komittee. A funeral will be held Tuesday, May 14, 2014 at 11am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st St.) in New York.

RUBIN--Phillip H.,A.S.I.D., age 87, peacefully at home in New York City, May 2, 2013, after a successful career creating interior designs independently for some of America's most affluent families and richest individuals; in addition to having served countless retail customers during his early years with Sloan's and B. Altman's. A 1947 graduate of the University of Chicago, followed by study at the Parsons School of Design, having served in the United States Army during WWII, Phil shared committed relationships with both Louis Ehrlich, who died in 1976, and then with Robert Davies, who died in 2007. With each lifemate he traveled the world for both pleasure and business, while spending summers in Cherry Grove, Fire Island, NY. For the last five years, although in declining health, cousin Michael Goldstein, friend Alton Bader and caregiver Roger Mabao insured that Phil continued to fully enjoy New York's cultural life.

NEUHAUS--Philip Ross. Philip Ross Neuhaus of Houston, passed away on the 23rd of April 2013, at the age of 93. Mr. Neuhaus graduated from St. Mark's School, 1938, and Yale University, 1942. He was president of Wolf's Head. He served as captain in the U.S. Army with the 124th Horse Cavalry, where he was charged with training, maneuvers and tactics of the division of more than 700 men, part of the Mars Task Force, who marched over 400 miles on the Burma Road in the China-Burma-India Theatre in World War II. Co-founder and CEO of Underwood, Neuhaus & Co with Joseph Rice Neuhaus and Milton Underwood, he was still enjoying a 66 year career in the investment business. Philip Neuhaus was preceded in death by his son, the late Philip Ross Neuhaus, Jr., his wife, Barbara Haden Neuhaus, and his step-daughter Barbara George Briner. He is survived by his daughters Lacey Neuhaus Dorn, her husband, Tucker; Elizabeth "Betts" Neuhaus Armstrong, her husband, "C.D."; and Joan Neuhaus Schaan; and his grandchildren, Lacey Neuhaus Dorn, Philip Prizer Armstrong, Katherine Neuhaus Armstrong, Laura Hilliard Armstrong, and Daniel Ross Schaan. He is also survived by his loving step-children Jennifer George Kuebler and Mark; John Harris Masterson and Catherine; Cecil Haden Masterson; and William Douglas Masterson and Shelly; and their children. A more detailed notice, including a listing of survivors and other specifics can be found at: www.chron.com. Services were held at Christ Church Episcopal Cathedral and burial and Glenwood Cemetery.

NATHANSON--Susan Malvin, passed away peacefully at 73, on May 13, 2013, after a long battle with Parkinson's Disease. She was born in New York on November 20 1939, the daughter of Ann Rabinowitz Malvin, and Irwin Malvin. On June 14, 1959, she married Noel (Buzzy) Nathanson, and they celebrated their 50th Wedding anniversary prior to his death in 2010. Susan received her undergraduate degree from Adelphi University, and later returned to receive her Master's Degree in Social Work, dedicating most of her professional years to fundraising for the Samuel Field YM-YWHA. A loving and devoted wife, mother, sister and grandmother, she will be sorely missed by all who loved her. She is survived by her children, Gary Nathanson and his fiance Jennifer Hart, Debra and Victor Giaime, Lisa and Jeffrey Rosen, her sister Wendy, her sister-in-law Bobbie, and her grandchildren Brian, Alexander, Daniel, Rachel, Sarah, Jacob, Talia and Kaylie. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Woodbury, NY on May 14, at 1pm. Shiva will held at Lisa's home at 55 Pasture Lane, Roslyn Heights, NY, following interment at the New Montefiore Cemetery. In addition, the family will be receiving visitors at Lisa's home on Wednesday May 15, from 1-9pm.

JOHNSON--Kristina Barbara. The Trustees and Staff of the American Folk Art Museum mourn the passing of Kristina Barbara Johnson, who served on the board of trustees from 1968 through 2010. Kristina loved, collected, and donated a sizable number of artworks to the Museum including significant examples of scrimshaw. She organized an exhibition in 1968 titled "Hunt for the Whale" and also inaugurated an annual lecture series, delivering the first talk, "The Art of the Whalerman." Kristina became Board President in 1971, at which time Adele Earnest, a founding director, said her "optimism and devoted work renewed our purpose and our strength." Kristina helped to establish The Clarion, which became one of the most respected folk art journals, and created a scholarship fund for the newly established Folk Art Institute. The guest of honor at the Museum's 1985 gala was Kristina's pet tortoise, George, who was 184 years old and had been a member of Queen Victoria's court. We express our deepest condolences to her family, who have asked that contributions in her memory be made to the American Folk Art Museum, Administrative Office, 1865 Broadway, 11th Floor, New York, NY 10023. Laura Parsons, Chair Edward V. Blanchard, Jr., President, Board of Trustees Dr. Anne-Imelda Marino Radice, Executive Director

HIBBS--Barbara Jeanne Haff, Died Monday, May 13, 2013 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Mrs. Hibbs was born in Astoria, New York and was employed over forty years by Pan American World Airways, her last position as a Project Engineer in the Flight Operations Department analyzing airport data. Barbara attended the New School for Social Research studying Computer Operations. As an Art student, first with her mother Ann Haff, a commercial artist, she studied at the Art Students League of New York for many years. Barbara was a life member of the League. She also served as a Board Member of the Pastel Society of America. Her art received numerous prizes and awards and is represented in collections in New York, London, Sao Paulo and Philadelphia. She is survived by her husband William. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St NYC, Thursday, May 16, 2013 2-5 and 7-9pm. Interment private.

GRACE--F. Cecil, 97, of Katonah, NY on Tuesday, April 30, 2013. Founder of the F. Cecil Grace Positive Role Model Program. Born August 1, 1915 in New York City. Graduate of Harvard University, United States Army World War II Veteran. He was a member of Squadron A of the New York National Guard. In August 1941 he was commissioned 2nd Lt. in the Signal Corps and assigned to the Electronics Training Group. He was sent with the army's first 30 to study radar in England, then attached to the Royal Air Force; specializing in airborne radar. He went overseas in July '44 as chief radar observer of a night fighter squadron with the 14th Air Force. He invented a device for FM radio that was accepted by the Signal Corps for patenting. He is survived by his beloved wife, Boo.

FELDMAN--Doctor Emanuel, who passed away on May 10, 2013 at the age of 99, was recipient of a Silver Star for Bravery under enemy fire in the European Theatre during WWII, where he served for five years as Battalion Medical Officer of the 11th Infantry. The citation states that for 60 hours, under incessant artillery and mortar fire, Captain Feldman attended the wounded of his unit, refusing to join the retreat of his regiment. Upon return, he resumed his medical career, culminating in the position of Assistant Chief of Anesthesiology at Long Island Jewish Hospital. Dr. Feldman was the beloved husband of the late Florence (Neuchatz); loving father of Amy (Mark) Juhas and the late Dr. Robert (Nobuko) Feldman; dear brother of Myron (Nettie), Edward (Ruth) and the late Dr. Matthew (Shirley) Feldman; grandfather of Naumi, Mori, Rachel and Amanda; and great grandfather of Sachie, Muri, Ian and Nathan.

BELSON--Arlene, 76, of West Palm Beach left us on May 13th, 2013 after a brave struggle with pancreatic cancer. Born in Rockville Centre, NY, to Bernard and Nan Oberlander, Arlene had a passion for life that showed in her relationships with people, children, dogs and horses. She read for the blind and to children, and trained dogs at Peggy Adams Dog and Cat Rescue. Arlene lived in Florida for the past 15 years and leaves behind her husband of 22 years, Victor Belson, her shih tzu, Max, her daughters, Lauren and Dana Abrams, and three grandchildren, five step-children and two step-grandchildren. Donations can be made to the Hospice of Palm Beach County or an animal rescue organization.

STRICK--Louis, died peacefully on May 12th at age 87 following a brief illness. He is survived by his wife of 41 years, Elizabeth, his three children, Ivy, Wesley and Charlotte, a stepson, Simon, seven grandchildren, and two younger brothers, Walter and Stanley. He was raised in Flatbush, the son of Rosalind and Charles Strick. Growing up near Ebbets Field, Strick was an ardent fan of the Brooklyn Dodgers. In 1940, he became a member of the first class of Midwood High School. Strick went on to attend Cornell University. His college education was interrupted by World War II, and at age 19 he served as a staff sergeant in occupied Italy. After the war, Strick completed his undergraduate studies and went on to Columbia to pursue a Master's in Economics. He then wrote a weekly column on the stock market for the Journal of Commerce. Next he worked as a financial analyst for the investor Fred Stafford. In the late 1950's he purchased H.M. Storms, a manufacturer of ink ribbons; the National Cash Register Company would become his primary customer. During this period, Strick bought a radio station in St. Louis; WAMV was the first American station to play the hit song "Volare." In the early 1960's Strick co-founded a pioneering quality paperback line, Meridian Books, publishing Philip Roth among others. After selling H.M. Storms, he acquired Artone Ink, whose distinctive bottle featured the letter "a" in the form of an ink drip, an idea of Strick's that was designed by Push Pin Studios and gave rise to a popular typeface. In the late 1960's Strick began importing calligraphic art supplies that he distributed through his Pentalic Corporation. By making special nibs, pens and instruction books widely available, Strick spearheaded a revival of the calligraphic movement in America; he also established the Calligraphy Workshop, a school on lower Fifth Avenue. In the late 1970's Strick purchased the Taplinger Publishing Company, bringing out works of literary fiction and volumes on modern art, reflecting two of his passions. Strick himself was an artist who focused on collage; several of his pieces were exhibited in juried shows in Westport, Connecticut where he lived with Elizabeth for his last 32 years.

SCHWARTZ--Ellen May. Loving and beloved wife of Michael Schwartz for 44 years, mother of Liza Lauber and Joseph, mother-in-law of Alyson, sister of Richard Rubenstein, grandmother of Lily and Isaiah Walsh, friend, collaborator, inspiration and teacher of too many to name. A beautiful, irrepressible spirit, she lit up every room she walked into. She created hundreds of wonderful songs, on her own and with partners. Her most recent success was her lyrics for A Letter to Harvey Milk, which won top awards at the 2012 New York Musical Theatre Festival. She will live forever in our hearts, and in her words. Funeral at the Riverside, Friday, May 17, at 11:45. The family will be sitting shivah and receiving visitors at the Schwartzes' apartment from Friday late afternoon until Thursday, May 23. Please give to the American Cancer Society or another charity of your choice in her memory.

O'BRIEN--Walter J. III, "Joe" died May 10, 2013 in Richmond, VA at the age of 46. Joe is survived by a son Connor; a daughter Caitlin, and his wife Debra. He has two "moms" Nancy Malmuth and Margaret O'Brien. His father is Walter J. O'Brien Jr. Joe graduated from Hotchkiss in Lakeville, CT. He earned a degree in Economics from the University of Richmond. He began his successful financial career at Smith Barney in New York City. When he left New York to join Scott and Stringfellow, he was a Senior Vice President at Citicorp. More recently, as Senior Managing Director for Capital Markets at BB&T, Joe was well known for his inspirational leadership, innovative thinking and financial acumen. Further information is at www.blileys.com.

A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Saturday, May 18th at 10am. Interment will follow later at Arlington National Cemetery.

LeFRAK--Ethel. We mourn the death of our cherished member and extend deepest sympathy to her family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

LeFRAK--Ethel. The entire Lighthouse International Family mourns the loss of our dear friend and benefactor Ethel LeFrak. The Ethel and Samuel J. LeFrak School at Lighthouse International changes the lives of children who suffer vision loss every day and will forever reflect Mrs. LeFrak's compassion and dedication to those most in need. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to the LeFrak family at this difficult time. The Lighthouse International Board of Directors Joseph A. Ripp, Chairman Mark G. Ackermann, President and CEO

LeFRAK--Ethel. The Ambassadors of Same Sky mourn the loss of Ethel LeFrak, the beloved mother of our founder Francine LeFrak. In creating Same Sky, a fair trade initiative that offers employment to women living with HIV/AIDS in Sub Saharan Africa, Francine was most certainly reflecting Mrs. LeFrak's work ethic, compassion and dedication to those most in need. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Francine and the entire LeFrak family at this difficult time. The Ambassadors of Same Sky

LeFRAK--Ethel. The Coller family joins our dear friends, the LeFrak family, in mourning the passing of Ethel LeFrak. As a visionary and deeply engaged philanthropist, she enriched the lives of countless people, especially children. As our beloved Aunt Ethel, she enriched, guided, and gave meaning to our lives. We will miss, but never forget, her elegance, grace, kindness, wit, and song. Bobbi and Barry Coller Mimi and Ed Coller

LeFRAK--Ethel. Ethel- a woman who defined class and character. A gracious, wise, loving "advisor" in life. A guiding example for us all forever. Our sympathy to the entire LeFrak family. Regina and Jerry McCallion

LeFRAK--Ethel. The Board of Trustees and Staff of The New York Academy of Medicine deeply mourn the passing of our dear friend, Ethel LeFrak. Ethel's generous support of NYAM will preserve the history of medicine and public health for years to come. Our sincere sympathies go to her children, Denise, Richard, Francine, and Jacqueline and their families. Thomas Q. Morris, MD Chairman, Board of Trustees Jo Ivey Boufford, MD President, The New York Academy of Medicine

LeFRAK--Ethel. The executives and associates of LeFrak wish to express their profound sympathy to the LeFrak Family on the passing of Mrs. Ethel LeFrak, the widow of the late Dr. Samuel J. LeFrak, who had been chairman of our firm for many years. Mrs. LeFrak was an elegant, intelligent, sensitive, and generous woman whose kindness and grace touched all who were fortunate to know her. She was recognized and praised internationally for her magnanimous philanthropic works, which reflected her passion for helping those in need, including the support of charitable organizations, institutions of higher learning, hospitals, research facilities, and cultural programs. A tender, refined, and charming woman, she was loved by all. Our deepest condolences are extended to Richard LeFrak, her son and current chairman and CEO of LeFrak; her daughters, Denise, Francine, and Jacqueline; as well as her grandchildren and great- grandchildren.

LeFRAK--Ethel. With profound sadness on the passing of Ethel LeFrak, adoring wife of Sam, loving mother to Denise, Richard, Francine, and Jacqueline, and doting grandmother. A devoted alumna and former Trustee of Barnard College, a steadfast benefactor of the American Museum of Natural History, and mother of dedicated Museum Trustee Richard. A dear friend, she will be missed. Ellen V. Futter

LeFRAK--Ethel. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation mourn the passing of Ethel LeFrak, an esteemed former Trustee. The LeFrak family have been engaged and generous friends of the museum for many years, with Denise LeFrak Callichio currently a member of the International Director's Council and son-in-law John Callichio a member of the Board. Peter Lawson-Johnston, Honorary Chairman; William L. Mack, Chairman; and Jennifer Blei Stockman, President, Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation; Richard Armstrong, Director, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and Foundation.

LeFRAK--Ethel. We are beyond heartbroken at the passing of our beautiful mother and grandmother. She was the most special person and nothing will ever fill this void. We love you so much. Denise, John, Allison, Jennifer, Jeff, Neil, Cameron, Julia, Rachel, Sydney
LeFRAK--Ethel. Dear Ethel, you were a great lady. Thank you for your friendship. Our sincere condolences to the LeFrak family. Lynn and Carl Goldstein

LeFRAK--Ethel, was a woman of grace and elegance. We extend our condolences to Richard, Karen, Denise, John, Francine, Rick, Jackie, Ed and to all her grandchildren and great grandchildren. Pam and Ed Pantzer and Family

LeFRAK--Ethel, on May 14th, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Samuel J. LeFrak. Devoted mother of Denise LeFrak Calicchio, Richard LeFrak, Francine LeFrak Friedberg and Jacqueline LeFrak Kosinski. Cherished grandmother of Allison, Jennifer, Harrison, James, and Dylan. Great-grandmother of Cameron, Julia, Ivan and Russ. Services Thursday, May 16th 1pm at Temple Emanu-El Fifth Avenue at 65 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Samuel J. and Ethel LeFrak School at Lighthouse International. 111 East 59th St, NY 10022.

KORMAN--Jack, of New York and Westhampton died on May 15, 2013 at 92 years of age. Beloved husband of Myra Z. Korman, loving father of Nancy Goodfellow, Marjorie Kass and Joanne Goldman, grandfather of Rachel and Hannah Kass and Sally Alfonso. Loved by all who knew him. Services will be held at Schwartz Brothers Jeffers Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills on May 17 at 10am.
KENARD--Virginia G.,at home, on May 12, 2013. Beloved wife of Raymond J. Kenard. Memorial service Sunday May 19, 2013, 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell. The Funeral Chapel, Madison Avenue at 81 Street.
JAYNES--Jeffrey S.,of Rockaway Township NJ, Beloved Son of Frizzell and Melba and Beloved Brother of David, Barry, Beth, Robin and Theodore, passed quietly on May 14, 2013.

DURKA--William Joseph, retired attorney and manager of General Electric's International Trade Policy Operation, died May 12th at age 91. He is survived by his wife Nancy, daughter Margaret, and stepdaughter, Phoebe Trachtenberg, her husband, Gordon, and their two children. He was beloved by his large extended family that honors his brilliance, and his belief in the fundamental rights of all living creatures.

DAVIS--Francis Xavier, 96, died peacefully on April 30, 2013. The son of Mary (Heaphy) and James Davis, Frank was born in Brooklyn on January 22, 1917 and was the brother of James Edward, Elizabeth (Comerford), Mary Virginia, William, and Charles Davis. He was deeply devoted to his wife, Dorothy (Yonto), who died in 1983, and dedicated to his children, Mary Elizabeth and James Edward; to their spouses, Richard Gordon and Charity (Nelson); and to his grandchildren, James, Emily, Richard, Joseph, and Michael Davis. Widely beloved, he will be greatly missed.

BAUTISTA--Juan V.,May 18, 1946, passed May 14, 2013. Always celebrated a passion for life. The most dedicated husband, father, and a true civil servant for 39 years. Service, 10am Saturday, May 18, Holy Family Church, 315 E 47 St. In lieu of flowers, donations to PanCan.org.

SLIVKA--Abraham Isaac 88 years old, son of Philip and Yetta, WWII veteran, businessman, beloved husband for 63 years of Harriet, loving father to Sandy and Linda, Mark and Moira, Ann and Gary, and Seth and Wendi, brother, uncle, devoted grandfather of Barry, Derek, Lyle, Liam, Martha, Hannah, Erik, Justin, Jason, Clayton and Jacqueline and doting great grandfather of Jaden, Remi, Parker and Blake died peacefully. Abe was a child of the Great Depression who cared for the welfare of his family and of all people. He lived a good life. SCHWARTZ--Ellen May. Loving and beloved wife of Michael Schwartz for 44 years, mother of Liza Lauber and Joseph, mother-in-law of Alyson, sister of Richard Rubenstein, grandmother of Lily and Isaiah Walsh, friend, collaborator, inspiration and teacher of too many to name. A beautiful, irrepressible spirit, she lit up every room she walked into. She created hundreds of wonderful songs, on her own and with partners. Her most recent success was her lyrics for A Letter to Harvey Milk, which won top awards at the 2012 New York Musical Theatre Festival. She will live forever in our hearts, and in her words. Funeral at the Riverside, Friday, May 17, at 11:45. The family will be sitting shivah and receiving visitors at the Schwartzes' apartment from Friday late afternoon until Thursday, May 23. Please give to the American Cancer Society or another charity of your choice in her memory.

Doctoroff, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

MESSER--Thomas M. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation deeply mourn the passing of Thomas M. Messer, who served as Director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum from 1961 to 1988 and as Director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation from 1980 to 1988. He was the museum's third director. Distinguished curator, eminent scholar, beloved professor, and friend to many, Tom enriched both the Guggenheim and the art community's understanding and appreciation of nineteenth-and twentieth-century art through his farsighted and discerning stewardship, scholarship, and leadership. By developing curators and giving them great freedom, and through the scores of insightful catalogues he authored and collaborated on, he helped write the history of contemporary American and European art. The friendships he nurtured helped create the Guggenheim's exceptional collections, including the acquisition of the Thannhauser Collection and the Peggy Guggenheim Collection and the remarkable Venice palazzo that houses it. A man of great style, diplomacy, and sensitivity, Tom's passion for great art was inexhaustible. His warmth, spirit, and brilliant legacy will be with us always. Peter Lawson-Johnston, Honorary Chairman; William L. Mack, Chairman; and Jennifer Blei Stockman, President, Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation; Richard Armstrong, Director, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and Foundation; Thomas Krens, Director Emeritus; and Philip Rylands, Director, Peggy Guggenheim Collection.

LeFRAK--Ethel. The Coller family joins our dear friends, the LeFrak family, in mourning the passing of Ethel LeFrak. As a visionary and deeply engaged philanthropist, she enriched the lives of countless people, especially children. As our beloved Aunt Ethel, she enriched, guided, and gave meaning to our lives. We will miss, but never forget, her elegance, grace, kindness, wit, and song. Bobbi and Barry Coller Mimi and Ed Coller

KRONFELD--Eric Norman, aged 71, beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle, passed away peacefully on May 15, 2013, surrounded by loved ones. Eric was born on July 4, 1941, the son of Aaron and Naomi Kronfeld. A graduate of Swarthmore College and Harvard Law School, he spent more than half a century as an attorney, manager and senior executive in the music industry. Eric also spent 30 years successfully breeding racehorses including the Champion and 2010 Horse of the Year, Zenyatta, as well as owning a UK champion, Mrs. Penny. He lived an incredibly full life and enriched so many who knew him. He is survived by his wife, Katie, daughters Kerry and Melissa, sons Andrew and Joshua as well as six grandchildren, and his brother Edwin. He will be missed greatly. Memorial Service Sunday, May 19, 1:00pm, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NY NY.

Funeral will be held at 11:30am on Friday, May 17 at Temple Beth El 200 South Bedford Road, Chappaqua, NY. Shiva will follow at the home of David and Leslie Jameson, Chappaqua, NY from 3-8 pm. SULLIVAN--Jerome L, MD, PhD, born October 13, 1944, died May 3, 2013. Physician, scientist, professor, and internationally recognized father of the "iron hypothesis", Dr. Sullivan first theorized a link between heart disease and increased stored iron in 1981. His seminal paper, published in The Lancet that same year, is still frequently cited today. He was a strong proponent of blood donations, which he believed could reduce the risk of heart attack in men and post-menopausal women. Dr. Sullivan served on the faculties of several university medical schools, including University of Florida and University of Central Florida, and he lectured widely in the United States and abroad. Jerome is survived by his loving wife, Dr. Laura Geisel Sullivan, of Orlando, Florida, and five children. He was buried in his childhood hometown of Dothan, Alabama. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Heart Association are appreciated.

LeFRAK--Ethel. The executives and associates of LeFrak wish to express their profound sympathy to the LeFrak Family on the passing of Mrs. Ethel LeFrak, the widow of the late Dr. Samuel J. LeFrak, who had been chairman of our firm for many years. Mrs. LeFrak was an elegant, intelligent, sensitive, and generous woman whose kindness and grace touched all who were fortunate to know her. She was recognized and praised internationally for her magnanimous philanthropic works, which reflected her passion for helping those in need, including the support of charitable organizations, institutions of higher learning, hospitals, research facilities, and cultural programs. A tender, refined, and charming woman, she was loved by all. Our deepest condolences are extended to Richard LeFrak, her son and current chairman and CEO of LeFrak; her daughters, Denise, Francine, and Jacqueline; as well as her grandchildren and great- grandchildren.

KENTON--Muriel was born in NYC on August, 9 1918 and died April, 26 2013 in Walnut Creek CA. She is survived by her loving daughter Melanie Widroe and family and sister Berrie Deutschman and family. She will be greatly missed.

GLENN--Phyllis Whitmore, Passed May 2, 2013, born November 20, 1919. Loving widow of Albert B. Glenn, daughter to Martha & Edgar Whitmore, Freeport, NY, brother to Edgar F. Whitmore II of Pasadena, CA. She was a graduate of Maryland College for Women, lived most of her life in Sharon, CT and is survived by her children Edward, Stephanie, Candace, Gareth and Lynette. She loved life and will be greatly missed.

COLE--Robert Theodore On Wednesday, May 15th, 2013, at the age of 81, Robert T. Cole of Washington, D.C. died of stomach cancer. Beloved husband of C. Margaret Hall. Devoted father of Elizabeth Cole Bangser, Tanya Cole-Lesnick, and Jamy Cole-Judd. Loving brother of Paula Greenberg. Also survived by sons-in-law Paul Bangser, Steve Lesnick, and Cary Judd, and grandchildren Cole Judd (15), Emma Lesnick (15), Molly Lesnick (13), Jonathan Bangser (13), Kevin Judd (13), Seth Bangser (11), and Sydney Judd (10). Bob was born in Brooklyn, NY on March 16, 1932. He was raised in Laurelton (a suburb of Queens, NY) by his parents, Harold I. Cole and Bella Sarah Cole (nee Weissman). He was a graduate of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and Harvard Law School, and was a volunteer for the U.S. Air Force (1957-59). Bob had a rich life with a full career as an International Tax Attorney. He was an expert on transfer pricing and wrote the book on the topic. He was also a co-owner of several successful locations of The Little Gym. His recent focus included his much-loved pro bono work with clean water projects through FoEME (Friends of Earth Middle East) and WRAP (Water Resources Action Project). He was a mentor to many and a devoted Grand Canyon enthusiast. His love for life was infectious. Always curious, always excited to solve the next problem. Dedicated to achievement, health, and doing good on this planet, he inspired people all over the world. Funeral Services will be held on Sunday, May 19th, at 2:15 pm at Washington Hebrew Congregation (Small Chapel) at 3935 Macomb St., N.W., Washington, DC. Interment will take place at Garden of Remembrance in Clarksburg, MD. The family will be sitting Shiva for three nights beginning at 7:00 pm on each night. On Sunday, May 19th at the home of Len and Susan Miller in Potomac, MD. On Monday, May 20th, at the home of Elizabeth and Paul Bangser in Bethesda, MD. On Tuesday, May 21st, at the home of Jamy and Cary Judd in Brambleton, VA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your choice of the following: Water Resources Action Project (WRAP), Check payable to: WRAP, Memo: Fund in Memory of Bob Cole, 2300 N ST NW, Suite 2130, Washington, DC 20037. EcoPeace/ FoEME, Check payable to: EcoPeace/ FoEME Memo: Bob Cole Memorial Fund c/o Mary Alexander, 6534 Spring Valley Drive, Alexandria, VA 22312. Grand Canyon Trust Check payable to: Grand Canyon Trust, Memo: Robert T. Cole Fund, 2601 N. Fort Valley Road, Flagstaff, AZ 86001.

AXELROD--Bernard M. On May 17, 2013 in his 93rd year of Alzheimer's-related causes. Husband, father and father-in-law, grandfather and great-grandfather, brother and brother-in-law, uncle and great-uncle. Services private. Contributions to the Dr. S. Gandy Alzheimer's Research Fund at the Mt. Sinai Medical Center, 1 Gustave Levy Pl., Box 1049, New York, NY 10027.

ALEXANDER--Mary, of New York, Palm Beach, Mansfield, New Jersey and Bucharest, Romania died peacefully at home in her 85th year, May 16th 2013, fighting to her last breaths, so bravely and surely, after an illness that took all of her away except her essence that remained to say goodbye to this good life she loved so much and lived so well. Mother of Raluca Allison of New York; grandmother to Raleigh Allison and Percy Allison; most loving wife to Nicholas Alexander, deceased and terribly missed these past seven years. She will be missed by so many whom she helped when help was needed; by so many whose course of life she changed; and above all by her closest family who inherited and were inspired by her energy, her ambition, her spirit of adventure, her love of culture, her unquenchable desire to improve, her vast curiosity, her presence as the force of life she was. Born and educated in Romania, she went on to get a PhD in economics, attain a senior position in the Central Bank where she oversaw major industries; winning the Medal of Honor, the nation's highest recognition for professional service; and yet accomplished all this without political affiliation under a communist system she viscerally opposed, and, despite marriage to a man, the 50-year love of her life, who was a scion of one of the country's leading pre-communist families. Here was a woman who had the courage and vision to flee this oppressive system in her forties, leaving everything behind family, friends, job, prestige, home, belongings, money for freedom and dignity and prosperity in the United States, the adopted country she and her husband so loved and gave so much to, and, most of all, for the opportunity to give their one and only daughter, Raluca, a life worth living. And Mary did all this with no supports except her own drives and family. She did all this with false starts. She did all this having to learn in mid-life a new language and new ways. And she succeeded establishing a successful business in the great American entrepreneurial tradition; building homes and new family roots; sending her daughter to Yale and Columbia and on to a successful family and business life of her own; involving herself politically as she felt she must and attending two Presidential inaugurals as an emblem of her American commitment; following her longstanding interest in poetry, opera, and the life of the mind; and all the while enjoying all the little, daily things of life. The life force she was devastated as she was by the loss of her dearest Nick in 2006 and by the onset of a long Alzheimer's journey never once was lost, so much so, that to her very last breaths she knew her family and her family knew her and she fought with the final grains of her body's strength to say goodbye. She will be remembered and honored. She will inspire those who knew her. Most of all her spirit is a presence in the lives of her family and descendants who are happy at her peace even as they grieve at their loss. A funeral service will take place at St. James' Church at 11:00am., May 20th followed by a private burial service at the Princeton Cemetery. Donations to St. James' Church in lieu of flowers.

ZEFF--Elaine (nee Bendich), 65, died May 9, 2013 after a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. Devoted daughter of Joseph and Lillian, she was the beloved wife of Oscar, supportive mother of Brian and Dustin Klein, step-mother to Kayla and Jana, adored sister of Adrianne Bendich (David Kafkewitz), caring aunt of Jorden and Debra and their families. Employed by the Social Security Administration for over 41 years as a technical expert specializing in disability, she helped thousands during the hardest times of their lives. Following retirement she and Oscar drove school busses, and she was beloved by students, parents and colleagues. Her bravery, grace, humor and deep love of life will be remembered and celebrated by her devoted friends and family.

ZEBROWITZ--Aaron Harry, of Cedarhurst, NY on May 10, 2013 at age 93. He was a devoted husband to Esther (Milgrom) Zebrowitz for almost 70 years. A beloved father of Leslie Zebrowitz, Sylvia Warren, Lisa Rodolitz and her husband, Gary; a wonderful grandfather to Caleb McArthur, Loren McArthur, Earth Warren, Lauren Rodolitz and David Rodolitz; a favorite uncle of many nieces and nephews, and a proud great-grandfather of Daniela and Gabriel McArthur and Terra Warren. Harry was a finance graduate of CCNY, Army First Lieutenant in WWII from 1942-1946, and served as Senior Vice President at Martin E Segal Company for many years until his retirement.

WARE--John A.,71, of New York City, died on April 27, 2013 of complications related to leukemia. He was president of John A. Ware Literary Agency in New York City. A native of Manhattan, he attended Staples High School in Westport, Connecticut, obtained a bachelor's degree in philosophy from Cornell University (where he also sang in a blues band), and pursued graduate study in literature at Northwestern University. He launched his literary agency in 1978 after working as an agent at Curtis Brown, preceded by eight years as an editor at Doubleday, where he was first to publish Tracy Kidder. His agenting interests included investigative journalism, current affairs, history, biography, fiction, and the offbeat. Books and authors he represented include the bestsellers Into the Wild and Into Thin Air by Jon Krakauer, The Ice Master by Jennifer Niven, and works by bestselling historian Stephen E. Ambrose, Caroline Fraser, Jack Womack, and Tony Daniel, among many others. He was known for his unswerving sense of fairness, his abiding interest in humanitarian issues and civil rights, and his infectious sense of humor. A lover of language, baseball, music, New York, the rugged independence of the boutique literary agent, his volunteer work as a student mentor, soft-shell crabs in season, and the occasional afternoon at the races, he will be missed by all who counted him colleague, family, and friend. He is survived by his sister Ellen W. Cowen, his nephew Jeff A. Cowen, and his niece Jane C. Hamilton. Donations may be sent to the New York Philharmonic, the Police Athletic League, or City Harvest.

WABER--Bernard, died Thursday, May 16th in New York. He was ninety-one. He leaves children Paulis, Louisa, and Gary, sons-in-law Rod and Dana, and grandchildren Mason, Anna, Rachel and Reuben, all of whom cherish the memory of a deeply loving, funny and wise father and grandfather. He is also survived by his big brother Isadore. His beloved wife Ethel died in 2006. Bernard leaves numerous friends, many in the children's book world. Bernard Waber published over forty books. He is best known for his Lyle, Lyle Crocodile books, and Ira Sleeps Over. He was also a graphic artist at Time, Inc. He loved his work in children's books and loved meeting children throughout the country. He treasured his relationships with his publisher Houghton Mifflin Harcourt and his agent, Elizabeth Harding at Curtis Brown. He cared deeply for everyone and rarely spoke of either his accomplishments or troubles. It's so hard to lose him but we were fortunate. To quote from his book, Courage, "Courage means sometimes having to say goodbye." A memorial service is planned for the near future.
