SULLIVAN--Jerome L, MD, PhD, born October 13, 1944, died May 3, 2013. Physician, scientist, professor, and internationally recognized father of the "iron hypothesis", Dr. Sullivan first theorized a link between heart disease and increased stored iron in 1981. His seminal paper, published in The Lancet that same year, is still frequently cited today. He was a strong proponent of blood donations, which he believed could reduce the risk of heart attack in men and post-menopausal women. Dr. Sullivan served on the faculties of several university medical schools, including University of Florida and University of Central Florida, and he lectured widely in the United States and abroad. Jerome is survived by his loving wife, Dr. Laura Geisel Sullivan, of Orlando, Florida, and five children. He was buried in his childhood hometown of Dothan, Alabama. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Heart Association are appreciated.

STRACHER--Dr. Alfred, Beloved husband, father, and grandfather, died on May 8, 2013, at the age of 82. Dr. Stracher is survived by his wife, Dorothy Stracher; their sons Cameron and Adam; their daughter Erica Fields, and three grandchildren, Simon and Veronica (Lulu) Stracher, and Ari Fields. Those who wish may make contributions in Alfred's name to Leukemia Fighters at New York Presbyterian Hospital.

SMITH--Holley Randall, died May 8th in Glen, Montana. Formerly of Irvington, NY. Widow of E. Maynard Smith. Mother of Kathy, Brack, Randy and Meg. Sister of Frances Wood. Commemorative celebration May 30th at her home in Glen.

SMITH--Charles G.,Ph.D., An internationally prominent biochemist and pharmaceutical industry executive, died on May 1, 2013, in Carlsbad, CA. He was 85. Beginning in the 1950's, Dr. Smith carried out personal research in the fields of antibiotics, cancer and industrial molecular biology. As a pharmaceutical executive, he had direct administrative responsibility for total drug discovery and development programs in many fields, including infectious diseases, cancer and cardiovascular diseases over a 30 year period. Dr. Smith was directly involved in or administratively responsible for the discovery, licensing and marketing of approximately 20 major medications and products. Dr. Smith was a co-founder and Director of Vanguard Medica, Ltd., Guildford, UK, and served on the Boards of Directors of Chemex Pharmaceuticals (Fort Lee, NJ) and Dura Pharmaceuticals (San Diego, CA). Charles Giles Smith was born on October 27, 1927, in Chicago, Il. He received a Bachelor of Science degree in chemistry from the Illinois Institute of Technology in 1950, a Master of Science degree in biochemistry from Purdue University in 1952, and a Ph.D. in biochemistry from the University of Wisconsin in 1954. He served in the United States Army from 1946 to 1947, from which he was honorably discharged. Dr. Smith began his professional career at The Upjohn Company, Kalamazoo, Michigan, where he worked from 1954 to 1967. Between 1967 and 1975, he was the Vice President, Research and Development and President, Squibb Institute for Medical Research (1974) at E.R. Squibb & Sons, Princeton, NJ. He was the Vice President, Research and Development of the Revlon Health Care Group, Tuckahoe, NY, from 1975 to 1986. After retiring in 1986, Dr. Smith served as a pharmaceutical consultant on a worldwide basis. He was an Adjunct Professor at San Diego State University for several years. He authored 50 full papers, abstracts and notes in major scientific publications and the book "The Process of New Drug Discovery and Development," CRC Press, Boca Raton, FL, 1992. Dr. Smith lectured extensively on various aspects of pharmaceutical research and development during the course of his career. In addition to his passion for scientific discovery, Dr. Smith enjoyed Italian opera, food and culture, military history, and lively discourse with children and adults alike. He engaged all people he encountered. He was a humanitarian and a true gentleman. Dr. Smith was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. He is survived by his beloved wife of 63 years, Angeline F. Smith, sons Giles, Kevin and Jeffrey Paul, daughter Tracy, ten grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

SLIVKA--Abraham Isaac 88 years old, son of Philip and Yetta, WWII veteran, businessman, beloved husband for 63 years of Harriet, loving father to Sandy and Linda, Mark and Moira, Ann and Gary, and Seth and Wendi, brother, uncle, devoted grandfather of Barry, Derek, Lyle, Liam, Martha, Hannah, Erik, Justin, Jason, Clayton and Jacqueline and doting great grandfather of Jaden, Remi, Parker and Blake died peacefully. Abe was a child of the Great Depression who cared for the welfare of his family and of all people. He lived a good life. Contributions may be made to: American Friends of Keshet Eilon, 25 Trinity Pass, Pound Ridge, NY 10576.

SIMONDS--Jane M.,died on May 12, 2013, at the age of 96. She was predeceased by her first husband, Craigh Leonard, and by her second husband, Robinson Simonds. She is survived by her daughter, Stephanie Leonard; a son, Edward Leonard, and his wife, Victoria; a son, Craigh Leonard, and his wife, Evie; a step-son, William Simonds, and his wife, Jane; a step-son, Robin Simonds; and by seven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. A service will be held at Saint Andrew's Dune Church, 12 Gin Lane, Southampton, NY, on June 11, 2013, at 11:30am. Memorial contributions may be made to Saint Andrew's Dune Church, P.O. Box 1245, Southampton, NY 11969.
SILVERSTEIN--Stuart, on May 15, 2013, of New York City. His Generous Spirit will be missed by All.

SCHWARTZ--Gerald, age 92 of Hewlett, NY passed away on May 17, 2013. Cherished husband to Roslyn for almost 63 years. Beloved father of Barry and Nancy, and Carol and Richard. Adored grandfather of Jason and Tara, Eric and Lauren, Andrew and Meredith and Dana. Great-grandfather of one adorable little girl, Avery. Gerald was a CPA with the firm of Maxwell Schaller and Co. for 70 years and completed his last tax season just before he became ill. Services will be held on May 20, 2013 at Gutterman's Inc. in Rockville Center, NY. He was a devoted and caring, loving and wonderful man and will be greatly missed by all who knew him.

SAID--Dr. Sami I. Distinguished Professor of Stony Brook University, New York, passed away April 30th, 2013. He was born in Cairo, Egypt in 1928, trained as a medical doctor, worked at the Naval American Research Unit, and came to the USA on a Fullbright Scholarship in 1953. He began a new career at Bellevue in New York and later at Johns Hopkins. Dr. Said was Professor of Medicine at the Medical College of Virginia, and Medicine and Pharmacology at Texas Southwestern. He was Chief of Pulmonary at the Dallas VA Medical Center, and then became Chief of Pulmonary and Critical Care at the University of Oklahoma. He then went to Chicago and directed research at the University of Illinois and the VA Hospital. He served his last years as Chief of Pulmonary and Critical Care at Stony Brook and ACOS/Research at VA Medical Center at Northport. His research work was completely funded, and he actively pursued research for his entire career. He actually never retired. Dr. Said was an inventor and held eight US patents. He received the VA's highest scientific honor, the Middleton Award, for his discovery of the neuropeptide vasoactive intestinal peptide, named VIP. The American Thoracic Society named him the "Amberson Lecturer" for his major contributions to pulmonary physiology and pharmacology. He is predeceased by his father, Rev. Ibrahim Said, mother Asma Atallah, and brother, Wadie ; survived by his brother, Mufeed and sister, Nadia. He will be missed by his loving nephews and nieces, Ibrahim, Mufeed, Hala, Sami, Curtis and Natalie. Dr. Said will be remembered as a great scientist, mentor, a gentleman, and a pillar to his immediate and extended family around the world.
ROSEN--Sanford (Sandy). Beloved childhood friend. You left us much too soon. You will be missed. Our hearts go out to Doris. The Goldberg and Sweder Families.

ROSEN--Sanford "Sandy," on May 16, 2013. Beloved son of Doris Rosen Margett and the late Michael Rosen and step-son of the late Hon. Charles Margett. Astute financial advisor, confidant to many and loyal friend. Services: Sunday, May 19, 12 noon at "Riverside- Nassau North Chapels" 55 No. Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

RIVERA--Hector, 62, CPA, educator, of Manhattan, died peacefully on April 30. He is survived by his brother Francisco and loving companion Maria. He will be missed by his many friends, family, students and colleagues.
RENEK--Morris, writer, 88, is survived by his wife, Ethel, his daughters Nava and Naomi and his grandson Evan.

REFF--Molly, beloved mother of Hariette Wittenberg-Saturn (Simeon Saturn) and Albert A. Reff. Cherished grandmother of Jacqueline, Joshua and David. Devoted sister, aunt, teacher and friend. Services Monday, 12:45pm, "Sinai Chapels," 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows.

RANIERI--Maria, on May 16, 2013. The wife of the late Thomas died peacefully at her home at the age of 96. She was the loving, devoted mother to Frank, Connie and Rose Crosby, and the mother-in-law to Marilyn Ranieri and Fred Crosby. She cherished her two granddaughters, Danielle and Nicole, and adored her great-grandson, Daniel Joseph, who she called "Baby Doll". She is also survived by one sister Rose Igneri. Her family and friends will sorely miss her generous nature and her keen mind. Mom was always known for her hospitality, welcoming family, friends and neighbors into her home. Visiting Sunday 2-5 and 7-9pm at Joseph G. Duffy & M.J. Smith Sons Funeral Home, 255 9th Street, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10:00am at Holy Name of Jesus RC Church. Interment to follow at The Green-Wood Cemetery.
PADAWER--Rose (Anolik), 107, on 9 May 2013, widow of Lewis, mother of Gerald and Saralta (Loeb), "Grammy" to four granddaughters and six great-grandchildren.

ORTEGA--John Evan, on May 16, 2013 at age 77. Formerly of Miami, Florida and NYC. Beloved father of John Evan Ortega Jr. and loving brother. Devoted uncle of James Freyre, Gianina Ireland and Miriam Waag. U.S. Army veteran having served in Germany. Alumni of Florida Atlantic University.

O'BRIEN--Walter J. III, "Joe" died May 10, 2013 in Richmond, VA at the age of 46. Joe is survived by a son Connor; a daughter Caitlin, and his wife Debra. He has two "moms" Nancy Malmuth and Margaret O'Brien. His father is Walter J. O'Brien Jr. Joe graduated from Hotchkiss in Lakeville, CT. He earned a degree in Economics from the University of Richmond. He began his successful financial career at Smith Barney in New York City. When he left New York to join Scott and Stringfellow, he was a Senior Vice President at Citicorp. More recently, as Senior Managing Director for Capital Markets at BB&T, Joe was well known for his inspirational leadership, innovative thinking and financial acumen. Further information is at www.blileys.com.

MORELLI--John, on May 14, 2013, at the age of 80, after a brief illness John left this world peacefully, the way he always wanted to - in his sleep and without pain. Beloved husband of Phyllis, devoted father of Steven, John Daryl, and Laura, beloved brother of Louis, sisters-in-law Joan and Maria, as well as a host of in-laws, cousins, nieces and nephews, all of whom loved him dearly. Proud graduate of Brandeis University, class of 1954, he loved tennis to the end, and weaving luxury yarns during his many years as president of Newcastle Fabrics. John lived his entire life as a wonderful human being and will be sorely missed by everyone who knew him. We will be celebrating his life at a memorial to be held at a later date.

MOLL--Bertram Daniel, on May 11, 2013, Bertram Daniel Moll, known to many for his kindness, compassion, and profound devotion to his wife Nessa, died peacefully in San Diego, California. The cause was complications from Alzheimer's disease. He was 87. Bert was born in Brooklyn, New York to Nathan and Bella Moll, immigrants from Eastern Europe. He attended Erasmus High, NYU, and Harvard Law School. During World War II, he served as a sergeant in the Army, stationed in the Philippines. Married to Nessa Ernstoff Moll for 55 years, they settled first in Rockville Centre and then Port Washington, both on Long Island. They later moved to Greenwich Village, Farmington Woods in Avon, Connecticut and then San Diego. Bert and Nessa shared a passion for politics, movies, theatre, The New York Times' Crossword, international travel, classical music and chocolate. Bert joined the Legal Department at Long Island Lighting Company and appeared on its behalf in the United States Supreme Court. He later joined Con Edison's Legal Department and subsequently moved into a business role as a Vice President, assuming responsibility for Con Ed's oil and then gas supply. He was dedicated to the communities in which he lived, serving on the school board and as a board member of Group House for troubled teens in Port Washington. Bert also served as a law guardian in the Nassau County Family Court. In Farmington Woods, he served on the Boards of the Home Owner's Association and Tax District. Bert was an ardent sports fan and had a love-hate relationship with the Yankees, Knicks and Jets. He enjoyed playing tennis and golf and could swish a set shot from 25 feet with admirable consistency. Bert's integrity, generosity and devotion to wife and family were an inspiration to all who knew him and will never be forgotten. In addition to Nessa, Bert is survived by his son Steve and his wife, Rhonda, daughter Laura and her husband, Dave, and daughter Julie and her husband Nick, as well as by grandchildren Karly and Nina, Evan and Jeremy, and Nate, Owen and Ben. Bert was predeceased by his parents and his brother Arthur. Contributions in Bert's memory can be made to Alzheimer's Disease Research Center, 8950 Villa La Jolla Drive Suite C129, La Jolla, CA 92037.
MILLS--Peter. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. We love you and miss you so much. Janet, Marc, Jonna, Elisa and Charlie

MILLARD--Anne. The 564 Park Avenue Preservation Foundation members mourn the loss of their founding President, Anne Millard. Her leadership in architectural preservation was inspirational. We extend our sympathy to her family. A memorial service will be held at St. Jean Baptiste Church, 76th Street and Lexington Avenue on Tuesday, May 28 at 4:00pm. Park Avenue Preservation Foundation, 564 Park Avenue, New York, New York, 10065.

MEYER--Edward. We mourn the passing of Edward Jay Meyer, age 75, accomplished business executive who died Tuesday, May 14th, of complications from cancer. Beloved by family, friends and colleagues, Meyer graduated from Brandeis University in 1960, with a degree in economics. After serving in the United States Army, he graduated from Harvard Business School in 1963. In 17 years at Clairol and Bristol Myers from 1963-1980, Meyer led the marketing strategy for successful products including Body on Tap Shampoo, Bufferin, Excedrin and Ban Roll-On. In 1981 Meyer joined Sun Refining and Marketing Co. (the parent company of Sunoco) in Philadelphia where he was Vice President of Marketing and Strategic Development, and oversaw the brand strategy behind Sun's acquisition and integration of the Atlantic service stations. From 1991-1999 he worked as an executive consultant to Leon Hess, Chairman of Hess Oil. In 1999, he became president of Philadelphia and Singapore-based AssetLine, a global internet-based auction market for the construction industry. He retired as a senior vice president of Equitable Resources, a gas utility in Pittsburgh, where he also was the president of the company's energy-management services subsidiary. He was married for 37 years to Elizabeth Meyer, known as Betsy, who died in 2004. He is survived by his second wife, Toby Meyer, brother Stephen (Erica), sons Scott (Andrea) and Andrew (Gayle), and his three adored grandchildren Nathan, Theo and Sidney. He loved tennis, and played avidly for over 50 years, right up to his passing. He was also a collector and benefactor of modern art, playing an instrumental role in the creation of the Betsy Meyer Memorial Exhibition at the Main Line Art Center in Haverford, PA that is now in its 9th year. His family will mourn his passing in a private service this Sunday in New York, and his life will be celebrated in a memorial service on Thursday June 13th at Bala Golf Club, 2200 Belmont Ave, Philadelphia, PA 19131. Donations can be made in his name to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

MESSER--Thomas M. The Noguchi Museum is deeply saddened by the loss of our esteemed friend and colleague Thomas M. Messer, who so elegantly and eloquently served as a Trustee to the New York Board and as our representative to the Board of our sister museum in Japan. His care of the collection and commitment to the artists and to Isamu Noguchi will continue to inspire us. To his beloved godson and family, we offer condolences. David D. Holbrook, Chairman Jenny Dixon, Director The Isamu Noguchi Foundation and Garden Museum

MAISLEN--Ruth, loving partner of 43 years and recent spouse of Jean Louise Engel, died peacefully May 13 of natural causes. Devoted mother of Meredith, Marc (Mary). Loving grandmother of Ramon (Diana), Kateri, Micah (Meghann), Adam and Marissa. Proud great-grandmother of Rio and Rome. Donations in Ruth's memory may be sent to The House of Ruth for Abused Women, P.O. Box 64036, Baltimore, MD 21264-4036.

LEIGHTON--Hallie Leland, 42, who fought successfully for passage of New York State's Breast Density Inform Bill, while fighting her own losing battle with metastatic breast cancer died on April 30, 2013. She gave media interviews telling her own story, urging women to find out if they have dense tissue, not itself abnormal but sometimes masking tumors in mammograms, and to inquire about further testing. She supported the organization, "Are You Dense?," lobbied for the bill in Albany, and started an advocacy blog. The bill became NYS law in January, 2013. Hallie brought the same passion, intellect, and devotion to this cause as to her other interests and many friendships. Born and raised in NYC, Hallie went to the High School of Performing Arts, attended St. John's College in Annapolis, and graduated from the Santa Fe campus where she was editor of the college newspaper. Her career was varied, but never strayed far from her love of language and writing. She started collecting words at age 13 when she encountered hussar and bivouac in Tolstoy's War and Peace. "I treat words I have just learned like new acquaintances; no matter how well we hit it off on a first meeting, I don't assume intimacy." With her late father, the actor/impersonator Jan Leighton, she co-authored two books, Rare Words I and II (Levenger Press, 2003, 2008), which used humor to help master meanings. After college, Hallie worked at Random House and Knopf, was a writer's assistant on As the World Turns at CBS, and wrote columns for Cotton, Inc. that appeared regularly in Women's Wear Daily. She went to Israel in an arts program in the Negev, where she wrote about the Bedouin and stayed two more years because "the adventure wasn't over," working with organizations that promoted peace between Arabs and Israelis. Back in the U.S. she became Director of Communications for Charity Brands, a firm that connected corporations with good causes. At the time of her death, she was working on a documentary on her father's unusual career he had played more roles than any other actor (2407) according to the 1985 Guinness Book of World Records. Hallie is survived by her mother, Lynda Myles, her Aunt Wendie Myles, her brother Ross Leighton, and a large, loving extended family. There will be a memorial service to celebrate her life and share memories at The Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, NYC, Thursday, June 13, 5:30pm. Gifts to support Hallie's favored charities can be made to the Jewish Communal Fund (att: Hallie Leighton Tikkun Olam Fund), 575 Madison Ave. #

LeFRAK--Ethel. The executives and associates of LeFrak wish to express their profound sympathy to the LeFrak Family on the passing of Mrs. Ethel LeFrak, the widow of the late Dr. Samuel J. LeFrak, who had been chairman of our firm for many years. Mrs. LeFrak was an elegant, intelligent, sensitive, and generous woman whose kindness and grace touched all who were fortunate to know her. She was recognized and praised internationally for her magnanimous philanthropic works, which reflected her passion for helping those in need, including the support of charitable organizations, institutions of higher learning, hospitals, research facilities, and cultural programs. A tender, refined, and charming woman, she was loved by all. Our deepest condolences are extended to Richard LeFrak, her son and current chairman and CEO of LeFrak; her daughters, Denise, Francine, and Jacqueline; as well as her grandchildren and great- grandchildren.

LeFRAK--Ethel. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of Ethel LeFrak, a dear friend and benefactor who, along with her late husband Samuel, was among the earliest members of our Society of Founders. In honor of her generous support of biomedical research and education at Einstein, the College named its Ethel and Samuel J. LeFrak Auditorium in their honor. Mrs. LeFrak played a leadership role in Einstein's National Women's Division, and was also a past trustee of Cardozo School of Law. To her son Richard, daughters Denise, Francine and Jacqueline, and the entire LeFrak family we extend our heartfelt condolences. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President
LeFRAK--Ethel. Dear Ethel, you were a great lady. Thank you for your friendship. Our sincere condolences to the LeFrak family. Lynn and Carl Goldstein

LeFRAK--Ethel. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Ethel LeFrak, wife of the late Samuel LeFrak, committed philanthropists whose devotion to the Jewish community lives on through their family. Jerry W. Levin, President; Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

LEDOUX--Jeanne-Nicole, 67, of Cornwall-on-Hudson, NY and East Dorset, VT died May 9, 2013. Memorials may be made to The William Ledoux Memorial Fund, Cornell University Feline Health Center, Hungerford Hill Road, Ithaca, NY 14853; The Storm King School, 314 Mountain Road, Cornwall-on-Hudson, NY 12520-1899; or The MDS Center, Columbia University Medical Center, 177 Fort Washington Ave., New York, NY 10032. Services handled by James F. Lulves Funeral Home, Inc Cornwall-on-Hudson.

KRONFELD--Eric Norman, aged 71, beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle, passed away peacefully on May 15, 2013, surrounded by loved ones. Eric was born on July 4, 1941, the son of Aaron and Naomi Kronfeld. A graduate of Swarthmore College and Harvard Law School, he spent more than half a century as an attorney, manager and senior executive in the music industry. Eric also spent 30 years successfully breeding racehorses including the Champion and 2010 Horse of the Year, Zenyatta, as well as owning a UK champion, Mrs. Penny. He lived an incredibly full life and enriched so many who knew him. He is survived by his wife, Katie, daughters Kerry and Melissa, sons Andrew and Joshua as well as six grandchildren, and his brother Edwin. He will be missed greatly. Memorial Service Sunday, May 19, 1:00pm, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NY NY.

KRISKO--Robert (Kris) Krisko, of Buckingham, PA passed away on Tuesday, May 14, 2013 at his residence. He was formerly employed as a Chief Financial Officer with Skandia Reinsurance Company of New York City for 20 years. Robert was a US Naval Veteran. Robert is survived by his beloved partner of 54 years, Gregory A. Nieto, dear brother of Ann Adams of California, loving uncle to many nieces and nephews. Cremation services were private under direction of the Varcoe-Thomas Funeral Home, Doylestown, PA. Send condolences to www.varcoethomas funeralhome.com

JOHNSON--Kristina Barbara. The Trustees and Staff of the American Folk Art Museum mourn the passing of Kristina Barbara Johnson, who served on the board of trustees from 1968 through 2010. Kristina loved, collected, and donated a sizable number of artworks to the Museum including significant examples of scrimshaw. She organized an exhibition in 1968 titled "Hunt for the Whale" and also inaugurated an annual lecture series, delivering the first talk, "The Art of the Whalerman." Kristina became Board President in 1971, at which time Adele Earnest, a founding director, said her "optimism and devoted work renewed our purpose and our strength." Kristina helped to establish The Clarion, which became one of the most respected folk art journals, and created a scholarship fund for the newly established Folk Art Institute. The guest of honor at the Museum's 1985 gala was Kristina's pet tortoise, George, who was 184 years old and had been a member of Queen Victoria's court. We express our deepest condolences to her family, who have asked that contributions in her memory be made to the American Folk Art Museum, Administrative Office, 1865 Broadway, 11th Floor, New York, NY 10023. Laura Parsons, Chair Edward V. Blanchard, Jr., President, Board of Trustees Dr. Anne-Imelda Marino Radice, Executive Director

GOTTESMAN--Milton, beloved husband of the late Barbara, and devoted father of Stefanie Gottesman (David Shelsky) and Michael (Erin); dear brother of Susie Springberg and cherished grandfather of Dylan, Brandon and Gianna. Services Sunday 12 noon at Star Of David Chapel, West Babylon, LI.
GORDON--Lillian, the staff at Burt Millwork extend condolences to our President, Eli Gordon and his family on the passing of Eli's dear wife.

GORDON--Lillian, 84, of Atlantic Beach, NY. December 7th, 1928 - May 12th, 2013. GORDON--Lillian, the employees of Balsan Village regret the passing of Lillian Gordon, loving wife of owner Eli Gordon and beloved mother of managing agent Stephen Gordon.

GLENN--Phyllis Whitmore, Passed May 2, 2013, born November 20, 1919. Loving widow of Albert B. Glenn, daughter to Martha & Edgar Whitmore, Freeport, NY, brother to Edgar F. Whitmore II of Pasadena, CA. She was a graduate of Maryland College for Women, lived most of her life in Sharon, CT and is survived by her children Edward, Stephanie, Candace, Gareth and Lynette. She loved life and will be greatly missed.

GEIGER--Karen, 78, died peacefully at home on May 5, 2013 in Berkeley, CA, cared for by friends and family. She is survived by her children Elizabeth Geiger (Atlanta, GA) and Peter Butt (Corte Madera, CA), their families and a world-wide community of loving family, friends and colleagues. A memorial celebration will be held June 22, 2013 at the Community Congregational Church of Tiburon, CA.
FENNIMORE--Linda, 67, died on February 23. Renowned jazz violinist, consummate entertainer and lover of life. Memorial service on June 10. Details: clarkchild@aol.com.

FELDMAN--Ruth T. We share the sorrow of our esteemed partner, Peter Feldman, on the passing of his mother, Ruth T. Feldman. Ruth was a devoted wife to her late husband, Albert, and a deeply committed mother and grandmother. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Peter, his wife Mary and their daughter, Sasha, and son, Benjamin, and to Peter's sister, Diane Salzberg, and the entire Feldman family. Otterbourg, Steindler, Houston & Rosen, P.C.

CRAWFORD--J. Hyde, Jr. 82, passed away peacefully at his home in Fort Lauderdale, FL on May 11th, 2013. Jay, as he was known to his friends, was the celebrated fashion illustrator for Bonwit Teller for 30 years as well as President and principal designer for Quadrille, the wholesale fabric and wall-paper company he founded. The only child of the late Nelda Francis Crawford and the late John Hyde Crawford, Sr., Jay was born October 16, 1930 in Jacksonville, FL. The family moved to Houston, TX and finally to Orlando, FL, where Jay attended High School. After graduation he studied art and fashion illustration at New York's Parsons School of Design and later was chosen to attend the prestigious Parsons European session. There he had exposure to not only fashion but to the world of interiors and outdoor painting. His room interior paintings are coveted to this day. After being graduated from Parsons he immediately began working for Bonwit Teller, the high end fashion store. In 1965 he was asked to update Bonwit Teller's violet logo which was reproduced on products from shopping bags to bathrobes. His fashion illustrations of haut couture designers such as Ungaro, Couregge, Cardin, and Calvin Klein could be seen daily in the New York Times. His impeccable eye and style easily translated to home decor, a talent that allowed him to design fabrics and wall-coverings, first for Woodson Wallpapers and then his own successful company, Quadrille. Jay assembled a substantial art collection, containing everything from dramatic 19th century European paintings to oversized canvases from the 1960s and '70s. With an artist eye he collected pieces not because they were deemed important, but because they "worked" in the environments where they were to be hung, thus becoming larger works of art. He is survived by his partner of 29 years Charles Andrews who is also now his husband. A private burial will be held in Salem, VA and a public memorial service will be held in New York City at a later date. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to SAGE, Services & Advocacy for Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual & Transgender Elders, at sageusa.org/donate.

COX--William C.,Jr. William C. Cox, Jr., of Hobe Sound, FL and Nantucket, MA, passed away peacefully on May 1, 2013 surrounded by his family. He was 82. Bill was born on November 8, 1930 in Boston, Massachusetts to William C. Cox and Jessie Bancroft Cox. He was the great-grandson of Clarence Barron, the owner of the Boston News Bureau, who later acquired the Dow Jones news service in 1902. The Bancroft Family are the former owners of Dow Jones & Company Inc., publishers of The Wall Street Journal. Bill attended Dexter School in Brookline Mass, Brooks School in North Andover and Boston University. He served in the United States Air Force during the Korean War. Bill's career at Dow Jones began in the late 1950s and would span over four-decades. In the 1960s he worked for the companys circulation services at their Chicopee, MA facility. While his career was spent on the business side of Dow Jones, he was a staunch supporter and steward of the journalistic integrity of the Wall Street Journal. In the 1970's, Bill moved to Detroit to be the mid-western advertising sales director of The Wall Street Journal. In 1976 Bill was elected to the Board of Directors of Dow Jones, a position he held for twenty-five years. In the 1980s he moved to London to help launch the European Edition of The Wall Street Journal. He returned to the United States in 1995 and served as the Journal's Executive Director of Client Relations, a position he held until his retirement in 2001. Growing up in Cohasset, MA, exposed to the equestrian world his parents loved, Bill realized his sporting interest lay outside of the riding ring. Much to his mother's consternation he never took to horses instead becoming an accomplished golfer, baseball player and ice hockey player, once being extended the opportunity to try out for the Boston Bruins. As a baseball player, he shared his mother's passionate support of the Red Sox. An avid golfer he cherished playing a round with friends or family. Bill was a long time member of the US Seniors Golf Association. He was also an accomplished outdoorsman who was equally at home in a Michigan duck blind or casting a plug for stripped bass and bluefish off Nantucket. Bill loved music and a good party. He especially enjoyed singing old Broadway show tunes or Cole Porter songs. Perhaps most notable was Bill's generous support to the communities in which he lived. He was a trustee emeritus of the Nantucket Conservation Foundation; trustee of The Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution; Board member of the Nantucket Boys and Girls Club and supporter of the Martin County Boys and Girls Club. As past president of The Sankaty Head Foundation, he took great pride in the Caddy Camp and its role in developing young men of character. Bill also served as a Commissioner for the Town of Jupiter Island, FL. Above all of his business, athletic, and philanthropic accomplishments, he was most proud of his family. He was a devoted husband, father, and grandfather. He is survived by his wife of 60 years; Martha W. Cox and their four children, William C Cox III, Ann Cox Bartram, Heidi Cox and Martha Cox Farrell, and 10 grandchildren, his sister Jane MacElree and his beloved dog Topper. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Nantucket Boys and Girls Club P.O. Box 269 Nantucket, MA 02554, The Nantucket Conservation Foundation P.O. Box 13, Nantucket, MA 02554 and the Sankaty Head Foundation, P.O. Box 875, Siasconset, MA 02564. Memorial Service will be 4pm, July 13, 2013 at St. Paul's Church in Nantucket.

COWETT--Wilbur A. The Friends of the Harvard Judaica Collection mourn the passing of Wilbur A. Cowett, a loyal and generous friend, and send condolences to his wife Peggy and to his children Frederick and Anne. David B. Keidan, President, Friends of the Harvard Judaica Collection Charles Berlin, Head, Judaica Division, Harvard Library

COWETT--Wilbur. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with great sadness the passing of Wilbur Cowett, a deeply compassionate philanthropist and former member of UJA-Federation's board of directors. His generosity, commitment, and leadership in the Jewish community was inspirational. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Wilbur's wife, Margaret; his children, Anne, Frederick, and daughter-in-law Diana Riesman; his grandchildren; and the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President; Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

COWETT--Wilbur Arnold, of New York, NY passed away on Wednesday, May 15, 2013. Born in Springfield, MA in 1924, Mr. Cowett was a prominent investment banker, a man of great generosity, integrity and intellect with a prodigious appetite for life. After serving in the OSS in World War II and graduating from Harvard College in 1947 and Harvard Business School in 1949, he joined Wertheim & Co where he specialized in corporate finance and ultimately became Vice-Chairman, before leaving in 1980 to form his own investment and consulting firm. His work was noteworthy for financial transactions of great complexity of a kind that were at the time many years in advance of the state of the art of the investment banking industry. He was a generous donor to numerous institutions, including Harvard University and UJA-Federation, and spent summers at a home in Tupper Lake, NY where he made many contributions to the community. He is survived by his wife Margaret Cowett, daughter Anne Cowett, son Frederick Cowett, daughter-in-law Diana Riesman, and grandchildren Theodore and Nora Cowett. He is also survived by his first wife Joan Leiman Jacobson, the mother of his children, brother- and sister-in-law Leonard and Joan Leiman, nieces Elizabeth Kraiem and Victoria Bender, and nephews Alan Leiman and Alexei Cowett. A funeral service will be held at 12 noon, Sunday, May 19, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY. The family will be at the home of Leonard and Joan Leiman, 1125 Park Avenue, from 5:30 to 7:30 on May 19. In lieu of flowers, a contribution in Mr. Cowett's memory may be made to the Harvard College Fund.

COMINS--Edith K. (nee Krich). Loving wife for fifty-seven years to Frederic M. Comins, who predeceased her in 2005, passed away peacefully at home in Briarcliff Manor, NY, on May 15, 2013. Born March 14, 1927 in South Orange, NJ, and a graduate of Columbia High School there, she enrolled at the University of Wisconsin. With an eye on a career in fashion, she transferred to the Tobe-Coburn Fashion Institute in New York City. Despite being elected class president, she chose a life of marriage and family. She was an elegant, intelligent, and generous woman, who was known and respected for her sense of taste and grace. She and Fred lived for many years in Short Hills, NJ where their sons grew up; at 870 United Nations Plaza in N.Y.C., and retired to Briarcliff Manor, NY. A devoted and adored mother, she leaves behind her three sons, Frederic M. Jr. of Ft. Myers, FL and Mystic, CT; Max of Woodstock, VT, and Andy of Los Angeles, CA; her sister Claire Hooton and cousin, Carol Jedel; her four grandsons, Scot, Jamison, Drew, and Jordan, and her nephew, Hart Hooton and his family.
CARLIN--William J.C.,Jr. Dear friend, you are missed. Sheila F. Murphy

BROWN--Dorothy Taylor, 87, beloved wife of the late Jack M. Brown, Princeton Class of 1935, passed away on May 15, in Princeton, New Jersey, after a long illness. She was born in Los Angeles, California, on January 25th, 1926, to parents Sigrid and Robert Taylor and grew up in California. She worked in the airline industry for many years and started her own travel business, Travel Desk of New York and St. Croix, which was very successful. Dorothy and her husband, Jack M. Brown, lived in Manhattan and St. Croix. For the past nine years, she lived in Princeton, New Jersey. Dorothy is survived by her two sisters Margaret Thackaberry of Sherman Oaks, California and Doryce McCutchan (Thomas) of San Marino, California, and many nieces and nephews: Eric Taylor (Laura) of Soma, California, Wendy Taylor of Phoenix, Arizona, Diana Baker (Rick) of the Dominican Republic, Lisa Thackaberry of Los Angeles, Mark Thackaberry of San Diego, Jeffery Thackaberry of Studio City, California, Thomas McCutchan (Dorothy) of La Canada, California, and Katherine Carey (Tim) of South Pasadena, California. Ceremony and interment will be private.

BRITZ--Billie Sherrill. Cherished mother, grandmother, friend, architectural historian. Her daughters, Diane Britz Lotti and Meredith Britz Shelley, along with her grandchildren, Ariane, Samantha, Atticus and Tyler, treasure the wonderful years of love and life they shared with her.

BLOCK--Dr. Michael, PhD, on May 5th, 2013. Husband of the late Millicent, father of Margaret, Jonathan, Bernard, Rachel, Alice, Robert; their spouses Kathy, Bob, Chris, Carrie; grandfather of David, Nicolas, Taylor, Hanna, Millicent, Tabitha; great-grandfather of Willa and Leo. Mike lived life to its fullest, enjoying each moment spent teaching and playing. An inventor, furniture maker, photographer, builder, teacher, lover of the arts, sailor, fisherman, outdoors man, and fighter for social justice and peace, Mike influenced all he touched with his kindness, humor and wisdom in his too short 94 years. Tally Ho!, Mike. The family requests donations given in his name to the Southern Poverty Law Center and Meharry College.

BENVENISTY--Albert. Born June 27, 1928 to Rebecca and Aaron, passed away on May 15, 2013. Loving husband of his adored 'bride' Irma (nee Cohen) of almost 64 years. Devoted father and father-in-law of Alan and Terri Benvenisty, Michele and David Softness, Ronnie and Jesse Davis, and Stuart and Lori Benvenisty. He was the proud Papoo of Alissa (Zachary Epstein), Brian, Melissa, Katie, Kenneth, Sara, Harrison and Adam. Big Papoo to Aviva and Leo. Worked hard and enjoyed life. He loved greatly and was greatly loved. Service will be Sunday, May 19 at 10:30am. Robert Schoem Menorah Chapel, Paramus, NJ.

AXELROD--Bernard. In loving memory of Bernard Axelrod. It is with much love and sadness, we say goodbye to Bernie Axelrod. Thank you, Bernie, for your humor and loving inspiration. You will be missed, but never forgotten. Cathy, Kenny & Maggie

AXELROD--Bernard M. On May 17, 2013 in his 93rd year of Alzheimer's-related causes. Husband, father and father-in-law, grandfather and great-grandfather, brother and brother-in-law, uncle and great-uncle. Services private. Contributions to the Dr. S. Gandy Alzheimer's Research Fund at the Mt. Sinai Medical Center, 1 Gustave Levy Pl., Box 1049, New York, NY 10027.

AXELROD--Bernard. On May 17th, 2013, died peacefully in his 93rd year. Beloved husband of Myrna. Devoted brother of Carlin and brother-in-law of Brenda, uncle of Cathie, Lawrence, Lisa and Kenneth, grand-uncle to Paul, Carly, Hunter, Ilana and Ian. Bernard and Carlin were partners for over 55 years and had an unprecedented relationship both personal and business. He will remain in our hearts forever.

ASHKIN--Beverly. Our darling mother Beverly Ashkin passed away gently on May 14 2013, a remarkable, wise, and courageous person loved by so many and capable of the most extraordinary love and compassion for everyone. Daughter of Anna Boisen one of the heroines of the historic Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire, who died when mom was only 18 months old, and Samuel, her beloved father who was forced to place her into an orphanage until she was nine years old, our mother would have celebrated her 85th birthday this September. She, and our father Sidney who passed away in 1992, were childhood sweethearts and lifetime soul mates who shared the truest and most profound love. Her gentleness towards everyone and every creature was the truest expression of her beautiful soul. Every lost, abandoned animal seemed to find its way into her embraces. So too, children and adults both, found understanding and a loving ear. Everyone who knew her, and even those who met her briefly would say the same thing: "She is so lovely"; "She is so elegant". Her patience, tolerance, and wisdom; her ability to see things and accept others' perspectives, even when they were so different from her own; and her courage wrapped in softness and beauty: these were only some of her extraordinary gifts, made even more extraordinary because she was so unaware of how profoundly she touched those around her. This is how everyone will remember her, honor her, and continue to learn from her. But it is the two of us, her daughters, Roberta and Michelle, who will make sure that her light continues to shine and that we pass on the lessons that she imparted to us throughout our lives together. Donations in her honor would be appreciated to Defenders of Wildlife or the Humane Society of the United States.

ALEXANDER--Mary, of New York, Palm Beach, Mansfield, New Jersey and Bucharest, Romania died peacefully at home in her 85th year, May 16th 2013, fighting to her last breaths, so bravely and surely, after an illness that took all of her away except her essence that remained to say goodbye to this good life she loved so much and lived so well. Mother of Raluca Allison of New York; grandmother to Raleigh Allison and Percy Allison; most loving wife to Nicholas Alexander, deceased and terribly missed these past seven years. She will be missed by so many whom she helped when help was needed; by so many whose course of life she changed; and above all by her closest family who inherited and were inspired by her energy, her ambition, her spirit of adventure, her love of culture, her unquenchable desire to improve, her vast curiosity, her presence as the force of life she was. Born and educated in Romania, she went on to get a PhD in economics, attain a senior position in the Central Bank where she oversaw major industries; winning the Medal of Honor, the nation's highest recognition for professional service; and yet accomplished all this without political affiliation under a communist system she viscerally opposed, and, despite marriage to a man, the 50-year love of her life, who was a scion of one of the country's leading pre-communist families. Here was a woman who had the courage and vision to flee this oppressive system in her forties, leaving everything behind family, friends, job, prestige, home, belongings, money for freedom and dignity and prosperity in the United States, the adopted country she and her husband so loved and gave so much to, and, most of all, for the opportunity to give their one and only daughter, Raluca, a life worth living. And Mary did all this with no supports except her own drives and family. She did all this with false starts. She did all this having to learn in mid-life a new language and new ways. And she succeeded establishing a successful business in the great American entrepreneurial tradition; building homes and new family roots; sending her daughter to Yale and Columbia and on to a successful family and business life of her own; involving herself politically as she felt she must and attending two Presidential inaugurals as an emblem of her American commitment; following her longstanding interest in poetry, opera, and the life of the mind; and all the while enjoying all the little, daily things of life. The life force she was devastated as she was by the loss of her dearest Nick in 2006 and by the onset of a long Alzheimer's journey never once was lost, so much so, that to her very last breaths she knew her family and her family knew her and she fought with the final grains of her body's strength to say goodbye. She will be remembered and honored. She will inspire those who knew her. Most of all her spirit is a presence in the lives of her family and descendants who are happy at her peace even as they grieve at their loss. A funeral service will take place at St. James' Church at 11:00am., May 20th followed by a private burial service at the Princeton Cemetery. Donations to St. James' Church in lieu of flowers.

ZUROSKI--Gregory. Horace Mann School deeply mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague and cherished friend, Greg Zuroski, Director of Alumni Relations at Horace Mann. A consummate role model and generous mentor to many, he made exemplary contributions to the Horace Mann Community. Always querying, "How can I help?" he was a gracious individual who charmed everyone. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his devoted wife, Patricia Zuroski, Director of Diversity Initiatives at Horace Mann, and his beloved children, Gena (husband Derek and daughter Ruby), Kathryn and Emma. Thomas M. Kelly, Ph.D. Head of School Steven M. Friedman'72 Chair, Board of Trustees

YARINSKY--Dr. Allen, Ph.D.,on May 18 at age 84. He is mourned by his beloved wife of 60 years, Estelle, his children Steven (Pamela), Carolyn Finkelstein (Myron), and Adam (Amy), his ten adored grandchildren, his sister Sondra Bogad, and many friends.

WABER--Bernard, died Thursday, May 16th in New York. He was ninety-one. He leaves children Paulis, Louisa, and Gary, sons-in-law Rod and Dana, and grandchildren Mason, Anna, Rachel and Reuben, all of whom cherish the memory of a deeply loving, funny and wise father and grandfather. He is also survived by his big brother Isadore. His beloved wife Ethel died in 2006. Bernard leaves numerous friends, many in the children's book world. Bernard Waber published over forty books. He is best known for his Lyle, Lyle Crocodile books, and Ira Sleeps Over. He was also a graphic artist at Time, Inc. He loved his work in children's books and loved meeting children throughout the country. He treasured his relationships with his publisher Houghton Mifflin Harcourt and his agent, Elizabeth Harding at Curtis Brown. He cared deeply for everyone and rarely spoke of either his accomplishments or troubles. It's so hard to lose him but we were fortunate. To quote from his book, Courage, "Courage means sometimes having to say goodbye." A memorial service is planned for the near future.

SULLIVAN--Jerome L, MD, PhD, born October 13, 1944, died May 3, 2013. Physician, scientist, professor, and internationally recognized father of the "iron hypothesis", Dr. Sullivan first theorized a link between heart disease and increased stored iron in 1981. His seminal paper, published in The Lancet that same year, is still frequently cited today. He was a strong proponent of blood donations, which he believed could reduce the risk of heart attack in men and post-menopausal women. Dr. Sullivan served on the faculties of several university medical schools, including University of Florida and University of Central Florida, and he lectured widely in the United States and abroad. Jerome is survived by his loving wife, Dr. Laura Geisel Sullivan, of Orlando, Florida, and five children. He was buried in his childhood hometown of Dothan, Alabama. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Heart Association are appreciated.

SIMONDS--Jane M.,died on May 12, 2013, at the age of 96. She was predeceased by her first husband, Craigh Leonard, and by her second husband, Robinson Simonds. She is survived by her daughter, Stephanie Leonard; a son, Edward Leonard, and his wife, Victoria; a son, Craigh Leonard, and his wife, Evie; a step-son, William Simonds, and his wife, Jane; a step-son, Robin Simonds; and by seven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. A service will be held at Saint Andrew's Dune Church, 12 Gin Lane, Southampton, NY, on June 11, 2013, at 11:30am. Memorial contributions may be made to Saint Andrew's Dune Church, P.O. Box 1245, Southampton, NY 11969.

SESSA--Catherine P.,on May 16th, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Francis X. Loving mother of Peter and Jay. Proud and loving grandmother of Courtney, Dana, Peter, Reid, Samantha and great-grandmother of Michael. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 11am, Our Lady of the Isle Church, Shelter Island.

ROGERS--Iris C.,(nee Bedrick), 86, of Rockleigh, NJ (formerly of Tenafly, NJ) on May 18. Beloved wife of the late Saul. Loving mother of Mark Rogers and Nancy Eichenbaum. Doting grandmother of Scott, Danielle and Zachary. A graduate of the Eastman School of Music, she was a talented and gifted musician. We will miss her beauty and elegance. Services will be held at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ on Tuesday, May 21 at 11am.

MILLER--Bennett I.,passed away in Dallas, Texas, on May 18, 2013. Survived by his wife Bette, his children Kerry Miller (Leslie), Jennifer Hillman (Tom), Elka Kopp (Alex), his brother Martin Miller (Madge), his sister Betsy Landis (Don), and his grandchildren and greatgrandchildren, nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Dallas Heritage Village, 1515 S. Harwood, Dallas, TX 75215 or the charity of your choice.

MACKOUL--Brian E. May 21, 1949 - May 18, 2013, after a long illness. He is survived by his partner Gregg Warren, his brother and sister-in-law Robert E. and Deborah K. Mackoul, three nephews, Robert G., Edward J., Jared A. Mackoul and two nieces, Erica R. Mackoul and Lacey Colucci, many cousins and friends. Brian was a graduate of Bethany College, WV, and held two Masters degrees from New York University. A lifetime educator of young children, he was the New Jersey teacher of the year in 1995 while in the Montclair, NJ elementary school system. A good kind man who was devoted to his family, friends and students. Wake at McLaughlins Funeral Home, 9623 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, Monday May 20th 2-5pm and 7-9 pm.Funeral Tuesday, May 21st, at 10am: St Mary's Orthodox Church, 8100 Ridge Blvd, Brooklyn. Internment: Greenwood Cemetery.

JACOBS--Linda Lee. Born on March 11, 1949 in Kenosha, WI; Deceased May 15, 2013 in Minneapolis, MN after a valiant battle with liver disease. A brilliant publicist who brought the Children's Theater Company to national prominence when in 2003 they received the Tony Award for outstanding regional theater. As Tiger Lily said: "Peter Pan is the sun, the moon and the stars." Linda was that to those who knew and loved her, especially her mother, Janet Jacobs. May your journey be magical.

LEDOUX--Jeanne-Nicole, 67, of Cornwall-on-Hudson, NY and East Dorset, VT died May 9, 2013. Memorial Service Thursday May 23, 12:30pm at Cornwall Presbyterian Church, 222 Hudson Street, Cornwall-on-Hudson. Memorials may be made to The William Ledoux Memorial Fund, Cornell University Feline Health Center, Hungerford Hill Road, Ithaca, NY 14853; The Storm King School, 314 Mountain Road, Cornwall-on-Hudson, NY 12520-1899; or The MDS Center, Columbia University Medical Center, 177 Fort Washington Ave., New York, NY 10032. DINOWITZ--Jessie. The entire Hebrew Home community mourns the loss of Jessie Dinowitz, beloved mother of our dear friend Jeffrey Dinowitz, Norman and Ken. Jessie was a strong and loving mother and grandmother. May her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Daniel Reingold, President & CEO The Hebrew Home at Riverdale

COWETT--Wilbur, Harvard Hillel mourns the passing of Wilbur Cowett, a steadfast supporter of Jewish life and its flourishing at Harvard University. An inspirational figure to those who knew and worked with him, Wilbur's belief in the future of the Jewish people and in the contributions of future generations of Harvard graduates to that future will continue to inspire and animate our work at Harvard Hillel, even as we miss him. Our Board of Directors, with David Keidan, and our professional staff extend sincere condolences to Wilbur's wife, Peggy; his children, Anne, Frederick, and daughter-in-law Diana Riesman, his grandchildren, and the entire family.

COMINS--Edith K. (nee Krich). Loving wife for fifty-seven years to Frederic M. Comins, who predeceased her in 2005, passed away peacefully at home in Briarcliff Manor, NY, on May 15, 2013. Born March 14, 1927 in South Orange, NJ, and a graduate of Columbia High School there, she enrolled at the University of Wisconsin. With an eye on a career in fashion, she transferred to the Tobe-Coburn Fashion Institute in New York City. Despite being elected class president, she chose a life of marriage and family. She was an elegant, intelligent, and generous woman, who was known and respected for her sense of taste and grace. She and Fred lived for many years in Short Hills, NJ where their sons grew up; at 870 United Nations Plaza in N.Y.C., and retired to Briarcliff Manor, NY. A devoted and adored mother, she leaves behind her three sons, Frederic M. Jr. of Ft. Myers, FL and Mystic, CT; Max of Woodstock, VT, and Andy of Los Angeles, CA; her sister Claire Hooton and cousin, Carol Jedel; her four grandsons, Scot, Jamison, Drew, and Jordan, and her nephew, Hart Hooton and his family.

AXELROD--Bernard. On May 17, 2013 in his 93rd year. We mourn the passing of a warm, good hearted man and express our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Myrna and his entire family. Phyllis and Bill, Chris and Richard, Kelly and Stephen, Sheila, Robin, Andrew & Ellen

AXELROD--Bernard. On May 17th, 2013, died peacefully in his 93rd year. Beloved husband of Myrna. Devoted brother of Carlin and brother-in-law of Brenda, uncle of Cathie, Lawrence, Lisa and Kenneth, grand-uncle to Paul, Carly, Hunter, Ilana and Ian. Bernard and Carlin were partners for over 55 years and had an unprecedented relationship both personal and business. He will remain in our hearts forever.

AXELROD--Bernard M. On May 17, 2013 in his 93rd year of Alzheimer's-related causes. Husband, father and father-in-law, grandfather and great-grandfather, brother and brother-in-law, uncle and great-uncle. Services private. Contributions to the Dr. S. Gandy Alzheimer's Research Fund at the Mt. Sinai Medical Center, 1 Gustave Levy Pl., Box 1049, New York, NY 10027.

RUDGAYZER--Albert. We mourn our esteemed member's passing and send heartfelt sympathy to his family. Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre

RUBENSTEIN--Dr. Betty Rogers, died at her home in Fairfield, Connecticut on Sunday May 19. She was born in Brookline, Massachusetts on December 29, 1920. She received her Bachelor's degree from Smith College in Northampton, Massachusetts on June 9, 1942 and the Ph.D. in Art History from Florida State University in Tallahassee in 1979. She married Dr. Richard L. Rubenstein, a theologian and historian of religion, on August 21, 1966. Throughout her long life, she was a woman of courage, integrity, wit and compassion. She marched with Dr. Martin Luther King, studied poetry with Paul Carroll, taught art history to a generation of students, was a passionate leader of her faith, a loving mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, and a devoted wife. That spirit lives on in our hearts. She was predeceased by her sister Jean Simpson and her step-son Aaron Rubenstein of Nassau, Bahamas. She is survived by her husband, her children by her first marriage, Jean Reed of New Brunswick, Canada, John H. Alschuler and his wife Dr. Diana Diamond Alschuler of New York City, and Liora Alschuler of East Thetford, Vermont, and two surviving step-children, Jeremy N. Rubenstein and his wife Linda Tang Rubenstein of Bethesda, Maryland and Hannah Rubenstein Feibel and her husband Dr. Frederick Feibel of West Simsbury, Connecticut. She is also survived by ten grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. A previous marriage to John Alschuler Sr. ended in divorce. Donations may be made in her honor to Smith College, Northampton, Massachusetts and to Congregation Beth El, 3500 Fairfield Woods Avenue, Fairfield, Ct. Services will be held on Tuesday, May 21st at 11am at the Congregation. The family will sit Shiva at 318 Collingwood Avenue, Fairfield, Ct. on Tuesday and Wednesday evening from 6-9pm and at the home of John and Diana Alschuler at 50 Riverside Drive, New York, NY on Thursday evening, also from 6-9pm.

ROSS--Linda, born April 2, 1960 New York, NY, died May 11, 2013, Buffalo, NY. Beloved daughter of Rosalyn and Jesse, devoted sister of Barbara and Judy. Services Wednesday, May 22, 1pm, New Montefiore Cemetery, West Babylon, NY. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to Riverkeeper.

RESNICOW--Melly (nee Engelberg), 87, sister of Edward Engelberg, wife of the late Herbert Resnicow, mother of Norman, Eva, David, and Ruth and grandmother of Daniel, Joel, Natalie, Alexander, Nicholas, and Kyra, passed away on May 17 after leading a vigorous life. Born in Chemnitz, Germany, to Jakob and Paula Engelberg (nee Weber), Melly lived in Munich until age 13, when the family was forced to flee after her father was taken to Dachau. Her mother somehow negotiated his release and the family bribed its way into Switzerland with a painting. Settling in Brooklyn, Melly attended Erasmus High School. Although Melly did not speak English when she arrived, by her second year she won the top prize in the school's essay writing contest. At 15, upon her father's untimely death, she became the family breadwinner and worked as a diamond cutter for Harry Winston (where she sought to unionize the workers) while attending night school. She met Herbert Resnicow when he was on leave from Fort Dix and their romance continued via mail while he was stationed in Burma and India during the Second World War. They married in 1946, and as they built a family, lived first in a basement apartment in Brooklyn, then in a two-family house in Glen Oaks, and finally, a home in East Williston. For the next two decades, Melly focused on her family--placing an emphasis on education, the arts, and civic engagement-- also had a wide circle of friends. As her children got older Melly started taking college courses, earning a library and then a teaching degree. She taught English at Northport High School for 20 years. After retiring, Melly became a docent at the Museum of Jewish Heritage in New York. Melly was smart, tough, and determined. She loved cooking, gardening, music, books, art, and above all her family. Donations in her honor can be made to HIAS: The Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society and The Museum of Jewish Heritage.

MACKOUL--Brian E. May 21, 1949 - May 18, 2013, after a long illness. He is survived by his partner Gregg Warren, his brother and sister-in-law Robert E. and Deborah K. Mackoul, three nephews, Robert G., Edward J., Jared A. Mackoul and two nieces, Erica R. Mackoul and Lacey Colucci, many cousins and friends. Brian was a graduate of Bethany College, WV, and held two Masters degrees from New York University. A lifetime educator of young children, he was the New Jersey teacher of the year in 1995 while in the Montclair, NJ elementary school system. A good kind man who was devoted to his family, friends and students. Wake at McLaughlins Funeral Home, 9623 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, Monday May 20th 2-5pm and 7-9 pm.Funeral Tuesday, May 21st, at 10am: St Mary's Orthodox Church, 8100 Ridge Blvd, Brooklyn. Internment: Greenwood Cemetery.

FINE--William M.,86, passed away Friday, May 17, in Beverly Hills. He is survived by his partner, Kay Pick, and four sons: B. William, Douglas, Tim, and Adam. COMINS--Edith K. (nee Krich). Loving wife for fifty-seven years to Frederic M. Comins, who predeceased her in 2005, passed away peacefully at home in Briarcliff Manor, NY, on May 15, 2013. Born March 14, 1927 in South Orange, NJ, and a graduate of Columbia High School there, she enrolled at the University of Wisconsin. With an eye on a career in fashion, she transferred to the Tobe-Coburn Fashion Institute in New York City. Despite being elected class president, she chose a life of marriage and family. She was an elegant, intelligent, and generous woman, who was known and respected for her sense of taste and grace. She and Fred lived for many years in Short Hills, NJ where their sons grew up; at 870 United Nations Plaza in N.Y.C., and retired to Briarcliff Manor, NY. A devoted and adored mother, she leaves behind her three sons, Frederic M. Jr. of Ft. Myers, FL and Mystic, CT; Max of Woodstock, VT, and Andy of Los Angeles, CA; her sister Claire Hooton and cousin, Carol Jedel; her four grandsons, Scot, Jamison, Drew, and Jordan, and her nephew, Hart Hooton and his family.

CLARK--Phyllis (nee Johnston), age 78, a peaceful death on May 15, 2013 of Manhasset, NY. Holder of B.A. and M.B.A. degrees from St. John's University, and beloved wife of its late Prof. Richard C. Loving sister of Ann, John, Edwina and the late Peter Johnston as well as aunt of many nieces and nephews. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel Friday 3-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Saturday 10am at St. Mary's RC Church. Interment to follow at Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

Carter, beloved husband of Joan, devoted father of Pam Attner (Paul); Alan Carter and Gayle Jo Carter (David Meyers), adored grandfather of Eric and Lindsay Attner; Jessica Carter and Ben and Hildy Meyers. CHOLOWSKY--Kelly Ann, on May 20, 2013. Founder and proprietor of Emily Sky Boutiques. Beloved wife of Michael, devoted mother of Peter, Michael, Emily and Isabella. Adored daughter of John and Patricia McLaughlin. Dear sister of Dawn, Trish and the late Timothy. She will also be dearly missed by her extended family and many friends. Friends may call Wednesday and Thursday, May 22 and 23, 2013 from 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. at 81 St. Funeral mass Friday, 10 am at Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 152 West 71 St. Burial St. Charles Cemetery.
BIENER--Phyllis. Our entire family is saddened by the loss of a beloved friend. She enjoyed a long life, living every single day to its fullest. Jane and Alan

BIENER--Phyllis (nee Axelrod), 91, of Roslyn, NY, Great Barrington, MA, Palm Beach, FL. Devoted wife of Martin for 69 years. Wonderful mother of Carol and Stanley Weinstock, Margie, Robert, Sara and RuRu Biener. Treasured Nanny of Jason and Lora Weinstock, Caryn and Matt Leingang, Andrew and Jara Weinstock, Patrea and Marica Honychurch. Proud great-grandmother of Jakob, Sasha, Amelia, Miles and Micah. Sister of Marvin and Buzzy Axelrod, Arlene and the late Jerry Axelrod. Sister in law of Elaine Wolf, Esther and Seymour Birnbaum. Her elegance, courage and strength was matched only by her boundless love and generosity. She was an extraordinary human being and will be in our hearts forever. Funeral services will be held at Temple Sinai of Roslyn on Thursday at 1pm. Donations in lieu of flowers to Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, NY 11577.

ANSPACH--Andrew Allan. On a Sunday in New York, May 5, 2013, Andrew Allan Anspach passed away peacefully in his sleep. He was 91 years old. He enjoyed and contributed to an amazing, memorable, distinguished life. He is lovingly remembered by his wife, Barbara Bodne Anspach, daughters Elizabeth Carlson and Roxanna Devlin, son-in-law Eric Carlson, and grandchildren Annie Carlson, Margaret Carlson, Bennett Devlin, Emma Devlin and William Devlin.

ALPERS--Paul Joel. Born on October 16, 1932, died on May 19, 2013. Son of the late Bernard J. Alpers and Lillian Sher Alpers. He is survived by his wife, Carol T. Christ; his sons, Benjamin L. and Nicholas C. Alpers; his step-children Jonathan M. and Elizabeth C. Sklute; four grand-children; two brothers, David H. and Edward A. Alpers; and his former wife, Svetlana L. Alpers. He received his B.A. and Ph.D. in English from Harvard University. He retired in 2002 from the English Department of the University of California at Berkeley after a thirty-eight year career on the faculty.

MARSH--Leonard. The Membership and Board of Governors of the Boca Rio Golf Club, Boca Raton, Florida announce with deep regret and sorrow the passing of our dear friend and esteemed member Leonard March, May 21st, 2013 and extend our sincerest condolences to his wife Marian and their family. David Fuente President Boca Rio Golf Club, Inc.

IVLER--Rene, 88, died peacefully at home in Hewlett, NY on May 24. Raised in Lawrence, NY. Formerly of Elkins Park, PA and Miami Beach, FL. Devoted wife of the late Myron W. Ivler. Beloved mother of Sanford (Joan), Jay (Robin), Marc (Cheryl) and Todd (Barbara). Loving nana to Jeffrey (Lisa), Michael (Loren), Neil (Alison), Jordan (Jillian), Matthew (Shari), Bradley (fiance Jaymie), Gail, Max and Marshall. Doting great-grandma to Brooke, Joshua, Gabrielle , Zoe, Camryn, Ethan, Zachary, Harper and Jake. Dear sister of Barbara Sigman and the late Myron Singer.

JOHNSTON--Donald H. "Pete." Respected, longtime professor at Columbia's Schools of Journalism and International and Public Affairs, died May 18 in New Paltz, NY, at age 89. He will be deeply missed by his family and a generation of former students around the world.

HAYES--Peter J. 84. Born in 1928, Peter was a member of St. Brendan's Parish in the Bronx until 1965 when he relocated to Manhattan where he died on May 21, 2013. Mr. Hayes was a former Marine Corps Officer and served with the First Marine Division in Korea. He joined the Radio Corporation of America in December, 1952 and retired from RCA as Staff Vice President in 1983. Visiting, Tuesday 3-7pm at McKeon Funeral Home, Bronx, NY. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated Wednesday at 10:45am at St. Brendan's Church, Bronx, NY. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.
GRENEMAN--Arlene. Beautiful friend, we will miss your wisdom and grace. Lovingly, The Search Group at Boca West

FISCHER--Harold, 93. Farewell big brother (brother-in-law) and lifelong mentor. We'll miss your ebullience, your wit, your Phi Bete smarts. We salute the US Army Captain who helped liberate Bataan. We love you. Rest in peace. Services private. Bob and Arlene Fischer

CRANIN--Allen S.,DDS., 90. Died peacefully May 24. Superbly ethical NYU graduate, beloved husband of Enid Nemerov, loving father of Randy (Linda), Scott (Patrick), Debbie Craft (Randy), grandpa of Danielle, Rachel and Matthew. He will be sorely missed by all of us.

CHARNET--Jack. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home at Riverdale deeply mourn the loss of Jack Charnet, beloved father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Jack was a kind-hearted, sweet and caring man who will be missed by his daughters, Judith and Barbara, son-in-law Joe Wygoda, our esteemed trustee, and all who had the privilege of knowing him. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Charnet and Wygoda families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Jeffrey S. Maurer, Chairman Daniel Reingold, President & CEO

BEAUCHEMIN--Helene A.,93, of Purdy's, NY formerly of Manhattan died Wednesday, May 22, 2013. Helene was born July 30, 1919 in The Bronx, NY. She is the daughter of Charles and Anne (Murray) Beauchemin. A graduate of Ursuline Academy and the College of New Rochelle, Helene was a Partner at Sanger-Funnell, an advertising agency in Manhattan. Helene is survived by her nieces: Genevieve (John) Malone of North Salem, NY, Barbara (Ernest) Damiani of Monroe, NY, Marie (Carmine) Ventarola of Monroe, NY, Anne (Scott) Murphy of New City, NY and her nephew: John (Thelma) Beauchemin of New City, NY. She is also survived by her cousin, Edward McLaren, Garden City, NY. The family will receive friends on Tuesday, May 28 from 7:00pm to 9:00pm at Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10:00am on Wednesday, May 29 at St. Joseph's RC Church, 10 Croton Falls Road, Croton Falls, NY. Burial will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

BERRY--Rachel, 87, of Peekskill, NY died in her sleep Sunday, May 26. She was born in London, England to Abraham and Yissua Yadgaroff. Rachel attended Parsons School of Design in Manhattan. After raising a family she returned to real estate to win many awards and sustain her love of travel. She retired at the age of 86. She is survived by her adopted son Frank Pagan, and her children: Michael, Claire, Alyson, Vivian and favorite grand-dog, Luna. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to: Desmond Fish Library (472 Route 403 Garrison, NY 10524). A memorial service will be held Thursday, May 30, 5pm at Clark Funeral Home, Yorktown Heights, NY.

EDELMAN--Hilda W. We felt your divine presence in Athens. Diana and Alex

WEILER--George Henry, III. George Henry Weiler of Bronxville, NY, born in Philadelphia to Jeanne and George H. Weiler, Jr., died suddenly and without warning from a massive heart attack playing tennis at The Bronxville Field Club. Mr. Weiler grew up in Drexel Hill, Pennsylvania and Ridgewood, New Jersey, where he graduated from Ridgewood High School. He earned a B.A. from Yale University, a J.D. from the University of Pennsylvania, and completed a Rockefeller fellowship at Harvard University. Mr. Weiler started his career as a civil rights lawyer in Washington. He won every case. He then started his financial services career in 1984 at Dillon Read in Corporate & Executive Services where he headed the group. He continued in this role at SBC Warburg Dillon Read and later UBS Warburg through a series of mergers. In 2000, George joined UBS Wealth Management US as Senior Vice President. He successfully led The Weiler Financial Services Group there. George Weiler was a man for all seasons with diverse interests and an engaging intellect. He was most happy when he was connecting with people and every new connection resulted in a friendship. He lived the best part of a Christian life reaching out to others, always seeking better understanding of life and never missing a moment singing with the Yale Glee Club around the world tour, fighting to save a Church with the Committee to Save St. Barts, running on the beach in Nauset, Cape Cod, campaigning for Romney and every other candidate who could make the world a better place. He adored his family and they adored him. In addition to his beloved wife Mary Ann, George is survived by his four children Katherine Weiler Crane, Blair Weiler, Winston Weiler, Christina Weiler and one grandchild Philippe Crane III, his siblings, Wendy Weiler Chappell of Franklin Lakes, NJ, Christopher Weiler of Wyckoff, NJ, Patricia Weiler Thiess of Pittsburgh, PA and Pamela Weiler Colling of Midland Park, NJ. Services will be held On Monday June 3, at 11am at the Reformed Church of Bronxville, 180 Pondfield Rd, Bronxville NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Reformed Church of Bronxville or the American Heart Association.

Their tradition of giving continues in their daughters, Marla (Steve Weishoff) Schaefer, Bonnie (Jamie) Schaefer, and Roberta (Bruce) Waller, who perpetuate the compassion and selflessness of these two extraordinary individuals. We extend our condolences to the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President; Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO
MORRIS--Joel F. To my big brother, Joel, from your baby sister, we will always have Camp Owaissa and Camp Monterey. Our wonderful memories. Love, Linda Joy Morris

MORRIS--Joel F.,is survived by wife Leslie, sons Benjamin (Deirdre) and Jonathan (Sophie), six grandchildren, sister Linda Joy Morris, and the memory of their dead brother and uncle, Allen E. Morris. We mourn the passing of our beloved husband, father, grandfather and brother, Joel Morris. His keen intelligence and humor along with his incredible philanthropic endeavors will remain with us all. After decades in the funeral industry he touched many lives and brought solace and comfort to thousands of families in New York City and beyond. In his retirement he continued being an active community member in the Berkshires, while loving all that country living afforded him. It is so true that the world is a better place because of him. Funeral services Friday, May 31 at 12:15 at Beth-El Synagogue of New Rochelle, 1324 North Ave. at Northfield Road. Donations in his memory may be made to the Otis Library and Museum, Inc., PO Box 126, Otis MA 01253.

LINDEN--Bella L. Words are insufficient to express the love and respect I feel for my long time friend and advisor Bella L. Linden. She will live in my heart forever. My sympathies go our to her family. Lee Lamont

LEWIS--James. January 1948-May 2013. Beloved son of Bernice and Arthur, adored brother of Marcia Lewis Smith, treasured Uncle to Amanda and Alex. Jimmy flies with Pale Male. Services to celebrate his life Sunday June 2, 3:30 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave.

ILLICK--Christopher David, (Kit), was born in Bethlehem, PA on March 21, 1939, and died peacefully on May 28, 2013 in Vero Beach, Florida, having been surrounded by his adoring family. Kit was the loving husband to Selden Dunbar Illick, devoted father to Hilary Selden Illick and Christopher Dunbar Illick, involved grandfather of eight grandchildren, Zoe, Esme, Nico, and Tea Valette, Thor, Cyrus, Kit, and Dwyer Illick, and proud father-in-law to Pierre Valette and Alison Ambach Illick. Born to Margaret Flexer Illick and Joseph Edward Illick, Kit was the third of four boys. He is survived by his three lively and kind brothers, Joseph, Flexer, and Tom Illick, and his dear first cousin, Marty Walzer. Raised in Coopersberg, Pennsylvania, Kit went to college at Trinity ('61) where he was a member of St. Anthony Hall. He earned his law degree the University of Virginia ('64), then worked as an investment banker in New York City while raising his family in Princeton, New Jersey. His inspired second home, the Lower Farm in North Dorchester, New Hampshire was a sanctuary to family and friends. Kit retired in Vero Beach, Florida with his wife, Selden, in their beloved Riomar community. Kit was a graceful, gifted athlete, passionate about tennis and squash, and in his recent years, golf. His love of music and his expressive dancing style were contagious. Kit treasured his friends, and displayed a remarkable ability to champion others. He was truly generous with his insight, kindness, and attentive enthusiasm for the lives of those he loved. Kit will be remembered for his warm engaging smile, his captivating blue eyes, his infectious laughter, and superb sense of humor. He will be deeply missed. Kit had Alzheimer's Disease, and chose to donate his brain to AD research. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Dr. Bradford Dickerson Dementia Research Fund, Mass General Development Office, 165 Cambridge Street, Suite 600, Boston, MA 02114; or to: Alzheimer Drug Discovery Foundation, 57 West 57th Street, New York, NY 10019. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am on Saturday, June 8th, 2013, at The Central Moravian Church in Bethlehem, PA. Services are under the direction of Cox Gifford Seawinds Funeral Home and Crematory in Vero Beach, FL. Online condolences may be sent at www.coxgiffordseawinds.com.

HELSEL--Randi. The Jeffrey Modell Foundation and its Co-Founders, Vicki and Fred Modell, mourn the passing of our precious sister Randi. She shared a committed love for her husband Harvey, for nearly 60 years. She took great pride in her children and grandchildren. Randi was high spirited, energetic, and taught all of us how to savor every moment of every day. She brightened our lives with unbridled joy, enthusiasm and a sense of humor encouraging each of us to reach up and do the best we could. Randi left an indelible imprint on this world gracing us with dignity and class, embracing us with compassion and understanding. Our lives will forever be enriched because of you, Randi. How we will miss you. Rest in Peace. With all our love, Vicki and Fred
