GALLANTZ--George G.,died of pneumonia April 24, the day after his 100th birthday. Born at home in a cold-water tenement, educated in East Harlem and Bronx public schools, George entered CCNY at age 15, the first in his family to attend college. He received his B.S. in 1932, then attended Brooklyn Law School, graduating cum laude in 1935. He soon distinguished himself as what his later colleagues at Proskauer Rose would call "a lawyer's lawyer". His most important work was as general counsel of the NBA, a position he held under its first three commissioners, and as a leading litigator at Proskauer, where he was a founding father of the field of sports law. He also served on the Brooklyn Law School Board of Trustees and as chair of the executive committee of the NYC Bar Association. But the bare facts, cases won, positions held, miss so much: beloved by younger, now famous, colleagues as a teacher, adviser, and mentor, he played the same roles with the same intensity to the immigrant children of his household staff. Justly remembered for his wit, intelligence, and total integrity, his most fitting epitaph might nonetheless simply be: "You helped so many people". His wife of 71 years, Laly, died in 2011, and he is survived by his son Michael, daughter and son-in-law Judy and Tony, grandchildren Abby and Ben, and great-grandchildren Micah and Emmet. His memorial will take place, Sunday, June 2, 1:00pm, at the NYC Bar Association, 42 W. 44th St. Send donations in his memory to the United Negro College Fund or the Center for Jewish History.

FOREMAN--Spencer, M.D. Continuum Health Partners acknowledges with sadness the passing of our esteemed colleague and a legendary healthcare leader, Dr. Spencer "Spike" Foreman. His more than two decades of leadership at Montefiore Medical Center exemplified innovative social leadership for an underserved, urban population and an unwavering commitment to high-quality patient care. To his entire family and his many friends and colleagues, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Steven Hochberg Chairman, Board of Trustees Stanley Brezenoff President and Chief Executive Officer Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman Emeritus, Board of Trustees Morton P. Hyman Chairman Emeritus, Board of Trustees Robert G. Newman, MD President Emeritus

FOREMAN--Dr. Spencer. The Officers, Board members, and global staff of The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn with sadness the passing of our Emeritus Board Member and devoted friend, Dr. Spencer (Spike) Foreman, whose passionate dedication to the needs of the most vulnerable among us defined both his medical career as well as the leadership roles he played in the Jewish community. A hospital and health systems CEO for over 35 years, Dr. Foreman retired as President of Montefiore Medical Center in 2007 after more than two decades of leadership. As a JDC Board member and Medical Consultant, he traveled numerous times to the former Soviet Union (FSU), advocating measures that have sustained and improved the quality of life for the elderly, poor Jews we help serve. Alerting us to the equally grave needs of a generation of impoverished, at risk Jewish children, he helped launch and subsequently co-chaired our FSU Children's Initiative, which has programs in place today in over 1,100 locations, assuring that these children "now have a chance in life." We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Sandra (Sandi), to his children Cori and Barry LeVine, Todd and Tracy Foreman, Cheryl and Kevin Boyarsky, and Andrea and Steve Kline, and to his ten grandchildren. May his memory be for a blessing to all those whose lives he touched. Penny Blumenstein President Dr. Irving A. Smokler Chairman of the Board Alan H. Gill Chief Executive Officer

FOREMAN--Spencer. The Officers and Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of dear friend and fellow member, Dr. Spencer Foreman. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife, Sondra and his entire family. Benjamin Kirschenbaum, President

BRAGIN--Ernest, was the last of a rare breed. An infinitely kind gentleman of elegance and wit, he died as gracefully as he had lived, at home May 11th anticipating another summer of gardening on the Cape. A brilliant artist, a dearly loved husband, he leaves behind a sad ache in many hearts at the Art Students League, where he sought solace after retiring as creative director of his agency. Taught and inspired by Marshall Glasier, who had been monitor to Georg Grosz, Ernest, when he himself became monitor, continued the great tradition of life size drawing. He is deeply missed.

SOLLAR--Siema. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Siema Sollar. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved husband, Arnold, and their family. Stuart Albrecht, President Robert D. Lang, Secretary

SOLLAR--Siema, left us peacefully on the morning of Thursday, May 30th, with her husband by her side. She was most certainly a woman of valor, and an adoring wife, mother, grandmother, and sister-in-law. Siema was a woman of great intelligence and insight, with a strong will and indomitable spirit. She used her considerable gifts throughout her adult life to champion the cause of care for the developmentally disabled and to help individuals with developmental disabilities lead lives of dignity and meaning. In this regard, Siema always had a special place in her heart for The Maplebrook School in Amenia, NY, and New England Village in Pembroke, MA, where her beloved son David currently resides. Siema's passion and creativity were the moving force behind the creation of New England Village's Sollar Wellness Center, an innovative facility designed to enrich the lives of those with developmental challenges. She was also deeply involved in numerous other charitable causes, and she touched the lives of many people over the course of her lifetime. Siema is survived by her husband Arnold Sollar, daughter Marilyn Sollar McCormack, son David Sollar, son-in-law John McCormack, granddaughter Phoebe McCormack, and sister and brother-in-law Elaine and Edwin Eisen. Funeral services will be held at 12:45pm on Monday, June 3rd at Riverside Memorial Chapel, located on Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street in Manhattan. Donations in Siema's memory may be made to New England Village, 664 School Street, Pembroke, MA 02359.

Roy Apple, Peter Brown Past Presidents and The Board of ICA USA

HELSEL--Randi. The Jeffrey Modell Foundation and its Co-Founders, Vicki and Fred Modell, mourn the passing of our precious sister Randi. She shared a committed love for her husband Harvey, for nearly 60 years. She took great pride in her children and grandchildren. Randi was high spirited, energetic, and taught all of us how to savor every moment of every day. She brightened our lives with unbridled joy, enthusiasm and a sense of humor encouraging each of us to reach up and do the best we could. Randi left an indelible imprint on this world gracing us with dignity and class, embracing us with compassion and understanding. Our lives will forever be enriched because of you, Randi. How we will miss you. Rest in Peace. With all our love, Vicki and Fred

MARKIN--David R.,82 years old, of Palm Beach, FL passed away on Thursday, May 30, 2013. He is survived by his wife Tracy; children John, Christopher, Maggie, Justin, Indy and Minnie; grandchildren David Manning, Sloan, Veronica, Sabrina, and Marigold; daughters-in-law Joy and Rachel Markin, and son-in-law Matt Shafer; a sister Shirley Buchman and brothers-in-law Sylvan Buchman and Sloan Kamenstein; and numerous other family members. David was a graduate of Cheshire Academy and Bradley University and remained actively involved on the Boards of both institutions. He was proud to have served his country as a Lieutenant in the United States Air Force. David was an astute businessman, a caring philanthropist, and generously gave both his time and valuable advice to those organizations in which he was involved. He was Chairman of the Board of Checker Motors Corporation, past President of Great Dane Trailers, and served on numerous corporate boards over his business career. David was past President of the U.S. Tennis Association 1989-1990. David employed his remarkable talent and keen vision in chairing the U.S. Open site committee in the mid 1990's, which planned and executed the revitalization of the National Tennis Center, including the construction of Arthur Ashe Stadium, the centerpiece of the U.S. Open and one of the finest sports facilities in the world. David was currently serving as a member of the USTA Major Construction Oversight Committee. An avid player and supporter of the sport, David was devoted to giving back to the game he loved so much. Prior to becoming USTA President, David was President of USTA Midwest, and is enshrined in both the USTA Midwest and USTA Eastern Halls of Fame. He also served as Chairman of the Davis Cup Committee, the Junior Tennis Council, and was, for many years, the official referee of the National 16-18 Boys Championships in Kalamazoo, MI. He was awarded the Samuel Hardy Award for long and outstanding service to the sport in 1991, and in 2010, was presented a USTA Volunteer Service Award for 40 years of devotion to tennis. There is a plaque on the outside wall of Arthur Ashe Stadium bearing David's likeness with an inscription that reads, "His inspiration and hard work made Arthur Ashe Stadium a reality." David was an avid art collector and served as a Trustee of the Museum for African Art soon to be opened in New York City. At the time of David's death, he served as Chairman of the Board of the MorseLife Foundation in West Palm Beach, FL. David was a true and loyal friend, and will be sorely missed not only by his devoted family but also by all who had the privilege and pleasure of knowing him. A Memorial Service will be held at 11am on Monday, June 3, 2013 at the MorseLife Foundation Traditions of the Palm Beaches Chapel, 4920 Loring Dr. West Palm Beach, FL 33417; followed by a reception. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The MorseLife Foundation 4847 Fred Gladstone Drive West Palm Beach, FL 33417. Services by Quattlebaum Funeral Home, 561-832-5171.

KANTRO--Ira (Sonny). Our family has lost our Patriarch. Sonny passed away after a short illness, on May 30, 2013 one month before his 85th birthday, surrounded by his loving family. Beloved husband of Beatrice (Bunny), father to Scott, Mark and Meryl. Beloved grandfather of Matthew, Lauren, Jason, Ben and Harris. Most cherished brother of Sybil Haberman. Born to Murray and Rae on July 4th, 1928 in Brooklyn, NY. Sonny served in the Marines during the Korean War. His loving warmth, generosity and huge heart for his family will be sorely missed as we continue life's journey with him always in our thoughts. The Kantro Family

SCHAEFER--Rowland, Sylvia. The Anti-Defamation League deeply mourns the passing of our beloved friends and benefactors Rowland and Sylvia Schaefer. Together, Rowland and Sylvia were generously committed to ADL's mission to combat anti-Semitism and bigotry, and their children continue to carry on that abiding legacy. Rowland was ADL's honorary national vice chair, honorary member of the National Executive Committee, and longtime member of the Florida Executive Committee. He was deeply devoted to our mission to eradicate bigotry and build bridges of understanding. Rowland and Sylvia's devotion to each other, to their family, and to countless charities will be long remembered. We extend our deepest condolences to their daughters, Marla, Bonnie, and Roberta, and to the entire family. Barry Curtiss-Lusher National Chair Abraham H. Foxman National Director

WEILER--George Henry, III. George Henry Weiler of Bronxville, NY, born in Philadelphia to Jeanne and George H. Weiler, Jr., died suddenly and without warning from a massive heart attack playing tennis at The Bronxville Field Club. Mr. Weiler grew up in Drexel Hill, Pennsylvania and Ridgewood, New Jersey, where he graduated from Ridgewood High School. He earned a B.A. from Yale University, a J.D. from the University of Pennsylvania, and completed a Rockefeller fellowship at Harvard University. Mr. Weiler started his career as a civil rights lawyer in Washington. He won every case. He then started his financial services career in 1984 at Dillon Read in Corporate & Executive Services where he headed the group. He continued in this role at SBC Warburg Dillon Read and later UBS Warburg through a series of mergers. In 2000, George joined UBS Wealth Management US as Senior Vice President. He successfully led The Weiler Financial Services Group there. George Weiler was a man for all seasons with diverse interests and an engaging intellect. He was most happy when he was connecting with people and every new connection resulted in a friendship. He lived the best part of a Christian life reaching out to others, always seeking better understanding of life and never missing a moment singing with the Yale Glee Club around the world tour, fighting to save a Church with the Committee to Save St. Barts, running on the beach in Nauset, Cape Cod, campaigning for Romney and every other candidate who could make the world a better place. He adored his family and they adored him. In addition to his beloved wife Mary Ann, George is survived by his four children Katherine Weiler Crane, Blair Weiler, Winston Weiler, Christina Weiler and one grandchild Philippe Crane III, his siblings, Wendy Weiler Chappell of Franklin Lakes, NJ, Christopher Weiler of Wyckoff, NJ, Patricia Weiler Thiess of Pittsburgh, PA and Pamela Weiler Colling of Midland Park, NJ. Services will be held On Monday June 3, at 11am at the Reformed Church of Bronxville, 180 Pondfield Rd, Bronxville NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Reformed Church of Bronxville or the American Heart Association.

SOLLAR--Siema, left us peacefully on the morning of Thursday, May 30th, with her husband by her side. She was most certainly a woman of valor, and an adoring wife, mother, grandmother, and sister-in-law. Siema was a woman of great intelligence and insight, with a strong will and indomitable spirit. She used her considerable gifts throughout her adult life to champion the cause of care for the developmentally disabled and to help individuals with developmental disabilities lead lives of dignity and meaning. In this regard, Siema always had a special place in her heart for The Maplebrook School in Amenia, NY, and New England Village in Pembroke, MA, where her beloved son David currently resides. Siema's passion and creativity were the moving force behind the creation of New England Village's Sollar Wellness Center, an innovative facility designed to enrich the lives of those with developmental challenges. She was also deeply involved in numerous other charitable causes, and she touched the lives of many people over the course of her lifetime. Siema is survived by her husband Arnold Sollar, daughter Marilyn Sollar McCormack, son David Sollar, son-in-law John McCormack, granddaughter Phoebe McCormack, and sister and brother-in-law Elaine and Edwin Eisen. Funeral services will be held at 12:45pm on Monday, June 3rd at Riverside Memorial Chapel, located on Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street in Manhattan. Donations in Siema's memory may be made to New England Village, 664 School Street, Pembroke, MA 02359.

SOLOMON--Irwin Ellis. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of our beloved Irwin Solomon on June 1, 2013. Born on July 15, 1927 to Benjamin and Rose. Devoted husband to Ruth. Loving father of Joel, Jonathan, Steven, Emily and Karen. Doting grandfather of Erica, Isabelle, Sarah and Jake. He struggled courageously against many chronic illnesses for over five years. His family was the center of his life. He was our rock and our anchor. Things won't be the same without him.

WACHSLER--Robert, 79, passed away May 25th in Portland, OR, of complications due to Parkinson's, surrounded by his family and beloved dog. Formerly a long-time resident of Westport, CT and Chilmark, MA, Bob was born in the Bronx in 1934, educated at City College of New York and earned a PhD in Aviation Psychology from Ohio State University. He had a distinguished career at General Motors, BBD&O and was a well-respected marketing consultant to many CEO's. Bob served on numerous boards, among them, Goodspeed Opera House, Westport Public Library, Jewish Home for The Elderly and Medici Archive Project. He was a lifetime learner and mentor to all. He served as an adjunct professor at the NYU Stern School of Business and Columbia Business School. An enthusiastic sailor, skier and tennis player, he loved his family and his home on Martha's Vineyard. He is survived by his wife of 53 years Jane, his three daughters, Anne (Paul) Niedergang of Portland, OR; Elizabeth Wachsler of Black Rock, CT; Susan Wachsler of New York, NY and grandchildren, Max and Zadie Niedergang. A private memorial service is planned.

MACE--Adelaide "Bunny" (Rowley). Passed away peacefully on May 22, 2013 at North Hill, in Needham MA. She was 100 years old and formerly lived in Dover, MA. The youngest child born into an academically distinguished family, Bunny was born January 7, 1913 in Minneapolis, MN, to Edith K. and Frank B. Rowley. She attended University High School in Minneapolis and graduated from the University of Minnesota in 1934 with a Fine Arts degree specializing in sculpture. Bunny followed her father in aviation and as a UM freshman became one of the youngest pilots of her time, earning her pilots license in 1930 flying an open cockpit American Eagle bi-plane. Although socially quite shy, during football season she loved to fly over the UM campus dropping tickets to the games from her open cockpit. She flew extensively over the Midwest, relying on road maps and water towers for navigation. She graced the cover of "The Aerologist Magazine" in 1930. In 1936, the pretty Pi Beta Phi member earned an MA from the Minneapolis School of Design, specializing in sculpture. Bunny married Myles L. Mace in 1937 and they moved to Cambridge, MA where he attended the Harvard Business School until posted in England for military service in 1942. They had two sons, Myles L. Jr., (Nick) and Terrence R. and lived in Concord, then Weston MA. In 1955 the family moved to Beverly Hills, CA while Myles helped found Litton Industries. When Myles returned to teaching at Harvard Business School in 1958, the Mace's moved to Dover, MA where they lived for 45 years. Bunny moved to North Hill in 2003 several years after Myles died. Intellectually curious, Bunny loved to travel. She arranged a series of family trips to Europe, and later an around the world adventure. Subsequently, she and Myles traveled extensively throughout the world. Her last trip, at age 89, taken with Nick and daughter-in-law Suzy, fulfilled her longtime wish to visit China. Recognized among Massachusetts horticultural societies for her extensive gardens and plant expertise, Bunny was an active member of the Garden Club of America, Noanett Garden Club and Winter Gardeners, receiving numerous awards for her impeccable gardens, arrangements, projects and displays. She was a long-standing member of The Country Club in Brookline, MA, the University Club in New York City and the Ekwanok Country Club in Manchester, VT. She leaves behind two sons, Myles, Jr. of Southport, ME and Terrence of Fox Island, WA, two granddaughters, Alexandra Abrahams of New York City and Alison Falk of Essex, MA, along with three great-grandchildren, Grace Abrahams, Peyton and Charlie Falk. At the request of the deceased, the family requests that financial contributions be made in her memory to the Dover Conservation Trust, Dover, MA.

RUTTER--Sam. Beloved husband to Evelyn for 56 years. Father to Arthur, Susan and Son-in-law Richard. Grandfather to Rachel and Billy. Graduate of NYU and Brooklyn Law. LINDEN--Bella, 90, died on Monday, May 27, 2013 after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Leonard J. Linden. Survived by her three sons: Paul R. Linden of Columbus, OH and wife, Margaret Berger; Leonard J. Linden of Ridgewood, NJ and his wife, Susan Linden; and Peter J. Linden of New York, NY and his wife, Faith. Loving, devoted grandmother of Noah, Joshua, and Peter Linden. Mrs. Linden, a graduate of McGill University and New York University School of Law, was a preeminent lawyer for the arts in the United States. She co-founded Linden and Deutsch in 1960 and represented distinguished authors, composers, book and music publishers, theater, TV and motion picture producers. An expert on copyright law and intellectual property, she helped negotiate revisions to the Berne and Universal Copyright Conventions, served on a State Department panel reviewing international copyright laws, and advised the Library of Congress in revising the US copyright laws. Mrs. Linden served as a Trustee of Carnegie Hall, the Pablo Casals Foundation, the National Theater for the Deaf, the Abe Fortas Memorial Fund at the Kennedy Center, and the NYU School of Law. Memorial service is Sunday, June 23, at 3:30pm in Lipton Hall of NYU School of Law 108 W. 3rd St. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to: West Bergen Mental Healthcare, 120 Chestnut, Ridgewood, NJ 07450 (201) 444-3550. The Michael J. Fox Foundation, Grand Central Station, PO Box 4777, New York, NY 10163 (212) 509-0995.

MARKIN--David R.,82 years old, of Palm Beach, FL passed away on Thursday, May 30, 2013. He is survived by his wife Tracy; children John, Christopher, Maggie, Justin, Indy and Minnie; grandchildren David Manning, Sloan, Veronica, Sabrina, and Marigold; daughters-in-law Joy and Rachel Markin, and son-in-law Matt Shafer; a sister Shirley Buchman and brothers-in-law Sylvan Buchman and Sloan Kamenstein; and numerous other family members. David was a graduate of Cheshire Academy and Bradley University and remained actively involved on the Boards of both institutions. He was proud to have served his country as a Lieutenant in the United States Air Force. David was an astute businessman, a caring philanthropist, and generously gave both his time and valuable advice to those organizations in which he was involved. He was Chairman of the Board of Checker Motors Corporation, past President of Great Dane Trailers, and served on numerous corporate boards over his business career. David was past President of the U.S. Tennis Association 1989-1990. David employed his remarkable talent and keen vision in chairing the U.S. Open site committee in the mid 1990's, which planned and executed the revitalization of the National Tennis Center, including the construction of Arthur Ashe Stadium, the centerpiece of the U.S. Open and one of the finest sports facilities in the world. David was currently serving as a member of the USTA Major Construction Oversight Committee. An avid player and supporter of the sport, David was devoted to giving back to the game he loved so much. Prior to becoming USTA President, David was President of USTA Midwest, and is enshrined in both the USTA Midwest and USTA Eastern Halls of Fame. He also served as Chairman of the Davis Cup Committee, the Junior Tennis Council, and was, for many years, the official referee of the National 16-18 Boys Championships in Kalamazoo, MI. He was awarded the Samuel Hardy Award for long and outstanding service to the sport in 1991, and in 2010, was presented a USTA Volunteer Service Award for 40 years of devotion to tennis. There is a plaque on the outside wall of Arthur Ashe Stadium bearing David's likeness with an inscription that reads, "His inspiration and hard work made Arthur Ashe Stadium a reality." David was an avid art collector and served as a Trustee of the Museum for African Art soon to be opened in New York City. At the time of David's death, he served as Chairman of the Board of the MorseLife Foundation in West Palm Beach, FL. David was a true and loyal friend, and will be sorely missed not only by his devoted family but also by all who had the privilege and pleasure of knowing him. A Memorial Service will be held at 11am on Monday, June 3, 2013 at the MorseLife Foundation Traditions of the Palm Beaches Chapel, 4920 Loring Dr. West Palm Beach, FL 33417; followed by a reception. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The MorseLife Foundation 4847 Fred Gladstone Drive West Palm Beach, FL 33417. Services by Quattlebaum Funeral Home, 561-832-5171.

ROYLANCE--Dale Ronald, 89, died peacefully Sunday morning, May 19, 2013, at University Medical Center of Princeton at Plainsboro, after a brief illness. Born on December 9, 1924, in Salt Lake City, Dale enlisted in the U.S. Army in 1943 and then attended the University of California, Berkeley, where he studied art history. A talented graphic artist and lover of books, Dale came to Princeton University Library in 1956 as an art cataloguer and the following year, was taken under the wing of Gillett G. Griffin, curator of graphic arts at Firestone Library. Working as assistant curator, Dale developed not only an appreciation for the history of printing but also a talent for passing on this knowledge and enthusiasm to students. In 1960, Dale transferred to Yale University's Sterling Memorial Library, where he developed a program on the arts of the book with classes, exhibitions, and publications. He also continued his own work as an artist, illustrating a number of children's books. When Griffin left Firestone and Joseph Rothrock returned to teaching, Dale was the ideal successor and held the position of curator of graphic arts at Princeton from 1980 until his retirement in 1995. Many generations of students and faculty have benefited from his passion for books, both in the classroom and in the galleries. During his long and distinguished career, Dale prepared more than 100 exhibitions and worked on 44 publications. Following his retirement, Dale continued to commit his talents to the community, serving as a founding member of the West Windsor Arts Council and organizing the book collection in the Manor House Library at the Princeton Academy of the Sacred Heart School for Boys. He was preceded in death by his parents, Kenneth and Una Roylance, brothers Vaun and Kaye and nephew Clifford. He is survived by his niece Cheryl Helms. A memorial gathering will be held at a future date. Services are under their direction of the Mather-Hodge Funeral Home.

HORNOR--Edith S.,86, died May 29 in New York. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, June 11th at 11am at Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and 64th Street, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Chapin School, 100 East End Avenue, New York, NY 10028.

LEVINSON--Irwin, M.D.,died of Alzheimer's disease, May 18 in Los Angeles, where, as a partner in the Southern California Permanente Medical Group at Kaiser Foundation Hospital, he practiced internal medicine and cardiology. He was also Associate Professor on the University of Southern California faculty. He was born in 1927 in the Bronx, NYC. After graduating from Northwestern University Medical School he performed his internship and residency in NYC and Chicago. In 1966 he married the former Nancy Smiler of Minneapolis. He is survived by his wife, sons Matthew and Daniel, daughter-in-law Dana and granddaughter Mira.

FISHER--Annette Brond, of Scarsdale, NY passed away May 15, 2013 at 85. Daughter of Helen and Morris Brond of Poughkeepsie, NY. At 19, Annette moved to NYC to pursue a legal secretarial career and adventures, marrying her true love, Gerald "Jer" Fisher, a toy business executive in 1955. They settled in Scarsdale, NY raising two children, traveling, collecting antiques and remained adoring partners until Jer's passing in 2000. Too vibrant to retire, Annette took on a retailing career in her 60's and remained active in the community until her recent unexpected illness. Annette is survived by her daughter Susan Fisher Haag and husband Larry Haag of NYC, son Steven Fisher of Bonn, Germany, brother, Mort Brond and wife, Lorraine of Southborough, MA and their children Karen and David. Her grand personality and warm heart will be greatly missed.

FISH--Stephen "Tibi". Artist, dancer, baritone, gardener, Brooklyn boy, cat-guy, beachbum, the middle brother. Who will sing happy birthday to Mr. Hood? Your two best friends cannot measure their loss. We raise our voices to you, dear pal. You "contain multitudes".

GINSBERG--Arnold, 85, passed away May 29, 2013. Beloved husband of Gail. Devoted father of Kathy, Adam, and Billy. Grandfather of Isabel. Son of the late Harry and Sophie Ginsberg. Brother of Beatrice Steyer, Rhoda Hecht, and Martin Ginsberg. Arnold was a founder of Albert Einstein College of Medicine. He will be sorely missed. The family will be receiving at The Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th St., New York, on Monday, June 3, 2013, from 5-7pm.

HEYMAN--Abigail, a distinguished photographer and feminist who broke ground in photojournalism by documenting women's lives for the country's leading publications, died on Tuesday at her home at the age of 70. Heyman was born in Danbury, Connecticut, on August 11, 1942 to Annette Heyman and Lazarus Heyman. She is survived by her mother, Annette Heyman, of Palm Beach, FL and son, Lazar Bloch, of Brooklyn, NY. Services to be held at: Riverside Memorial Chapel in New York City, Sunday, June 2nd, 2013, 6pm

HELSEL--Randi. The Jeffrey Modell Foundation and its Co-Founders, Vicki and Fred Modell, mourn the passing of our precious sister Randi. She shared a committed love for her husband Harvey, for nearly 60 years. She took great pride in her children and grandchildren. Randi was high spirited, energetic, and taught all of us how to savor every moment of every day. She brightened our lives with unbridled joy, enthusiasm and a sense of humor encouraging each of us to reach up and do the best we could. Randi left an indelible imprint on this world gracing us with dignity and class, embracing us with compassion and understanding. Our lives will forever be enriched because of you, Randi. How we will miss you. Rest in Peace. With all our love, Vicki and Fred

LETHBRIDGE--George M. Jr.,"Bud". 1925 2013, resident of Essex, CT for 6 years and Lyme, CT for 18 years before, died peacefully on May 20 with his children around him: Sally Hunsdorfer (Peter Hunsdorfer) of Marion, MA, Thomas "Todd" Lethbridge of Sierra Madre, CA and Scott Lethbridge (Catherine Aubrey Lethbridge) of Yonkers, NY. The son of the late Gertrude Dodd and George M. Lethbridge, Bud was raised in Upper Montclair, NJ. He graduated from Phillips Academy, Andover in 1943 and Princeton University in 1947, where his studies were interrupted by service in the Army Air Corps, now the Air Force. During a training mission, Bud survived a crash that took the lives of fellow crew members. Bud spent his professional career at General Electric until he retired in 1980. His wife, Helen Thomas Lethbridge died in 1986. She was the Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Colby-Sawyer College, New London, NH at the time of her passing. Bud followed in her footsteps and served on the Board of Colby-Sawyer from 1991 to 1999. Bud chaired the Finance Committee and under his leadership, the college doubled the student body and built new facilities. Helen and Bud independently received the Susan Colgate Cleveland Award for Distinguished Service to the college and, in 2004, the college dedicated a new recreational and study center to Helen and Bud, naming it Lethbridge Lodge. Bud spent 80 summers returning to Point O' Woods on Fire Island, a community he loved, where many of his life long friendships began. In addition to his children, Bud is survived by his brother, John D. "Jack" Lethbridge, and 4 grandchildren: Thomas "Todd" Hunsdorfer, Ben Hunsdorfer, Aubrey Lethbridge and Charlotte Lethbridge. Bud is known for his humility, unwavering interest in others, loyalty to his friends and schools, dedication to his family and for being the last one on the dance floor. There will be Memorial Services at Essex Meadows, 30 Bokum Road, Essex, CT at 11:30, Saturday, June 8th and at The Church at Point O' Woods at 12:30, Saturday, August 3rd. Donations may be made to The Himalayan Project (himalayanproject.org), or Musica Sacra (musicasacrany.org), organizations that he supported and his children champion.

GORVOY--Dr. Jack, founder of the world-renowned Cystic Fibrosis center at Schneider Children's Hospital, died peacefully at his home on Long Island, NY at age 94. During his 60-year tenure as a pediatrician, Gorvoy became an integral part in the advancement of Cystic Fibrosis treatment and was named Director Emeritus of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine upon his retirement in 2002. Dr. Jack David Gorvoy is survived by his beloved wife of 65 years, Florence; his children, Jill and Joseph, and grandchildren, Alex and Jana. He was a kind and compassionate man, and a constant source of comfort and inspiration. He will be greatly missed.

GRAUBARD--Helen, passed away peacefully May 30, age 81 surrounded by her family. She is survived by her husband Mickey, children Robin, Bob, Shelley, Jay LeBoff and Abby Gruen. Grandchildren Jared, Ariel, Spencer, Nora and Sylvie, and the Roberts family: Bernie, Elaine, Reisa and Debbie. Service at Shaaray Tefila, Bedford, NY noon Monday June 3.

GRAY--Nina, an independent curator of American decorative arts, died at home in Manhattan on May 20, 2013. Nina was born in Boston and attended Phillips Academy, Andover. She received a B.A. from Connecticut College and an M.A. from the Institute of Fine Arts, New York University. A well known curator of decorative arts and architectural historian, Nina held curatorial positions at The New-York Historical Society from 1985-1990 and later at The Park Avenue Armory. She served as a consultant to numerous institutions including The Brooklyn Museum, The Munson-Williams-Proctor Arts Institute and several National Park Service properties. She is the author of numerous publications, many the result of her ground-breaking scholarship on the work of Louis C. Tiffany. Nina is recognized for the diversity of her projects, publications and discoveries of previously unknown aspects of American decorative arts that stand as a testament to her passion, diligence and exceptional acuity in research and connoisseurship. She was also an avid collector in many areas, a brilliant craftsperson and active participant in the civic life and historic preservation of the Manhattan neighborhood where she lived for thirty years. Nina was a loving and dedicated wife, mother, daughter, sister, friend and colleague. She is survived by her husband John W. (Jack), her children Alexander, a student at Trinity College, and Julia, a student at Northwestern University; her mother, Dr. Selma Rutenburg of Boston; and siblings Richard Rutenburg of Paris and Dr. Karen Segal of New York. She was predeceased by her father, Dr. Alexander Rutenburg and sister, Jeanne Rutenburg. A memorial will take place at the Ethical Culture Society at a future date. Memorial donations may be made to The New-York Historical Society.

HAMMOND--Hazel, died peacefully at her Manhattan home on May 27. She was 59 and had displayed great courage dealing with cancer for more than a year. Born in Youngstown, OH, Hazel graduated from Kent State, then came to New York City to earn a graduate degree at NYU. A radiant, generous person with the loveliest of smiles and a flair for style, Hazel forged a career as a photo editor at Travel & Leisure and other magazines. She loved her partner of 25 years, Alen MacWeeney, her friends and family. Hazel was an artist and took great pleasure in painting and their little house in Sag Harbor with terriers, Bachelor and later, Bandit. She created Hammond Editions, publisher of custom hand-made books, highlighting Alen's photography. Predeceased by her husband, Christopher Carlos Gibson, Hazel is survived by Alen, her sisters Jean Thompson and Amy Gambrel, brother Gary Hammond, as well as nieces and nephews: Carly Johnson, Sophie Thompson, Matthew Gambrel, Jon Hammond, Guy Hammond, Robert Thompson and Michael Thompson. A gathering will be held at a later date. Contributions may be made to NYU Langone Medical Center (attn of margo.bloom@nyumc.org) or Amnesty International (http://www.amnestyusa.org/donate).
HELSEL--Dr. Randi. We cherish the time you spent with us. You will be missed by all. Love, Harryette, Stan & family

KATZ--Jeanne Sprung, 94, of Palm Coast, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY. Widow of Leon S. Katz, DDS. Survived by daughter Isabelle Katz Pinzler of New York, NY, son Joel of Athens GA; four grandchildren, four great- grandchildren, sister Judith Menken of New Rochelle, NY and brother David Sprung of Oakland, CA. Donations may be made to Jewish Federation of Volusia & Flagler, 470 Andalusia Avenue, Ormond Beach, FL 32174.

BIRNBAUM--Ezra, 81, of Manhattan and Highmount, NY, passed away unexpectedly at home on Monday, May 27, 2013. We loved Ezra so much because he gave his all for everything he believed in. He had an incredible ability to understand others' points of view. He earned a Masters in Social Work degree from Columbia University, and worked in housing rights, welfare rights, and substance abuse counseling. He dedicated himself to community, political, and union organizing. After retiring, he developed a continuing education program for professionals in Local 1199 Health and Hospital Workers' Union. Ezra was known for his infectious personality, funny stories, and overall sense of humor. He loved the mountains and every blade of grass at his country home. Sharing meals and music with friends and family gave him tremendous joy. Ezra and the 63-year love of his life, Carol, met while on a long-distance bicycle trip in New England. Their shared love of the outdoors and many years of camping led them to build their dream house at the end of a dirt road in the Catskill Mountains. Ezra is lovingly missed by his wife Carol; children Nina, Danny, Richie and wife Geeta, Lisa and husband Geovanny; grandchildren Joel, Rachel, Naava, Ilana; and sister Naomi and husband Jack. Memorial celebrations of his life will be held in Manhattan on Friday, June 14 at 5pm at 310 West 43rd St, and in the Catskills later in the summer. Donations in Ezra's memory can be made to the Fleischmanns Playground Project, payable to MARK Project, PO Box 516, Arkville, NY 12406, or Honest Brook Music Festival, PO Box 309, Delhi, NY 13753.
CASHIN--Francis J.,PE Former resident of Williston and North Hills, NY, passed away on May 22, 2013 in Atlantic Beach, FL.

DOMAN--Glenn. Glenn Doman, 93, founder of The Institutes for the Achievement of Human Potential, died on the 18th of May. Doman was world-renowned for his pioneering work with brain-injured children and well children. In 1940 he graduated from the University of Pennsylvania School of Physical Therapy. Study with Dr. Temple Fay at Temple University Hospital followed. On the day of the attack on Pearl Harbor, Doman enlisted and served as second Lt. Infantry Platoon Leader and Rifle Co. Commander in combat in Europe. He was decorated by George VI with the British Military Cross for outstanding heroism in action. From the U.S. he received the Distinguished Service Cross for extraordinary heroism in combat, the Silver Star for gallantry against an armed enemy, and the Bronze Star for heroism in close combat, and he was nominated for the Congressional Medal of Honor. He was decorated for services to the Duchy of Luxembourg during the Battle of the Bulge. Following his discharge, Doman began pioneering the field of child brain development. In 1955 he founded The Institutes for the Achievement of Human Potential with the goal of successfully treating the brain. Doman and Fay believed that the brain had great capacity for recovery. At that time brain-injured patients were routinely warehoused and considered hopeless. Doman insisted, "The brain grows by use." Today the concept of neuroplasticity embraces the work of The Institutes. In the early 1960s, the successful work with brain-injured children led to vital discoveries about the development of well children. Doman authored "The Gentle Revolution Series" for parents, the first of which was "How To Teach Your Baby To Read." Doman taught more than twenty-five thousand families, and he strongly influenced millions of families through the book "What To Do About Your Brain-Injured Child." In 1966 he was knighted by Brazil and received that country's highest decoration, the Knight Order of the Southern Cross. In 2007 he received the Medal of the Italian Senate. He is survived by his wife, children, and grandchildren. His daughter, Janet, and his younger son, Douglas, continue to lead his dedicated staff around the world, ensuring that children both hurt and well continue to get the help they need. Donations may be made to The Founder's Fund at The Institutes, 8801 Stenton Ave., Wyndmoor, PA 19038, or iahp.org.

FELDMAN--Robert Paul, of Nashville, TN died May 29 at age 74. He is survived by his four children, Alexandra Redwine, Kyle Feldman, Jeremy Feldman and Elizabeth Feldman, as well as his three grandsons, his brother William, and his dear friend Patsey Carney Reed. Born and raised in New York City, a graduate of Brooklyn Friends School, Yale College and Yale Law School, Bob devoted his life to the service of not-for-profit organizations and charitable institutions. He touched countless lives throughout the years. His towering presence, insightful wit and irresistible charm will never be forgotten. Funeral services will be held at St. Augustine's Chapel, 200 24th Avenue South in Nashville, on Wednesday, June 5th at 3pm. A reception with the family will immediately follow the service at the University Club of Nashville. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Bob Feldman Memorial Fund c/o St. Augustine's Chapel, Box 6330 B, Nashville, TN 37235.

BRADY--Sallie J. (nee Motsch), age 47. Passed away unexpectedly at her home in New Jersey. Beloved wife of the late James Brady; loving daughter of Donald and Susan (nee Burke) Motsch; dearest sister of Kevin (Vanessa Dawes) and the late Sheila Motsch. Contributions suggested to the Ursuline Sisters of Cleveland, 2600 Lander Rd., Pepper Pike, Ohio 44124. Funeral Mass Monday, June 3, 2013 at 11:00 am at St. Philomena Church, East Cleveland, Ohio. CONNOR--Tyrrell Cohalan, 74, died peacefully on May 24, 2013 in Vero Beach, FL. She was a graduate of the Academy of the Sacred Heart at Kenwood, Albany and Marymount College in New York. She worked for many years as the Director of Public Relations for Davidoff Cigars. She is survived by her daughter, Katherine of Stamford, CT and son, Daniel of Shelton, CT. She was predeceased by her son, Robert, her brother, Daniel and parents, Daniel F. Cohalan and May Leslie. Services held at The Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Ave and 66th St., 6/10 at 10:30am.

ELLIOTT--Norman J.,98, a retired CPA, lawyer and management consultant died on April 15, 2013 in Vancouver, WA. He founded his own CPA firm of Norman J. Elliott & Co. in New York City and practiced tax law since 1940. Mr. Elliott was a graduate of City College and of Brooklyn Law School. He was a past Treasurer of the NY State Society of CPAs, a former director and a former Dept Editor of the Journal of Accountancy. In 1982 Mr. Elliott passed the California Bar and started a practice of investigative forensic accounting. He was an expert witness for legal cases with complex financial and accounting issues; he retired in 2000. Mr. Elliott was an accomplished sailboat racer on Long Island Sound. In 1962 he won the Ann Kathleen Cullen Memorial Trophy given annually to Larchmont Race Week's "outstanding skipper" and first in the Rhodes-19 class. He teamed with his daughter Pat to win the 1980 Ranger 20 National Championship. He is survived by his son, Roger Elliott of Mt. Pleasant, SC and his daughter, Patricia Elliott Cavanaugh of Portland, OR. His beloved wife of over 73 years, Loretta, predeceased him at the end of 2010.

FEIN--Allen, on May 29, age 91. Beloved husband of the late Margie. Loving father of Susan (Mike) Lefkowitz and Merri (Murray) Benbasset. Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Devoted brother of Harvey and the late Libby and Evelyn. For info: shermanschapel.com

FILONUK--William. Fordham University's Graduate School of Business Administration (GBA) community mourns the passing of William "Bill" Filonuk Jr., FCRH '77, GBA '83 on May 25, 2013 at the age of 58. Bill was tireless in his commitment to GBA. He recently served as first Vice Chair of the GBA Board of Overseers. He gave his time, knowledge, and expertise to numerous areas within GBA including career services, quantitative financial research, entrepreneurship, and positive marketing. He was a superb mentor to students, drawing upon his successes as a managing director at BNY Mellon. We will miss Bill's wisdom, optimism, generosity and selfless service to GBA. On behalf of the GBA community we extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Susan, son David, and his entire family. Edward Stroz, Chair Board of Overseers David A. Gautschi, Ph.D., Dean Graduate School of Business Administration Fordham University

DEMETROWITZ--Sarah "Kit Ryan". Survived by Charles, devoted husband of 42 years. Daughter of Florence (Iddings) Ryan, she was born in Asheville, NC on October 12, 1926. She graduated from UNC Chapel Hill in 1947 and later from NYU. A child of the Depression and WWII, she followed her dreams to live in New York City. Blessed with perfect pitch, she was a consummate musician, enjoyed the theater, and held season tickets for the Metropolitan Opera for 50 years. She had a 36-year career with The New York Times. Upon retirement, she moved to Ocean Pines, MD, and later to the Collington Retirement Community in Mitchellville, MD. These moves signaled a life of community service and extensive travel. A gracious life, well lived.

CARRUTHERS--Roy, 74, Artist, illustrator, graphic designer. Roy Carruthers, an internationally-known painter, award-winning illustrator and graphic designer for more than five decades, died following a long illness on May 3, 2013, in Flagler County, FL. From 1974 onward he populated his vibrantly colored paintings and prints with enigmatic, disproportionate, large-scale figures often engaged in surreal activities. He exhibited in one-man shows at ACA Galleries in New York City, besides showing throughout Europe, South Africa and the United States. Some of his best-known illustrations adorned the cover of Time magazine and the Op Ed page of The New York Times. Mr. Carruthers twice received the Society of Illustrators gold medal in the early 1970s. His work in print and television advertising created for Seagram's, as a Senior Art Director at Ogilvy & Mather, Inc., in New York City, earned him an Andy Award of Distinction in 1987. Mr. Carruthers was born on December 14, 1938, in Port Elizabeth, South Africa, to the late Robert James and Irene (Wilson) Carruthers. During the 1960s, his career took him first to London, England, then to the United States. He resided in Old Greenwich, CT, between 1968 and 1990, maintaining a studio at the Chelsea Hotel in New York City for part of that time. He settled in Florida in 1998. He is survived by his wife, Valerie (Brooks) Carruthers; daughter Alison Carruthers Garb, son-in-law Matthew Garb and grandsons Kyle and Ryan Garb of Madison, CT; and former wife, J. Pamela Carruthers, of Wallingford, CT. He was pre-deceased by his brother, Robert James, Jr. A memorial service was held May 11, 2013, in Bunnell, FL.

BROWN--Cynthia Granger, of NYC and Sherman, CT (May 24, 1952 - May 12, 2013). A daughter of the late Helen Niblack McKelvie and the late Charles E Brown III, Cynthia's work as a Congressional aide, free-lance journalist and editor led her to join Americas Watch in 1981. She did field work in combat zones and prisons in Central and South America, ending with a two year stay in Chile, 1990-1992. Upon her return she worked for Human Rights Watch at their headquarters in New York. She became their first program director from 1994 until her retirement in 1999. During this time she was instrumental in creating a new division for women's rights. Although she remained involved with HRW, the focus of her last years was on study, travel, landscape gardening, jazz singing and, especially, the practice of Buddhism. She is survived by her daughter Emilia Rafaela Barrios-Brown, her sisters Austi Brown of Kent, CT and Lucy Tower of Saratoga Springs, NY, niece Aurora Tower and nephew Alfred Tower. Her husband, Jaime Barrios, died in 1989. A memorial for Cynthia will be held on June 4th at Soho House (29 Ninth Avenue) at 11:30am. Donations may be sent to Still Mind Zendo (37 W 17th St #

BIRNBAUM--Alice Weinman. Born July 16, 1929. Lived on Long Island, New York and Sarasota, Florida before her death there on May 13. Cultivated and generous, gentle and resilient, loved and beloved. Survived by children Janice, Jess and Matthew and brother Roy.

DICKENSON--Dorothy, 89, born in Florida, died May 27, 2013 in Queens, NY of a terminal illness. New York City Board of Education Guidance Counselor. Past President Greater New York Chapter of the Links Inc. Survived by Harriet Dickenson M.D. Services to be held at Church of the Resurrection E. Elmhurst June 13, 4-9pm.

CROSBY--Thomas M.,Jr. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Walker Art Center mourn the passing of their beloved friend whose wise counsel, intelligent care, and steadfast commitment to the Walker touched all of us. The Walker extends its deepest condolences to his wife Ellie, their children Stewart, Brewster, Grant, and Brooke, and extended family and friends. The Board of Trustees & Staff of the Walker Art Center, Minneapolis, MN

BENNETT--Roger H. Sheldon Lobel, P.C. mourns the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Roger H. Bennett, P.E. Roger was not only an advisor to our firm on land use and zoning matters, but a trusted mentor on life, positivity, and friendship. An inspiration to us personally and professionally; he will be missed. We extend our condolences to his friends and family.
In “The Last Cyclist,” a play that was written inside a Nazi concentration camp, all bicyclists — or anyone whose ancestors had anything to do with bicycles — face deportation or death.
Claire McCaskill discusses the record number of women on the Senate Armed Services Committee and their impact on the debate about sexual assault in the military.
The United States national team celebrated U.S. Soccer’s 100th anniversary by breaking out of its offensive slump on Sunday, defeating Germany, 4-3, in an exhibition match.
Thousands of Istanbul residents marched from Besiktas district to Taksim Square, in a massive public protest to the government’s plans to redevelop the public park.
As billions of cicadas enter the brief, noisy mating stage of their 17-year life cycle, David Rothenberg performs with some of the insects to show how animals use musical sounds to communicate.

There’s an ayatollah pulling the strings in the Iranian presidential race.

Mikko Ilonen took a two-shot lead over Sweden’s Alexander Noren into the final round of the Nordea Masters in Stockholm as he seeks to end a six-year winless drought on the European Tour.
The Cleveland Indians issued an apology to fans who attended Friday night’s game with Tampa Bay that had nearly five hours of rain delays and ended at 2:53 a.m.
Ruler of the World won the English Derby by one and a half lengths, with the favorite, Dawn Approach, finishing 11th.
Justin Gatlin won the 100 meters at the Prefontaine Classic in Eugene, Ore., in a wind-aided time of 9.88 seconds, besting his fellow Americans Michael Rodgers and Ryan Bailey.

HOFFMAN--Eleanor, beloved wife of Dr. William Hoffman for 70 years, passed away from natural causes on May 31, 2013. She is survived by her husband, devoted children Andrew, Robert, David, and Meyer, and eight grandchildren Kathryn, Sean, Sara, Graham, Kenji, Naomi, Lauren and Emily. She was a diehard New Yorker who was intimately involved with the League of Women Voters of New York and served on the Board of Directors of the Brooklyn Museum. She graduated from New York University in 1942 and was a longtime member of the East Midwood Jewish Center in Brooklyn. One of her passions was bridge and she became a Life Master. They were married at the Eastern Parkway Synagogue on October 24, 1943 with Richard Tucker as the Cantor, about which they often reminisced. A private funeral service will be held Sunday at Barron Hirsch Cemetery on Staten Island.

HIRSCH--Henry E. Born July 9, 1914 - died May 30, 2013. Father of Corrine London and Michael Hirsch. Loving grandfather and great-grandfather. He had a good run! He will be missed by all. Rest in peace.

HORNOR--Edith S.,86, died May 29 in New York. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, June 11th at 11am at Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and 64th Street, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Chapin School, 100 East End Avenue, New York, NY 10028.
SOLLAR--Siema. We would like to express our deepest condolences to the Sollar and Eisen families on their great loss. We all loved Siema and she will be greatly missed. Marilyn and Richard Davimos

MILLER--Saul, 97, June 1, on his beloved twin brother Bernie's 6th Yahrzeit. Cherished husband of the late Irma Goldstein. Loving father of Susan J. Brother of Hannah Wolff and George Miller. Services today 1pm at Gutterman's 8000 Jericho Tpke. Woodbury, NY.
SCHMITTER--Charles H, born February 4, 1928 died April 17, 2013. He was the beloved husband of Margaret Roose Schmitter. He will be fondly remembered by his family and friends.

SOLLAR--Siema, left us peacefully on the morning of Thursday, May 30th, with her husband by her side. She was most certainly a woman of valor, and an adoring wife, mother, grandmother, and sister-in-law. Siema was a woman of great intelligence and insight, with a strong will and indomitable spirit. She used her considerable gifts throughout her adult life to champion the cause of care for the developmentally disabled and to help individuals with developmental disabilities lead lives of dignity and meaning. In this regard, Siema always had a special place in her heart for The Maplebrook School in Amenia, NY, and New England Village in Pembroke, MA, where her beloved son David currently resides. Siema's passion and creativity were the moving force behind the creation of New England Village's Sollar Wellness Center, an innovative facility designed to enrich the lives of those with developmental challenges. She was also deeply involved in numerous other charitable causes, and she touched the lives of many people over the course of her lifetime. Siema is survived by her husband Arnold Sollar, daughter Marilyn Sollar McCormack, son David Sollar, son-in-law John McCormack, granddaughter Phoebe McCormack, and sister and brother-in-law Elaine and Edwin Eisen. Funeral services will be held at 12:45pm on Monday, June 3rd at Riverside Memorial Chapel, located on Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street in Manhattan. Donations in Siema's memory may be made to New England Village, 664 School Street, Pembroke, MA 02359.

STEINER--Elaine Bennett, 84, was an intelligent, stylish, energetic and compassionate woman. She was an accomplished writer on gardens, interior design and art, an active member of the literary Lotus Club and a past leader of the National Council of Jewish Women. The beloved wife of the late Dr. Lenard Steiner, she is survived by her brother, Joseph, children, Andrea, Rob and Jim and cherished grandchildren, Rosalie, Lily and Simon. They and the many friends she continued to make throughout her life will miss her deeply. Services to be held Wednesday. For details, riversidememorialchapel.com.
REESE--Terrell Pearce, Passed away on May 5, 2013 peacefully in his New York City residence. For further information please send e-mail to jhanus@insulfab.com.

SMITH--Gadiel, MD, 100, former Chief of General Internal Medicine at VA hospital in East Orange, NJ. After attending medical school in Switzerland, he practiced in the Bronx. He moved to New Jersey where he was an associate professor at the UMDNJ and served at the Daughters of Israel. Active in the American Jewish Committee where he promoted interfaith dialogue he was also a leader at Temple Emanu-El in Livingston. He loved classical music, Shakespeare, devouring The New York Times, and, above all, his family.

SOLOMON--Irwin Ellis. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of our beloved Irwin Solomon on June 1, 2013. Born on July 15, 1927 to Benjamin and Rose. Devoted husband to Ruth. Loving father of Joel, Jonathan, Steven, Emily and Karen. Doting grandfather of Erica, Isabelle, Sarah and Jake. He struggled courageously against many chronic illnesses for over five years. His family was the center of his life. He was our rock and our anchor. Things won't be the same without him.
CHRISTENSEN--Angela. 06/04/36 - 09/29/05. Dearest wife and mom, a beautiful woman, So loved by all who knew her.

HASSON--Jack, MD, born on January 26, 1925 in NYC, passed on May 31st in Bloomfield, CT at the age of 88. Dr. Hasson was a highly regarded pathologist and teacher. He is survived by his wife Alice T. Loomis, brother Robert Hasson, sons Kenneth and Perry Hasson, and grandson Benjamin Jack Hasson. Private memorial services are being held by the family.
MARKIN--David. We mourn the passing of David Markin, a visionary who moved mountains, and a generous and loyal friend. Nick, Betsy, Jamie & Matthew

DICKENSON--Dorothy, 89, born in Florida, died May 27, 2013 in Queens, NY of a terminal illness. New York City Board of Education Guidance Counselor. Past President Greater New York Chapter of the Links Inc. Survived by Harriet Dickenson M.D. Services to be held at Church of the Resurrection E. Elmhurst June 13, 4-9pm.
GORDON--Patricia, of Glen Cove, NY passed away June 2nd, 2013. Beloved mother, sister, aunt, grandmother and friend.

HARTSTEIN--Gertrude (nee Greenberg). Age 96. Devoted wife of the late Milton Hartstein. Beloved mother of Elysa (Andrew) Barkin and Elaine. Loving grandmother of Laura and Daniel. Dear sister of Anne, and the late Bertie and Rose. So kind, funny, gentle and loving. So special. So missed.

BORENSTEIN--Eugene, on May 30th. Beloved husband of Maxine. Devoted son of Charles and the late Gloria Borenstein. Cherished brother of Merry and Harvey Levinson and Mitchell Borenstein. Fond cousin of Steve and Pamela Bennett. Funeral services were held yesterday at the Riverside Memorial Chapel.

GRAY--Nina, an independent curator of American decorative arts, died at home in Manhattan on May 20, 2013. Nina was born in Boston and attended Phillips Academy, Andover. She received a B.A. from Connecticut College and an M.A. from the Institute of Fine Arts, New York University. A well known curator of decorative arts and architectural historian, Nina held curatorial positions at The New-York Historical Society from 1985-1990 and later at The Park Avenue Armory. She served as a consultant to numerous institutions including The Brooklyn Museum, The Munson-Williams-Proctor Arts Institute and several National Park Service properties. She is the author of numerous publications, many the result of her ground-breaking scholarship on the work of Louis C. Tiffany. Nina is recognized for the diversity of her projects, publications and discoveries of previously unknown aspects of American decorative arts that stand as a testament to her passion, diligence and exceptional acuity in research and connoisseurship. She was also an avid collector in many areas, a brilliant craftsperson and active participant in the civic life and historic preservation of the Manhattan neighborhood where she lived for thirty years. Nina was a loving and dedicated wife, mother, daughter, sister, friend and colleague. She is survived by her husband John W. (Jack), her children Alexander, a student at Trinity College, and Julia, a student at Northwestern University; her mother, Dr. Selma Rutenburg of Boston; and siblings Richard Rutenburg of Paris and Dr. Karen Segal of New York. She was predeceased by her father, Dr. Alexander Rutenburg and sister, Jeanne Rutenburg. A memorial will take place at the Ethical Culture Society at a future date. Memorial donations may be made to The New-York Historical Society.

GACHOT--Irene T.,of Old Westbury, NY on June 1, 2013. Beloved wife of Richard. Loving mother of Richard, Theodore, Peter, Paul and John. She is also survived by a sister and four grandchildren. Longtime trustee of Old Westbury Gardens and active in North Country Garden Club and Manhasset Art Association. Funeral Service Monday evening at the Church of Our Lady of Kazan. Contributions may be made to the Fund for the Preservaton of the Church of Our Lady of Kazan. Further information Whitting Funeral Home 300 Glen Cove Ave., Glen Head, NY 11545 www.whitting.com.

FELDMAN--Robert Paul, of Nashville, TN died May 29 at age 74. He is survived by his four children, Alexandra Redwine, Kyle Feldman, Jeremy Feldman and Elizabeth Feldman, as well as his three grandsons, his brother William, and his dear friend Patsey Carney Reed. Born and raised in New York City, a graduate of Brooklyn Friends School, Yale College and Yale Law School, Bob devoted his life to the service of not-for-profit organizations and charitable institutions. He touched countless lives throughout the years. His towering presence, insightful wit and irresistible charm will never be forgotten. Funeral services will be held at St. Augustine's Chapel, 200 24th Avenue South in Nashville, on Wednesday, June 5th at 3pm. A reception with the family will immediately follow the service at the University Club of Nashville. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Bob Feldman Memorial Fund c/o St. Augustine's Chapel, Box 6330 B, Nashville, TN 37235.

ZATLOW--Anita, on June 2, 2013. Founder of Special Citizens Futures Unlimited, Inc. Pioneer in the field of service to people on the autism spectrum. Passionate, loving, dedicated mom. She moved mountains to make a world that was humane, loving and compassionate for children like her son. Autistic children in 1976 were often undiagnosed, misunderstood and mistreated. Anita saw to it that services for adults with autism would be available as an alternative to institutionalization. Her legacy in the form of group homes, vocational and supplemental programs for families of autistic children and adults will live on forever. Beloved and devoted mother of Gerri, who will always carry her torch and Douglas, who was the inspiration for her life's work. Services Wednesday, 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

PALESTRINI--John, 66. The Lively Group and all its employees express our profound sympathy to the Palestrini Family on the passing of our beloved founding partner, John Palestrini. We extend our condolences to his wife Lisa, his daughter Jennifer (Marc), son Kris (Erin) and grandchildren, Ben, Sam, Lola and Fiona. John was an editor, an innovator, an entrepreneur, a charismatic leader and a passionate post production industry advocate. He was a compassionate and cherished friend and colleague who touched many lives with his warmth and wit. We shall miss him always. The wake will be held on Sunday, June 9th 6:00pm-9:00pm and Monday, June 10th 6:00pm-9:00pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home. The burial will be private. There will be a memorial service for John in the coming weeks. Ethel Rubinstein Managing Partner

PALESTRINI--John. Over more than three decades, John was my client, my business colleague, but most of all my friend. I can never fully express my gratitude for all he did to help me and my family professionally and personally. He was more than a giant in commercial post production he was a giant in life. Susan and I extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Lisa, who was with him every step of the way on his final journey; his children, Jenny and Kris, who reflect the values that were so important to John, his brother and sister, his grandchildren, his entire extended family, and his innumerable friends. David and Susan Rosen
PALESTRINI--John. My wonderful friend and wise mentor. I will never forget you. Roe

PALESTRINI--John. With great sadness and deep affection I bid good-bye to my friend and business partner of more than 20 years. I am privileged to have known him and honored to have been his partner. Ethel

McCLINTOCK--Michael Robert, age 55, of Larchmont, New York, died on June 2, 2013. He was born to the late George D. McClintock and Aileen McHugh McClintock on August 20, 1957 in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Mike married Cynthia Ann Crowley on June 21, 1986 on Nantucket Island. Together they have three wonderful children: Christina Carey McClintock, Clare Melissa McClintock, and William Crowley McClintock, all of whom survive him. Mike is also survived by his four sisters and one brother: Jessie McClintock Kelly, Brooklyn, NY; Catharine R. McClintock, Edina, MN; George D McClintock, Purchase NY, Jane M Wyatt, Edina MN, Anne D McClintock, Medford MA. He was also beloved by his sisters-in-law and brothers-in-law: John Meeker, Binita Mehta, Wiz Wyatt, Catherine Poole, Melissa and Penry Price, Peter and Gretchen Crowley, and his parents-in-law Joan and Paul Crowley, and numerous nieces and nephews. Mike was a 1976 graduate of the Blake School in Hopkins, Minnesota. He graduated from Dartmouth College with a B.A. in 1980, and from Harvard Business School with an M.B.A. in 1986. Since 2011, Mike has been a Senior Managing Director at Macquarie Capital, in the Financial Institutions Group. Previously he held senior positions at FBR Capital Markets, CIBC Capital Markets, Merrill Lynch, and JP Morgan. Mike was Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Merchants Bank of Rugby, North Dakota, a family business established by his great-grandfather in 1898. Mike believed strongly in the importance of education and was very active as an alumnus of Dartmouth College. Always a fan of the Big Green, Mike worked tirelessly to encourage support for Dartmouth, and was inducted into the Stephen F. Mandel '52 Society in recognition of his extraordinary service to the College. He was also a member of the Board of Directors Catholic Youth Organization, Archdiocese of New York, a program he wanted to support after years of watching his children's CYO basketball games. He is a past member of the Board of Governors of the Apawamis Club of Rye. Mike was an Eagle Scout, Troop 33 in Minneapolis, Minnesota. He put his scouting skills to use while at Dartmouth. For his senior honors thesis on the Canadian fur trade he retraced the major trade route from Saskatchewan to Lake Superior by canoe over three months. Mike loved sports. He was an avid skier, biker and golfer. He recently completed his first Olympic length triathlon and was so proud to finish after months of training. He also loved watching sports and cheering on Minnesota teams, but he took the most pleasure in watching his kids' sports and cheering loudly from the sidelines. Mike will be remembered for his smile and the generous way he celebrated the accomplishments of others. He always had handwritten notes tucked into pockets, and was frequently working on the speeches he gave for graduations, confirmations, weddings, birthdays and any special event for someone he loved. A sincere and loyal friend, Mike was always available to give good advice, offer a hug, or just listen and comfort. Mike was a devoted husband, and a wonderful father to his three children. His children knew that even though he worked hard, he would always be there at games, or at home to help with homework. He had a Teddy Roosevelt quote for every situation. Most importantly, he modeled a life of compassion for all. Mike was in love with his wife Cynthia, and through this love his children saw how trust and love build a strong family and a meaningful life. Visiting Hours Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Thursday 10am at St. Augustine Church in Larchmont. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Dartmouth College.

LOWENSTEIN--Hugh Price, of Mountain Lake, Lake Wales, FL and Linville, NC died June 2, 2013. Born 1930 to Katherine and Melvyn Lowenstein. Graduated from Salisbury School. 1949; attended North Carolina State College; served in U.S. Army in Korea; worked at Burlington Industries before starting his Wall Street career at Unterberg, Towbin, LF. Rothschild and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Director, Bloomberg LP since 1996. Former resident of New York City and Bermuda. Survived by his wife Sandy) daughter Maggie Burnett (Tyler) of San Antonio) TX, son Michael of Mill Valley, CA and daughter Lauren de Lavalette (Philip) of Paris; France, seven grandchildren. Brothers James and Peter and many nephews and nieces. He will be remembered for his kindness, generosity, wisdom, strong love of friends and family, and his amazing sense of humor. He will be greatly missed. Memorial donations may be made to Our Children's Charitable und, attention Hugh Price Lowenstein Furn, 150 Ave. B, SE, Winter Haven, FL. 33880. www.OurChildrens.org.

LAUTENBERG--Frank. The Yeshiva University family and the Board of Overseers of the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law deeply mourn the loss of Hon. Frank Lautenberg, who for twelve years was an esteemed friend, board member, and a YU Guardian donor of the law school and the university. Senator Lautenberg's life illustrated both the transformative power of education and the dedication of committed public service. His service as a Cardozo board member from 2002 to 2009 and thereafter as an honorary member until his death reflects his values as well as his aspirations. The Senator participated actively in the life of the law school supporting a variety of initiatives that improved the educational experience of the students including establishing a scholarship in his name, speaking frequently at law school events, expanding loan assistance for new graduates, and consistently lending his support to the public service summer internship program. On the board, he was a pillar of strength and integrity, serving as vice chair, chairing the nominating committee, and always deeply engaged in advancing the law school and its students. His belief in a just society, and compassion for the individuals who comprise it, guided his vision, made a difference in the lives of our students and enriched our world. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Bonnie Englebardt Lautenberg; to their children and their spouses, our alumna Ellen Lautenberg '93 and Doug Hendel, Nan and Joe Morgart, Josh and Christina Lautenberg, Lisa and Doug Birer, Danielle Englebardt and Stuart Katzoff, Lara Englebardt Metz and Corey Metz; and 13 grandchildren. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law Matthew Diller, Dean

LAUTENBERG--Sen. Frank U.S. Senator Frank Lautenberg Dies A Loss To Lupus Patients Nationwide. The Board of Directors and staff of the S.L.E. Lupus Foundation and the Lupus Research Institute join the lupus patient and scientific communities across the nation in mourning the death of U.S. Senator Frank Lautenberg (D-N.J.). Our organizations will remember Senator Lautenberg as a great statesman, a dedicated proponent for public health and a strong advocate for all patients. As just one of his many successful initiatives, the Senator led the drive in Congress to improve professional education so all healthcare providers nationwide have the tools they need to recognize, diagnose and treat the too-often overlooked disease of lupus. The Senator was equally passionate about protecting the country's commitment to advancing biomedical research. As recently as this spring, Senator Lautenberg co-hosted a Senate briefing on lupus to apprise Congress of the imperative need to protect scientific advances and assure strong support to the National Institutes of Health. On behalf of people with lupus as well as those suffering with any challenging disease, we thank Senator Lautenberg for his years of turning concern into action and compassion into legislation, said Richard DeScherer, President of the S.L.E. Lupus Foundation. The Senator was a powerful proponent for what he believed in, and he passionately believed in our government's responsibility to ensure the safety and good health of the American people. Our hearts go out to the Senator's wife, our beloved Board Member Bonnie Englebardt Lautenberg, and to his entire family for the loss of a man as devoted to those he loved as to those he served.

LAUTENBERG--Frank. It is with deep sadness that we mourn the passing of Senator Frank R. Lautenberg. I've known Frank since 1961 when we met for the ADP underwriting. A private funeral service will be held Sunday at Barron Hirsch Cemetery on Staten Island.

ENGLISH--Betty Lou, passed away peacefully on May 27 at the age of 86. A lifelong resident of New York City, she received her B.A. from Queens College and her M.A. from Columbia University. Her marriage to her loving husband, George, was all-too-brief, ending with his death in 1952. She never remarried, but went on to live an extraordinary life. She touched hundreds of young lives at their most formative stages as a pre-K teacher for 40 years at the Ethical Culture Fieldston School. She combined her avocation, photography, with her passion for children as the author and photographer of three acclaimed children's books, Women at their Work, You Can't Be Timid with a Trumpet, and Behind the Headlines, a profile of the New York Times. In addition to her husband, she was predeceased by her brother, Richard Silver, Sr. She is survived by her brother, Ben, her sister-in-law Kathryn, niece Patricia Russo (Armando), nephews Richard Silver, Jr. (Karen), John Silver (Faith), Robert Silver (Theresa) and Thomas Silver (Fawn), and eleven grand nieces and nephews, all of whom she loved as if they were here own children. Services were private.

GRANITO--Helen Elizabeth. Helen Elizabeth "Betty" Granito, of Stamford, CT died peacefully at her home on June 1, 2013, after a long but valiant battle with Alzheimer's disease, surrounded by her loving children. Betty was predeceased by her devoted husband of over 56 years, Frank H. Granito Jr. "Ditto", in February of this year. Betty was the daughter of the late Peter and Kitty Altieri of Dumont, New Jersey. She was born on April 11, 1933 in Manhattan and spent her grammar school years in the Clason Point area of the Bronx, where at seven years old she met her future husband. Betty attended St. Cecilia High School in Englewood, New Jersey and Montclair State Teachers College in Montclair, New Jersey. After her graduation in 1955 Betty joined the faculty of Hackensack High School, teaching English. Betty married Ditto, then an Ensign in the U.S. Navy, on May 19, 1956. They spent the early years of their marriage in Alameda California where Ditto was stationed as a Naval Aviator with the Pacific Fleet and where their first child was born. In 1958 Betty and Ditto returned to civilian life on the east coast, ultimately settling in Clason Point where they raised their four children. They moved to Stamford in 1992 where they frequently entertained their children, grandchildren, extensive family, and many friends. Betty was a devoted daughter, caring sister, loyal friend and loving wife, mother and grandmother. Blessed since birth with extraordinary beauty, charm and intelligence, Betty was the perfect hostess and the life of every gathering. Betty found her greatest joy in nurturing her children, the birth of every grandchild and every moment she spent with her childhood sweetheart and love of her life, her devoted husband Ditto. Betty was the proud mother of Catherine and Tim Langan, Frank and Monica, Nora and Dan Harris and John and Luci. Betty was blessed with 16 grandchildren. She is survived by her brothers Richard (Sharon), Jimmy (Geri) and John (Kathleen) Altieri. She was predeceased by her brothers Tommy and Peter Altieri. She is survived by her sister-in-law Nora (Cass) Chomicz, Eileen (Andy) Simons and Sheila (Don) Dunphy and her brother-in-law Gennaro (Maureen) Granito. She was predeceased by her sister-in-law Meg Granito and her brother-in-law John Teeple. Betty was a loving aunt to many nieces and nephews and grand nieces and nephews. Information regarding funeral services may be obtained by contacting Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, Stamford, CT (203) 327-1313 or leopgallagherstamford.com. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Betty and Frank Granito Scholarship Fund at Cardinal Hayes High School, 650 Grand Concourse, Bronx, New York 10451.
