APPLEMAN--Mark. You were the most beautiful person who made my world. I'll love you forever, Marguerite.

ZATLOW--Anita, on June 2, 2013. Founder of Special Citizens Futures Unlimited, Inc. Pioneer in the field of service to people on the autism spectrum. Passionate, loving, dedicated mom. She moved mountains to make a world that was humane, loving and compassionate for children like her son. Autistic children in 1976 were often undiagnosed, misunderstood and mistreated. Anita saw to it that services for adults with autism would be available as an alternative to institutionalization. Her legacy in the form of group homes, vocational and supplemental programs for families of autistic children and adults will live on forever. Beloved and devoted mother of Gerri, who will always carry her torch and Douglas, who was the inspiration for her life's work. Services Wednesday, 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.
STAPLETON--Jean. The Council of Actors' Equity Association mourns the passing of our colleague Jean Stapleton, a dedicated member and former Councillor of this Association.
Rosenberg--Judith. Art Beyond Sight honors the life of Judith Rosenberg. Her generous spirit lives on in those she held dear.

ROSENBERG--Judith, on June 3, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Loving partner of Ken Mark Zitrin. Devoted mother of Francesca and mother-in-law of Jared Epstein. Cherished grandmother of Hollis and Channing.

RAWSON--Hugh R.,76, died June 1st, 2013 in Washington, CT. He is survived by his loving wife Margaret and his children, Nathaniel and Catherine. Hugh was an author and editor, as well as an active volunteer in his community. Widely loved by his friends, colleagues, neighbors, and family, his humor, wisdom, and hard work will be sorely missed. Memorial Service: Sunday, June 9th, at 2pm in the Roxbury, CT Town Hall. Inquires: 860-354-4655
PALESTRINI--John. My wonderful friend and wise mentor. I will never forget you. Roe

PALESTRINI--John. With great sadness and deep affection I bid good-bye to my friend and business partner of more than 20 years. We grew and learned from each other every day as we worked together to grow our company. His vision and generosity of spirit inspired me and taught me the true meaning of partnership. I am privileged to have known him and honored to have been his partner. Ethel

PALESTRINI--John, 66. The Lively Group and all its employees express our profound sympathy to the Palestrini Family on the passing of our beloved founding partner, John Palestrini. We extend our condolences to his wife Lisa, his daughter Jennifer (Marc), son Kris (Erin) and grandchildren, Ben, Sam, Lola and Fiona. John was an editor, an innovator, an entrepreneur, a charismatic leader and a passionate post production industry advocate. He was a compassionate and cherished friend and colleague who touched many lives with his warmth and wit. We shall miss him always. The wake will be held on Sunday, June 9th 6:00pm-9:00pm and Monday, June 10th 6:00pm-9:00pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home. The burial will be private. There will be a memorial service for John in the coming weeks. Ethel Rubinstein Managing Partner

LOWENSTEIN--Hugh Price, of Mountain Lake, Lake Wales, FL and Linville, NC died June 2, 2013. Born 1930 to Katherine and Melvyn Lowenstein. Graduated from Salisbury School, 1949; attended North Carolina State College; served in U.S. Army in Korea; worked at Burlington Industries before starting his Wall Street career at Unterberg, Towbin, L.F. Rothschild and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Director, Bloomberg LP since 1996. Former resident of New York City and Bermuda. Survived by his wife Sandy, daughter Maggie Burnett (Tyler) of San Antonio, TX, son Michael of Mill Valley, CA and daughter Lauren de Lavalette (Philippe) of Paris, France, seven grandchildren, brothers James and Peter and many nephews and nieces. He will be remembered for his kindness, generosity, wisdom, strong love of friends and family, and his amazing sense of humor. He will be greatly missed. Memorial donations may be made to Our Children's Charitable Fund, attention Hugh Price Lowenstein Fund, 150 Ave. B, SE, Winter Haven, Fl. 33880, www.OurChildrens.org.

LAUTENBERG--Frank. The Board and staff of the Alzheimer's Drug Discovery Foundation are deeply saddened by the passing of Senator Frank Lautenberg. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Bonnie Englebardt Lautenberg and the entire Lautenberg Family. Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman; Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman; Nancy Corzine, President; Howard Fillit, MD, Executive Director; Nancy Lynn, Executive Director

LAUTENBERG--Frank R. American Friends of The Hebrew University (AFHU) and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem are deeply saddened by the passing of Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, whose commitment to Israel and The Hebrew University spanned nearly four decades. The loving husband of Bonnie, and treasured father and grandfather, Senator Lautenberg will long be remembered for his inspired leadership and tireless efforts to foster human progress. Senator Lautenberg helped to establish the Lautenberg Center for General and Tumor Immunology at The Hebrew University, a top cancer research center worldwide. He supported the university's Rothberg International School and student scholarships. The distinguished recipient of an Honorary Doctorate from Hebrew University and AFHU's national Scopus Award, Senator Lautenberg served as an Honorary President and national board member of AFHU. We extend our deepest sympathies to Bonnie and the entire Lautenberg family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menahem Ben-Sasson, President American Friends of The Hebrew University Michael S. Kurtz, Chairman Daniel I. Schlessinger, President Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director

LAUTENBERG--Frank. It is with deep sadness that we mourn the passing of Senator Frank R. Lautenberg. I've known Frank since 1961 when we met for the ADP underwriting. Frank was a successful businessman with a huge social conscience. He led ADP from a small bookkeeping company to a giant in the data processing industry. Frank entered politics at the top as a U.S. Senator where he successfully promoted health issues and helping those less fortunate. He missed the golden age of corporate executives to accomplish his communal goals. I will miss him, and I know the U.S. and N.J. have lost a major force in the advancement of life. Our sincerest condolences to Bonnie, Ellen, Nan, Lisa, Josh, Danielle and Lara. Stanley and Roberta

LAUTENBERG--Senator Frank. Our dear and cherished friend for almost 40 years. The son of poor immigrants and always a champion for the forgotten in our society, he blessed the United States everyday of his life for the opportunities given to him. Frank loved the State of Israel, working tirelessly as a national leader before and after his election to the United States Senate. To Bonnie and the entire family our sincere condolence on your loss. We loved him and will miss him as well. Irma and Norman Braman

LAUTENBERG--Frank, We are deeply saddened by the loss of a great man and our great friend, Senator Frank Lautenberg. He lived a meaningful life and he made a real difference. We truly respected his passion, his integrity and his commitment. Heartfelt condolences to Bonnie and to the whole family. Susan and Morris Mark

LAUTENBERG--Sen. Frank R. To America, you were an outstanding and distinguished Senator who made a difference in the world. To us, you were a loving brother and uncle. You made our world a better place. With all our love, Michael, Carol, Brett, Gregory and Jed

LAUTENBERG--Sen. Frank The Officers, Members of the Board and Staff of the American Society for Yad Vashem mourn the passing of Senator Frank Lautenberg, a member of the International Board of the American Society for Yad Vashem. Lankin, Executive Director/CEO American Society for Yad Vashem
LAUTENBERG--Frank R. An outstanding Senator, a special friend. We will miss you. Our love and sympathy to Bonnie and the entire family. Betsy and Alan

LAUTENBERG--Frank, was our dear friend, an outstanding U.S. Senator and humanitarian. I am proud to say that I worked for him for 40+years from ADP to now, an amazing journey. My husband and I enjoyed his company, wit and counsel. We will miss him. Ellie & Vince Rigolosi

LAUTENBERG--Senator Frank. The Board of Governors and Membership of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Bonnie Englebardt Lautenberg, Lara and Corey Metz, and the entire family. Frederic Krieger, President

LAUTENBERG--Senator Frank. Family man, Friend, Statesman. We were fortunate to have known and been touched by a great, special and just man. When we once asked Frank to define his political philosophy, he answered that it is how he would define his life - in a word, "Progressive." He was, indeed, always in the forefront, ahead of his time in business and in his politics, a visionary with a humane touch. He always considered and fought for those who were less fortunate, using his wealth and power to benefit the many. We learned so much from him and will miss him greatly. To his wife, Bonnie, his children and grandchildren, we remember the many times Frank spoke of his love for all of you and of your prominent presence in his heart and spirit. We, like you, will deeply miss him but we all should be comforted in the knowledge that he will live on through his great deeds and as a large part of our memories as he lived large in our lives. Ron Berk & Judie Ripka Berk

LAUTENBERG--Senator Frank. We mourn the loss of our beloved brother-in-law and Uncle. You were the light of our family and a tower of strength for so many. You will forever be missed and forever remembered. With Love and Great Respect, Lois, Andrew, Olivia, Stephen, Victoria and Alex

LAUTENBERG--Sen. Frank. You were a very good, kind and decent man who truly made a difference in this world having touched the lives of so many. Rest in peace, Frank. You will never be forgotten. Susan, Lynn, Justin and our families

LAUTENBERG--Frank R. Dearest Frank, thank you for an extraordinary life together. I'll miss your smile, your laugh and your joie de vivre! You were my destiny and everything to me! Rest in peace my love, Bonnie

LAUTENBERG--Frank R.,on June 3, 2013. Beloved husband of Bonnie. Devoted father of Ellen, Nan, Lisa and Josh. Loving step-father of Danielle and Lara. Adoring grandfather to 13 grandchildren. Services Wednesday, June 5, 11:30am at Park Avenue Synagogue, Madison Avenue at 87th Street.

KIRBY--Herbert Weldon, 79, of Longwood FL, passed away unexpectedly on June 2, 2013. He was born on November 21, 1933 in Birmingham, MI. Herb was a graduate of Michigan State University in 56 with a degree in Chemical Engineering. At the pinnacle of his career, he led a group of fellow Allied employees in the successful buyout of a major division of the corporation. Under Herb's leadership as president and CEO of Arcadian Corporation, ultimately became a cornerstone unit of the largest fertilizer company in the Western Hemisphere. He retired in 97. Herb was a resident of Mountain Lakes, NJ for 37 years where he served as Mayor in 98 and was honored as Citizen of the Year in 00. He was a member of St. Peter's Episcopal Church. He enjoyed spending time with his family and grandchildren. He was a world traveler of over 100 countries and enjoyed photography, computers and restoring cars. Herb was an avid golfer and gardener. Herb and his wife Joan were major benefactors to many charitable organizations, including Children's Hospice International and the MSU College of Engineering and the Department of Chemical Engineering and Material Science, serving on advisory boards for both. Herb is survived by his five children, 17 foster children, five grandchildren, one great-grandchild. Herb is also survived by his younger brother and two sister-in-laws. Herb is predeceased by his wife, Joan of 50 years and a daughter. Relatives and friends are invited to attend Memorial services on Friday June 7th at 2pm at the St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 215 Boulevard, Mountain Lakes, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in memory of Herbert to Children's Hospice International at 1101 King Street, Suite 360, Alexandria, VA 22314. Services under direction of Norman Dean Home for Services, Denville, NJ www.normandean.com, (please share a memory of Herb on website).

Graduate of Power Memorial High School and St. Francis College. Michael served in the US Army in Germany during the Korean Conflict. President and CEO of MJ Kelly Associates International. Michael was also an avid runner and golfer. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10am at St. Monica's RC Church, 413 East 79 Street, NYC. Interment Private. For further information contact Krtil Funeral Home at 212-744-3084. In lieu of flowers donations preferred to Mary Manning Walsh NH, 1339 York Avenue, NYC 10021.

GELFMAN--Stanley, passed away on June 4, 2013, beloved husband of Judge Sondra Miller, loving brother of Jordan Gelfman, devoted father of Sari and Debra, proud grandfather of Zachary, and loving stepfather of David, Seth, Miriam and Wendy. SAXE--Raymond D. III, passed away on Saturday, June 1, at Sound Shore Medical Center in New Rochelle, New York. He was 50 years old. He is survived by his ex-wife Naomi Reinitz Saxe, of Rye Brook, New York; his daughters, Amanda, Abigail, and Rachel; his sister Emily Saxe Nydam of Wellesley, Massachusetts; and his mother JoAn Teetor Marder of Tucson, Arizona. There was a private memorial service for family and friends at Congregation Kneses Tifereth Israel in Port Chester, New York, officiated jointly by Rabbi Jaymee Alpert and The Reverend Dr. John W. Miller of Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale. There will also be a memorial plaque placed in his memory at the Teetor Mausoleum in Hagerstown, Indiana. He was loved and will be missed.

RUBEL--Stanley B. Stanley B. Rubel, passed away on June 2, 2013. Beloved husband of Isabel for over 61 years, loving father of Howard (Janet), Matthew (Melissa), and Laurence, and grandchildren Todd, Sarah, Jeremy, Jeffrey, Michael, and Joshua. Stanley represented the best of his generation. He served in the Army Air Force in World War II and completed his B.S. in Business at NYU in 1947. He established Alan Evan in 1958, which expanded to become a recognized men's and woman's sportswear chain in the Pompano Beach, FL area. He was also a founding member of Temple Sholom in Pompano Beach. Outside of Business, he and Isabel enjoyed many years of travel and the arts. He will be remembered by his family and many friends.
Rosenberg--Judith. Art Beyond Sight honors the life of Judith Rosenberg. Her generous spirit lives on in those she held dear.

RITZ--Norman, of Spring Valley, NY passed away June 4, 2013 at age 74. Norman worked as a corporate bond trader and was a Senior Vice President for Lehman Brothers in New York City. Survived by his beloved wife Sandy, cherished children Stephen (Lizette) and Barry (Staci) Ritz, adoring granddaughter Michaela, and his loving sister Sara Karen. Funeral services today, 1pm, at Congregation Sons of Israel in Spring Valley, with interment to follow at Congregation Sons of Israel SV Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the charity of your choice. Services are under the direction of Hellman Memorial Chapels, Jewish Funeral Directors, 15 State Street Spring Valley, NY 10977. 845-356-8600.

RIBOLOW--Hedda, Ph.D.,73, of Teaneck, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, Chicago, and Portland, OR, died June 2 in hospital, from results of a chronic illness. Devoted wife of Neal Rosenau, loving mother to Josh, fiercely proud grandmother of Miles, she is also survived by beloved sisters Irene Leff and Naomi Berman of Commack. After graduating from Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn, Hedda's career in biochemistry research included college at Syracuse University, a Masters from Brooklyn College with research at Kings County Hospital, Doctoral and Post-Doctoral work at the University of Chicago and University of Illinois-Chicago, and research at Reed College. She helped found the Chicago Womens Liberation Union, and was active in Science for Vietnam and Science for the People. In Portland, she worked with community groups to renovate city parks. In Teaneck, she helped create a pathway along the Hackensack River and served on the steering committee of Bergen Grassroots. She expressed her passion for the arts through membership in a range of cultural organizations, and was especially active with the Metropolitan Museum of Art and arts classes at the Teaneck Senior Center. She also served on the Teaneck Community Gardens Committee, having used the community garden since 1991. She was an agent with Russo Real Estate. She was Northern New Jersey representative of the University of Chicago Alumni Schools Committee, and worked with other parents of Horace Mann students to support the high school and its programs. A memorial service will be held in her honor on Saturday, June 8 at 1pm, in the Volk-Leber Funeral Home in Teaneck. The family is receiving visitors at their home in Teaneck, from 1-6 pm. this week. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory should be directed to the Metropolitan Museum of Art or to the Planned Parenthood Federation of America. volkleber.com

Dorothy loved her skating, sewing, volunteer work and the many family and friends that surrounded her life. Services will be held June 9th at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY at 11am. A memorial gathering will be held immediately following at Valhalla Crossing Restaurant. All donations in memory of Dorothy should be sent to the Alzheimer's Association.

LORING--Joseph R, "Joe", an electrical engineer and co-founder of the firm that bears his name, died peacefully last week at his home in Arlington, Virginia. He was 86. Joseph Robert Loring was born in Brooklyn, NY on June 21, 1926. One of two children he was raised in Brooklyn and, in 1944, enlisted in the Army Reserve. Due to his high entry test scores, the Army sent him to Virginia Polytechnic Institute to study engineering. After 12 months of study, he was assigned to work on a top-secret voice scrambling installation in the Pentagon for the remainder of World War II. He rose to the rank of staff sergeant and after the war returned to Virginia Tech to complete his degree in electrical engineering and graduated in December, 1947. In 1956, Joe co-founded the New York City mechanical and electrical engineering firm Joseph R. Loring and Associates, Inc. In 1962, after being in private practice for only six years, he was selected by The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey as the electrical engineer for the 12 million square-foot World Trade Center Complex in NYC. In addition to the World Trade Center, he was responsible for the engineering of many world-class structures, including the IBM Building on Madison Avenue and Citicorp Center in NYC, The Parliament House in Canberra, Australia and the recent renovations at the United States Supreme Court Building in Washington, D.C. Loring was responsible for the engineering design of buildings in South America, China, Europe and the Middle East. In 1970, Loring opened a branch office in Washington, D.C. office where he worked for the past fourteen years until his retirement in 2012. "Joe always said that one of the reasons for his success was the education that he received at Virginia Tech", his wife Sheila noted. He served on many advisory boards at Tech and was an avid Hokie fan. In 1999, he was inducted into the Bradley Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering's Academy of Distinguished Alumni. He also funded a scholarship in electrical engineering. In 2001, he was inducted into the College's Academy of Engineering Excellence. And in 2012, he was awarded two of Virginia Tech's highest honors: the University Distinguished Service Award and the College of Engineering's Distinguished Alumni Award at the school's commencement, where he was delighted to meet and be congratulated by First Lady Michelle Obama. In addition to his love of reading and his art collection, Joe took up skiing in his 50's and windsurfing in his 70's. Joe is survived by his wife, Sheila, his daughters, Lisa and Debra, five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

Dear brother of the late Martha Lawrence Wieners and Dr. Robert Marshall Lawrence (Dr. Ruth Lawrence). Mass of Christian burial Saturday 9:45am at Epiphany Church on Second Ave. at 22nd St.

DOTY--Richard. The American Numismatic Society mourns the death of Dr. Richard G. Doty, who died June 2, 2013. From 1974-1986 he served as the Society's Curator of Modern Coins and Paper Money prior to joining the Smithsonian Institution. Doty was a leading expert on coins and currency, renowned not only for his profound knowledge, but also for his evocative personal writing style, his helpfulness to all, his charming wit, and sense of good fun. GLADSTONE--Ruth. Aunt Ruth: You lived to be 100. You were the matriarch of our family, and you will live in our hearts forever.
DICK--Marion Pokoik. In memory of my darling mother, thinking of you, as always, on your birthday. Always remembered, I cherish your zest for life and your beautiful smile. Your daughter, Gail

YAEGER--Nancy Rogers. Born in NYC, died June 1, 2013. Wife of the late David J. Yaeger. Beloved mother of Robin, Jonathan, Suzanne, and Lisa (deceased), and grandmother of David, Kathryn and Jonathan. An honest, creative and generous soul. Never boring.

SIMONS--Harriette A. (Tabak). Born in Brooklyn August 29, 1919, died in Manhattan June 3, 2013. Daughter of David A. Tabak and Alice Kessler. Graduated Cornell 1940. Married Henry Noble Simons October 1942. Their daughter Victoria Alda born August 9, 1944 and son Frederick Adam December 31, 1956. She lived in East Rockaway for 27 years, then 40 years in Manhattan, where Hank died in 1986. She worked most of her life, including years as a counselor and administrator in women's health and abortion. A notable beauty, she was admired for her social grace, love of travel, strong support of women's issues, and Jewish bonds. She took great pride in her family and their accomplishments. At her request, there are no services.

ROSS--Sherwood "Jerry", 92, passed peacefully in South Florida on June 4, 2013. He was the founder of Ross Bicycles, Allentown, Pennsylvania and past President of the Bicycle Manufacturers of America. He was a combat wounded and highly decorated veteran of the Pacific campaign during World War II. Survived by his children Andy, Candy and Randy, wife Francine, six grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. He was truly one of the "Great Generation" and will be missed by all that knew him.

RAWSON--Hugh R.,76, died June 1st, 2013 in Washington, CT. He is survived by his loving wife Margaret and his children, Nathaniel and Catherine. Hugh was an author and editor, as well as an active volunteer in his community. Widely loved by his friends, colleagues, neighbors, and family, his humor, wisdom, and hard work will be sorely missed. Memorial Service: Sunday, June 9th, at 2pm in the Roxbury, CT Town Hall. Inquires: 860-354-4655

PALESTRINI--John H.,on June 3, 2013. Beloved husband of Lisa. Devoted father of Jennifer and her husband Marc, and Kris and his wife Erin. Loving brother of Joseph and Annette. Cherished grandfather of Sam, Ben, Lola and Fiona. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Sunday, June 9 and Monday, June 10, 6-9pm. Funeral private.

MORRIS--Maxine. Temple Adas Israel of Sag Harbor, NY and its board and all its members mourn the passing of Maxine Morris, mother of our much loved Rabbi, Leon Morris. We share Leon's sadness and know his fond memories will comfort him and his family. Neal Fagin, President.

MORRIS--Maxine, age 74, of Apopka, FL, formerly of Connellsville, PA passed away June 5th. Beloved wife of the late Jay M. Morris; devoted mother to Andrea Holt and Rabbi Leon A. Morris (Dasee Berkowitz); loving sister of Beth Wasserman; proud grandmother of Austin, Kaitlin, Tamir, Yael and Shalva. Graveside service Friday in Pittsburgh and Shiva in Sag Harbor, NY. Contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

McCARTHY--Cecelia, lost her battle against breast cancer at age 62. She died on May 26, 2013 in her home in Astoria, NY with her husband, Kirk Bigelow, by her side. She was a beautiful, devoted wife who loved her family deeply. She was also a true, blue unionist who was an indefatigable fighter for workplace justice. She brilliantly represented many public sector employees over the years.

LAWRENCE--Donald Richard, on June 5, 2013 at age 86. Beloved husband of the late Margaret (nee Doherty). Loving father of Richard. Dear brother of the late Martha Lawrence Wieners and Dr. Robert Marshall Lawrence (Dr. Ruth Lawrence). Also survived by many nieces, nephews, grandnieces, grandnephews, great-grandnieces and great-grandnephews. Born in Rolla, MO and grew up in Teaneck, NJ. WWII Army Veteran, fought in European Theater. Alumnus of Columbia University and Columbia Law. Attorney in corporate and banking Law. Avid reader, lover of opera and patron of Metropolitan Opera. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home 353 Second Ave. (between 20th & 21st St.) Thursday 7-9pm and Friday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian burial Saturday 9:45am at Epiphany Church on Second Ave. at 22nd St.

HALLETT--Emma V. on June 6, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Robert, cherished mother of Dennis Hawkins (Eileen), sister of Dr. Helen Allen, Paul Milone and Georgia Jones, grandmother of McCarthy and Ryan Hawkins, Eileen McCarthy (John) and James Galleshaw (Jo Marie). Survived by loving sister-in-law, Helen Ryan (nee Hawkins) and her nephews, Ron, Don and Tim Ryan. Funeral Mass: Epiphany Church, 2nd Ave. at 22nd St. Saturday, June 8th at 1:00pm. Please send contributions, in lieu of flowers, to Loyola School Annual Fund, 980 Park Ave. NY, NY 10028 and/or St. Jude's Hospital for Children.
GOSTIN--Ruth. Adored mother of Judy, (Michael) and Deborah, (Brian). Treasured Nana of David, Jennie and Mickey. You made us what we are.

GELFMAN--Stanley, Passed away on June 4, 2013. Beloved husband of Judge Sondra Miller, loving brother of Jordan Gelfman, devoted father of Sari and Debra, proud grandfather of Zachary, and loving stepfather of David, Seth, Miriam and Wendy. Stanley was a talented engineer/inventor admired and loved by his loyal staff at Shane Industries and by the many friends he accumulated over the years. His extraordinary aides, Joel, Margaret, Andrea and Patience will never be forgotten. A skilled pilot, war veteran, swimmer, skier, dancer and workaholic, Stanley's feisty, lovable, warm personality will be missed by his many friends, colleagues and family. Funeral Service: Today 9:30am at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 2080 Boston Post Road Larchmont, NY 10538. Shiva will be held at the home of Judge Sondra Miller in Larchmont today, Sunday and Monday from 3pm until 7pm. Please send contributions, in lieu of flowers, to the Alzheimer's Association.

MITCHELL--Mary, died June 6, 2013. Mary is mourned by all of her colleagues at Scholastic where she served as Senior Vice President of Marketing for Scholastic Education. Mary was a human dynamo. Her commitment to improving educational outcomes for underserved children drove her professional efforts and philanthropic work. In both venues, she was an innovator, visionary and marketing genius. Mary was the driving force behind the marketing of all of Scholastic Education's major technology programs, including READ 180, which became the best-known single brand in the K12 education market. As a founding trustee of Girls Prep, Mary was devoted to providing a quality single-sex education for families unable to afford private school. She was instrumental in opening Girls Prep Lower East Side Elementary School in 2005 and helping the program expand to include Middle School in 2009. Mary was a champion talent spotter who mentored innumerable individuals directly and indirectly, and they carry her brilliance onwards. Mary is survived by her parents, Linda and Paul Mitchell, a brother, Jim Mitchell and his wife Kristen, a sister, Patty Gallagher and her husband, Joe, and their three children, Clare, Kevin and Grace Gallagher. Contributions in her memory can be made to Public Preparatory Network, 291 Broadway, Suite 1202, New York, NY 10007. Margery Mayer EVP, Scholastic Inc.

LAUTENBERG--Frank. We mourn the loss of our lifelong friend, Senator Frank Lautenberg. The bond of friendship that Frank shared with Henry and with our entire family spanned 60 years, and his devotion and commitment were critical to the success of ADP. Above all, we are grateful for Frank's outstanding contributions to our nation and we admire the skill, determination and pride with which he represented his beloved State of New Jersey. Frank was proud of his heritage, his immigrant roots and his Paterson soul--and we were blessed to know him. We offer our sincere condolences to the entire Lautenberg family. Marilyn Taub, Judy and Ron Gold, Benay and Steven Taub, Shelley and Ira Taub.

HOMES--Herbert Charles. 86, of Bronxville, NY, and Nantucket, MA, beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend, passed away peacefully after a brief illness on Wednesday, June 5th. Born in New York City on November 21, 1926, he was the son of the late Frieda and Charles Homes, 1st generation Americans. He was a graduate of the High School of Music and Art and NYU Business School. He met his wife of 64 years, Shirley Williams Homes, while at Emerson College in Boston. Herb was a WWII Veteran of the Air Force. Through the GI Bill, he attended The School of Radio and Television Technique, and his destiny was set. When offered a one-day job in the Channel 11 WPIX mail room, he used his charms and skills to advance into directing major productions at PIX. He directed and produced "The Ted Steele Show", a live variety show of the 1950's. He also directed and produced the popular WPIX schedule of children's shows i.e. "The Chuck McCann Show", "Bozo the Clown", "Officer Joe Bolton", "Captain Jack McCarthy" and more. After a brief stint at Colpix Records, and weekends directing live news briefs at the RCA Pavilion at the New York World's Fair, Herb joined the early years of Channel 13 WNET in 1967. He ran production in the heyday of public television and was producer/director of the Channel 13 Auction. Over the decades, as his negotiating skills became evident, he was named Director of Labor Relations where he remained until his retirement at 80. Having spent nearly 60 years in television, Herb continued to enjoy summers in his cherished home on Nantucket with his wife and a parade of family and friends. He will be missed more than words can say a finer and funnier man we've never known. He is survived by his wife Shirley Homes, sister Phyllis Lewis, daughter Pat Catchpole, son Peter Homes and his wife Gina, grandchildren Alexandra Catchpole, Jessica, Jeffrey, Judith, Jenn and JR Homes, many nieces and nephews, and a fan club too big to list. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Nantucket Conservation Foundation, www.nantucket-conservation.org. A gathering to share memories of Herb will be held Saturday, June 15th, 1pm at McGrath Funeral Home, 20 Cedar Street in Bronxville, with a nosh to follow.

GOLDSMITH--Hank Louis. We note with sorrow the passing of our member Hank Louis Goldsmith and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein and President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City

GOLDSMITH--Hank (Herman) L. The lawyers and staff of Proskauer Rose LLP mourn the untimely passing of our beloved partner, colleague and friend Hank Goldsmith. Hank waged a valiant battle against his illness over the past year, displaying the unyielding optimism he brought to life every day and the toughness that made him such a formidable legal talent. Throughout his struggle, Hank made clear to all of us how deeply he loved his family. Nothing meant more to him than his sons Eric, Jake and Ryan Goldsmith. Indeed, no conversation with Hank was complete until the latest event involving each boy was discussed in depth. He adored his wife Debbie and embraced his stepsons Avery and Ethan Kriss with his characteristic warmth because no disease could ever diminish his immeasurable heart. Hank received a B.A., cum laude, from the State University of New York at Binghamton and earned his J.D., cum laude, from Georgetown University Law Center in 1987. He spent nearly his entire legal career at Proskauer and became a Partner in 1997. A brilliant trial and appellate lawyer, Hank represented clients in the financial services, real estate and entertainment industries. In two of his most significant cases, he represented the recording industry trade group in the copyright case against Napster and acted as lead counsel on an important amicus brief for a number of international copyright holders in the U.S. Supreme Court. Hank loved to teach and countless Proskauer litigation associates developed under his tutelage and guidance. The enormous appreciation that Hank's clients had for his work was perhaps best expressed by the number who surrounded his bedside over these past few weeks. Hank loved the practice of law, the firm and his clients and the feeling was mutual. He had a unique wit that he used as a lawyer to persuade and as a friend and colleague to entertain. No one was quicker with a quip to illustrate a point. And in the tradition of great lawyers who were artists in their off hours, Hank was a skilled guitarist, bass player and singer who performed in several tribute bands most recently The Newspaper Taxis (Beatles), the Carjackers (the Cars) and the Petty Thieves (Tom Petty). Proskauer extends its deepest sympathies to his wife Debbie, sons Eric, Jake and Ryan Goldsmith and stepsons Avery and Ethan Kriss. Hank and Debbie showed us all the power of love and devotion, inspiring hope in the human condition at a time when we might otherwise have only felt grief. Hank never faltered or despaired despite the challenges he faced. That was a gift to his friends and colleagues and, most of all, his family. Joseph M. Leccese Chairman Proskauer Rose LLP

GELFMAN--Stanley, Passed away on June 4, 2013. Beloved husband of Judge Sondra Miller, loving brother of Jordan Gelfman, devoted father of Sari and Debra, proud grandfather of Zachary, and loving stepfather of David, Seth, Miriam and Wendy. Stanley was a talented engineer/inventor admired and loved by his loyal staff at Shane Industries and by the many friends he accumulated over the years. His extraordinary aides, Joel, Margaret, Andrea and Patience will never be forgotten. A skilled pilot, war veteran, swimmer, skier, dancer and workaholic, Stanley's feisty, lovable, warm personality will be missed by his many friends, colleagues and family. Funeral Service was Friday at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc. 2080 Boston Post Road Larchmont, NY 10538. Shiva will be held at the home of Judge Sondra Miller in Larchmont on Sunday and Monday from 3pm until 7pm. Please send contributions, in lieu of flowers, to the Alzheimer's Association.

FRIEDMAN--David Lawrence, on June 1, 2013 in Grenada, West Indies. Beloved son of Judith Friedman and the late Sandor Friedman. Dear Brother of Peter. Service Sunday, 2pm at "The Riverside", 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

EICHLER--Peter, 76, of Scottsdale, AZ passed away on April 2, 2013. He is survived by his cherished wife of 47 years, Wendie, son David and beloved daughter-in-law Diane. Peter graduated from the Peddie School, Wesleyan University and Columbia Law School. He practiced Intellectual Property law for 51 years, with firms in NY, CA and AZ.

COHEN--Steven M.,56 years old, died on June 5th, 2013. Beloved father of Brandon and Spencer. Devoted son of Rita Cohen and the late Marty. Loving brother of Jason and Diane and Alan and Susan. Services: Sunday, 2pm at Riverside Nassau-North Chapels of Great Neck.

BROOK--Lester, 97 years old, passed on June 7, 2013. Beloved husband of Gloria. Devoted father of Richard and Lisa. Cherished grandfather of Alex and great-grandfather of Cameron. A WWII veteran, successful and well respected real estate developer. A perfect gentleman. Services 12 noon Sunday at Riverside Chapels of Great Neck.

YOUCHA--Geraldine, 87, passed peacefully on June 5. A respected and adored wife, mother, grandma, great-grandma, and friend; she was a veteran journalist and author. She graduated from Northwestern University in 1946 and was a staffer for Coronet magazine. She went on to write the weekly column, "As I Was Saying," for the Journal-News and contributed to Parents magazine, Women's Day, and others. She wrote the books "Minding the Children: Child Care in America from Colonial Times to the Present" and "Women and Alcohol: A Dangerous Pleasure," and co-authored with Judith Seixas: "Drugs, Alcohol, and Your Children: What Every Parent Needs to Know" and "Children of Alcoholism: A Survivor's Manual." She leaves behind her husband of 62 years, Isaac Zeke Youcha, along with her children, Victoria Youcha, Sharon Youcha, and Joe Youcha (Jessica Kaplan), grandchildren, great-grandchildren, nieces, nephews, and cousins. Her family will miss her every day and continue to live by her three tenets: be of use, never buy retail, and don't make a fuss.

YAEGER--Nancy Rogers. Born in NYC, died June 1, 2013. Wife of the late David J. Yaeger. Beloved mother of Robin, Jonathan, Suzanne, and Lisa (deceased), and grandmother of David, Kathryn and Jonathan. An honest, creative and generous soul. Never boring.

TURIM--Ruth Kessler, 99. The treasure of our family; loving, caring, honest and our hero. passed on to a place where a mind like hers will still knock their socks off (May 31, 2013.) Eldest daughter of Harry and Yetta (Feigenbaum) Kessler: Predeceased by her beloved husband Arthur (Icky), sweet son Irwin, dear brother Daniel, and loving sister Irma. Sister to Pearl. A life long resident of Brooklyn and then Great Neck, NY. She leaves a family that celebrates her life - but will always miss her - Children: Frances Zeitler, Linda and Michael Krasner, Grandchildren: Kenneth and Marcie Zeitler, Bracha Leah Zeitler, Alissa and Jay Maizes, and 10 great-grandchildren: Andrew, Ariel, Steven, Moriah, Ezra, Lauren, Rebekah, Zachary, Amital, and Joshua, and nieces and nephews who love and miss her. A dedicated and caring teacher and Assistant Principal in the NYC school system. Ruth attained her undergraduate (dean's list) and two masters degrees at Brooklyn College. Donations: Ruth Turim Fund at Brooklyn College. (Endowed fund to annually aid students in need and continue in perpetuity). 718-951-5074, 2900 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11210. brooklyncollegefoundation.org

STONE--Helen Dolores, age 80, of New York City, quietly passed away on May 22, 2013. Co-founder of National Foster Parent Association, she will be missed by all who knew her. Funeral details at startribune.com/obituaries.

STEFFAN--Vincent Creighton. President & Founder of The Steffan Group, the event and destination management company based in New York City, died suddenly on May 20. Vince was sought out throughout his more than 25-year career for his expertise and vast experience in planning and staging epic galas, fundraisers, and corporate destinations for an exclusive list of worldwide clients. He was known above all for his enigmatic personality, his gregarious love of people and life, and his gift for transfixing a room with his storytelling, his steel-trap memory for dates, and his never forgetting a detail of a time well enjoyed. Born and raised in Buffalo, NY, Vince made his home in New York City. He graduated from Babson College in Wellesley, MA, where his business acumen was acknowledged by his professors and friends. He was the Director of George Trescher Associates, launching his own business in 2001. His crowning achievements were the 2007 opening of the new New York Times building, the 75th Anniversary of Time, Inc., and the first-ever Jazz at Lincoln Center. Vince will be missed by all who loved him, and relied upon his steadfast loyalty, and deep care that was extended with unreserved affection. His charm, wit, and dancing will never be forgotten. Vince is survived by his siblings, Robert Steffan, Barbara Gallagher, Susan Mathias and Lisa Barnett. He was predeceased by his parents Geraldine and Robert Steffan. Funeral services were held in Buffalo, NY. A celebration of his life will take place in New York City in June. Memorials may be made to The Vincent Steffan Memorial Fund, Babson College Alumni Hall, Babson Park, MA., 02457

SIMONS--Harriette A. (Tabak). Born in Brooklyn August 29, 1919, died in Manhattan June 3, 2013. Daughter of David A. Tabak and Alice Kessler. Graduated Cornell 1940. Married Henry Noble Simons October 1942. Their daughter Victoria Alda born August 9, 1944 and son Frederick Adam December 31, 1956. She lived in East Rockaway for 27 years, then 40 years in Manhattan, where Hank died in 1986. She worked most of her life, including years as a counselor and administrator in women's health and abortion. A notable beauty, she was admired for her social grace, love of travel, strong support of women's issues, and Jewish bonds. She took great pride in her family and their accomplishments. At her request, there are no services.

Cardozo School of Law extend heartfelt condolences to Barry Shenkman and his family for the loss of his beloved wife, Gail. Barry and Gail are Benefactors to Cardozo Law School where Barry serves as an officer and has served as a board member for over 13 years; bringing to bear his strong sense of ethics to all his work on behalf of Cardozo. We will miss deeply Gail's spirit of openhearted giving to others and making a difference in this world. May her name ever remain as a source of enduring blessings for your entire family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President

ROLAT--Jacqueline, on June 7, 2013. Beloved wife of Sigmund A. Devoted mother of Samantha Asulin and Amanda Rolat. Loving grandmother of Henry, Maya, and David Asulin. Services: Sunday, June 9, 9:45am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

PERNICONE--Nunzio, professor of History and Politics at Drexel University since 1988, died at Jefferson University Hospital on May 30, 2013. PALESTRINI--John, 66. The Lively Group and all its employees express our profound sympathy to the Palestrini Family on the passing of our beloved founding partner, John Palestrini. We extend our condolences to his wife Lisa, his daughter Jennifer (Marc), son Kris (Erin) and grandchildren, Ben, Sam, Lola and Fiona. John was an editor, an innovator, an entrepreneur, a charismatic leader and a passionate post production industry advocate. He was a compassionate and cherished friend and colleague who touched many lives with his warmth and wit. We shall miss him always. The wake will be held on Sunday, June 9th 6:00pm-9:00pm and Monday, June 10th 6:00pm-9:00pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home. The burial will be private. There will be a memorial service for John in the coming weeks. Ethel Rubinstein Managing Partner

PALESTRINI--John H.,on June 3, 2013. Beloved husband of Lisa. Devoted father of Jennifer and her husband Marc, and Kris and his wife Erin. Loving brother of Joseph and Annette. Cherished grandfather of Sam, Ben, Lola and Fiona. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Sunday, June 9 and Monday, June 10, 6-9pm. Funeral private.

O'BRIEN--Joan B.,Atlantic Highlands, NJ and NYC, June 6. Beloved sisters Betty, Elaine, nieces Mary Ellen, Marguerite, Beth, Susan, Jennifer, nephews Stephen, Justin, Christopher, in-law Jerome, Carmen, preceded in death by beloved brother Joseph, niece Hilary. Mass at St. Agnes in Atlantic Highlands, NJ followed by Burial Maryrest, Mahwah, June 12.

MODY--Mukund, MD, 73, passed away on Staten Island, NY on June 3. Dr. Mody practiced pediatrics in East NY for over 40 years. His commitment to his patients was unwavering. He was deeply devoted to his wife, daughters, extended family, friends and the Indian community in NY. He and Kokila, married for 46 years, raised their daughters Swati and Sushama on Staten Island. He is survived by them. His humor, intelligence and generosity were always evident, as were his courage and resilience throughout his health battles of the past year. We will miss him - The Mody Family.

MITCHELL--Mary, died June 6, 2013. Mary is mourned by all of her colleagues at Scholastic where she served as Senior Vice President of Marketing for Scholastic Education. Mary was a human dynamo. Her commitment to improving educational outcomes for underserved children drove her professional efforts and philanthropic work. In both venues, she was an innovator, visionary and marketing genius. Mary was the driving force behind the marketing of all of Scholastic Education's major technology programs, including READ 180, which became the best-known single brand in the K12 education market. As a founding trustee of Girls Prep, Mary was devoted to providing a quality single-sex education for families unable to afford private school. She was instrumental in opening Girls Prep Lower East Side Elementary School in 2005 and helping the program expand to include Middle School in 2009. Mary was a champion talent spotter who mentored innumerable individuals directly and indirectly, and they carry her brilliance onwards. Mary is survived by her parents, Linda and Paul Mitchell, a brother, Jim Mitchell and his wife Kristen, a sister, Patty Gallagher and her husband, Joe, and their three children, Clare, Kevin and Grace Gallagher. Contributions in her memory can be made to Public Preparatory Network, 291 Broadway, Suite 1202, New York, NY 10007. Margery Mayer EVP, Scholastic Inc.

MITCHELL--Mary. On behalf of the Public Prep community, we honor Mary Mitchell for her unwavering dedication, passion for excellence and commitment to strengthening the educational opportunities we offer our students. As a founding Trustee, she challenged us to strive for nothing less than the very best for our students. Girls Prep Lower East Side, Girls Prep Bronx and Public Prep would not exist without Mary's love and relentless focus on student achievement. Her memory and tenacious spirit will continue to inspire us. We will use her memory to strengthen our work together, and will miss her deeply.

MILLMAN--Sidney, passed away June 4th 2013 in Tucson AZ. Husband for 60 1/2 years of wonderful Doris Helen Millman, devoted father of two loving sons, Richard (deceased) and Robert Alan of Basalt CO. Sincere friend to old treasured chums. He was an honest, unpretentious, forthright and loving life partner. Life member of the NYSSPE. Former contractor in the heavy construction business for over 40 years in and around NYC with partner and friend Joseph Bernardo. Installed at the time new and varied approaches of traditional construction techniques. Contracted mainly with the City of New York Department of Public Works, New York City Parks Department, Federal Park Service and Army Department of Construction. Lived with Doris and sons in Belle Harbor for 25 years, then in Woodmere for another 25 years before moving to Arizona to be near sister Nancy and brother-in-law Dr. Edward and son Robert. Service will be private and burial will be in Mt Neboh Cemetery, Flushing NY.

MICHAEL--Dorothy M.,January 10, 1927 - June 4, 2013. Dorothy M. Michael died peacefully on June 4th. Her husband Martin and son David preceded her in death in 1976 and 2006 respectively. Dorothy is survived by her brother Richard and her five remaining children Nancy, Elliot, Dorothea, Cathy and William; grandchildren Ian, Jenna, Rachael, Michael, Marty, Lauren, Melissa, Robert, Brittany, Courtney, William, Kaitlyn and great-grandchildren Ethan, Khloe and Evan. Dorothy loved her skating, sewing, volunteer work and the many family and friends that surrounded her life. Services will be held June 9th at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY at 11am. A memorial gathering will be held immediately following at Valhalla Crossing Restaurant. All donations in memory of Dorothy should be sent to the Alzheimer's Association.
McCARTHY--Cecelia, May 26, She leaves sorrowful sister Sara McCarthy Velez, niece Laura, nephew Daniel; other relatives, friends, colleagues in US and Ireland, who will always cherish her memory.

McCARTHY--Cecelia, lost her battle against breast cancer at age 62. She died on May 26, 2013 in her home in Astoria, NY with her husband, Kirk Bigelow, by her side. She was a beautiful, devoted wife who loved her family deeply. She was also a true, blue unionist who was an indefatigable fighter for workplace justice. She brilliantly represented many public sector employees over the years.

LYNN--Peter C.,on October 4, 2012. Beloved husband of Hildegard, and father of dearest Roxane, who predeceased him. Dr. Lynn was born in 1919, in Vienna, and emigrated to New York in 1940. He co-founded the C.G. Jung Institute here, and practiced Jungian analysis until shortly before his death.

LOWENSTEIN--Hugh Price, of Mountain Lake, Lake Wales, FL and Linville, NC died June 2, 2013. Born 1930 to Katherine and Melvyn Lowenstein. Graduated from Salisbury School, 1949; attended North Carolina State College; served in U.S. Army in Korea; worked at Burlington Industries before starting his Wall Street career at Unterberg, Towbin, L.F. Rothschild and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Director, Bloomberg LP since 1996. Former resident of New York City and Bermuda. Survived by his wife Sandy, daughter Maggie Burnett (Tyler) of San Antonio, TX, son Michael of Mill Valley, CA and daughter Lauren de Lavalette (Philippe) of Paris, France, seven grandchildren, brothers James and Peter and many nephews and nieces. He will be remembered for his kindness, generosity, wisdom, strong love of friends and family, and his amazing sense of humor. He will be greatly missed. Memorial donations may be made to Our Children's Charitable Fund, attention Hugh Price Lowenstein Fund, 150 Ave. B, SE, Winter Haven, Fl. 33880, www.OurChildrens.org.

LONDON--Michael, age 75, beloved husband of Berta, devoted father of Gail (Steven), Laura (Joe) and Nancy (Tony) died on June 6, 2013 in Charlotte, NC. He was adored by his seven grandchildren. Loving brother of Ira D. London (Phyllis). Michael embraced life full tilt and loved with great passion. Donations can be made to LLS.org.

LITTIG--John. The family of John Strickland Littig mourn his recent death during the last week of May. John, 47, died along side his wife, Lynne Rosen, 46, in their Brooklyn apartment. They lost their struggle with depression and so, with profound love, they chose to die together. John, a talented musician, wrote music, sang and played the drums. He studied music and received his B.A. from Long Island University Brooklyn. He performed as Jadex. The music world will miss him. He and Lynne were well-known for their work as counselors and life coaches on WBAI-FM, while apparently dealing with their own personal pain. John is survived by his parents, a brother and sister who request that donations be sent to the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention.

LAUTENBERG--Frank. We mourn the loss of our lifelong friend, Senator Frank Lautenberg. The bond of friendship that Frank shared with Henry and with our entire family spanned 60 years, and his devotion and commitment were critical to the success of ADP. Above all, we are grateful for Frank's outstanding contributions to our nation and we admire the skill, determination and pride with which he represented his beloved State of New Jersey. Frank was proud of his heritage, his immigrant roots and his Paterson soul--and we were blessed to know him. We offer our sincere condolences to the entire Lautenberg family. Marilyn Taub, Judy and Ron Gold, Benay and Steven Taub, Shelley and Ira Taub.

LAUTENBERG--Senator Frank. We mourn the loss of our beloved brother-in-law and Uncle. You were the light of our family and a tower of strength for so many. You will forever be missed and forever remembered. With Love and Great Respect, Lois, Andrew, Olivia, Stephen, Victoria and Alex

LAUTENBERG--Sen. Frank R. The Children's Environmental Health Center (CEHC) at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai is deeply saddened by the passing of U.S. Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, husband of Bonnie and father of Ellen, Nan, Lisa, Joshua, Danielle, and Lara. As Mount Sinai's inaugural Champion of Children honoree, we are truly grateful for Senator Lautenberg's commitment to protecting children and families from unsafe and untested chemicals. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Lautenberg family. Senator Lautenberg will be remembered as a hero in public health for his work protecting the rights of those who are most vulnerable. Philip J. Landrigan, M.D., M.Sc., Director, Children's Environmental Health Center, Department of Preventive Medicine, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

LANE--Ann J.,81. Because our mother knocked down walls of gender oppression, we, her daughters, are blessed to experience the freedom of being who we really are, mostly unencumbered by our culture's misguided values. Our mother taught us that we could do anything we wanted with our lives. She believed in us. She loved us. She fought for us. She was never threatened by our power, our accomplishments, our joy or our sorrow. We will be forever grateful to her for these precious gifts, and we will pass them on. Leslie Nuchow & Joni Lane, Proud daughters of Ann Lane.

LANE--Ann J.,81, Pioneer in Women's History, died peacefully on May 27, with her daughters Leslie Nuchow and Joni Lane at her side. An eminent historian, she was a faculty member at Douglass College, John Jay College, Colgate University, and the University of Virginia. Endowed with a sharp mind and wit, she was a persuasive advocate for feminist and other progressive causes. She is also survived by three grandchildren, her brother Mark Lane, her companion Wayne Roberts, and numerous bereaved friends. Memorial service information: annlanememorial@gmail.com

KNAB--Klaus K.,died on May 25th, 2013, at age 81. Born in Starnberg, Germany, he emigrated to the U.S. with his family at the age of eight. He was a violin prodigy; seminarian; recipient of the Distinguished Service Medal from the Air Force for his service during the Korean conflict; teacher of Latin, Greek and AP English; West Coast sales rep for several publishers, and sales manager for Simon & Schuster. Leaving publishing in 1984, Klaus became a brilliant, self-taught wood-carver, working in shallow relief; a gourd artist, using natural, narrative, and abstract themes, and a wire portraitist of people and animals. His works are in private collections on both coasts. Klaus loved opera and baseball, basketball and track; fine art; puns; chamber music; poetry, history and biography, good food, and the beautiful Oregon coast. A warm and generous friend, a loving husband, father, brother, and grandfather, he was a man of integrity and honesty, incapable of guile. Klaus was diagnosed with esophageal cancer in December, 2012, and faced his inevitable end with characteristic grace, dignity and humor. He showed the rest of us how to do it. He leaves behind his grieving family: his wife of 36 years, Linda Zuckerman; his children, Michael, Thomas and Jude; his granddaughter, Kristi; his sister, Judith, and his brothers, Bernard and Christopher; his friends, and the many people whose lives were made richer for knowing him. Contributions in Klaus's memory may be made to: Compassion & Choices of Oregon, PO Box 6404, Portland, OR 97228, or to the charity of your choice.

KEAVENY--Thomas Leo II, 77 died May 31 in Northbrook, IL. Bridgeport native, Fairfield Prep '53, Marquette '57. US Navy veteran. Beloved husband of Colleen for 53 years, adoring father to Martha Bradt, Tom d. 2002, Chris. Fun grandfather of 12.

JAFFE--Dr. J. Christopher, a 58 year resident of Norwalk, CT, died peacefully at home among his loving, devoted family on Thursday, May 23, 2013. Dr. Jaffe was born in Brooklyn, NY in 1927, the son of Dr. Boris and Ludmila Jaffe. He was married to Marcia Paris Jaffe in 1951. He attended Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and received a B.S. in Chemical Engineering, an M.A. in Theatre from Columbia University and an honorary doctorate from Rensselaer. A pioneer in the field of acoustical design, in 1958, he founded Stagecraft Corporation, which later became Jaffe Acoustics. He has worked on more than 250 performance halls including such prestigious projects as the acoustic renovations of the Hollywood Bowl, Zankel Hall at Carnegie Hall, John F. Kennedy Center, Bass Performance Hall, Severance Hall, Tokyo International Forum and Sala Nezahualcoyotl in Mexico City. He most recently was a Principal Consultant with Acentech in Cambridge, MA. He has taught acoustics at the Juilliard School, City University of New York, and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute where he is the founder of the master's program in architectural acoustics. His honors include the Ellis Island Medal of Honor for Business, the American Institute of Architect's Award for Collaborative Achievement, and election to the RPI Hall of Fame. In 2010, he authored The Acoustics of Performance Halls: Spaces for Music from Carnegie Hall to the Hollywood Bowl. In 2011, he received the Wallace Clement Sabine Medal from the Acoustical Society of America, "for innovative acoustical solutions in performance hall design and for architectural acoustics education." An active outdoorsman who hiked, swam, skied and sailed, he spent his summers in the Adirondack mountains of New York State. He first hiked Mount Marcy at the age of eight with his mother and sister. He is survived by his children Irene, Chris, Jr., and Nina, his daughter-in laws, Trudy and Karen, his grandchildren, Matthew, Courtney and Kayla and his three cats. He was predeceased by his wife, Marcia Paris Jaffe, his parents and sister, Irene. A memorial service in his honor will be held on Thursday, June 27 at 5:00pm at the Norwalk City Hall, 125 East Avenue, Norwalk CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Adirondack Council or to the ASPCA.

HOMES--Herbert Charles. 86, of Bronxville, NY, and Nantucket, MA, beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend, passed away peacefully after a brief illness on Wednesday, June 5th. Born in New York City on November 21, 1926, he was the son of the late Frieda and Charles Homes, 1st generation Americans. He was a graduate of the High School of Music and Art and NYU Business School. He met his wife of 64 years, Shirley Williams Homes, while at Emerson College in Boston. Herb was a WWII Veteran of the Air Force. Through the GI Bill, he attended The School of Radio and Television Technique, and his destiny was set. When offered a one-day job in the Channel 11 WPIX mail room, he used his charms and skills to advance into directing major productions at PIX. He directed and produced "The Ted Steele Show", a live variety show of the 1950's. He also directed and produced the popular WPIX schedule of children's shows i.e. "The Chuck McCann Show", "Bozo the Clown", "Officer Joe Bolton", "Captain Jack McCarthy" and more. After a brief stint at Colpix Records, and weekends directing live news briefs at the RCA Pavilion at the New York World's Fair, Herb joined the early years of Channel 13 WNET in 1967. He ran production in the heyday of public television and was producer/director of the Channel 13 Auction. Over the decades, as his negotiating skills became evident, he was named Director of Labor Relations where he remained until his retirement at 80. Having spent nearly 60 years in television, Herb continued to enjoy summers in his cherished home on Nantucket with his wife and a parade of family and friends. He will be missed more than words can say a finer and funnier man we've never known. He is survived by his wife Shirley Homes, sister Phyllis Lewis, daughter Pat Catchpole, son Peter Homes and his wife Gina, grandchildren Alexandra Catchpole, Jessica, Jeffrey, Judith, Jenn and JR Homes, many nieces and nephews, and a fan club too big to list. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Nantucket Conservation Foundation, www.nantucket-conservation.org. A gathering to share memories of Herb will be held Saturday, June 15th, 1pm at McGrath Funeral Home, 20 Cedar Street in Bronxville, with a nosh to follow.

HOFSTETTER--Mildred, died on June 6, at age 91. Beloved wife of the late Max for 58 years. Cherished mother of Steven Hofstetter, Rose Weiss the late Neil Hofstetter, mother-in-law to Estelle and to Bruce. Dear sister to Joseph and the late Dorothy. Mildred is survived by seven grand-children and 12 great-grandchildren. Please make any donations to The Department of Surgery, NYU Medical Center, 530 1st Ave, Suite 6C, New York, NY 10016 in honor of Mildred Hofstetter. Shiva will be observed at the home of Steven and Estelle Hofstetter.

GOLDSMITH--Hank (Herman) L. The lawyers and staff of Proskauer Rose LLP mourn the untimely passing of our beloved partner, colleague and friend Hank Goldsmith. Hank waged a valiant battle against his illness over the past year, displaying the unyielding optimism he brought to life every day and the toughness that made him such a formidable legal talent. Throughout his struggle, Hank made clear to all of us how deeply he loved his family. Nothing meant more to him than his sons Eric, Jake and Ryan Goldsmith. Indeed, no conversation with Hank was complete until the latest event involving each boy was discussed in depth. He adored his wife Debbie and embraced his stepsons Avery and Ethan Kriss with his characteristic warmth because no disease could ever diminish his immeasurable heart. Hank received a B.A., cum laude, from the State University of New York at Binghamton and earned his J.D., cum laude, from Georgetown University Law Center in 1987. He spent nearly his entire legal career at Proskauer and became a Partner in 1997. A brilliant trial and appellate lawyer, Hank represented clients in the financial services, real estate and entertainment industries. In two of his most significant cases, he represented the recording industry trade group in the copyright case against Napster and acted as lead counsel on an important amicus brief for a number of international copyright holders in the U.S. Supreme Court. Hank loved to teach and countless Proskauer litigation associates developed under his tutelage and guidance. The enormous appreciation that Hank's clients had for his work was perhaps best expressed by the number who surrounded his bedside over these past few weeks. Hank loved the practice of law, the firm and his clients and the feeling was mutual. He had a unique wit that he used as a lawyer to persuade and as a friend and colleague to entertain. No one was quicker with a quip to illustrate a point. And in the tradition of great lawyers who were artists in their off hours, Hank was a skilled guitarist, bass player and singer who performed in several tribute bands most recently The Newspaper Taxis (Beatles), the Carjackers (the Cars) and the Petty Thieves (Tom Petty). Proskauer extends its deepest sympathies to his wife Debbie, sons Eric, Jake and Ryan Goldsmith and stepsons Avery and Ethan Kriss. Hank and Debbie showed us all the power of love and devotion, inspiring hope in the human condition at a time when we might otherwise have only felt grief. Hank never faltered or despaired despite the challenges he faced. That was a gift to his friends and colleagues and, most of all, his family. Joseph M. Leccese Chairman Proskauer Rose LLP

GOLDBERG--Philip, M.D.,86. Died on May 29, 2013. Devoted husband of Ann. Loving father of Andrew (Dina), Ruth (Philippe) and Michael (Michelle). Dear grandfather of Samuel, Amalya Meira, Elie, Emma, Ilan, Jacob, Etan and Adam. Born in Reading, England July 20 1927 he emigrated to the U.S. in 1958 and practiced psychiatry on Long Island until his last illness. We mourn his loss and celebrate his long productive life.

GELFMAN--Stanley, passed away on June 4, 2013, beloved husband of Judge Sondra Miller, loving brother of Jordan Gelfman, devoted father of Sari and Debra, proud grandfather of Zachary, and loving stepfather of David, Seth, Miriam and Wendy. Stanley was a talented engineer/inventor admired and loved by his loyal staff at Shane Industries and by the many friends he accumulated over the years. His extraordinary aides, Joel, Margaret, Andrea and Patience will never be forgotten. A skilled pilot, war veteran, swimmer, skier, dancer and workaholic, Stanley's feisty, lovable, warm personality will be missed by his many friends, colleagues and family. Funeral Service was Friday at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc. 2080 Boston Post Road Larchmont, NY 10538. Shiva will be held at the home of Judge Sondra Miller in Larchmont Today and Monday from 3pm until 7pm. Please send contributions in lieu of flowers to the Alzheimer's Association.

FRIEDMAN--David Lawrence, on June 1, 2013 in Grenada, West Indies. Beloved son of Judith Friedman and the late Sandor Friedman. Dear Brother of Peter. Service Sunday, 2pm at "The Riverside", 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

FRIED--Sylvia. Jeanette and I have lost a great friend. Sylvia was the pediatrician for our three children. She and Cy, her recently departed husband, were great role models in our community. They will never be forgotten. Jeanette & Herb Spiegel

FOLEY--Dorothy E. On May 25th, my role in life changed from mother, grandmother, sister, aunt and friend to guardian angel. A memorial mass to celebrate Dorothy's life will be held at Mohonk Mountain House, New Paltz, NY., June 10th at noon. Dorothy has requested an act of kindness be offered up in her memory.

FEINGOLD--Adele, 97, 1915 - May 22, 2013, Scottsdale, AZ. Preceded by husband Bill Feingold and daughter Cynthia Gwin. She leaves daughters Kathy Hotchner, Virginia Clark, granddaughters Brandy Hotchner-Syllaba, Jennifer Hotchner and two grandsons.

EIDUS--Arnold. World famous violinist. Winner of the International Jacques Thibaud Award. Predeceased by wife Doris and daughter Ilicia. Father of Robert, grandfather of Jonah, Rafi and Sam. Brother of Trudy and Adele. His music will always remain an inspiration.

EICHLER--Peter, 76, of Scottsdale, AZ passed away on April 2, 2013. He is survived by his cherished wife of 47 years, Wendie, son David and beloved daughter-in-law Diane. Peter graduated from the Peddie School, Wesleyan University and Columbia Law School. He practiced Intellectual Property law for 51 years, with firms in NY, CA and AZ.
EDENS--Joseph Cook, Jr.,85, of The Plains, Virginia died on June 3, 2013. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, June 26 at 1:00 pm at Grace Episcopal Church in The Plains, Virginia.

DAVIS--Barbara E.,wife of the late Dr. Lowell B. Davis, mother of Jonathan Davis, M.D., Susan Davis, Ph.D., and Adam Davis, M.D., grandmother to Emma and Abigail Kingsberg, Rebekah Davis, Eliza and Rachel Davis, sister of Joel Spiro, M.D. and longtime fiance of Howard Lewis, passed away May 25, 2013, at the age of 79. Barbara will always be remembered for her indomitable will to live, her courage, her deep love of family and friends and her exquisite sense of style and design. Donations in her memory can be made to the New York University - Langone Medical Center Lung Cancer Research Fund or the Jewish National Fund. We will always keep her in our hearts.

CUMMINGS--Ann Marie. (1923-2013). Ann Marie Cummings of Brooklyn, NY; Tarrytown, NY; Westerly, RI and Westmore, VT; born on Sunday May 22, 1932 to the late Julia Fogarty Cummings and John Cummings, passed away June 5, 2013. As an educator for the New York City Board of Education, Ann was passionate about making a difference in the lives of students and colleagues. Her work of many years has touched many lives. As her nephew-in-law, Matthew Kratz, recently wrote "Ann is a blessing to everyone she meets, and an inspiration to all on how to live, celebrate and love." Those she leaves behind will continue to embrace the legacy of her joy of life. She was preceded in death by her brother James Cummings and her nephew Peter Murphy. She is survived by her sister Julia Cummings Murphy, her dear friend Dolores Grieco, her sister-in-law Marylou Cummings, ten nieces and nephews, eleven grand-nieces and nephews, and lifelong friends. A superlative story teller, a kind, generous and thoughtful person, some of her favorite things included: children, music, any celebration, Willoughby Lake, and time spent laughing with loved ones. Ann will be dearly missed. Friends may call from 1-4pm on Monday June 10, 2013 at the Curtis-Britch-Converse-Rushford Funeral Home, 12 Elm Street, Barton, VT. Funeral services will be held at 11:00am on Tuesday, June 11, 2013 at St. Paul's Catholic Church in Barton, VT, with the Rev. Patrick Forman celebrating a mass of Christian burial. Interment will follow in Lakeview Cemetery, Westmore, VT. Should friends desire, contributions in her memory may be made to the St. Francis Breadline, 135 West 31st Street, NY, NY 10001. On-line condolences may be sent to the family through the funeral home website at: www.curtis-britch.com.

COONEY--Martha, June 2, 2013 after a courageous battle with cancer, with her husband Larry Kirschenbaum and son Jonathan Kirschenbaum by her side. Her death leaves a tremendous void in their hearts and those of her family, many friends and colleagues, who will forever remember her sincerity, strong work ethic, and infectious humor.

COHEN--Steven M.,56 years old, died on June 5th, 2013. Beloved father of Brandon and Spencer. Devoted son of Rita Cohen and the late Marty. Loving brother of Jason and Diane and Alan and Susan. Services: Sunday, 2pm at Riverside Nassau-North Chapels of Great Neck.

CLAYTON--William L.,of Green Village, NJ, passed away at home on June 7, 2013. He was 83 years old. Born in Tenafly, NJ, Mr. Clayton lived most of his life in Short Hills, NJ. Mr. Clayton attended LaSalle Military Academy. He graduated from Lehigh University in 1951 and later attended graduate school at New York University. He proudly served his country in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War. Mr. Clayton joined E.F. Hutton's first training class in 1954. He became Vice President in 1964, advancing to Executive Vice President and a member of E.F. Hutton's Board of Directors. During his 38 years at E.F. Hutton, Mr. Clayton was the founder of Hutton Capital Management, a highly successful group that managed institutional and high net worth client assets. He was also known for the creation of the ad campaign, "When E.F. Hutton talks, people listen." In his last years at E.F. Hutton, he was instrumental in the design and construction of E.F. Hutton's new headquarters building at 31 West 52nd St., in New York. Mr. Clayton retired from Hutton's successor company, Morgan Stanley, in 2009, following a stellar 55-year career on Wall Street. Mr. Clayton's devotion to Lehigh University was unwavering. He served as member of the Board of Trustees for over 34 years and was a major fundraiser throughout his tenure. In 1984, he received the "L-in-Life" award for his service to the University. In 1987, Lehigh University awarded Mr. Clayton an Honorary L.L.D. degree. In addition, Mr. Clayton was a long-standing member of the Board of Directors of Stabler Companies, Inc. and the Standard Dredging Corp. Mr. Clayton also served on the Board of Trustees of Oak Knoll School in Summit, NJ; Blair Academy in Blairstown, NJ; and New Eyes for The Needy in Short Hills, NJ. In 1988, Mr. Clayton became a Knight in the Sovereign Order of Malta, an organization dedicated to the care of the sick and the poor. He was a long-time member of Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, NJ. Mr. Clayton was the loving husband of Carol, whom he married in 1951, and the devoted father of Andrew Clayton; Robin (William) Roach; Kathleen (David) Veshosky; Kevin (Lisa) Clayton, Susan (Glenn) Starkman; and Christopher (Carolyn) Clayton. He took great joy in his grandchildren: Meghan and Brendan Roach; Ryan, Todd, and Lauren Haselton; Jessica (Brian) Hess; Patrick and Grace Clayton; Alex, Taylor, and Chelsea Starkman; Emma and William Clayton; and his great-granddaughter, Georgia Anne Hess. Mr. Clayton is also survived by his beloved sister, Grace Folker of Portland, Maine and pre-deceased by his brother, Walter Clayton of Sarasota, Florida. In addition, he leaves behind his dedicated caretaker, Yvette Douglas. Friends and relatives may pay their respects on Tuesday, June 11, 2013 from 2:00-4:00pm and 7:00-9:00pm at Burroughs, Kohr & Dangler Funeral Home, 106 Main Street, Madison, NJ. A Roman Catholic funeral mass will be held at 11:00am on Wednesday, June 12, 2013 at Church of Christ the King, 16 Blue Mill Road, New Vernon, NJ. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Carol and William L. Clayton Scholarship Fund, Lehigh University, 27 Alumni Memorial Drive West, Bethlehem, PA 18015.

BURKHART--Richard "Dick," 1931-2013, a Korean War Navy Corpsman, died peacefully on Memorial Day after a long battle with congestive heart failure, surrounded by family and friends. His extensive travels took him around the world; however he liked nothing better than sailing on the crystal clear waters of Sebago Lake, ME. He is survived by his wife Vicky and her sons John and Tom Greene and his five sons with first wife Fay: Richard II, George, Kyle, Jay and David; as well as ten grandchildren and his sister, Marilyn "Cookie" Underwood. Preceded in death by infant son Montgomery.

BROOK--Lester, 97 years old, passed on June 7, 2013. Beloved husband of Gloria. Devoted father of Richard and Lisa. Cherished grandfather of Alex and great-grandfather of Cameron. A WWII veteran, successful and well respected real estate developer. A perfect gentleman. Services 12 noon Sunday at Riverside Chapels of Great Neck.

BRODY--Bernie, passed away on June 2, 2013 at age 97. Predeceased by the love of his life Edie cherished and loved by daughters Jane and Amy their spouses Michael and Steven grandchildren great-grandchildren sister Rhoda daughter Renee (Richard) many nieces nephews cousins and dear friends. A celebration of life will take place on LI this August. Daddy we love you we will miss you and as you always would say "Good Night & Good Luck"

BRODY--Bernard. Deepest condolences to the Brody- Baker- Mercurio families on their great loss. We love you and miss you, Bernie, and the wonderful memories we made together during the summers at the Sandcastle. Nat and Marlene Blumberg

BING--Elisabeth G. Elisabeth G. "Betsy" Bing of New York and Philadelphia, died accidentally, June 1, 2013. She is survived by loving daughter, Virginia Bing; former companion, John Cooney; his children, Kevin, Mary and Carol Cooney; former husband, Alexander Bing III; brother, John Githens (Denver). 38-year employee of The Metropolitan Museum of Art; volunteer of several organizations; graduate of Brown University and German Town Friends (Philadelphia). She will be greatly missed by her many friends and colleagues. Memorial Service and reception: 11am, June 14, Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Ave and 90th St., NY, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Metropolitan Museum of Art.
AXELROD--Dorothy, died on May 29, 2013. Mother of Judy and Stephanie, and a grandmother and great-grandmother. We will forever miss you.

ASKLAR--Drake, 47, June 1, 2013, died peacefully at home of cancer. Design VP at Baum-Essex; beloved husband of Joe Raccuglia, Manhattan; son of Lois and Edward, Torrington, CT; brother of Mark and Heidi; uncle of Adam, Eric and Nicole. He brought joy, happiness and love to all he touched. Private memorial service. Donations in his honor to: https://supportbethisrael.org/support-us/tributememorial

ARNOLD--Martin, on June 4th, 2013. Devoted father of Mark and his wife Ginny, and Christopher. Loving brother of William. Cherished grandfather of Martin and Max. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Memorial visitation Sunday, June 16, 2013 2-5 and 7-9pm and Frank E Campbell 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The New York Times Gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund.

ARMITAGE--John L.,96, of Essex, CT, formerly of Madison, NJ and Morris Plains, NJ died peacefully on May 14, 2013. A graduate of the 1938 class of Princeton, he wed Karen Marie de Chambaud Conze on September 22, 1939 and served as President of John L . Armitage & Co from 1949 - 1982 and President and Chairman of the National Paint and Coatings Association. He is survived by his children, Adra Carr of Old Saybrook, CT, Spencer Leineweber of Honolulu, HI, Norman Armitage of Nashville, TN, Amelia Armitage of Ridgefield, CT, twelve grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. His life will be celebrated by his family and close friends in a service Sunday, June 23, 2013 at the First Congregational Church in Essex at 1:00. In memory, the family requests donations be made to the Weiss Hospice Unit, Middlesex Hospital, Office of Philanthropy, 28 Crescent Street, Middletown, CT 06457.

APRUZZI--Gene, died peacefully at home in Fort Lauderdale, FL on May 30, 2013 after a lingering illness, with his wife Gail and daughter Claire at his bedside to say goodbye and wish him Godspeed. Gene was born February 16, 1934 in Bari, Italy, the second son of General Francesco Apruzzi and Giulia Tritto Apruzzi. He was educated at University of Bari in Italy and graduated with a combined doctoral degree in Finance and Economics. He immigrated to the United States in 1956 and took graduate courses at New York University. He was later employed by Cyrus J. Lawrence and Sons, a "carriage trade" Member of the New York Stock Exchange. He rose to partner and was subsequently instrumental in the conversion and recapitalization of the partnership to Cyrus J. Lawrence Incorporated in preparation for "May Day" in 1975. Gene functioned as Executive Vice President-Operations and Administration and remained in that capacity after the company was sold to Morgan Grenfell, PLC in 1986. He retired in 1994 from Deutsche Bank AG after it completed its acquisition of Morgan Grenfell. Gene was active in the affairs of the securities industry, was a member of the Arbitration Panels of both the New York Stock Exchange and the National Association of Securities Dealers, and a member of the NASD District No. 12 Committee. He was a member of the Downtown Athletic Club, resided for many years in Manhasset and was a longtime member of the Plandome Country Club. He later lived in Manhattan for a few years prior to his retirement. He is survived by his wife Gail, daughter Claire, his sister-in-law, niece and nephew. He was predeceased by his brother Angelo and his first wife Ida. A Memorial Mass was held at St. Sebastian Catholic Church, Fort Lauderdale on Monday, June 3, 2013. Gene's ashes will be interred at sea at the convenience of the family. Memorial contributions may be made in his name to the American Diabetes Association, PO Box 11454, Alexandria, VA 22312.
