TURIM--Ruth Kessler, 99. The treasure of our family; loving, caring, honest and our hero. passed on to a place where a mind like hers will still knock their socks off (May 31, 2013.) Eldest daughter of Harry and Yetta (Feigenbaum) Kessler: Predeceased by her beloved husband Arthur (Icky), sweet son Irwin, dear brother Daniel, and loving sister Irma. Sister to Pearl. A life long resident of Brooklyn and then Great Neck, NY. She leaves a family that celebrates her life - but will always miss her - Children: Frances Zeitler, Linda and Michael Krasner, Grandchildren: Kenneth and Marcie Zeitler, Bracha Leah Zeitler, Alissa and Jay Maizes, and 10 great-grandchildren: Andrew, Ariel, Steven, Moriah, Ezra, Lauren, Rebekah, Zachary, Amital, and Joshua, and nieces and nephews who love and miss her. A dedicated and caring teacher and Assistant Principal in the NYC school system. Ruth attained her undergraduate (dean's list) and two masters degrees at Brooklyn College. Donations: Ruth Turim Fund at Brooklyn College. (Endowed fund to annually aid students in need and continue in perpetuity). 718-951-5074, 2900 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11210. brooklyncollegefoundation.org

SULLIVAN--Most Rev. Joseph M.,retired auxiliary Bishop of the Diocese of Brooklyn, passed away on June 7th due to injuries sustained in a car accident. He is survived by his sisters Margaret White (John), Betty Haggerty (Joseph) and Frances Brennan (John); brothers John (Bridie), Ralph (Pat), Peter (Kathleen) and predeceased by brothers Thomas (Anne), Gerard (Frances) William (Ursula), and Richard (Barbara). Also survived by 40 nieces and nephews and 73 grand-nieces and nephews. He will be waked at McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, Third Ave at 97th st. Brooklyn on Monday 2-5pm and 7-9pm and Tuesday 2-5pm. A Mass of Transferal will be celebrated at Our Lady of Hope, Middle Village at 7:30pm on Tuesday. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Catholic Charities of Brooklyn and Queens.

MITCHELL--Mary. On behalf of the Public Prep community, we honor Mary Mitchell for her unwavering dedication, passion for excellence and commitment to strengthening the educational opportunities we offer our students. As a founding Trustee, she challenged us to strive for nothing less than the very best for our students. Girls Prep Lower East Side, Girls Prep Bronx and Public Prep would not exist without Mary's love and relentless focus on student achievement. Her memory and tenacious spirit will continue to inspire us. We will use her memory to strengthen our work together, and will miss her deeply.

CLAYTON--William L.,of Green Village, NJ, passed away at home on June 7, 2013. He was 83 years old. Born in Tenafly, NJ, Mr. Clayton lived most of his life in Short Hills, NJ. Mr. Clayton attended LaSalle Military Academy. He graduated from Lehigh University in 1951 and later attended graduate school at New York University. He proudly served his country in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War. Mr. Clayton joined E.F. Hutton's first training class in 1954. He became Vice President in 1964, advancing to Executive Vice President and a member of E.F. Hutton's Board of Directors. During his 38 years at E.F. Hutton, Mr. Clayton was the founder of Hutton Capital Management, a highly successful group that managed institutional and high net worth client assets. He was also known for the creation of the ad campaign, "When E.F. Hutton talks, people listen." In his last years at E.F. Hutton, he was instrumental in the design and construction of E.F. Hutton's new headquarters building at 31 West 52nd St., in New York. Mr. Clayton retired from Hutton's successor company, Morgan Stanley, in 2009, following a stellar 55-year career on Wall Street. Mr. Clayton's devotion to Lehigh University was unwavering. He served as member of the Board of Trustees for over 34 years and was a major fundraiser throughout his tenure. In 1984, he received the "L-in-Life" award for his service to the University. In 1987, Lehigh University awarded Mr. Clayton an Honorary L.L.D. degree. In addition, Mr. Clayton was a long-standing member of the Board of Directors of Stabler Companies, Inc. and the Standard Dredging Corp. Mr. Clayton also served on the Board of Trustees of Oak Knoll School in Summit, NJ; Blair Academy in Blairstown, NJ; and New Eyes for The Needy in Short Hills, NJ. In 1988, Mr. Clayton became a Knight in the Sovereign Order of Malta, an organization dedicated to the care of the sick and the poor. He was a long-time member of Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, NJ. Mr. Clayton was the loving husband of Carol, whom he married in 1951, and the devoted father of Andrew Clayton; Robin (William) Roach; Kathleen (David) Veshosky; Kevin (Lisa) Clayton, Susan (Glenn) Starkman; and Christopher (Carolyn) Clayton. He took great joy in his grandchildren: Meghan and Brendan Roach; Ryan, Todd, and Lauren Haselton; Jessica (Brian) Hess; Patrick and Grace Clayton; Alex, Taylor, and Chelsea Starkman; Emma and William Clayton; and his great-granddaughter, Georgia Anne Hess. Mr. Clayton is also survived by his beloved sister, Grace Folker of Portland, Maine and pre-deceased by his brother, Walter Clayton of Sarasota, Florida. In addition, he leaves behind his dedicated caretaker, Yvette Douglas. Friends and relatives may pay their respects on Tuesday, June 11, 2013 from 2:00-4:00pm and 7:00-9:00pm at Burroughs, Kohr & Dangler Funeral Home, 106 Main Street, Madison, NJ. A Roman Catholic funeral mass will be held at 11:00am on Wednesday, June 12, 2013 at Church of Christ the King, 16 Blue Mill Road, New Vernon, NJ. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Carol and William L. Clayton Scholarship Fund, Lehigh University, 27 Alumni Memorial Drive West, Bethlehem, PA 18015.

SULLIVAN--Most Rev. Joseph M. The board and staff of United Hospital Fund are deeply saddened by the death of our long-time board member and wonderful friend. His deep commitment to the health and welfare of New Yorkers, particularly the most vulnerable, and his open-hearted optimism were a source of strength and inspiration for all who knew him. His caring presence, unwavering wisdom, great good humor, and compassion set him apart as a leader, colleague, and friend. We have lost an extraordinarily good man, whose hope and work for a better, more caring world has improved the lives of many and set a wonderful example for all of us. J. Barclay Collins II, Chairman James R. Tallon, Jr., President

SULLIVAN--Bishop Joseph. The Board and Staff of the Fund for the City of New York and the members of the Fund's Sloan Public Service Awards Selection Panel mourn the loss of Bishop Joseph M. Sullivan. A former member of the Fund's Board of Directors, Bishop Sullivan has for the past 20 years served as Chairman of the Fund's Sloan Public Service Awards Selection Panel. In his remarks each year about the winners at their work-place ceremonies and at the city-wide celebration at Cooper Union, he spoke eloquently about the meaning of public service and those special qualities that enable these individuals to serve the public over decades with unfailing skill, dedication and integrity and with no thought of personal reward. In these speeches, he was also describing himself. We shall miss him. Vaughn Williams, Board Chair Mary McCormick, President

SULLIVAN--Most Rev. Joseph M. Greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) and New York's entire health care community deeply mourn the loss of Retired Auxiliary Bishop of the Diocese of Brooklyn Joseph Sullivan. "Bishop Joe," as he was affectionately known, was a dear friend, mentor, and stalwart health care leader who devoted his life to the poorest and neediest. Among his many positions across a remarkable career were executive director of Catholic Charities of Brooklyn and Queens, chairman of the national Catholic Health Association, chairman of Fidelis, and member of the U.S. bishops' Task Force on Health Care. He was also essential to the development of St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers. Bishop Sullivan's life of humble service was defined by his wit, charm, and steadfast principles. He made a true difference in countless lives. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family and many friends. James Kaskie, Chairman Kenneth E. Raske, President GNYHA

SULLIVAN--Most Reverend Joseph M. With great sadness, we mourn the loss of Most Reverend Joseph M. Sullivan, who served as a member of the Board of Directors of Fidelis Care New York for the past 17 years. He retired as Board Chairman in December 2011 after serving in that capacity for 15 years, but continued to remain on the Board as a faithful steward and colleague. With gratitude for God's blessings and grace and with typical humility, he described his service on the Board as positive, fulfilling, and a "happy chapter in his life." As Chairman from the health plan's earliest days, Bishop Sullivan was universally recognized as the one who had the foresight to see what Fidelis Care could be and what it could become as a unique expression of the healing ministry of the Catholic Church. With ever-present passion, warmth and wit, he maintained a clear focus throughout his leadership. He took the challenges and complications inherent in managed care and spun them into a compelling vision where the Church's commitment to social justice was continuously given new outlets and opportunities for serving the poor, pursuing the greater good, and reflecting the love of Jesus. By colleagues and friends, he was referred to as "a hard worker who labored in the Lord's vineyard" and a "star of the priesthood" who possessed the unique ability to encourage lively discourse and debate, and provide cogent and effective reflections that led to consensus while never wavering from his values or his innate sense of kindness. All facets of his life were integrated into one unified personality and presence that was respected, admired, and revered by all. The hearts of the greatest servants are forged by an uncommon passion to instill hope while walking side by side with those most in need. Bishop Sullivan walked this walk for a lifetime, and we are proud and blessed to have joined him along the way. He is truly irreplaceable, and will be greatly missed. The Board and Staff of Fidelis Care New York

SULLIVAN--Bishop Joe. The Board and staff of Welfare Research, Inc. mark with great sadness the passing of our former chair and board member emeritus, Bishop Joe Sullivan. For many decades he led this organization with wisdom, dedication, and compassion. He will be greatly missed.

SASS--Henry, 84 years old, passed on June 8, 2013. He is survived by his devoted wife of 59 years, Arlene. Cherished father of Alison, Robert (Sharon) and Steven (Garen). Dear brother to Irving (deceased) and Sidney. Adored grandfather to Daniel, Benjamin, Alec and Sydney. He was the best of the best and we will miss him forever.

SINGER--Ellen, (January, 31st, 1953 - June 9th, 2013) of Youngsville, NY (formerly of New York City and Tulsa, OK). Adored wife of Don Simkin and mother of Vincent Moses Simkin. Beloved sister of Sandra Anderson, George Singer, Mark Singer, Stephen Singer, sister-in-law of Doug and Jane Smith, David Anderson, Rita Singer, and Michel Boynton, and cousin and soul sister of Amy Singer. Admired for her beauty, wit, generosity, and her courage and humility in the face of adversity. Ellen loved learning and teaching, and she strove to live a righteous Jewish life. Contributions may be made to ATZUM Justice Works or TheWomen.org, payable to Livingston Manor Community Ctr, P.O. Box 1096 Livingston Manor, NY 12758.

RICHMAN--Marvin, 78, passed away on June 8, 2013. Beloved husband of Rochelle, devoted father of Barry, Eric and Hayley and proud and inspirational grandfather to Blake, Margaux, Ryan, Adam and Bennett. He was born in New York City and traveled the world with his family in service of his country. Marvin had a long and distinguished military career, rising to the level of Lt. Colonel in the United States Air Force and then serving in senior levels of U.S. intelligence agencies. Later he returned with his family to settle on Long Island, where he continued his pioneering work in satellite imaging. Marvin was a warm, charming and honest person who touched all those who were fortunate enough to know him. He will be deeply missed by his friends and family. Shiva will be held at the home of his wife Rochelle Richman in Melville on Tuesday between 3pm and 7pm, and at the home of his daughter Hayley Boesky in Manhattan on Wednesday between 4pm and 8pm. Charitable donations in memory of Marvin can made to Memorial Sloan- Kettering Hospital, New York City, by calling 866-815-9501.

RAYMES--Frederick, 84 of Sarasota, Florida, formerly of Huntington, New York died on June 8, 2013. He was a survivor of The Holocaust and his life story is chronicled in a published memoire. Former Vice President of Grumman International Bethpage, New York. Beloved husband of Lydia Raymes. Loving husband of the late Diane Raymes. Cherished father, grandfather and great-grandfather. The family suggests donations to the Tampa Holocaust Museum, 55 5th St. S, St. Petersburg, FL 33701. 727-820-0100. For the full obituary visit: www.IJMorrisDixHills.com

MARGOLIN--Florence. American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev is deeply saddened by the passing of Florence Margolin. She and her husband, Efraim, have been ardent supporters of the city of Beer-Sheva and Ben-Gurion University for many years. We extend our sincerest condolences to Efraim and the Margolin family and all who mourn her loss. Lloyd Goldman, President Doron Krakow, Executive Vice President Kevin Leopold, Executive DirectorNortheast

MARGOLIN--Florence. The extended family of friends, supporters and dependents of Colel Chabad Lubavitch mourn the passing of our dear friend and longtime supporter, Florence Margolin. Our hearts go out to her beloved husband, Efraim Margolin. May the L-rd comfort you amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arthur Luxenberg, Chairman United Soup Kitchens of Colel Chabad, Rabbi Sholom Duchman, Dir.

MARGOLIN--Florence, passed away on June 9, 2013. A supporter of Technion University-Haifa, Ben-Gurion University, B'nai Zion Hospital, Hadassah, Jewish National Fund, Colel Chabad, Be'er Sheva City. Survived by her beloved husband, Efraim, son, David, and brother, Irving Rapaport. Services Wednesday, June 12 at 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

LOTTMAN--Eileen, age 85, passed away at home in New York on June 7. Born in Minneapolis, she grew up in Sioux City, Iowa, and attended the University of Iowa Writers Workshop. She began her career in New York with publicist Lois Smith, becoming publicity director and then editor at major publishing houses including Putnam, Dell, and Bantam before turning to writing full-time. Eileen was the author of 23 novels including After the Wind (1979), The Brahmins (1982), and She and I (1991). A lifelong advocate for free speech and social justice, she also loved animals and supported animal rights. Her husband of more than 40 years, noted film editor Evan Lottman, and daughter Jessica Lottman both predeceased her; she is survived by loving friends who feel deeply the loss of her humor, honesty and companionship. Memorial on Friday, June 14, 3pm, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St. at Amsterdam Ave., New York. No flowers; donations welcome to any charity helping animals.

KRAMER--Arnold Guy "Arnie", age 82, formerly of Fleetwood, Mount Vernon NY on June 7, 2013. Husband of the late Ann Cohn Kramer and father of Judith G. "Judy" Kramer and the late Eric "Ricky" Kramer. Brother of Jessica Friedlander. For service information, please call Levine Chapels, Brookline, MA 617-277-8300.

KANTOR--Martin E. died peacefully in his sleep on June 10. He was 91. His unerring sense of direction guided an extraordinary life in business, philanthropy and travel, and a passionate involvement in learning. He was a discerning collector and patron of the arts and served on the boards of major museums. His belief in humanitarian values led to the founding of "A World of Difference," a program of the Anti-Defamation League, providing training in diversity and tolerance to teachers throughout the United States and Europe. He is survived by his wife of 68 years, Lucille; his sister, Ruth Shir, and brother, Howard; sons Jonathan (Barbara), Joshua, and Earle (Anne); and his six grandchildren Joseph (Melanie), Eli, Luke, Adam, Samuel and Kyla. Visitors are welcome at his home on Wednesday and Thursday, June 12 and 13, 3-5pm and 7-9:30pm. Donations may be made to North Shore Child and Family Guidance Center, 480 Old Westbury Rd., Roslyn Heights, NY 11577.

HAWKINS--Helen Foley, passed away peacefully on June 6, 2013 of respiratory failure. She was 89 years old. Mrs. Hawkins lived a full life complete with devotion to God and her family. She is survived by her brother John James Foley, her children Katherine Hawkins, Howard R. Hawkins, Jr., Rosemary Hawkins and Suzanne Hawkins; her daughter-in-law Linda Whitmarsh, her son-in-law Paul Chrzanowski; her grandchildren Eric and Brian Hawkins, her granddaughter-in-law Sarah Williams Hawkins, her grandsons Terence and Jeffrey Gibbons, her great-grandson Henry Hawkins and numerous nieces and nephews. Mrs. Hawkins and her husband, Howard R. Hawkins, who passed away in 2003, traveled the world in connection with his extensive work in global communications. Helen will be remembered as an intelligent, energetic and loving person who enriched the lives of all who were lucky enough to know her. Visiting hours will be held on June 14, 2013 at the Gallagher Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street in Greenwich, CT from 3pm to 7pm and the funeral will be held at St. Michael's Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT on June 15th at 10am. Donations may be made to Catholic Relief Services.

BROOKS--Russell E.,74 years old, died June 8, 2013. Survived by his devoted wife, Patricia, loving children Sarah (Erik Gunderson) and Samuel (Rebeccah), and cherished grandchildren, Max and Ben Gunderson, and Annabelle and William Brooks. Russell graduated from Dartmouth College, Class of 1960, and Columbia Law School, Class of 1963. He practiced litigation for 36 years at Milbank, Tweed, Hadley and McCloy and was a fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. Services were private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Dartmouth College or Columbia Law School.

BENHAM--Isabel Hamilton. Isabel Benham died May 18, 2013 in her New York City apartment, at age 103, after an exceptional life. She was one of the first women partners of a Wall Street brokerage firm, one of the first women to hold a seat on the New York Stock Exchange, and an expert on railways and railroad finance. Her career on Wall Street extended from 1931 to 1992, when she retired as President of Printon Kane Research. She graduated from Bryn Mawr College in 1931 with honors in economics. Her first job was with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in 1932, and in 1934 she joined RW Pressprich & Co, a investment bond firm, as a statistician, becoming a partner in 1964. As her career advanced, she become widely known and respected as a financial expert on railroads, and was profiled in Forbes Magazine in 1987 as "Madam Railroad." She was highly regarded for her detailed research on railroads and also for actually riding the rails and inspecting facilities.

ARYE--Leonard, passed away peacefully June 9, 2013. Loving and adored husband of the late Leonora, and Christa Saffran; father of Larry, Lowell and Lane; father-in-law to Linda and Lecia and grandfather to Mollie, Kai, and Nika. He was a gifted trial lawyer who provided wit and humor both in his work and to his family and friends. Funeral at 11:30am Tuesday, June 11, Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck.

VanVORT--Philip, on June 11, 2013. Devoted husband of Ruth (Toffel Salles) and the late Madelon (Kaplan). Loving father of Gretchen Miller, Jennifer VanVort and Heidi Stern. Beloved grandfather of Courtney, Max, Sarah, Jason, Jake, Mia, Josh and Hannah. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Services on June 12, 2013 at 2pm in the Menorah Chapels at Millburn.

TITUS--James, T.,age 69, of Lehigh Acres, Florida passed away peacefully with his loving family at his side on Saturday, June 1, 2013 following a recent illness. He was born on September 3, 1943 in Queens, New York, the proud son of Mabel (Sullivan) and Thomas Titus. James served his country in the United States Navy onboard the Guided Missile Cruiser USS Albany (CG-10). James leaves to cherish his loving memory his wife Patricia (Anastasio); son Patrick and daughter-in-law Melissa; grandaughter Paige and grandson Jake. A Memorial Gathering will be held from 6-8pm on Tuesday, June 11, 2013 in the chapel at Anderson-Patterson Cremation and Funeral Services, 2701 Lee Boulevard, Lehigh Acres, Florida 33971, (239) 368-7080. An honor guard will conduct memorial exercises at 7:30pm in recognition of his military service. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10am the following morning, Wednesday, June 12, 2013 at Saint Raphael's Catholic Church, 2514 Lee Boulevard, Lehigh Acres, Florida 33971. Those who wish to offer condolences to the family at this difficult time are urged to visit James' memorial webpage at www.andersonpatterson.com and sign the guestbook.

SUTTON--Al (Abraham). The trustees, physicians and staff of Maimonides Medical Center mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague and friend. A member of the Maimonides Board of Trustees since 1983, Al was a devoted family man, successful businessman and generous supporter of the hospital and its mission. His legacy includes the dedication of a hospital chapel to his parents' memory, and publishing The Aristocrat, a tribute to the inspiring life of his father, Hillel Menashe Sutton. Al was a kind and gentle person who did not seek recognition for his many good deeds, and he will be deeply missed by all those whose lives he touched. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Paulette, and the entire Sutton family. Martin D. Payson, Chairman Pamela S. Brier, President & CEO Maimonides Medical Center

SULLIVAN--Bishop Joseph. The Board and Staff of the Fund for the City of New York and the members of the Fund's Sloan Public Service Awards Selection Panel mourn the loss of Bishop Joseph M. Sullivan. A former member of the Fund's Board of Directors, Bishop Sullivan has for the past 20 years served as Chairman of the Fund's Sloan Public Service Awards Selection Panel. In his remarks each year about the winners at their work-place ceremonies and at the city-wide celebration at Cooper Union, he spoke eloquently about the meaning of public service and those special qualities that enable these individuals to serve the public over decades with unfailing skill, dedication and integrity and with no thought of personal reward. In these speeches, he was also describing himself. We shall miss him. Vaughn Williams, Board Chair Mary McCormick, President

SULLIVAN--Most Rev. Joseph M. The board of directors and staff of the Milbank Memorial Fund mourn the passing of our beloved colleague, Bishop Joseph M. Sullivan. He lived his profound commitment to the overwhelming importance of preventing and ameliorating suffering. As a director of the Fund for the past 15 years, Joe has been an exemplar, a mentor, and a friend. He brought wisdom and compassion to our work of helping to apply the best available evidence to policy and practice for maintaining and improving health. Joe contributed enormously to human betterment in the city, the state and the nation. He blended spirituality with commitment to people and institutions; and did it with wit, charm, analytical precision, and--when persuaded to use it--a beautiful singing voice. Samuel L. "Tony" Milbank Chairman, Milbank Memorial Fund

SHABEL--Frances, 101 of Albany, NY former Queens resident on June 10, 2013. Wife of the late Philip. Mother of Henda (Samuel) Strasser. Loving grandmother, greatgrandmother, sister-in-law and aunt. Predeceased by daughter, Jewele Shabel. Services, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Queens, NY on Wednesday, June 11, 2013 at 11:00am. Services by Levine Memorial Chapel Albany, NY.

ROSENBERG--Ethel, age 105 of Fort Lee, NJ, beloved wife of late Lester Rosenberg MD, devoted mother of Dr. Mary Donahue, Dr. Sidney Rosenberg and daughter-in-law Dr. Erica Rosenberg. Adored and cherished grandmother of Laurie, Rachel, Jennifer, Deborah and great-grandmother of Peyton, Tyler and Emma. Loving and devoted sister of Dr. Milton Hyman and the late Gertrude Jacobs. Information: "Eden memorial Chapel" 1-888-700-3336.

RANIOLO--Paul S.,passed away on June 6, 2013 at the age of 74 due to natural causes. Paul spent 52 years working as a Bond Broker on Wall Street and loved every moment of it. He will be missed very much by all who knew him. He is survived by his wife, two brothers, a sister-in-law, two daughters, two step-daughters and many grandchildren. There will be a Mass in celebration of his life held on June 20th at noon at St. Mary Lady of the Lakes in Eustis, FL. In his honor, donations may be made to: woundedwarriorproject.org to help those who served our country.

MARGOLIN--Florence, passed away on June 9, 2013. A supporter of Technion University-Haifa, Ben-Gurion University, B'nai Zion Hospital, Hadassah, Jewish National Fund, Colel Chabad, Be'er Sheva City. Survived by her beloved husband, Efraim, son, David, and brother, Irving Rapaport. Services Wednesday, June 12 at 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

MARGOLIN--Florence. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) are saddened by the loss of Florence Margolin. She, and her husband, Efraim, a distinguished Technion alumnus, have supported the university for many years. We extend our deepest sympathies to Efraim, son David, brother Irving Rapaport, and the entire Margolin family. American Technion Society Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

KUSCH--Robert E.,87, died June 9, 2013, at Indian River Medical Center in Vero Beach. He was born in New York City, the son of Dr. Ernest and Else Kusch. He moved permanently to Vero Beach in 1978 from Greenwich, Connecticut. He proudly served in the Army of the United States from 1948 to 1952, achieving the rank of Captain. He was an attorney at law having begun his career with Davies Hardy and Schenck, proceeding to Lewis, MacDonald and Varian in New York. He was a partner of the firm Ivey, Barnum & O'Mara, and Diserio, Martin, O'Connor, both of Stamford, Connecticut, before settling in Vero Beach in 1978 where he opened the Vero Beach office of Diserio, Martin, O'Connor. He received Bachelor of Arts from Lafayette College in 1948 and his LL.B. from Fordham University in 1951. He served as a Trustee on the Board of Directors of the Greenwich Academy, Lafayette College, Dearfield Associates, John's Island Club and various others.He enjoyed playing tennis and later on the game of golf. He was a former member of Greenwich Country Club, and a founding member of Red Stick, Hawk's Nest Golf Club and Indian River Club, all in Vero Beach. He was also a member of John's Island Club, Quail Valley River Club, and a charter member of the Lyford Cay Club. He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Ann Dana Kusch; daughter, Laurie Ruth Kusch and her two children, Robert Hart Talcott and Charles Dana Talcott of Washington, D.C.; sons Jeffrey Charles Kusch of Miami Beach, and Robert Alexander Kusch of Vero Beach. Memorial contributions may be made to the Humane Society of Indian River County, 6230 77th Street, Vero Beach, FL 32967, or the Visiting Nurse Association Hospice Foundation for Professional Education, 1111 36th Street, Vero Beach, FL 32960. A private memorial service will be held for the family only.

KOIZIM--Harvey L.,of New Haven, CT, formerly of Westport, CT, died peacefully at home on May 31, 2013. Son of the late Moses and Beatrice (Bernstein) Koizim. Graduate of Colby College and the Yale Law School, Veteran of the United States Merchant Marine, lawyer, judge, banker, teacher, real estate developer, tireless community activist. Beloved husband of Ruth; dear father of John Koizim (Martha Castillo), Candy Goldstein (Bob Goldstein) and Benjamin Koizim; cherished grandfather of Matthew and Joseph Koizim, all of whom survive to carry on his memory and good deeds. Contributions in Harvey's memory may be made to City Seed (cityseed.org), New Haven Farms (newhavenfarms.org) or to another worthy organization.

KANTOR--Martin E. died peacefully in his sleep on June 10. He was 91. His unerring sense of direction guided an extraordinary life in business, philanthropy and travel, and a passionate involvement in learning. He was a discerning collector and patron of the arts and served on the boards of major museums. His belief in humanitarian values led to the founding of "A World of Difference," a program of the Anti-Defamation League, providing training in diversity and tolerance to teachers throughout the United States and Europe. He is survived by his wife of 68 years, Lucille; his sister, Ruth Shir, and brother, Howard; sons Jonathan (Barbara), Joshua, and Earle (Anne); and his six grandchildren Joseph (Melanie), Eli, Luke, Adam, Samuel and Kyla. Visitors are welcome at his home on Wednesday and Thursday, June 12 and 13, 3-5pm and 7-9:30pm. Donations may be made to North Shore Child and Family Guidance Center, 480 Old Westbury Rd., Roslyn Heights, NY 11577.

KANE--Raymond Peter, of Northport, NY passed away peacefully in his sleep at home on Monday, June 10, 2013. Mr. Kane was born in Manhattan and was a veteran of both WWII, where he served as a member of the Merchant Marine, and the Korean War where he served in the Army as a medic. Mr. Kane later sailed the world aboard both the S.S. United States and the S.S. America leading to a long career in the travel industry. He retired in 2003 after 41 years as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Pisa Brothers Travel Service, Inc., a world-renowned boutique travel firm located in Rockefeller Center. Mr. Kane appeared in many television and print advertisements for the travel industry, and was a regular on Eyewitness News, the Today Show, and other programs. Most notably, Mr. Kane was selected to represent the travel industry in its epic battle with the IRS. His testimony in front of the U.S. House of Representatives ultimately led to a victory for the industry. Mr. Kane was the beloved husband of the late Marilyn Langford Kane. He is survived by his son, Scott C. Kane of Sands Point, NY, and two grandsons, Dylan S. Kane and Christian A. Kane. The funeral service is Saturday, June 15th at 11am at Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home in Northport, with visiting hours on Friday, June 14th from 2pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm. Burial immediately following at Northport Rural Cemetery. Donations may be made in Raymond's memory to the Wounded Warrior Project. Driving directions at nthfh.com.

JANKOWITZ--Abraham, MD, on June 10, 2013. Associate Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, member of the NY Psychoanalytic Society. Beloved husband of Nikki Brierton. Devoted father of Rachel, Naomi and Adam and father-in-law of James Brownson. Loving brother of Vera Balter. Cherished grandfather of Benjamin Brownson. Services Thursday, 11:45am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

GOODFRIEND--Murray. It is with deep sorrow that we record the passing of our esteemed member, Dr. Murray Goodfriend, and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Muriel, and their family. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Jeffrey Sands, President for the Board of Governors

GOODENOUGH--Ward Hunt, PhD, 94, of Haverford, PA, died on Sunday, June 9, 2013. He was University Emeritus Professor of Anthropology at the University of Pennsylvania. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, June 27, 2013 at 2pm at The Quadrangle, 3300 Darby Road, Haverford, PA. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name can be made to: American Philosophical Society, 104 South 5th Street, Philadelphia, PA 19106. Services by Bringhurst Funeral Home at West Laurel Hill Cemetery. www.forever-care.com

FRIED--Sylvia Kosovsky, MD, 90, beloved wife of Seymour Fried, MD, z"l, died on June 3rd, surrounded by family; her brother, children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. A remarkable woman, ahead of her time, a pediatrician who lived her personal and professional life with dignity and determination, with depth and humility, with intelligence and joy. She and her husband of 64 years shared a passion for travel and the arts. She was a leader in her community and a trustee of Temple Emanu-el in Closter. They sponsored scholarships for rabbinic students at JTS and medical students at Hadassah Hospital. Her warmth and inner soul will remain alive in all who were touched by her.
FELDMAN--Marcia. We will miss your warmth, great jokes and deep frienship. You're in our hearts forever. Deepest sympathies to the family and Jerry; your strength. Sharon and Alan Briskman

FANELLI--Edward A.,89, Manhattan resident, died June 4, 2013. Born in Shenandoah, PA, a '48 graduate of Villanova University, he served in WWII Army Air Corp and USN Reserves. He was Assistant Treasurer at NDP (Kraft), and Assistant Secretary at GTE. Funeral Mass at Our Mother of Good Counsel Parish, Bryn Mawr, PA, Friday, June 14, 11am. Donations in Ed's memory to St. Thomas Monastery, Villanova University, Villanova, PA. 19085 or The John and Natalie Clarke Fanelli Scholarship which Ed established at Villanova University. Louis D. Truskowsky Funeral Home & Crematory Inc. Mahanoy City PA, is in charge of services. truskowskyfuneralhome.com to sign the guest book.

DUNNE--Rev. Msgr. Joseph A.,was ninety-six at the time of his death at Our Lady of Consolation Residence in Riverdale, NY. Born September 14, 1916 in Richmond Hill, Queens, he was predeceased by his parents Philip and Margaret Dunne, his sisters Virginia Ruckel and Janet White, and his nephew James Ruckel. He is survived by eight nieces, three nephews, five grandnieces, ten grandnephews, four great-nieces and seven great-nephews. He was ordained in 1942 at Saint Joseph's Seminary Dunwoodie, in Yonkers and served as a parish priest at Saint Peter's in Poughkeepsie. In 1944 he joined the U.S. Army as a Chaplain and paratrooper serving during WWII and Korea. He was discharged at the rank of Major from the XVIII Airborne Corps in 1953 due to disabilities from injuries suffered in Korea. He received the Silver Star, Bronze Star and Purple Heart for courage under fire after jumping behind enemy lines with the 187th Airborne into Munsan-ni, Korea, where he was seriously wounded by a land mine while tending to the wounded and dying. He was also awarded the Army Commendation Ribbon and Senior Parachutist Badge. He returned to the New York Archdiocese and worked at Our Lady of Victory in Manhattan, Saint Sylvester's in Staten Island and Saint John's in White Plains. He was appointed Vice-Chancellor of the Military Ordinariate by Cardinal Spellman in 1956 and elevated to Monsignor in 1957. In 1958 he was appointed Chaplain of the New York City Police Department where he worked for twenty-three years. During this time he founded and directed the NYPD Alcoholism Rehabilitation Program. In addition, he founded and directed the National Council on Compulsive Gambling and co-founded Debtors Anonymous. From 1981 until 1986 he worked at John Jay College of Criminal Justice where he served as the Executive Director of The Institute on Alcohol and Substance Abuse and as an adjunct professor teaching the alcoholism and substance abuse counseling course. Although he retired to Florida in 1986, to play more golf, he assisted St. Bernadette's Parish in Hollywood and continued counseling police officers at the Seafield 911 Rehabilitation Center in Dania. After suffering a major stroke in 1991, he concentrated on his physical therapy and recovery. In 2000, he returned to New York to be near his family and friends. Visiting hours will be held at David J. Hodder & Son Funeral Home, 899 McLean Ave., Yonkers on Friday, June 14, 2013 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated by His Eminence Timothy Cardinal Dolan at St. Barnabas Church, Bronx on Saturday June 15, 2013 at 11:30am. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne. In lieu of flowers, donations in may be made to the New York Catholic Foundation, in memory of Msgr. Joseph A. Dunne, for the Egan Pavilion, 1011 First Ave. NY, NY 10022 or to Calvary Hospital Hospice, 1740 Eastchester Rd. Bronx, NY 10461.

BING--Elisabeth G. Elisabeth G. "Betsy" Bing of New York and Philadelphia, died accidentally, June 1, 2013. She is survived by loving daughter, Virginia Bing; former companion, John Cooney; his children, Kevin, Mary and Carol Cooney; former husband, Alexander Bing III; brother, John Githens (Denver). 38-year employee of The Metropolitan Museum of Art; volunteer of several organizations; graduate of Brown University and German Town Friends (Philadelphia). She will be greatly missed by her many friends and colleagues. Memorial Service and reception: 11am, June 14, Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Ave and 90th St., NY, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Also survived by ten grandchildren: Diane, Lisa, Wendy, Silas, Andrew, Katie, Chrissie, Arthur, Mimi, and Sarah, as well as six great-grandchildren: Cliff, Brady, Maggie, Will, Reed, and Carter. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Green Vale School, Valentine's Lane, Old Brookville, NY, 11545.
NEWMAN--Debra S. Dear Debra, Happy Birthday. I love you and miss you. Hugs, Aunt Sharon

PATRICK--Casimir C. July 21, 1939-June 13, 2012. Beloved husband of Mary, beloved father to Casimir, Michael and Maggie, brother to Edward, Carol, and Martia, grandfather to Jackson, Isabel, James and Casimir Liam. Your passing leaves a space that cannot be filled. We remember with fondness your remarkable intelligence and true wisdom, your dedication to your grandchildren, your passion for life, and your devotion to Mary and to all of your family. You continue to be an inspiration we will draw on always. Each day, as we move through the hours, we hold you in our hearts, and are thankful for the gift of your life.

THOMSON--Rev. Dr. Alan C.,82, passed away in Queens, NY on May 25, 2013. A retired Presbyterian minister, graduate of Union Theological Seminary and member of the Presbytery of New York City, he was also an overseas missionary, scholar, peace activist and former Executive Director of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship. A memorial service to be held at 11am on Saturday, June 15, 2013 at the Bowne Street Community Church in Flushing, Queens, NYC.

SULLIVAN--Most Rev. Joseph M. The board of directors and staff of the Milbank Memorial Fund mourn the passing of our beloved colleague, Bishop Joseph M. Sullivan. He lived his profound commitment to the overwhelming importance of preventing and ameliorating suffering. As a director of the Fund for the past 15 years, Joe has been an exemplar, a mentor, and a friend. He brought wisdom and compassion to our work of helping to apply the best available evidence to policy and practice for maintaining and improving health. Joe contributed enormously to human betterment in the city, the state and the nation. He blended spirituality with commitment to people and institutions; and did it with wit, charm, analytical precision, and--when persuaded to use it--a beautiful singing voice. Samuel L. "Tony" Milbank Chairman, Milbank Memorial Fund

SULLIVAN--Bishop Joseph. The Board and Staff of the Fund for the City of New York and the members of the Fund's Sloan Public Service Awards Selection Panel mourn the loss of Bishop Joseph M. Sullivan. A former member of the Fund's Board of Directors, Bishop Sullivan has for the past 20 years served as Chairman of the Fund's Sloan Public Service Awards Selection Panel. In his remarks each year about the winners at their work-place ceremonies and at the city-wide celebration at Cooper Union, he spoke eloquently about the meaning of public service and those special qualities that enable these individuals to serve the public over decades with unfailing skill, dedication and integrity and with no thought of personal reward. In these speeches, he was also describing himself. We shall miss him. Vaughn Williams, Board Chair Mary McCormick, President

SULLIVAN--Bishop Joseph. Safe Horizon mourns the loss of Bishop Joseph Sullivan, our first Chairman and a Board Member Emeritus, who was a tireless champion of our efforts to provide victims of crime and abuse with the justice, and the healing they deserve.

SEIDEN--Robert, of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved father to Neil and Suzanne, cherished father-in-law of Janet and Kevin, loving grandfather of Andrew, Eric, Michael, Jason and Samantha; passed away peacefully on June 12. Will be greatly missed. Services June 14, 11:30 am, Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows.

LaBRUNA--Dr. Vincent V.,of New York City, age 79, passed away on June 12, 2013. Vincent was a beloved husband, father, grandfather, philanthropist, leader, teacher, visionary and friend. Vincent graduated from St. John's College with a B.S. Degree in 1954, New York University College of Dentistry in 1958, and Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery with a specialty in Orthodontics in 1961. Vincent was a pioneer in the field of Orthodontics, and was involved in numerous professional organizations throughout his career including, Cabrini Medical Center/ Columbia Hospital, The American Dental Association, The Metropolitan Research Institute, The Italian Dental Society, and The New York State and County Dental Societies. Vincent maintained involvement with New York University College of Dentistry and Columbia University where he served as Alumni President in the 1970's. Vincent's contributions to his church and community were many. He served as President of the Italian Businessmen's Association from 1985 to 1997. Vincent was a believer in giving back to the community and in 1988 was honored as Community Mayor's "Man of The Year" for his many years of aiding handicap children. Until his demise, Vincent served as an Honorary Police Surgeon and Fire Chief. He was dedicated to his church and was inducted as a Knight of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulcher of Jerusalem by Cardinal Terrance Cook in 1970. In 1977 he was elevated to Knight Commander of the Holy Sepulcher. In 1995, Vincent was awarded the United Nations Metal by Pope John Paul II. In December 2002, Vincent was invested as a Knight Commander of the Equestrian Order of St. Gregory, by Pope John Paul II. Despite his busy and productive life, Vincent's first priority was his family. He is succeeded by his beloved wife of 54 years, Nina DiGiovanna LaBruna, two sons, Dr. Vincent A. LaBruna of New York and Dr. Anthony N. LaBruna of New York, his daughters-in-law, Dr. Diane Hanan LaBruna and Lucille Messina LaBruna, and his five adored grandchildren, Christopher, Nina, Anthony, Nicole and Kristen. A true renaissance man, Vincent will be deeply missed by whose lives he touched. Visitation will be held on Friday 2-5 and 7-9 and Saturday 6-9 at Campbell's Funeral Home, Madison and 81st Street, New York City, 212-288-3500. A funeral mass will be said at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church located at Lexington Avenue and 76th Street at 10am, Monday June 17, 2013. Burial will follow at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

JANKOWITZ--Abraham, MD, on June 10, 2013. Associate Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, member of the NY Psychoanalytic Society. Beloved husband of Nikki Brierton. Devoted father of Rachel, Naomi and Adam and father-in-law of James Brownson. Loving brother of Vera Balter. Cherished grandfather of Benjamin Brownson. Services Thursday, 11:45am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

GRAVES--Ralph. Died June 10 in New York City. Born in Washington D.C., in 1924 he was the son of Ralph Graves Sr., a founding editor of the National Geographic and Elizabeth Evans. After his father's death his mother married Francis B. Sayre, who became high commissioner of the Philippines where Mr. Graves spent part of his youth. He served in World War II as a cryptographer and returned to attend Harvard, where he published the first of his eleven books and graduated Phi Beta Kappa. He was hired by LIFE magazine, and during the ensuing 35 years he served in many capacities, becoming Managing Editor, and finally overseeing the closing of the weekly magazine. He then became Editorial Director of Time Inc. where he worked until his retirement. Within weeks of becoming Managing Editor he published "the Faces of the Dead" an article showing the 243 faces of every American killed in the previous week in Viet Nam. The article was a strong antiwar statement that widely affected public opinion. He married Patricia Monser, with whom he had two children, William and Katherine. He later married Eleanor MacKenzie Parish, with whom had two children, Sara and Andrew. He became stepfather to William and Alexander. He is also survived by 11 grandchildren. Mr. Graves had homes in Sarasota, Fl., New York City and Martha's Vineyard. He was a member of the Century Association, the Edgartown Reading Room and the Dutch Treat Club, where he served as president. He was an avid, and mostly successful, backgammon player.

CLAYTON--William L. Forest City Ratner Cos. mourns the passing of William L. Clayton, father of our colleague and friend Christopher Clayton. William proudly served his country in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War. During his stellar 55-year career on Wall Street, William was Executive Vice President and a member of E.F. Hutton's Board of Directors. William retired from Hutton's successor company, Morgan Stanley, in 2009. William maintained unwavering devotion to his alma mater, Lehigh University and was involved in many organizations dedicated to bettering the lives of others. We offer our deepest condolences to his devoted wife Carol, to Christopher and to the entire Clayton Family. Bruce Ratner and MaryAnne Gilmartin, Forest City Ratner Companies

ROTENBERG--Anne Lisa, passed away peacefully on June 12th, 2013. The wife of the late Morris Rotenberg, Anne, a Holocaust Survivor, escaped Germany, on the last Kindertransport train in August 1939, and first settled in England, where she was taken in by a Jewish family who introduced her to Dr. Anna Freud, daughter of Sigmund Freud, under who Anne studied. In 1946, she came to the United States and received a Bachelors of Science degree in education at Columbia University. She became a registered nurse and worked with children until she retired. Anne enjoyed her memberships at Central Synagogue and Temple Emanuel where she was an integral part of each community.

PORTER--Stephen W.,87, died June 11, 2013. A distinguished stage director and teacher, he received his MFA from the Yale Drama School and was a professor of English and Theater at McGill University. He brought classical French theater to NYC by producing and directing The Misanthrope. His first Broadway show was the APA Phoenix Right You Are, starring Helen Hayes and Donald Moffat, followed by The Show Off, and Harvey. During his long and stellar career he received two Tony nominations, two Drama Desk Awards; directed plays ranging from ancient Greek to Shakespeare to modern comedies; taught playwriting classes; translated several plays from ancient Greek and French; and adapted works for the theater. He directed over 125 plays, 20 for the APA, 21 as the artistic Director of the New Phoenix Repertory Company, and 12 for the Circle-in-the-Square, and for many other regional, Off-Broadway and Broadway theaters. He was known and beloved by his stage families for his exceptional command of the material, his gentle manner, his steely resolve, his humor, and the success of his productions. He gave penetrating and witty discourses on classical theater until his death. He was never at a loss for just the right words. He was a life-long traveller and dedicated patron of the arts, frequently seen at ballet, theater, film, and museum exhibitions throughout the world. He is sorely missed by his devoted life partner of 53 years, Arnold Somers, and his adoring nieces and nephews, for whom he affirmed the beauty and uniqueness of the world.

LaBRUNA--Dr. Vincent V.,of New York City, age 79, passed away on June 12, 2013. Vincent was a beloved husband, father, grandfather, philanthropist, leader, teacher, visionary and friend. Vincent graduated from St. John's College with a B.S. Degree in 1954, New York University College of Dentistry in 1958, and Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery with a specialty in Orthodontics in 1961. Vincent was a pioneer in the field of Orthodontics, and was involved in numerous professional organizations throughout his career including, Cabrini Medical Center/ Columbia Hospital, The American Dental Association, The Metropolitan Research Institute, The Italian Dental Society, and The New York State and County Dental Societies. Vincent maintained involvement with New York University College of Dentistry and Columbia University where he served as Alumni President in the 1970's. Vincent's contributions to his church and community were many. He served as President of the Italian Businessmen's Association from 1985 to 1997. Vincent was a believer in giving back to the community and in 1988 was honored as Community Mayor's "Man of The Year" for his many years of aiding handicap children. Until his demise, Vincent served as an Honorary Police Surgeon and Fire Chief. He was dedicated to his church and was inducted as a Knight of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulcher of Jerusalem by Cardinal Terrance Cook in 1970. In 1977 he was elevated to Knight Commander of the Holy Sepulcher. In 1995, Vincent was awarded the United Nations Metal by Pope John Paul II. In December 2002, Vincent was invested as a Knight Commander of the Equestrian Order of St. Gregory, by Pope John Paul II. Despite his busy and productive life, Vincent's first priority was his family. He is succeeded by his beloved wife of 54 years, Nina DiGiovanna LaBruna, two sons, Dr. Vincent A. LaBruna of New York and Dr. Anthony N. LaBruna of New York, his daughters-in-law, Dr. Diane Hanan LaBruna and Lucille Messina LaBruna, and his five adored grandchildren, Christopher, Nina, Anthony, Nicole and Kristen. A true renaissance man, Vincent will be deeply missed by whose lives he touched. Visitation will be held on Friday 2-5 and 7-9 and Saturday 6-9 at Campbell's Funeral Home, Madison and 81st Street, New York City, 212-288-3500. A funeral mass will be said at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church located at Lexington Avenue and 76th Street at 10am, Monday June 17, 2013. Burial will follow at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

Eisenberg, President George W. Schaeffer, Chairman of the Board Jack Grunspan, Executive Vice President Mel Parness, Executive Vice President Emeritus Raymond M. Patt, Honorary Chair.

FANELLI--Edward A. Dear, sweet 'cousin' Ed: You were our leprechaun and truly one of a kind. We cherish memories of many shared adventures, going back 15 years to our first meeting in Sicily. EIDUS--Arnold. World renowned Violinist, passed away on June 3, 2013 at the age of 90. He was a child prodigy at age five who studied with Louis Persinger, the teacher of Yehudi Menhuin and Isaac Stern. He gave his first concert at Carnagie Hall at age 11 with Leonard Bernstein. He was asked by the State Department to represent the United States in the prestigious Jacques Thibaut International Competition. From among 160 worldwide entrants he won 1st Prize for the United States at the age of 24. He went on to become Concertmaster of the ABC Symphony and Music Director for ABC Radio. He also performed with Benny Goodman, Frank Sinatra, Tony Bennett, Perry Como, Harry James and other leading recording artists of his day. In 1967 he joined a noted New York advertising agency where he produced some of the most beloved commercials of all time such as Ummm Ummm Good for Campbell Soups and Double Your Pleasure with Doublemint Gum for Wrigleys Gum. He retired to Boca Raton, Florida and was predeceased by his Wife, Doris, and their daughter, Licia. He had a wonderful life for many years with his loving companion, Rose Kahn, who survives in Delray Beach to cherish and honor his memory.

DEUTSCH--David S. It is with deep sorrow that we record the passing of our esteemed member, Mr. David Deutsch, and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Francine, and their family. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Jeffrey Sands, President for the Board of Governors

D'ANGELO--Angele (Carabillo), 80, died unexpectedly on Tuesday, June 11, 2013 at the University Medical Center of Princeton at Plainsboro. Born in New York City, Mrs. D'Angelo lived in East Rockaway, NY where she owned and operated a community pharmacy for 42 years before moving to Monroe Twp. NJ in 2000. Mrs. D'Angelo was a Professor of Pharmacy and Assistant Dean of St. John's Univ. College of Pharmacy, Jamaica, NY. She retired from St. John's in 1990 to become the editor-in-chief of US Pharmacist, a national pharmacy publication, until her retirement in 2003. She was a registered pharmacist and held a Master's Degree in Pharmaceutical Administration and an honorary Ph.D., from the Massachusetts College of Pharmacy. Mrs. D'Angelo was the first woman appointed to the New York State Board of Pharmacy in 1971. She was a member of the American Pharmacist Assoc., the National Association of Boards of Pharmacy, Rho Chi Honor Society and a Lady of the Holy Sepulcher. She is predeceased by her son, Ernest. Surviving are her husband of 59 years, Deacon Gregory D'Angelo; her sons and their spouses John and Janet, Gregory Jr. and Janice and Gerard and Lori, and her brother Ernest Carabillo Jr., wife Dolores and family, and her four grandchildren, Andrew, Catherine, Sarah, Sofie and Shane. Services will begin 9:30am Saturday, June 15th at the Lester Memorial Home, 16 W. Church St., Jamesburg followed by a 10:15am funeral liturgy at Immaculate Conception RC Church, Spotswood. Visiting hours for family and friends will be Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm and Saturday 8:30-9:30am at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Immaculate Conception Church, 23 Manalapan Rd., Spotswood, NJ 08884. For directions to the funeral home or to send condolences to the family visit www. lestermemorialhome.com.

MEAGHER--James P.,(Age 78) died suddenly on Monday June 10 en route to his home in Chatham, New Jersey from Washington, D.C. Jim was a lifelong newspaperman. Beginning at the age of 15 in his hometown of Rock Island, Illinois, he covered his high school sports for the "Argus" newspaper. He also reported local news during summer vacations through high school and college. After graduating from the University of Notre Dame in 1957, Jim served as a Public Information Officer for the US Army at Fort Bragg, North Carolina and then joined the Chicago Tribune as an editor. From its establishment in 1961 until its closing in 1977, Jim was an editor at the weekly Dow Jones Publication "The National Observer" headquartered in suburban Washington. Next it was the weekly Dow Jones business publication "Barron's" where Jim served as managing editor, editor in chief and in executive managerial roles from the mid-nineties until the middle of the last decade. After his retirement from Dow Jones and through last week, Jim still contributed his editorial talents to "Barron's" as a consultant every week in preparing the paper for its Saturday publication. In his retirement, in addition to keeping his hand in the news business, Jim traveled extensively and actively served his parish on committees and as a lector. James Proctor Meagher was born June 2, 1935, in Rock Island, Illinois, to Edmund Joseph Meagher and Pauline (nee Proctor). In 1959, he married Marie Lyman of Crete, Illinois, a Saint Mary's Notre Dame alumna. They lived in Chicago for two years before living in the Maryland suburbs from 1961 until 1978, when they moved to Chatham, New Jersey. His wife Marie died in January 2012. He is survived by his daughter Kate Raffa (Angelo) of Pearl River, New York, his son Chris (Susan) of Nutley, New Jersey, two granddaughters, Grace Marie Raffa and Ava Clare Raffa, a grandson Andrew James Meagher and a brother Paul (Jackie) of Capitol Hill. A sister, Ann Vander Vennet of Wilmette, Illinois died in 2009. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 10:30 am on Monday, June 17, at St. Patrick Church, Washington Ave., Chatham, NJ. Friends may visit on Sunday June 16, from 3-5 pm and 7-9pm at Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main St., Chatham, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Saint Mary's College, Development Office, Le Mans Hall, Notre Dame, IN 46556.

McTAGUE--John Paul, 1938- 2013. a distinguished scientist who impacted the world of science in research, academia, industry and government, died on Friday, June 7, 2013 at the age of 74 at his home in Montecito, California. John McTague graduated from Xavier High School in New York, NY. Growing up in Jersey City, he met and married Carole Frances Reilly, to whom he was married 35 years when she passed in 1997. A physical chemist, John McTague received his undergraduate degree with honors in chemistry from Georgetown University in 1960 and his Ph.D. from Brown University in 1964. Brown also bestowed on him an honorary Sc.D. in 1997. He was a technical staff member at North American Rockwell Center from 1964 to 1974 and a professor of chemistry and a member of the Institute of Geophysics and Planetary Physics at UCLA from 1970 to 1982. There and at Riso and Brookhaven National Laboratories, he led experiments in the structure and dynamics of condensed phases. He then became the first chair of the National Synchrotron Light Source Department at Brookhaven National Laboratory. Following his position as Chair of the National Synchrotron Light Source, he was appointed as Deputy Director then Acting Director of the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy under President Reagan. He then joined Ford Motor Company in 1986 as Vice President of Research and then Vice President of Technical Affairs until his retirement from Ford in 1999. He was a founder of cooperative automotive research efforts, including USCAR and the Partnership for a New Generation of Vehicles. During the first Bush Administration, he was a member of the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology, and U.S. chair of the U.S.-Japan High Level Advisory Panel on Science and Technology. Dr. McTague was founding co-chair of the Department of Energy's Laboratory Operations Board, and a member of the Secretary of Energy Advisory Board from its inception in 1990 through 2000. In 1992, he was a founding member of the University of California President's Council on the National Laboratories and was the first chairman of the council's Technology Transfer Panel, serving on both until 1995. From 1994 to 1999, he was also chairman of the Fermilab Board of Overseers. He was a member of the National Academy of Engineering and a fellow of the American Physical Society and the American Association for the Advancement of Science. He has received Alfred P. Sloan, John Simon Guggenheim, and NATO Senior Fellowships, as well as the California Section Award of the American Chemical Society. In 1998 the American Physical Society honored him with the Pake Prize "For insightful experiments and contributions...for major contributions in management of science in government, national laboratories, and industry; and for championing new paradigms for collaboration, such as the Partnership for New Generation Vehicles." In 1999 he was the honored recipient of the Glenn T. Seaborg Medal at UCLA for his achievements in academia, government and industry and for significant contributions to chemistry and biochemistry. At that time, McTague announced the endowment of the Reiss Chair, which honors another UCLA professor and also established the John P. McTague Career Development Chair at UCLA, which supports outstanding junior faculty in UCLA's Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry. McTague said "When I was a professor at UCLA, the department was very supportive. There was a great sense of collegiality, of community. Helping to bring in and nurture younger members of the community, early in their careers, has more leverage than other ways of giving support," says McTague. "I saw this as an opportunity to say thank you, and to help a superb public university stay competitive with private schools and preserve the excellence of faculty and students." In his later career years, McTague served as vice president of laboratory management for the University of California, Office of the President, and then as a Professor Emeritus of Materials at the University of California, Santa Barbara. In retirement John McTague continued to enjoy his favorite things: his family and travel. In this leisure time he ventured to Antarctica, Dubai, Egypt, Bali and favorite places like New York City. His children and grandchildren were the most important things to him; he created a legacy of bringing the whole family together for vacations in Barbados and creating great family memories. John McTague is survived by his four children; son, Kevin (Christine) McTague of Santa Barbara, CA; daughter, Catherine (Douglas) Bregenzer of San Anselmo, CA; daughter, Margaret (Daniel) McCreary of East Longmeadow, MA; and daughter, Maureen (Mark) Sandoval of Orinda, CA; along with nine grandchildren and his sister Mary (Andrew) Dempsey of Hilton Head, SC. The family will hold a private memorial in late June. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The John P. McTague Career Development Chair Endowment in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at UCLA. Checks may be made payable to the UCLA Foundation, noting Fund Number 8986 in the check memo line. Please direct donations to: Kerri Yoder, Director of Development Division of Physical Sciences UCLA College of Letters & Science 1309 Murphy Hall, P.O. Box 951413 Los Angeles, CA 90095-1413.

HOUGHTELING--Peter Delano, a psychologist, died at home in Boston on June 14th from Parkinson's disease. He was 67 years old. Dr. Houghteling worked for three decades in the Dedham, Brookline, and Boston schools as a child psychologist, and later with the Suffolk County Juvenile Court Clinic as a forensic psychologist. He graduated from Harvard College in 1967, served as a Peace Corps Volunteer in El Salvador, and received his Ph.D. from UC Berkeley in 1978. Born in Waltham, Mass. in 1946, Houghteling lived in Paris, France as a young child. Houghteling was raised in Pittsburgh, attended Taylor Allderdice High School, and graduated from Newton High. Houghteling and his wife Susan Waisbren were married for 38 years and raised their four daughters in Brookline, MA. Houghteling was an enthusiastic and active participant in the Boston music and musical theatre community. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Susan Waisbren, and their daughters and their families: Sara of Palo Alto, CA; Charlotte of London, England; Sylvia, of Los Angeles, CA; and Pearl, of Worcester, Mass. He is also survived by his mother, Fiora Houghteling, of Newtonville, Mass. his siblings Lawrence of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY; Robert of Oakland, CA; and Nan of Myrtle Beach, SC. His memory lives on in grandsons Raphael Mason and Jasper Smallwood and numerous nieces and nephews. Burial services will be held at Chatham Synagogue in Chatham, NY. The family will receive visitors at their home in Boston from 7-9 on Saturday and 2-4 on Sunday. Donations in Houghteling's memory will fund a fellowship at The Family Center, Inc. thefamilycenterinc.org 366 Somerville Ave., Somerville, MA 02143.

WEINSTEIN--Jerome J.,on June 13, 2013 of pneumonia. A long-time resident of Sands Point, NY, recently of Great Barrington, MA and NYC. Forever beloved and always remembered. He leaves many loving friends and relatives. Born in 1924 Jerry was raised in Lynbrook, NY, graduated from Harvard University and served in the US Army during WWII. Jerry ran, reoriented, and served as President of Apex Plastic Industries, Inc, Hauppauge, NY. Jerry was a plastics industry leader as well as a local government official serving as Trustee and Mayor of Sands Point and then as North Hempstead Town Councilman. He was handily elected four times and was one of the longest serving councilmembers in recent history. Deeply admired and genuinely loved by everyone who knew him, he leaves behind legions of people who remember his kindness, wit, and unfailing interest in the welfare of others. He is survived by his adored and adoring wife Marjorie, son Jon (Ilana) of Port Washington, daughter Susan Dobuler (Kenneth) of Branford, CT and by his loving grandchildren who will never forget him: Diana Weinstein Mark, Rachelle, and Robert; Zoe Dobuler and the late Paul. A memorial service will be held Sunday, June 23, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC at 3:30pm. Donations in Jerry's memory may be sent to the Paul A. Dobuler Memorial Research Fund, Children's Hospital Trust, 1 Autumn Street, Boston, MA 02215.

STONE--Edward Luke, 76, of Newport, RI, died April 26, 2013. He is survived by his wife, Cassandra (Reeve) Stone, his sister-in-law, Judy Stone, and several nieces and nephews. He graduated from Yale, Phi Beta Kappa, in 1958, read economics at Cambridge from 1961-1962, and received his MBA from Harvard Business School in 1966. He worked in finance and real estate and was the trustee of many charitable organizations. He was a kind and gentle man who always had a twinkle in his eye. His funeral services were private.

SELIGSOHN--George Joshua, 90, died peacefully on May 11 at his home in Florida. George grew up in the Bronx and Brooklyn at a time when there were still some dirt roads in New York City and horses were sometimes seen pulling delivery carts. As a child, he was known for bringing home stray dogs, his tremendous curiosity, and his six-year old solo forays across the Brooklyn Bridge to visit his father Sam's law office. In the 1930s, his family moved to Belle Harbor, Rockaway Beach. George was a 1940 graduate of Far Rockaway High School where he was a member of the honor society and excelled on the math team. Originally admitted to the Cornell University Class of 1944 with a Regents Scholarship, George was graduated in 1943 with a BA in Physics. He was recruited to work at Oak Ridge, TN and served in the US Army Signal Corps. After receiving his law degree (NYU, 1953), George became a patent attorney, with a career (at RCA in Princeton, NJ, and in private practice in Florida) that spanned almost 60 years and brought him deep engagement and satisfaction. In Rochester, NY, he worked at Stromberg-Carlson and was a member of Toastmasters. In East Windsor, NJ, where George lived for 24 years, he was a member of Kiwanis and volunteered as a math tutor for children in need, while practicing patent law at RCA and then GE at David Sarnoff Research Center. He was one-of-a-kind, and will be remembered for his sense of justice, his generosity, his humility, his equanimity, his intelligence, and his trademark point-of-view. He often quoted great writers to most pithily make a point. A favorite quotation, reflecting his love of his profession, was, "Work is the greatest of all virtues, because it simultaneously overcomes poverty, vice, and boredom," from Voltaire's Candide (1759). A man who cared about function, not appearance, he would remind us, "Vanity of vanities; all is vanity." (Ecclesiastes 1:2) His matter-of-fact acceptance of the flow of life was embodied in, "The Moving Finger writes; and, having writ, Moves on: nor all thy Piety nor Wit Shall lure it back to cancel half a Line, Nor all thy Tears wash out a Word of it." (from The Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam). He lived by his motto, "Live and let live," truly not judging or seeking to control others. George was consistently a person of great honesty, loyalty, and nobility. George is survived by his wife of 51 years, Phyllis, his three children, Diane, Steven, and Laura; five grandchildren, Juliet, Isabelle, Hannah, Tivon, and Lachlan, his brother, Leo, and his sister, Nancy. George will continue to be deeply missed. His family requests that donations in his honor be sent to the George J. Seligsohn Far Rockaway Scholarship Fund, which, starting this June, will benefit students excelling in math and science in the academies now housed at the Far Rockaway High School Campus. Donations can be mailed to George J. Seligsohn Far Rockaway Scholarship, PO Box 334, Fairfax, CA 94978-0334. A memorial in George's honor is being planned, date and location to be announced.

SCHEUBER--William Karl, 94, Martinez, CA, May 1st, 2013. 2nd Lt US Army under CO Dalton Howatt. Self-made man, liked to say he graduated 265 in a class of 266, University of Wisconsin. Executive Director ACCMA, founder first doctor-owned insurance company in California, MIEC; resolved commercial carrier crisis in western US. Founding President of the first nationwide Physician Insurers Association. Only son of William A. and Christine Scheuber of Milwaukee; brother of Lois Scheuber, deceased; survived by wife Sylvia of Martinez, and daughter Heidi Scheuber of New York City.

SAXE--Raymond D.,III Passed away on Saturday, June 1, at Sound Shore Medical Center in New Rochelle, NY. He was 50 years old. Known to his friends and family as "Ray," he was born in New York City on November 14, 1962, to R. Daniel Saxe, Jr., of Winchester, VA, and JoAn Teetor Saxe, of New Castle, IN, and New Orleans, LA. He grew up in Scarsdale, NY, where he attended Scarsdale High School, graduating in 1980. He received a BS in electrical engineering from the University of Bridgeport in 1985, and an MBA in Finance from the Stern School of Business at New York University in 1990. After working in systems engineering and project management for fifteen years at Deutsche Bank AG, he moved to HSBC, where he was Senior Vice President in charge of global risk technology for the Americas, and later Senior Vice President/Global Head for client onboarding. He was married to Naomi Reinitz, also of Scarsdale, NY, and lived in Rye Brook, NY. They have three daughters: Amanda, Abigail, and Rachel. Ray was a devoted husband and father, and he loved spending time with his family and friends. He loved skiing, tennis, a good mystery, and the Grateful Dead. He was an excellent drummer, and he was thrilled and proud when one of his daughters decided to take up the drums too. One of his favorite times of the year was his family's annual summer vacation at Lake George, in the Adirondacks. He has requested that his ashes be scattered there. He is survived by his ex-wife Naomi Reinitz Saxe, of Rye Brook, NY; his daughters, Amanda, Abigail, and Rachel; his sister Emily Saxe Nydam of Wellesley, MA; and his mother JoAn Teetor Marder of Tucson, AZ. There was a private memorial service for family and friends at Congregation Kneses Tifereth Israel in Port Chester, NY, officiated jointly by Rabbi Jaymee Alpert and The Reverend Dr. John W. Miller of Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale. There will also be a memorial plaque placed in his memory at the Teetor Mausoleum in Hagerstown, IN. He was loved and will be missed.

RUDOLPH--Frederick, Professor Emeritus of History, at Williams College, died Monday June 3, 2013 at his home in Williamstown, MA. He was born in Baltimore, MD, on June 19, 1920 a son of the late Charles Frederick and Jennie Hill (Swope) Rudolph. He was raised in Wilkes-Barre, PA, graduated from Wyoming Seminary in 1938. He received his BA from Williams College in 1942. He was a Veteran of WW II serving with the United States Army as a captain from 1942-1946. Following his military service he received his Ph.D. from Yale University in 1953. Mr. Rudolph joined the history department at Williams College in 1951, including with the introduction of what is now called the American studies program and also introduced African- American history. He served as college marshal, as administrator of the Tyng Bequest, and as a member of the Committee on Admitting Women, The Bicentennial Commission, and the Visiting Committee of the Williams College Museum of Art. Mr. Rudolph was a Guggenheim Fellow from 1958-1959 and from 1962-1963: director, United World College of American West, member, National Academy of Education, Massachusetts Historical Society, American Historical Association, Organization of American Historians, American Association of University Professors Trustee at Hancock Shaker Village, Trustee at Bennington Museum and founding member of the Berkshire County Historical Society. He enjoyed gardening and traveling. His writing included "Mark Hopkins and the Log," "The American College and University: A History," "Curriculum: A History of the American Undergraduate Course of Study Since 1636," "Essays on Education in the Early Republic," "Perspectives: A Williams Anthology." He was awarded the Frederick W. Ness Award from the Association of American Colleges Rogerson Cup from Williams College and Distinguished Service Award from Wyoming Seminary. Williams College bestowed on Mr. Rudolph a Bicentennial Medal and one of his several honorary degrees, and established the Frederick Rudolph '42 - Class of 1965 Professorship of American Culture. Survivors include his wife Dorothy (Dannenbaum) Rudolph whom he married June 18, 1949 and two daughters Marta Rudolph of Northampton, MA and Lisa Rudolph Cushman and her husband Michael of Williams- town, MA, six grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by a brother Richard H. Rudolph. Private burial will take place in the Williams College Cemetery. Memorial Donations are suggested for the Frederick Rudolph Williamsiana Fund at Williams College or through the Flynn & Dagnoli - Montagna Home for Funerals, West Chapels, 521 West Main St. North Adams, MA. 01247. Please visit: www.flynn dagnolifuneralhomes.com

PORTER--Stephen W.,87, died June 11, 2013. A distinguished stage director and teacher, he received his MFA from the Yale Drama School and was a professor of English and Theater at McGill University. He brought classical French theater to NYC by producing and directing The Misanthrope. His first Broadway show was the APA Phoenix Right You Are, starring Helen Hayes and Donald Moffat, followed by The Show Off, and Harvey. During his long and stellar career he received two Tony nominations, two Drama Desk Awards; directed plays ranging from ancient Greek to Shakespeare to modern comedies; taught playwriting classes; translated several plays from ancient Greek and French; and adapted works for the theater. He directed over 125 plays, 20 for the APA, 21 as the artistic Director of the New Phoenix Repertory Company, and 12 for the Circle-in-the-Square, and for many other regional, Off-Broadway and Broadway theaters. He was known and beloved by his stage families for his exceptional command of the material, his gentle manner, his steely resolve, his humor, and the success of his productions. He gave penetrating and witty discourses on classical theater until his death. He was never at a loss for just the right words. He was a life-long traveller and dedicated patron of the arts, frequently seen at ballet, theater, film, and museum exhibitions throughout the world. He is sorely missed by his devoted life partner of 53 years, Arnold Somers, and his adoring nieces and nephews, for whom he affirmed the beauty and uniqueness of the world.

OSMAN--Holly. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our past board member, Holly Osman, and extend sincere condolences to her family. Alan Fischer, President

MILETI--Robert Anthony, of Sharon CT and West Palm Beach, FL, on May 30, 2013. He is survived by his wife, Susan DeBlasio Bartsch; brother, Joseph Mileti of Camarillo, CA; two daughters, Meredith Mileti Cohen and Cara Witasick; two step-sons, Jeffrey Bartsch and Michael Bartsch; and seven grandchildren.
