McTAGUE--John Paul, 1938- 2013. a distinguished scientist who impacted the world of science in research, academia, industry and government, died on Friday, June 7, 2013 at the age of 74 at his home in Montecito, California. John McTague graduated from Xavier High School in New York, NY. Growing up in Jersey City, he met and married Carole Frances Reilly, to whom he was married 35 years when she passed in 1997. A physical chemist, John McTague received his undergraduate degree with honors in chemistry from Georgetown University in 1960 and his Ph.D. from Brown University in 1964. Brown also bestowed on him an honorary Sc.D. in 1997. He was a technical staff member at North American Rockwell Center from 1964 to 1974 and a professor of chemistry and a member of the Institute of Geophysics and Planetary Physics at UCLA from 1970 to 1982. There and at Riso and Brookhaven National Laboratories, he led experiments in the structure and dynamics of condensed phases. He then became the first chair of the National Synchrotron Light Source Department at Brookhaven National Laboratory. Following his position as Chair of the National Synchrotron Light Source, he was appointed as Deputy Director then Acting Director of the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy under President Reagan. He then joined Ford Motor Company in 1986 as Vice President of Research and then Vice President of Technical Affairs until his retirement from Ford in 1999. He was a founder of cooperative automotive research efforts, including USCAR and the Partnership for a New Generation of Vehicles. During the first Bush Administration, he was a member of the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology, and U.S. chair of the U.S.-Japan High Level Advisory Panel on Science and Technology. Dr. McTague was founding co-chair of the Department of Energy's Laboratory Operations Board, and a member of the Secretary of Energy Advisory Board from its inception in 1990 through 2000. In 1992, he was a founding member of the University of California President's Council on the National Laboratories and was the first chairman of the council's Technology Transfer Panel, serving on both until 1995. From 1994 to 1999, he was also chairman of the Fermilab Board of Overseers. He was a member of the National Academy of Engineering and a fellow of the American Physical Society and the American Association for the Advancement of Science. He has received Alfred P. Sloan, John Simon Guggenheim, and NATO Senior Fellowships, as well as the California Section Award of the American Chemical Society. In 1998 the American Physical Society honored him with the Pake Prize "For insightful experiments and contributions...for major contributions in management of science in government, national laboratories, and industry; and for championing new paradigms for collaboration, such as the Partnership for New Generation Vehicles." In 1999 he was the honored recipient of the Glenn T. Seaborg Medal at UCLA for his achievements in academia, government and industry and for significant contributions to chemistry and biochemistry. At that time, McTague announced the endowment of the Reiss Chair, which honors another UCLA professor and also established the John P. McTague Career Development Chair at UCLA, which supports outstanding junior faculty in UCLA's Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry. McTague said "When I was a professor at UCLA, the department was very supportive. There was a great sense of collegiality, of community. Helping to bring in and nurture younger members of the community, early in their careers, has more leverage than other ways of giving support," says McTague. "I saw this as an opportunity to say thank you, and to help a superb public university stay competitive with private schools and preserve the excellence of faculty and students." In his later career years, McTague served as vice president of laboratory management for the University of California, Office of the President, and then as a Professor Emeritus of Materials at the University of California, Santa Barbara. In retirement John McTague continued to enjoy his favorite things: his family and travel. In this leisure time he ventured to Antarctica, Dubai, Egypt, Bali and favorite places like New York City. His children and grandchildren were the most important things to him; he created a legacy of bringing the whole family together for vacations in Barbados and creating great family memories. John McTague is survived by his four children; son, Kevin (Christine) McTague of Santa Barbara, CA; daughter, Catherine (Douglas) Bregenzer of San Anselmo, CA; daughter, Margaret (Daniel) McCreary of East Longmeadow, MA; and daughter, Maureen (Mark) Sandoval of Orinda, CA; along with nine grandchildren and his sister Mary (Andrew) Dempsey of Hilton Head, SC. The family will hold a private memorial in late June. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The John P. McTague Career Development Chair Endowment in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at UCLA. Checks may be made payable to the UCLA Foundation, noting Fund Number 8986 in the check memo line. Please direct donations to: Kerri Yoder, Director of Development Division of Physical Sciences UCLA College of Letters & Science 1309 Murphy Hall, P.O. Box 951413 Los Angeles, CA 90095-1413.
MAHONEY--Colette. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Sr. Colette Mahoney, and send condolences to the Marymount community.

MAHONEY--Sr. Colette, RSHM. A Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary for 65 years, she taught at the Academy of the Sacred Heart of Mary, Manhattan; Marymount University, Arlington, VA; and Marymount College, Tarrytown. She was President of Marymount Manhattan College, NYC, from 1967 to 1988. She served as director and advisor to numerous educational and civic organizations devoted to improving the well-being of women, youth, and the community at large. Services Marymount Convent, 32 Warren Avenue, Tarrytown, NY. Visiting Tuesday, June 18, 3:00 - 7:30pm with Vigil Service 7:30pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday, June 19, 10:30am. LIEBESMAN--William P.,MD, died at his home in Westfield, NJ, June 10, 2013, age 83. Raised in Bradley Beach, NJ, graduated Rutgers University, earned MD SUNY Downstate. Captain US Air Force, ophthalmology residency Mayo Clinic. Clinical Professor Mt. Sinai Medical School. Practiced 40 years in Westfield. Survived by beloved wife Stella, four children, six grandchildren.

LEVINE--Laurence Brandt, age 71 of New York City, Palm Beach, FL, and Washington Depot, CT, passed away peacefully in his sleep in the early morning of June 12th, 2013. Born in New York City on December 17th, 1941, the son of Beulah (Brandt) Levine and Martin Levine, Mr. Levine attended The Fieldston School in his elementary and high school years. He was a college graduate of Princeton University, Class of 1963, where he was awarded the Francis Biddle Prize. He graduated from the Stanford University School of Law in 1967, and was admitted to the New York and Pennsylvania Bar Associations. Shortly after his graduation from Stanford, Mr. Levine became Sr. Vice President and the youngest voting shareholder at Drexel Burnham and Co. He subsequently became the Corporate Planning Officer at the Ogden Corporation (NYSE). Later, he became Executive Vice President and Director of Investment Banking at Henry Ansbacher & Co. (New York, London). He then filled the same role at Rothschild Inc. and Smith New Court. His specialty was in Mergers and Acquisitions within the shipping and transportation industries, with notable clients such as the Sun Oil Company and many others. Mr. Levine spent many years in Palm Beach, FL, where he was a founder of the Kravis Center for the Performing Arts, as well as Chairman of The Dreyfoos School of The Arts Foundation. He was a member of the board of directors of the Manhattan Theater Club, The Drama League of New York, Musica Sacra, and Ballet Florida. He was a proud veteran of the U.S. Marine Corps Reserve, and most recently a member of St. John's Episcopal Church and the Lions Club in Washington Depot, Ct. He was a member of The Old Oaks Club in Purchase, NY and the Harmonie Club of New York City. He is survived by his partner of many years, Nancy Winston; his son, Blair Brandt, of New York City; and his former wife, Laura Vitale Levine, of Palm Beach, FL. Burial will take place Wednesday, June 19th at 1:00pm at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to St. John's Episcopal Church, www.stjohnswashington.org, or to The Dreyfoos School of the Arts, www.awdsoa.org. Memorial service information to follow.

LaBRUNA--Vincent V.,DDS The officers and board members of the New York County Dental Society are saddened to learn of the passing of its 1995 president. Dr. LaBruna served the society with distinction and great leadership and was dedicated to his patients and the profession. Our sympathies to Nina and the family. James H. Doundoulakis, DMD, President

KAISER--Guenther August Wilhelm, passed away on June 8, 2013 despite the best efforts of the caring staff at Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was born on October 15, 1937 in Hamburg, Germany. He worked as an apprentice at the prestigious hotel Vier Jahreszeiten, located on the western side of the Inner Alster Lake of Hamburg, Germany. He then worked as a steward on the SS Hanseatic cruise liner. It was during his tenure on the SS Hanseatic that he met and fell in love with his wife Helga. He immigrated to the United States in 1962 and ultimately started a successful delicatessen with his wife, from 1973 to 2010. Guenther is survived by his dedicated wife of 50 years, Helga, his sons Steven, an attorney, Michael, a neurosurgeon, his daughter-in-law Michelle, and his beloved grandchildren, Nicole, Cindy, and Christopher. Guenther shared a passion for animals with his wife and will forever be missed by Gian Carlo, his faithful cat for over 15 years. Guenther loved to refurbish antiques and spend Sundays at local flea markets selling antiques and knick-knacks. He had a lust for life, was an exceptional historian, always provided entertaining stories, and loved to be the life of the party. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Guenther's name to your local chapter of the ASPCA, https://donate.aspca.org, or other organizations helping animals in need.

HOFFMAN--Ruth Harfield, 69, Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and friend. She worked for 17 years as a clinical social worker and administrator at the Mt. Sinai Adolescent Health Center. She suffered during her last 10 years with multiple myeloma and dialysis as a result of polycystic kidney disease. She leaves behind her husband Chuck, daughters Anya and Kira, granddaughters Ruby and Tema, and son-in-law Jonathan, as well as many dear friends. She was a trooper to the end.

HOFFMAN--Martin. Martin Hoffman was a dynamic and admired leader in the Columbus Jewish Community and owned the Hoffman Container Corp. with his brother Max for 50 years. Martin Hoffman is survived by a loving family who carry on his family's legacy. He was preceded in death by his eleven brothers and sisters, His devoted children are: Bradley Hoffman, Eric (Anny) Hoffman, Cheri (Tod) Friedman, Debra (Jeff) Meyer and Seth (Leslie) Hoffman and many Hoffman grandchildren. He is also survived by YU Benefactors: Jay (Jeanie) Schottenstein, Ann (Ari) Deshe, Susan (John) Diamond and Lori Schottenstein and their large number of grandchildren and great grandchildren. "Marty" will be sorely missed by his many friends. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor
HAYS--Shifra, age 95, died Saturday June 8th. Shifra was wife to Otto, mother to Daphna and Ram.

GROARKE--James. Scientist, scholar and loyal friend, James Michael Groarke, Ph.D., 58, died of a heart attack in San Francisco on June 7, 2013. Born in New York City to the late James and Margaret Groarke, Dr. Groarke was recognized as a leading authority on Baculovirus Protein Expression. He was a Chief Scientist for Biortus Biosciences and a partner with James von Stein in Groarke von Stein, LLC. Dr. Groarke is survived by his partner Brendon Connors of New York City, four siblings, and nine nieces and nephews

GRAVES--Ralph. Died June 10 in New York City. Born in Washington D.C., in 1924 he was the son of Ralph Graves Sr., a founding editor of the National Geographic and Elizabeth Evans. After his father's death his mother married Francis B. Sayre, who became high commissioner of the Philippines where Mr. Graves spent part of his youth. He served in World War II as a cryptographer and returned to attend Harvard, where he published the first of his eleven books and graduated Phi Beta Kappa. He was hired by LIFE magazine, and during the ensuing 35 years he served in many capacities, becoming Managing Editor, and finally overseeing the closing of the weekly magazine. He then became Editorial Director of Time Inc. where he worked until his retirement. Within weeks of becoming Managing Editor he published "the Faces of the Dead" an article showing the 243 faces of every American killed in the previous week in Viet Nam. The article was a strong antiwar statement that widely affected public opinion. He married Patricia Monser, with whom he had two children, William and Katherine. He later married Eleanor MacKenzie Parish, with whom had two children, Sara and Andrew. He became stepfather to William and Alexander. He is also survived by 11 grandchildren. Mr. Graves had homes in Sarasota, Fl., New York City and Martha's Vineyard. He was a member of the Century Association, the Edgartown Reading Room and the Dutch Treat Club, where he served as president. He was an avid, and mostly successful, backgammon player.

GOODENOUGH--Ward Hunt, PhD, 94, of Haverford, PA, died on Sunday, June 9, 2013. He was University Emeritus Professor of Anthropology at the University of Pennsylvania. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, June 27, 2013 at 2pm at The Quadrangle, 3300 Darby Road, Haverford, PA. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name can be made to: American Philosophical Society, 104 South 5th Street, Philadelphia, PA 19106. GOLDSMITH--Dr. Jerome, a giant in the field of community and adolescent mental health, died on March 12, 2013. Jay led the merger of the Jewish Board of Guardians and Jewish Family Services to create the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services in 1978. He remained at the helm until 1991. Under Jay's leadership, JBFCS became the largest provider of community mental health clinics for children, families, and adults in the country. Added to the clinics were programs he developed to prevent abuse and neglect and provide consultation in schools and community centers. Jay was the JBFCS CEO during the height of the HIV AIDS epidemic, and was one of the first to recognize the need for mental health services to people with AIDS. Jay's professional life continued long after his formal retirement. He was a visionary and a passionate leader and spokesman. A Memorial Service will be held for Jay on Thursday, June 20, 2013 at UJA Federation, 130 East 59th Street, NYC, NY, 45:30pm. Donations can be made to: JBFCS, 135 West 50th Street, NYC, NY 10010.

FELDMAN--Robert P. In memory of my beloved brother Robert, who passed away in May, whose greatest pleasure was his children - Alexandra, Kyle, Jeremy and Elizabeth Logan - whose greatest regret was missing his grandchildren growing up. William

FELDMAN--Marcia. Marcia's greatest love was her family; she was the adored and beloved wife of Jerry, a loving and devoted mother, grandmother and daughter. Marcia was a cherished and treasured friend with an amazing sense of humor and a quick wit, a love of life and an uncomplaining nature. We shall miss you forever. Love You More, Dale and Martin.

EIDUS--Arnold. World renowned Violinist, passed away on June 3, 2013 at the age of 90. He was a child prodigy at age five who studied with Louis Persinger, the teacher of Yehudi Menhuin and Isaac Stern. He gave his first concert at Carnagie Hall at age 11 with Leonard Bernstein. He was asked by the State Department to represent the United States in the prestigious Jacques Thibaut International Competition. From among 160 worldwide entrants he won 1st Prize for the United States at the age of 24. He went on to become Concertmaster of the ABC Symphony and Music Director for ABC Radio. He also performed with Benny Goodman, Frank Sinatra, Tony Bennett, Perry Como, Harry James and other leading recording artists of his day. In 1967 he joined a noted New York advertising agency where he produced some of the most beloved commercials of all time such as Ummm Ummm Good for Campbell Soups and Double Your Pleasure with Doublemint Gum for Wrigleys Gum. He retired to Boca Raton, Florida and was predeceased by his Wife, Doris, and their daughter, Licia. He had a wonderful life for many years with his loving companion, Rose Kahn, who survives in Delray Beach to cherish and honor his memory.

DiPAOLO--Louis, age 87 of Salisbury, CT, formerly of Tenafly NJ and River Edge NJ, died peacefully on June 4, 2013. He enlisted in the USMC in 1943, attending summer school in order to graduate early from Blair Academy. He fought in the battle of Iwo Jima as a member of the 4th Marine Division. In recent years, he shared his experiences in the Marine Corps and on Iwo Jima with students in various grades in local schools. A graduate of Princeton University, he joined the family business, Reprostat Corporation, which later became GSO Graphics, retiring in 1996. An avid bicycle rider, Lou rode across the United States three times to benefit Alzheimer's and the NYC Bicycle Police. Lou was active in town government for 31 years while living in Tenafly. He was appointed by five different Republican mayors to board positions and was elected to the town council as a Democrat. He is survived by his wife of 47 years, Germaine (Rousseau) eight children (Linda Love, Joan Cribben, Gary, Gail Hussong, Tom, Erik, Evan, Adam) and ten grandchildren. Memorial visitation will be at Barrett Funeral Home 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly NJ on Thursday, June 20th from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral service will be at The Church of the Atonement 97 Highwood Ave., Tenafly NJ at noon on Friday, June 21st, followed by burial at Brookside Cemetery Englewood NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to a charity of individual choice.

CRESS--Paul. In loving memory of Paul Cress (Apostolos Chrisomales) born February 19, 1919 died June 11, 2013 age 94. He's survived by wife Julie, partner Rita, and his three sons William, John, and Russell. He lived a happy life.

CLARK--William Goodman, of Watch Hill, Rhode Island and Basalt, Colorado passed away peacefully in his wife's arms on June 11, 2013 from complications due to Alzheimer's. He was 80 years old. Luckily two days before, he was surrounded by his loving family. Bill was born on January 14, 1933 in Englewood, New Jersey to Helen Mary G. Clark who was a well know WAFS pilot in World War II, while the US Air Force was still part of the US Army and to W. Gerould Clark, Jr. who was the mayor of Englewood, New Jersey. Bill graduated from Cornell University in 1955 with a BA in Economics and an MBA. He had an illustrious career in the reinsurance industry. Bill spent 22 years at General Reinsurance after serving as an Officer in the U.S. Air Force as a MATS pilot. As Senior Vice President at General Reinsurance Corporation, Bill led the Facultative Division to be recognized as the premier market for this reinsurance product. In particular, his leadership and innovation led Casualty Facultative to prominence within the reinsurance market. Following four years as President of Transinsco, a subsidiary of Gulf Oil Corporation, Bill was instrumental in spearheading and founding several more reinsurance companies - including Clarendon National Insurance Co., Transamerica Reinsurance Co. and TIG Re. "More than his corporate contributions, Bill impacted many lives in the re/insurance industry with his innovation; his positive attitude, charm, vibrancy and enthusiasm; his promotion of talents and skills throughout; his magnetism; his leadership and management style. He believed in "meritocracy" and in team brainstorming. Bill's impact will live on in the people that had the privilege to know him and work closely with him!" (Recent quotation from past colleagues). Bill is survived by his adoring wife Tania, four sons William G. Clark, Jr. (Sarah H. Clark), Michael W. Clark (Colleen F. Clark), Jonathan B. Clark (Alice S. Clark) and Timothy A. Clark (Vincianne V. Clark) and two stepsons Allen C. Post, Jr. "Casey" (Sarah L. Post) and John S. Post "Jeep" (Jessica G. Post), thirteen grandchildren and his brother W. Gerould Clark II. Bill's interests spanned a wide variety of subjects. He was an accomplished equestrian and pilot, loved building and decorating his homes and had great fun captaining his own classic boats. He was a mentor and father to so many and a beloved husband who will be greatly missed for his endless optimism, his "terrifics" and 'absolutely fabulouses". He brought joy and harbor to us all. Bill's smiling blue eyes will sparkle in our hearts forever. The Alzheimer Foundation, the Village at Waveny Care Center in New Canaan, Connecticut or Masonicare Home Health and Hospice of Norwalk, Connecticut would appreciate any gifts in his name. There will be a celebration of Bill's life in Watch Hill, Rhode Island later this summer.

CHRISTENSEN--Barbara H.,age 85, of Chappaqua, NY, died on Tuesday, June 4, 2013, at Westchester Medical Center, Valhalla, NY of a heart attack. Born in Newark, NJ, on March 26, 1928, she was the daughter of Dr. J. Wallace and Sarah R. Hurff of South Orange, NJ. She and her husband of 61 years resided in Chappaqua for 51 of those years, as well as many years at their summer home in Cutchogue, NY. They previously lived in Princeton, NJ and Poughkeepsie, NY. She was an alumna of The Ethel Walker School, Simsbury, CT and Mt. Vernon Junior College. Earlier active in Chappaqua real estate sales, she had been an enthusiastic skier and tennis player. An avid gardener, she was a member of the Chappaqua Garden Club and the Herb Society of America. She was a long-time member of the First Congregational Church of Chappaqua, where she participated in many of its parish-wide activities. Barbara is survived by her husband, Robert L. Christensen, and three sons, Robert L. Jr. and former wife Sara of Darien, CT; William H. and wife Pamela of New York City; and John G. and wife Sheila of Rumford, RI; as well as nine grandchildren. A celebration of Barbara's life will be held on Saturday, June 29 at 2pm at the First Congregational Church, 210 Orchard Ridge Rd., Chappaqua, NY, 10514, phone: 914-238-4411. Memorial contributions may be made to SPCA of Westchester, 590 North State Rd., Briarcliff Manor, NY, 10510.

CAREDDU--John, of New York, NY, age 87, died peacefully June 11. Beloved husband of Kathy Careddu and uncle to nephews and a niece. Born in Bridgeport, CT. Army medic in WWII. Lover of New York City Ballet and of opera.

BROWN--Robert A.,90, died at his home on May 23, 2013 in Southbury, CT. Originally from Chicago, IL, he was a WWII Army veteran, a career US diplomat, a Merck executive, a realtor, a gourmet, an art collector, the devoted husband to Catherine Y. Brown and loving father to Alan Brown.

BROWN--Catherine Y. "Kay" 3/5, 89, died at her home on May 25, 2013 in Southbury, CT. She was born in Emporia, KS, was a WWII Marine, a retailer, the devoted wife of Robert A. Brown, and loving mother to Alan Brown.

He was a member of Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, the Creek Club and John's Island Club. He was predeceased by his loving wife Nancy after 45 years of marriage in 2003. He is survived by his four children, Chris, Erik, Joanne and Jason, his eight grandchildren, and his brother John. The funeral service will be held on Friday, June 21 at 11:15am at St. Mary's Catholic Church in Manhasset. His was a life well-lived. We will miss him dearly and will remember him as a devoted husband, father, friend and a great man.

WEINBERG--Ruth Jeanette Mindlin, 97, beloved wife of the late Bertram Ullman Weinberg, died peacefully in her sleep on June 16th surrounded by her large and loving family. Ruth was the youngest of five daughters born to Max and Celia (Socolof) Mindlin in East Orange, New Jersey on August 27th, 1915. The Mindlin sisters were exceptionally close all of their lives. Lillian Semel, Pauline Forman, Mildred Burstein and then the baby, Ruthie, followed Sadie Aaron, the eldest. When Bert Weinberg interviewed head counselors for his family's summer camp, Pocono Highland, Ruth landed the job and a husband in the bargain. Ruth and Bert were married in 1939 and had four children; the late Patricia Lee Smith (Dr. Robert), Nancy Winston (late Laurence Levine, late James V. Higgins), Max Weinberg (Rebecca), and Abby Levin (Michael). Ruth leaves eight grandchildren who adored her beyond measure; Dr. Michelle Goncalves (Manny), Dr. Nicole Steckler (Matt), Sharon Boyd (Scott), Dani Kupperman (Justin), Ali Weinberg, Jay Weinberg, Jake Levin, Noah Levin and 11 great grandchildren, Alexa, Jack, Lina, Noa, Amanda, Sabrina, Ben, Joseph, Finn, Bryce and Layla. Ruth Weinberg taught physical education in the Newark School System for 26 years and with Bert owned and operated Pocono Highland Camps in Marshall's Creek, PA and Laurel Lake Camp, in Tyler Hill, PA. She was a lifelong member of Hadassah as well as Temple Sharey Tefilo-Israel of the Oranges. Her father, Max, was one of the founding members of Sharey Tefilo in East Orange. She loved Broadway musicals, Hershey bars, organizing and winning at Mahjong and Canasta and being with her large and loving family of which she was the very proud matriarch. Ruth traveled the world with her son Max, drummer with the E-Street Band. Members of the band always called her "Mighty Mommy," and mighty she was. She will be greatly missed. A private graveside service will be held on Monday, June 17th, with a future memorial to be announced.

SOROS--Paul, If the American dream had a patron saint, he would look a lot like Paul Soros, who achieved so much himself and then supported the highest aspirations of this country's most talented immigrants through the Paul and Daisy Soros Fellowships for New Americans. The world lost a remarkable intellect and visionary. We will miss his wit and charm and generosity. Our heartfelt condolences to Daisy, Peter, and Jeffrey and the Soros family. Ann Kirschner Dean, Macaulay Honors College of The City University of New York Director, The Paul and Daisy Soros Fellowship for New Americans

SOROS--Paul. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts deeply mourn the passing of Paul Soros, husband of Daisy, Director Emerita and long-time member of Lincoln Center's Board of Directors. Paul and Daisy have been key supporters of Midsummer Night Swing, Lincoln Center's annual dancing under the stars festival, since its early years, and were frequently the first couple out on the dance floor. Their generosity extended to other members of the Lincoln Center family, as well as to The Paul & Daisy Soros Fellowships For New Americans. Our heartfelt sympathies go to Daisy, her sons, Peter and Jeffrey, and to their family and friends. Katherine Farley, Chair Reynold Levy, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

SOROS--Paul. Paul Soros, of New Canaan, CT, New York City, and Nantucket, MA passed away after a long illness on June 15, 2013, at age 87. He is survived by Daisy, his loving wife of 62 years, their sons Peter and Jeffrey, daughter-in-law Catharine; his adored grandchildren Preston, Simon, Sabrina, Thomas, step-granddaughter Stella Powell-Jones, and by his younger brother, George. Paul Soros was born in Budapest, Hungary in 1926. After surviving the Nazi and Soviet occupations of World War II, he skied for the Hungarian National Team until the 1948 Olympics in St. Moritz and then emigrated to the United States on a scholarship in 1948. He graduated from Polytechnic Institute of New York University in 1950 and worked for a year in heavy construction before joining Hewitt-Robins International as a sales engineer. He and his wife Daisy met while both were studying in New York and were married in 1951. In 1956 he founded the engineering firm Soros Associates. Over the next 30 years Soros Associates was recognized as the leading international engineering firm in the design and development of bulk handling and port facilities. The firm won the American Engineering Council's Annual Excellence Competition Award 18 times, received the 1983 Award of Outstanding Materials Handling Engineer from the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) and the 1989 Outstanding Engineering Achievement Award from the National Society of Professional Engineers. The firm also received the Gantt Medal from ASME in 2000. Mr. Soros holds several patents related to his innovations surrounding material transport and was the author of more than a hundred technical articles. During this time, he also served as a delegate to the U.S.-Japan Natural Resources Committee under President Johnson, as a member of the White House Panel on Science & Technology under President Nixon, and as Special Ambassador of the U.N. on missions to Morocco, Jordan and Czechoslovakia. After the firm was acquired in 1989 by ENI, the Italian energy company, he continued to focus on his related business interests in resources and shipping, and his philanthropy. He was a member of the board of Quantum Industrial Holdings as well as several of its portfolio companies. He also served on the board of Brooklyn Polytechnic, TechnoServe and was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. His contributions to public life earned him several distinctions including the Fulbright Award for Contributions to International Understanding and election to the Hall of Distinction by the Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities. He received honorary doctorates from Bates College, Macaulay Honors College and Polytechnic Institute of New York University. He and his wife played an active role in the support of many New York institutions including International House, Weill Cornell Medical School, The Metropolitan Opera, The New York Philharmonic and Lincoln Center, where they underwrote Midsummer Night Swing for many years. One of his proudest achievements was the establishment in 1997 of The Paul and Daisy Soros Fellowships for New Americans. These fellowships were created to recognize the contribution of immigrants to America and identify future leaders in their fields. Under the direction of the family, together with a distinguished board of trustees, the Fellowships each year provide support to 30 immigrants and first-generation Americans in pursuit of their graduate studies. A memorial service will be held at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday, the 27th of June at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to International House or the New York Philharmonic.

SCHMIERER--Hortense, 84, passed away June 15, 2013, unexpectedly after a happy and full life with accomplishments of teaching in the Rockville Centre School District, co-owner of Camp Starlight, Starlight, PA, active in Malverne Jewish Center, League of Women Voters, Albany University Alumni, President of the Gardens East Board, Weston, FL. Her great joys were shared with her close family and friends. She was the wife of the late Hy Schmierer, survived by her children Susan and Matthew Silverman, Merri and Harry Bragg, Nana to Rachel and Spencer Roberts, Jaime and Abbey Silverman, great-grandmother to Harrison, Addison and Jacob. Sister of Shirley Greene, Dolores London, twin of the late Arline Strumeyer/Dinkoff and sister-in-law Muriel Schmierer and brother-in-law and close friend Harris Dinkoff. She was also an aunt and great-aunt to many nieces and nephews. Funeral will be held on Sunday, June 16th at 10am at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY followed by burial at New Montefiore Cemetery in Farmingdale.

ROUHANA--William Joseph, Sr. Born January 18, 1922, died June 14, 2013. ROSENBERG--Theodore (Ted), 88, passed away on June 15th. Cherished husband of the late Beverly, devoted father of Richard (Laura), Linda (Howard), Michael (Michael), cherished grandfather of Melissa (Bradford), Shari, proud great-grandfather of Skylar, Chase, Brooke, Lindsay. He loved his life, his wife, family and his work. Dad, you will be greatly missed. Services Monday, June 17th at noon at Gutterman's in Woodbury, NY.

OSMAN--Holly, Surrounded by her loving family, Holly Cohen Osman of Scarsdale, NY, died at home on June 14th. Holly fought stage IV breast cancer for seven years, determined to go about her life as usual. She inspired everyone with her positive outlook, and she lived by her motto, "You can find something positive in everything." Devoted to supporting other people living with cancer, Holly volunteered with the American Cancer Association, as well as with Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Holly's creative talents abounded, and were exemplified through the interior design firm she founded and led, Holly Osman Designs. She is survived by her devoted husband of 27 years, Richard, her children, Sarah and Eric, her father, Murray Cohen and his partner, Beverly Albert, her brother, Thomas Cohen, her sister, Amy Cohen, sisters-in-law Elisa Singer, Nancy Kaplan, and Meg Osman, brothers-in-law Josh Kaplan and Martin Levion, in-laws Betty and Al Osman, and five nieces and nephews. Holly was predeceased by her mother, Joyce Arnoff Cohen. We will forever treasure our memories of her smile, her laugh, her warmth, her incredible style, her amazing dinner parties, and most of all her brave, positive, fighting spirit. Donations in memory of Holly may be directed to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (with "Roz Kleban Patient Fund" in the memo line), Attention: Jane Weyl, 633 Third Avenue, 28th Floor New York, NY 10017, or to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation (bcrfcure.org)

GLIKLICH--Henrietta Paula, nee Gotajner, born February 1, 1915 in Czestochowa, Poland, devoted wife of Henry who predeceased her, loving mother and grandmother, died surrounded by her family Saturday, June 15th. Her spirit was forged in the extraordinarily rich and diverse Jewish culture of pre-war Poland. Possessed of a fierce independence and passion for life, she loved people and they loved her. She was the lone Holocaust survivor of seven siblings and extended family. A proud American and stalwart supporter of Israel, she is survived by her son, Jerry (Jane Salmon), and grandsons, David (Brittany Bagley) and Benjamin. Funeral was private. Family will receive visitors at their home Monday from 4pm to 9pm and Tuesday from 6pm to 9pm.

EVANS--Thomas W. The current Trustees of Teachers College, Columbia University, and his former Trustee colleagues mourn the passing of Tom, who not only chaired our Board but also taught in what was then the College's Department of Educational Administration. Tom's wide-ranging accomplishments included his stellar career in the law; his service in the Marines and co-chairmanship of the Korean War Veterans Memorial Commission; his counsel to two U.S. Presidents; and his widely admired books on education and politics. Above all, Tom was a passionate believer that, as he put it, "education's role is to straighten out the many problems of our society." He practiced what he preached through his founding of the MENTOR program, which paired law firms with public schools; his creation and stewardship of the National Symposium on Partnerships in Education; and his efforts to launch the High School of Law and Justice at Martin Luther King High School in Manhattan. Our condolences to Tom's beloved wife, Lois; their three children, Heather, Logan and Paige, and their grandchildren; and their extended family, colleagues and friends.

Di SCIPIO--Giuseppe Carlo. Passed away at his home on June 15, 2013 at the age of 66. Lovingly remembered by his family and friends. Chairperson of the department of Romance Languages at Hunter College until 2011. A Dante Alighieri scholar, beloved father and professor. His life was a testament to the arts and humanities. Visitation today Monday, June 17, 2-4 and 7-9pm at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Avenue, Brooklyn. Funeral mass at St. Anselm's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn, Tuesday, June 18 at 9:45am. Interment to follow at St. Charles Resurrection Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Professor Di Scipio Scholarship Fund. For details, contact Adriana Di Scipio: adiscipio@gmail.com.

DiPAOLO--Louis, age 87 of Salisbury, CT, formerly of Tenafly NJ and River Edge NJ, died peacefully on June 4, 2013. He enlisted in the USMC in 1943, attending summer school in order to graduate early from Blair Academy. He fought in the battle of Iwo Jima as a member of the 4th Marine Division. In recent years, he shared his experiences in the Marine Corps and on Iwo Jima with students in various grades in local schools. A graduate of Princeton University, he joined the family business, Reprostat Corporation, which later became GSO Graphics, retiring in 1996. An avid bicycle rider, Lou rode across the United States three times to benefit Alzheimer's and the NYC Bicycle Police. Lou was active in town government for 31 years while living in Tenafly. He was appointed by five different Republican mayors to board positions and was elected to the town council as a Democrat. He is survived by his wife of 47 years, Germaine (Rousseau) eight children (Linda Love, Joan Cribben, Gary, Gail Hussong, Tom, Erik, Evan, Adam) and ten grandchildren. Memorial visitation will be at Barrett Funeral Home 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly NJ on Thursday, June 20th from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral service will be at The Church of the Atonement 97 Highwood Ave., Tenafly NJ at noon on Friday, June 21st, followed by burial at Brookside Cemetery Englewood NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to a charity of individual choice.

You will be missed but never forgotten. My sympathy to Karen, whose devotion was outstanding and the family. With Love, Steve.

BLECHMAN--Howard. Howard was a special man loved by all who were fortunate to know him. His passing leaves his family and friends with a heartache no one can heal and memories no one can steal. We will miss him dearly. The Gottlieb's and The Yellin's

BLECHMAN--Howard. Although Howard may be gone the wonderful memories we have of him will be in our hearts and minds forever. We will miss this very special man beyond words, as his love, kindness, friendship and thoughtfulness is an inspiration to Ellie and me. We wish Karen and the family our deepest sympathy and our never ending love. Rest in peace dearest friend. Ellie and Norman

SOROS--Paul. His passing on June 15, 2013 at the age of 87 is deeply mourned by the Paul & Daisy Soros Fellowships for New Americans Program and the 475 Soros Fellows whose graduate study it has funded over 16 years. The Program has been informed by Paul's inspiring personal story, his commitment to American constitutional democracy, and his visionary philanthropy. As an 18-year-old in Hungary in 1944, Paul assumed a false identity and survived the Holocaust era. When the Soviets invaded Budapest, he was arrested, became a Russian prisoner of war, and escaped while in transit to Russia. A member of the Hungarian Olympic ski team in 1948, he defected, initially to Austria and subsequently to the United States. His experiences under both Nazi and Communist regimes awakened in him a powerful and enduring commitment to the American constitution and Bill of Rights. He believed that active and informed citizenship is essential to the protection of our democracy. And he was convinced that immigrants and others who have recently achieved citizenship have a special responsibility to support and defend our constitutional system. As an extremely promising young engineering student in New York City - he met his wife-to-be, Daisy, at International House - Paul struggled to afford graduate study. A Master's degree from Polytechnic Institute in Brooklyn, however, launched his distinguished career as a creative, innovative, and highly accomplished civil engineer. His innovative ideas, and his determination to see them implemented, transformed port design worldwide. Paul and Daisy's lives as immigrants informed and shaped their decision to fund and personally support a national graduate fellowship program that helps launch careers of New Americans. It supports individuals whose creativity and drive suggest that they have special promise of making distinctive contributions to American life. It recognizes that such individuals can be found at more and less distinguished institutions throughout the country. And it emphasizes and encourages active citizenship among its Fellows. Paul was especially proud of the contributions that Paul & Daisy Soros Fellows have already made to American life. They, and all of us who play roles in implementing his vision, mourn his passing and pay tribute to the enduring legacy of his wisdom and philanthropy. We extend our deepest sympathy to Daisy, their sons Peter and Jeffrey, and their families. A Memorial Service honoring Paul's life will be held on Thursday, June 27th at 11am at Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center. Stanley Heginbotham, Director Paul & Daisy Soros Fellowships for New Americans

SOROS--Paul. The New York Philharmonic mourns the passing of Paul Soros, a longtime, dedicated, devoted supporter of the Orchestra. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Daisy, our Board Secretary, and his entire family.

SOROS--Paul. The Overseers, faculty, students and staff of Weill Cornell Medical College are deeply saddened by the death of our dear friend Paul Soros, beloved husband of Daisy, esteemed long-time member of Weill Cornell's Board of Overseers. A genial co-host with Daisy, Paul dedicated more than 20 years in service and philanthropy to Weill Cornell and leaves an outstanding legacy of stewardship and benevolence. From endowments to support both junior and senior faculty members to capital commitments for research, clinical and educational space on our campus, the Soros' generosity has touched every facet of our mission. We are honored to have enjoyed his friendship, sage advice, strong values and marvelous humor. Our heartfelt condolences to Daisy, her sons Peter and Jeffrey, and to their family and friends. Dr. Laurie H. Glimcher, Dean, Weill Cornell Medical College Dr. Antonio M. Gotto Jr., Co-Chairman, Board of Overseers Sanford I. Weill, Chairman, Board of Overseers

SOROS--Paul. Paul Soros, of New Canaan, CT, New York City, and Nantucket, MA passed away after a long illness on June 15, 2013, at age 87. He is survived by Daisy, his loving wife of 62 years, their sons Peter and Jeffrey, daughter-in-law Catharine; his adored grandchildren Preston, Simon, Sabrina, Thomas, step-granddaughter Stella Powell-Jones, and by his younger brother, George. Paul Soros was born in Budapest, Hungary in 1926. After surviving the Nazi and Soviet occupations of World War II, he skied for the Hungarian National Team until the 1948 Olympics in St. Moritz and then emigrated to the United States on a scholarship in 1948. He graduated from Polytechnic Institute of New York University in 1950 and worked for a year in heavy construction before joining Hewitt-Robins International as a sales engineer. He and his wife Daisy met while both were studying in New York and were married in 1951. In 1956 he founded the engineering firm Soros Associates. Over the next 30 years Soros Associates was recognized as the leading international engineering firm in the design and development of bulk handling and port facilities. The firm won the American Engineering Council's Annual Excellence Competition Award 18 times, received the 1983 Award of Outstanding Materials Handling Engineer from the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) and the 1989 Outstanding Engineering Achievement Award from the National Society of Professional Engineers. The firm also received the Gantt Medal from ASME in 2000. Mr. Soros holds several patents related to his innovations surrounding material transport and was the author of more than a hundred technical articles. During this time, he also served as a delegate to the U.S.-Japan Natural Resources Committee under President Johnson, as a member of the White House Panel on Science & Technology under President Nixon, and as Special Ambassador of the U.N. on missions to Morocco, Jordan and Czechoslovakia. After the firm was acquired in 1989 by ENI, the Italian energy company, he continued to focus on his related business interests in resources and shipping, and his philanthropy. He was a member of the board of Quantum Industrial Holdings as well as several of its portfolio companies. He also served on the board of Brooklyn Polytechnic, TechnoServe and was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. His contributions to public life earned him several distinctions including the Fulbright Award for Contributions to International Understanding and election to the Hall of Distinction by the Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities. He received honorary doctorates from Bates College, Macaulay Honors College and Polytechnic Institute of New York University. He and his wife played an active role in the support of many New York institutions including International House, Weill Cornell Medical School, The Metropolitan Opera, The New York Philharmonic and Lincoln Center, where they underwrote Midsummer Night Swing for many years. One of his proudest achievements was the establishment in 1997 of The Paul and Daisy Soros Fellowships for New Americans. These fellowships were created to recognize the contribution of immigrants to America and identify future leaders in their fields. Under the direction of the family, together with a distinguished board of trustees, the Fellowships each year provide support to 30 immigrants and first-generation Americans in pursuit of their graduate studies. A memorial service will be held at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday, the 27th of June at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to International House or the New York Philharmonic.

PIELENZ--Hanns A. Died June 13, 2013 at his home in Vero Beach, Florida with his beloved wife and daughters by his side. Pielenz, who alternated between residences in Vero Beach, Bonnigheim, Germany and Harbor Springs, Michigan passed away after a brave and valiant battle against myelofibrosis that began more than two years ago. Hanns Alfred Pielenz was born in Heilbronn, Germany on November 22, 1939. After a stint in banking, he returned to school and graduated from the Academy Hohenstein in 1963 in Textile Management-Engineering. He joined Amann/Ackermann Group, a regional textile business that was founded by his maternal great grandfather in 1854. From 1968 until his retirement in 2005, Mr. Pielenz was Chairman and CEO of the company and under his stewardship the provincial textile manufacturing company became a dominant and innovative leader in the global textile industry. Pielenz's contributions to the industry were recognized in 2009 as he was the first recipient of the Otto-Mecheels Medal for his contributions and innovations to the textile industry. While at the helm of Amann, he was also the Chairman of URS, an Atlanta based refrigerated warehouse company and commuted to Atlanta to manage the company. Under his visionary guidance, URS became one of the largest refrigerated warehouse companies in the US before he sold it in 1997. Knowing he would retire from Amann in 2005, he formed a family office in Atlanta, Georgia in 2000, HAP Investment Group, LLC, and used it as a platform for a multitude of investments including real estate, venture capital, angel investing for start-ups and minority ownership in operating companies. Pielenz loved business and was interested in any investment that provided the opportunity to create value as well as fuel his passion for knowledge and his acumen for business strategy. Pielenz was a brilliant business strategist with a personality and presence that was bigger than life. He loved people and they loved him as he left an indelible mark on everyone he interacted with over the years. He was a mentor to many in the business world and was always eager to provide input, guidance, and motivation though he always set high expectations and empowered people to reach them. He leaves behind a legacy few will fulfill in life as his business contributions provided jobs for thousands of people in many different businesses spread around the globe. His business creed was "Close ties to the customer and knowledge of the market are the essentials of business success. The secret is passion." This was not only the motto for his business but his philosophy for living his life as he was passionate about the things he valued. While business strategy was a passion, he dearly loved being in the woods, either hiking with his wife or hunting and he loved golf...though he admitted with pride that his wife was the better golfer. His greatest passion was his family, his wife of 45 years, Christa, who he always referred to as his sweetheart, his daughters, Nici and Katja, and his four grandchildren. Since his diagnosis in 2011, Pielenz worked tirelessly to fund, develop and coordinate resources to find a cure for myelofibrosis. While his efforts were not in time to change his destiny, his legacy will be to continue this research for all of the others suffering from this disease. Hanns Pielenz is survived by his wife, Christa Herzog Pielenz, his daughter Nicola Dowling (Colin), his daughter Katja White (Houston), and his grandchildren Maxie Klemm and Colin, Nicholas and Claire Dowling. The family would like to express its heartfelt appreciation to Dr. Srdan Verstovsek of MD Anderson as well as the entire team in the Leukemia Department who worked tirelessly to help not only Mr. Pielenz but his family on the journey as he battled myelofibrosis. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in his memory to the MPN Clinical Research Center under the direction of Dr. Srdan Verstovsek, Department of Leukemia (Unit 428), The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center, 1515 Holcombe Boulevard, Houston, Texas 77030 or The Boys and Girls Club of Vero Beach, 1729 17th Ave., Vero Beach, Florida 32960. A memorial service will be held in Vero Beach, Florida in the fall.

MAHONEY--Sr. Colette, RSHM. Sister Colette, of the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary order for 65 years, served as President of Marymount Manhattan College from 1967 to 1988. During her presidency she guided the College with conviction and dedication during a transformative time for our nation. Well known within the New York City area and national arena, she engaged with government leaders to promulgate an understanding for the College's mission and rich history. As a trailblazer of diversity, her work provided women and the underserved with access to higher education. She was also President, Presentation College in South Dakota and Saint Xavier University in Chicago as Interim President. Sr. Colette had a cumulative 65 years or more of service on educational, corporate and religious boards.She will be remembered by thousands of students, faculty, staff and alumni whom she personally touched. The entire community of Marymount Manhattan College is saddened by the loss of Sister Colette. We will keep her in our prayers. Judson R. Shaver, Ph.D., President Marymount Manhattan College

LEVY--Joseph. Beloved husband of Gabrielle. Loving father of Jack (Frances), Marcia Beck (Michael), Louise, and Edward (Margot). Devoted grandfather of Jessica, David, Emily, Julia, Sophie, Caroline, Joanna and Lexi. He touched everyone he knew and he will be greatly missed.

KROLL--Sol. We mourn the loss of Sol Kroll. He arrived as a young immigrant child through Ellis Island, lived a long and very full life, had a wonderful marriage to Ruth, four children, devoted and loving grandchildren, adorable great-grandchildren, upon all of whom he showered unequivocal and unconditional love. This brilliant multi-talented, erudite, gracious, tough as nails but sweet as sugar, full of mischief, master of the universe was a unique individual possessed of an indomitable spirit who rose to great success personally and professionally. During his early years, Sol was a politician in Putnam County, New York where he served as its County Attorney from 1960-1964. After leaving politics, Sol Kroll became a legend in the field of insurance law (an Elector to the Insurance Hall of Fame) and the first truly global insurance lawyer. Starting in the 1950's when he traveled by boat continuing in the jet age -- he opened up the English, Japanese and European insurance marketplaces for American lawyers. He was featured in the Institutional Investor magazine for his 30-year tradition of hosting the opening cocktail party each year at the Rendez-vous de Septembre, the annual Reinsurance conference in Monte Carlo. As an insurance lawyer for 71 years, he worked closely with Lloyd's of London and was the first U.S. General Counsel to the Institute of London Underwriters. He represented France in negotiating insurance aspects of tax treaties with the United States and Sweden in major insurance M & A transactions. Among his most celebrated cases, Sol was respondent's counsel in Bing v. Thunig where the New York Court of Appeals eliminated the concept of charitable immunity in the State of New York. Forty-years ago, he pioneered the concept of multi-state law firms when such firms, commonplace today, were virtually non-existent. He also pioneered the concept of "claims made" insurance that became the universal form of professional liability insurance that is used today. He was particularly proud of his 20-year service as a Director of the Insurance Federation of New York and, at his death, remained a Director Emeritus. In his spare time, he was a sculptor and a poet. One of his sculptures, Mr. Internet, remains on display at the University of Alabama. For decades, Sol was Chairman of the U.S. Friends of the London Symphony Chorus. He will always be in our hearts.

KARLE--Jerome. The City University of New York mourns the death of Nobel Laureate Dr. Jerome Karle, 1937 graduate of City College of New York, who with his CCNY classmate Herbert Hauptman, won the 1985 Nobel Prize in chemistry for their research discoveries in X-ray crystallography, now used daily by scientists all over the world. With his wife Dr. Isabella Karle, he worked on the Manhattan Project and continued research at the Naval Research Laboratory until he retired at 90. We offer our deepest condolences to his wife and family. Benno Schmidt Chairperson, Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein Chancellor

KAPLEN--Wilson (Bill). The Kaplen JCC on the Palisades mourns with profound sadness the loss of Wilson Kaplen, a visionary and philanthropist who dedicated his life to making a difference. He worked tirelessly on behalf of both Jewish causes and the community at large with a generosity of spirit that is well known. For more than 50 years, Mr. Kaplen demonstrated unparalleled support for our JCC. He was a founding member, a long time Board member, Vice President from 1966 - 1970 and remained active on the Board of Advisors until the present. Dedicated to the JCC's mission, Bill established the Kaplen Family Gym in 1986. In 2000, the JCC adult day care program for those suffering with Alzheimer's and dementia was renamed the Kaplen Adult Reach Center in recognition of Bill and his wife Maggie's personal investment in the welfare of the elderly. Their unwavering support of this program has been both personal and financial. In April 2003, the JCC presented the Kaplens' with the Chaver Award to acknowledge their dedication to enriching the quality of life for everyone who enters our doors. The Kaplen's became the Diamond Sponsors for the 2003 JCC Maccabi Games, enabling our Center to serve as a point of entry for Jewish teens from around the world. They also established The Kaplen Youth Athletic Endowment Fund to provide Maccabi scholarships for all deserving teens in our community. The athletic delegation to the games from our Center is named the Kaplen Team Palisades in their honor. In 2007, Bill and Maggie Kaplen helped launch the JCC Gift of Community Capital and Endowment Campaign with a lead gift. In grateful appreciation the JCC now proudly bears their name. Mr. Kaplen once stated: when you engage in philanthropy, you realize that you are not really giving anything away. You're multiplying what you have a hundred times over and keeping it for yourself. He lived by these words and will be remembered for his wisdom, guidance and leadership. We send our sincerest condolences to his wife Maggie, their four sons, Lawrence (and wife Veronica), Alexander, Peter and James and their three grandchildren, Nicolas, Benjamin and Isabelle. He was deeply loved and will be sorely missed. May his memory be for a blessing. Tina Guberman, President Avi A. Lewinson, CEO

KAPLEN--Wilson, New York Public Radio mourns the loss of Wilson Kaplen, a true philanthropist with a deep commitment to his community. He was a Trustee of the Kaplen Foundation, which has generously supported the work of New York Public Radio throughout the years. We extend our deepest condolences to his family.

KAPLEN--Wilson ("Bill"). AJC mourns the passing of a cherished friend. KAPLEN--Wilson R.,a builder turned philanthropist, died on Sunday at his home in Tenafly, NJ. He was 95. Born in Weehawken and educated at John Marshall Law School (now Seton Hall), he returned from service in the Second World War to start a construction company with his father, A. Kaplen & Son, and then a real-estate firm, Wilson Mgt., which acquired and ran apartment complexes around the country but mainly in New Jersey, where it was one of the largest owners of residential property. After selling his businesses in 1999, he devoted himself to a family philanthropy, The Kaplen Foundation, which he had established 30 years earlier. Especially interested in Jewish causes, healthcare, and the problems of aging, he was the driving force behind the construction of many significant charitable projects in northern New Jersey, including a new emergency wing at Englewood Hospital; the JCC on the Palisades, in Tenafly; the Jewish Home at Rockleigh; and the Jewish Home for Assisted Living, in River Vale. He is survived by his wife, Margaret; his sons, Lawrence and Alexander; his grandson, Benjamin; two stepsons, Peter and James Tate; and two stepchildren, Nicholas and Isabelle Tate-Arevalo. His oldest son, Michael, died in 1992. Funeral services will be held at Temple Sinai, in Tenafly, on Wednesday morning at 11.

American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

GLIKLICH--Henrietta Paula, nee Gotajner, born February 1, 1915 in Czestochowa, Poland, devoted wife of Henry who predeceased her, loving mother and grandmother, died surrounded by her family Saturday, June 15th. Her spirit was forged in the extraordinarily rich and diverse Jewish culture of pre-war Poland. Possessed of a fierce independence and passion for life, she loved people and they loved her. She was the lone Holocaust survivor of seven siblings and extended family. A proud American and stalwart supporter of Israel, she is survived by her son, Jerry (Jane Salmon), and grandsons, David (Brittany Bagley) and Benjamin. Funeral was private. GLASSER--Gerald. Beloved friend for more than half a century. We miss you already. Paul and Janice

GLASSER--Gerald J, PhD, We met in the mid-1960s. Respect and friendship evolved into a new business venture, Statistical Research, Inc. (SRI). It was a growing enterprise for over 30 wonderful years, serving the media and advertising industries. We often operated as interchangeable parts. It was a special kinship of shared values and a dedication to providing services that aided clients in making better business decisions through trustworthy information. Gerry was a man of integrity with a strong moral compass. His passing is a shocking and devastating loss. I and my family send condolences to all who knew, respected and loved him. Gale Metzger, Co-Founder and President of SRI

GLASSER--Gerald J, PhD, Died June 16th, 2013 after a brief illness. Gerald J. Glasser was a lifelong resident of Westfield, NJ. His higher education at New York University included B.S. in Economics and Statistics, an MBA in statistics, and a PhD in mathematics and statistics. Professor Glasser was a fulltime member of the New York University faculty for 39 years. He held the rank of Professor Emeritus of Business Statistics. He received several teaching awards including the Lindback Foundation award for distinguished teaching and the prestigious Great Teacher award from NYU. Gerry was also a co-founder and principal in a media marketing research company, Statistical Research, Inc. (known as SRI). Prior to the sale of the business in 2001, SRI had upwards of 200 employees engaged in research activities. Clients included all the major television and radio networks, many local stations, advertising agencies and national advertisers. Gerry was a member of a number of professional associations including The American Statistical Association (Fellow), The International Statistical Institute (Fellow), The Institute of Mathematical Statistics, The Operations Research Society of America and the American Society for Quality Control. He was co-author of a text book, Statistics for Business Decisions. He also authored dozens of research and discussion papers published in scientific journals. Gerry was a trustee with the Westfield Foundation, a member of the Board of Governors Union County College and a trustee on the advisory board at Overlook Medical. He was also chairman of the Overlook Foundation from 2008-2010. Gerry was president of a family charity foundation, The Thomas Glasser Foundation. One of the highlights of Dr. Glasser's philanthropic endeavors was the initial and ongoing funding of Imagine, a center of healing and hope for families dealing with loss in the Westfield area and beyond. Gerry is survived by his wife, Marlene, his daughter, Laura Glasser-Baker and her husband Joel of Westfield, and his daughter, Marjorie Ticknor and her husband, Samuel of Madison, and his daughter-in-law, Meg Glasser of Summit. His son, Thomas, is deceased. He has 8 grandchildren. Charitable donations may be made to Imagine, PO Box 711, Westfield, NJ 070, in memory of Gerald J. Glasser.

DI SCIPIO--Giuseppe. Distinguished scholar and educator. A man of great faith, integrity and generosity. His exegesis of Dante's "Candida rosa" helped readers behold Dante's vision of the Empyrean. This is the vision we hope he is now beholding as we join his family in the sorrow for his passing. Maria & Don

BREGER--Herbert Joseph (aka "Doc"), died at the age of 92 on June 15. Beloved husband of Sue, esteemed father of Bruce, Kenneth, Jonathan and Beth. PopPop to Isabelle, Nicole, Olivia, Barbara and Sammy. Brother to Gloria Wolf and the late Leonard Breger. Doc was a practicing dentist for almost 40 years after serving as a Captain in the US Army Dental Corps in WWII. He loved being a dentist but he was a businessman and entrepreneur at heart and had a legendary career as a telecommunications executive. NEWMAN--George. Beloved husband of Frances Newman passed away on June 16, 2013 at the age of 93. Panebianco, of Valley Cottage, NY and his niece; Camille Pane-Hunger, MD, of Greenwood Village, CO. Nick was a graduate of Iona College in 1954. He proudly served in the US Army in Germany 1955-1956, after which he worked in the family business, Super Fuel Corp. in New York City in many capacities, most recently as President. He will be missed by his loving nephews and niece and their families, as well as his many cousins, numerous friends, employees and business associates. Calling hours at the Fred H. KAPLEN--Wilson. The officers and members of the Boards of Trustees of the Jewish Home Family note with profound sorrow the passing of one of our past presidents, long standing board member, devoted supporter and very dear friend, Wilson Kaplen. Bill's successes in life were only surpassed by his commitment to philanthropy and helping others less fortunate. His foresight, counsel, drive and ability to involve others in our mission of providing for elders in our community resulted in the creation of two incredible facilities, one that bears his name. An extraordinary man who exhibited a profound commitment to countless organizations and causes in the local, national and international Jewish and secular communities, he will be missed by many. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife and our board member Margaret (Maggie), his children, Lawrence & Veronica, Alexander, James and Kenia, Peter and Koy, his grandchildren, Benjamin, Nicolas, and Isabelle and his entire family. Bill's legacy will be the quality of life that so many will experience because of his deep generosity. May his memory be for a blessing. Eli Ungar, Chairman of the Board Charles P. Berkowitz, President and CEO
KANTOR--Martin. Your legacy lives on. The Board of Directors of North Shore Child & Family Guidance Center

GOLUB--Sharon, passed away on June 16, 2013 of pneumonia. Sharon Bramson grew up in Far Rockaway with her sister Bunny and her parents Ray and Hy. At 16, brilliant and determined, she left home to enter nursing school. At 20, when she was the Head Nurse on her unit, she met the man who would become her husband of 49 years, Leon Golub. Soon after they married, they began a family. Lawrence, then David arrived to make their family complete. When her boys began going to school fulltime, Sharon went back to college, eventually earning a PhD in Psychology. She had a professional career full of milestones and accomplishments. She was a college professor, an author of multiple books on menstruation and women's lives, a long-time editor of the journal Women & Health, and a dedicated psychotherapist. She became a Professor at the College of New Rochelle, and her students sought her guidance not just in their studies, but in life. She accomplished all this while also a loving mother and devoted wife. Reluctantly, some years after being diagnosed with Parkinson's disease, Sharon made the sacrifice of retiring before she became unequal to her own high standards. She faced her Parkinson's disease with courage and grace and refused to let it prevent her from living. She loved to paint, to go to the theatre with friends, to swim, to sing, and to dance as best she could. And she loved the wii. Most of all, she and Leon loved their role as grandparents and doted endlessly on their six grandchildren. She collected friends, maintaining an array of friendships that in many cases lasted most of her life. Their love supported her through to the end. Through innumerable physical challenges, her spirit would only briefly wane, but never for long. Each time she would rally back and live as full a life as she could. She died as she lived, peacefully and surrounded by a loving family and friends. She is survived by her sister Bunny, her sons and daughters-in law, David and Lisa and Lawrence and Karen, her six grandchildren, Lucy, Jack, Elena, Ben, William and Kate, and her grand-dog Buddy. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Michael J. Fox Foundation.

With a BA in Italian from Hunter College, Pino was a longtime professor and chairperson of the Department of Romance Languages until 2011. He was admired and loved by faculty, students and staff. We will miss him and extend our condolences to his family. Contributions may be made to the Giuseppe Di Scippio Fund established in his memory, Hunter College Foundation, 695 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10065 Jennifer J. Raab, President and Vita Rabinowitz, Provost, Hunter College
GLASSER--Gerald. Beloved friend for more than half a century. We miss you already. Paul and Janice

GLASSER--Gerald. The Board and Staff of the Overlook Foundation and Overlook Medical Center in Summit, NJ, deeply mourn the passing of Gerald Glasser, Ph.D, husband of Marlene Glasser, life-long resident of Westfield, NJ, and beloved member of the Overlook family. Gerry was a valued Trustee and former Chairman of the Overlook Foundation Board as well as a Trustee of the Overlook Medical Center Advisory Board and Chairman of Overlook's Community Health Committee. Gerry's contributions as a philanthropic leader and champion of services to benefit the Overlook community are extensive and include the Thomas Glasser Lecture Series and the Thomas Glasser Caregivers Center at Overlook. He was an accomplished professor, statistician, businessman, father, civic leader, author and a recipient of numerous professional and civic awards, including an induction into the Westfield Hall of Fame in 2012. Gerry was a wonderful friend and mentor, and he will be deeply missed. Our heartfelt sympathies go to Marlene and her sister Joan, Gerry's daughters: Marjorie Ticknor and Laura Glasser-Baker and Gerry's daughter-in-law, Meg Glasser, and their respective families.

KAPLEN--Wilson (Bill). The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of a kind, generous and outstanding philanthropist. Bill and his beloved wife, Maggie, were recipients of ADL's Torch of Liberty Award and were honored for their magnanimous support of ADL's anti-bias education programs. The world is a better place due to Bill's commitment to so many. We extend our sincerest condolences to Maggie and the entire family. May Bill's memory be for a blessing Barry Curtiss-Lusher National Chair Abraham H. Foxman National Director

MAHONEY--Sr. Colette, RSHM. Sister Colette, of the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary order for 65 years, served as President of Marymount Manhattan College from 1967 to 1988. During her presidency she guided the College with conviction and dedication during a transformative time for our nation. Well known within the New York City area and national arena, she engaged with government leaders to promulgate an understanding for the College's mission and rich history. As a trailblazer of diversity, her work provided women and the underserved with access to higher education. She was also President, Presentation College in South Dakota and Saint Xavier University in Chicago as Interim President. Sr. Colette had a cumulative 65 years or more of service on educational, corporate and religious boards.She will be remembered by thousands of students, faculty, staff and alumni whom she personally touched. The entire community of Marymount Manhattan College is saddened by the loss of Sister Colette. We will keep her in our prayers. Judson R. Shaver, Ph.D., President Marymount Manhattan College

LECKIE--Frederick, a resident of Pelham Manor and New Rochelle, NY since 2005 passed away peacefully at Calvary Hospital, NY on Friday, 14th June 2013. He was 84. Dr. Leckie was born on 26th March 1929 in Dundee, Scotland, the second child of Frederick Leckie and Mary Barclay Leckie. He gained a B.Sc. Degree with First Class Honours in Engineering and was the Engineering Medalist at the University of St. Andrews in 1949. He then left Scotland to take up a position with Mott, Hay & Anderson in London followed by military service from 1951 to 1954 in the Royal Air Force where he was OCTU Sword of Honour winner. He next moved to the US and earned M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in Mechanical Engineering from Stanford University in 1955 and 1958, where he met and married Elizabeth Wheelwright of Greenwich, CT, his wife for 43 years. Upon graduation he spent a year at the Technische Hochschule, Hanover, Germany and then ten years as a lecturer in Mechanical Sciences at the University of Cambridge and Director of Studies and Fellow of Pembroke College. From 1968 to 1978 he was the Professor of Engineering at the University of Leicester, England. For the next decade Fred was a Professor of Mechanical Engineering and Head of the Department of Theoretical and Applied Mechanics at the University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign and then from 1988 to 2005 as chair of the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the University of California, Santa Barbara. Public service included stints with the US and UK Departments of Energy, the UK Nuclear Inspectorate, the UK Atomic Energy Authority, Euratom, the US Army Corps of Engineers, the Pressure Research Council and numerous committees of the National Science Foundation. Awards included an honorary D.Sc. from the University of Leicester, the Nadai Medal from the American Society of Mechanical Engineering and the Halliburton Award from the University of Illinois. Fred's publishing career spanned 50 years, over 150 journal articles and several books, the most recent published in 2009. Fred is survived by his son Gavin and wife Elizabeth of Pelham Manor, NY and his son Gregor and wife Sylvia of Deerfield, IL and his six grandchildren Hamish, Catriona, Mia, Isabel, Angus and Elspeth, as well as sister-in-law Margaret Canada of Stamford, CT and many nieces, nephews, cousins and close friends all over the world. His parents, wife and son Sean predeceased him. Funeral services will be held at Christ Church, 1415 Pelhamdale Avenue, Pelham Manor, NY at 10am Friday 21st June, 2013 with lunch afterwards at 990 Edgewood Avenue, Pelham Manor. In lieu of flowers the family would like to suggest a contribution to the University of St. Andrews American Foundation Inc. with a note for it to be applied to bursaries for Scottish students in memory of Professor F.A. Leckie. Services by Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham 10803 (pelham-funeralhome.com) Telephone: 914-738-1060

KAPLEN--Wilson (Bill). The Kaplen JCC on the Palisades mourns with profound sadness the loss of Wilson Kaplen, a visionary and philanthropist who dedicated his life to making a difference. He worked tirelessly on behalf of both Jewish causes and the community at large with a generosity of spirit that is well known. For more than 50 years, Mr. Kaplen demonstrated unparalleled support for our JCC. He was a founding member, a long time Board member, Vice President from 1966 - 1970 and remained active on the Board of Advisors until the present. Dedicated to the JCC's mission, Bill established the Kaplen Family Gym in 1986. In 2000, the JCC adult day care program for those suffering with Alzheimer's and dementia was renamed the Kaplen Adult Reach Center in recognition of Bill and his wife Maggie's personal investment in the welfare of the elderly. Their unwavering support of this program has been both personal and financial. In April 2003, the JCC presented the Kaplens' with the Chaver Award to acknowledge their dedication to enriching the quality of life for everyone who enters our doors. The Kaplen's became the Diamond Sponsors for the 2003 JCC Maccabi Games, enabling our Center to serve as a point of entry for Jewish teens from around the world. They also established The Kaplen Youth Athletic Endowment Fund to provide Maccabi scholarships for all deserving teens in our community. The athletic delegation to the games from our Center is named the Kaplen Team Palisades in their honor. In 2007, Bill and Maggie Kaplen helped launch the JCC Gift of Community Capital and Endowment Campaign with a lead gift. In grateful appreciation the JCC now proudly bears their name. Mr. Kaplen once stated: when you engage in philanthropy, you realize that you are not really giving anything away. You're multiplying what you have a hundred times over and keeping it for yourself. He lived by these words and will be remembered for his wisdom, guidance and leadership. We send our sincerest condolences to his wife Maggie, their four sons, Lawrence (and wife Veronica), Alexander, Peter and James and their three grandchildren, Nicolas, Benjamin and Isabelle. He was deeply loved and will be sorely missed. May his memory be for a blessing. Tina Guberman, President Avi A. Lewinson, CEO
